npc.speed: 40 ft., burrow 20 ft., fly 80 ft., swim 40 ft.

trait.name: Ice Walk
trait.text: The dragon can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra moment.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The dragon makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 15 (2d10+4) piercing damage plus 4 (1d8) cold damage.

action.name: Claw
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d6+4) slashing damage.

action.name: Cold Breath (Recharge 5-6)
action.text: The dragon exhales an icy blast in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 45 (10d8) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

npc.label: Sister Garaele
npc.name: Acolyte
npc.text:
Read Aloud: A young elf in the blue-and-silver vestments of Tymora tends a humble shrine tucked into the edge of Phandalin. Her sharp eyes betray both exhaustion and purpose as she lights a candle before a weather-worn statue. “Luck favors the bold,” she murmurs, more to herself than anyone else.
DM Info: Sister Garaele is a member of the Harpers and keeper of Phandalin’s Shrine of Luck. Outwardly serene and dutiful, she’s inwardly torn between her spiritual role and her duties as a Harper operative. She’s recently returned from a failed mission to speak with the banshee Agatha (see the Banshee’s Bargain quest). • Race/Class: Moon elf, Cleric of Tymora (Trickery Domain) • Alignment: Chaotic Good • Visual Trait: A thin scar runs along her jawline, usually hidden beneath a lock of white-blonde hair. • Quirk: Flips a coin before making any major decision—even if it’s just for show.
Motivations & Hooks: • Wants trustworthy adventurers to help complete her failed mission (recovering knowledge from Agatha). • Will quietly recruit PCs into the Harpers if they impress her with selflessness or cleverness. • Secretly fears that Tymora’s luck is leaving her after her recent failure.
Sample Quips: • “Fortune doesn’t just favor the bold—it tests them.” • “The gods don’t speak plainly, but Tymora? She laughs.” • “I offer healing, but not absolution. That’s above my pay grade.”
Roleplay Tip: Play Garaele with quiet intensity and intelligence. She’s always reading people, rarely shows her full hand, and uses faith as both armor and mask

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 342

trait.name: Spellcasting
trait.text:
The acolyte is a 1st-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save DC 12, +4 to hit with spell attacks). The acolyte has following cleric spells prepared:
Cantrips (at will): light, sacred flame, thaumaturgy
• 1st level (3 slots): bless, cure wounds, sanctuary

action.name: Club
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +2 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 2 (1d4) bludgeoning damage.

spell.name: Light
spell.materials: a firefly or phosphorescent moss
spell.text:
You touch one object that is no larger than 10 feet in any dimension. Until the spell ends, the object sheds bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. The light can be colored as you like. Completely covering the object with something opaque blocks the light. The spell ends if you cast it again or dismiss it as an action.
If you target an object held or worn by a hostile creature, that creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw to avoid the spell.

spell.name: Sacred Flame
spell.text:
Flame-like radiance descends on a creature that you can see within range. The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take 1d8 radiant damage. The target gains no benefit from cover for this saving throw.
The spell's damage increases by 1d8 when you reach 5th level (2d8), 11th level (3d8), and 17th level (4d8).

spell.name: Thaumaturgy
spell.text:
You manifest a minor wonder, a sign of supernatural power, within range. You create one of the following magical effects within range.
• Your voice booms up to three times as loud as normal for 1 minute.
• You cause flames to flicker, brighten, dim, or change color for 1 minute.
• You cause harmless tremors in the ground for 1 minute.
• You create an instantaneous sound that originates from a point of your choice within range, such as a rumble of thunder, the cry of a raven, or ominous whispers.
• You instantaneously cause an unlocked door or window to fly open or slam shut.
• You alter the appearance of your eyes for 1 minute.
If you cast this spell multiple times, you can have up to three of its 1-minute effects active at a time, and you can dismiss such an effect as an action.

spell.name: Bless
spell.materials: a sprinkling of holy water
spell.text:
You bless up to three creatures of your choice within range. Whenever a target makes an attack roll or a saving throw before the spell ends, the target can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the attack roll or saving throw.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Cure Wounds
spell.text:
A creature you touch regains a number of hit points equal to 1d8 + your spellcasting ability modifier. This spell has no effect on undead or constructs.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the healing increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Sanctuary
spell.materials: a small silver mirror
spell.text:
You ward a creature within range against attack. Until the spell ends, any creature who targets the warded creature with an attack or a harmful spell must first make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature must choose a new target or lose the attack or spell. This spell doesn't protect the warded creature from area effects, such as the explosion of a fireball.
If the warded creature makes an attack or casts a spell that affects an enemy creature, this spell ends.

npc.label: Halia Thornton
npc.name: Commoner
npc.text:
Master of the Miner’s Exchange, Zhentarim Liaison, Political Opportunist
Location: Miner’s Exchange, Phandalin Stat Block: Use Cultist (MM p.345) with the following modifications: • +2 Intelligence (13 total) • Add Deception +4, Persuasion +4 • HP: 22 (4d8+4), AC: 12 • Add ability: Whispers of the Network. Once per day, Halia can cast comprehend languages or disguise self (Zhentarim connections provide magical favors).
Visuals & Personality • Appearance: Late thirties, businesslike yet elegant. Auburn hair in a tight bun, dark green eyes, always dressed in high-collar coats and silver-threaded gloves. A leather-bound ledger always on hand, pages filled with coded trade records and observations. • Demeanor: Calculating, ambitious, calm under pressure. She speaks like someone used to getting her way—never raises her voice, never wastes a word.
Quips and Roleplay Hooks 1. “Every coin spent in this town passes through my hands eventually. Best you stay on the right side of them.” 2. “Phandalin is a prize waiting for someone clever enough to claim it. I intend to be that someone.” 3. “Harbin may be the townmaster, but I’m the one who knows what’s really going on.” 4. “I deal in favors and futures. Gold’s just the middleman.” 5. “The Zhentarim? What an unpleasant rumor. But useful, if you know how to play them.”
Motivations and Secrets • Zhentarim Agent. Secretly reports to high-ranking Zhentarim operatives in Neverwinter. Her goal is to bring Phandalin under Zhentarim influence by controlling trade, security, and adventurer loyalty. • Power Broker. Sees the arrival of Cryovain as a power vacuum she can exploit. She aims to recruit or manipulate adventurers to clear threats, then fill the void with mercenaries loyal to her. • Eyes Everywhere. Pays off miners, prospectors, and traveling merchants for gossip. Keeps a coded ledger of adventuring parties and their deeds. • Stone-Cold Reaver Ties. Has paid mercenaries (like the Reavers) to test the waters in dangerous ruins. Unofficially endorses whatever it takes to claim valuable sites like Axeholm or the Dragon Barrow first. • Linked to Tyranny of Dragons. Could later possess or intercept messages connected to Cult activity—either as a foil to the players or as a reluctant informant seeking to stay ahead of the cult’s rise.
Potential Interactions • Information Broker. Offers intelligence, rumors, or minor magic items in exchange for favors. • Zhentarim Recruitment. Might try to seduce morally flexible PCs into joining her growing power base. • Faction Intrigue. Can become a recurring rival, uneasy ally, or secret villain—especially in faction politics (Harpers vs Zhentarim, etc.). • Quest Hook. “Find out who’s been selling to the orcs out of Axeholm—and don’t get caught looking.

npc.label: Harbin Wester
npc.name: Commoner [2024]
npc.text:
Location: Townmaster’s Hall, Phandalin Race: Human Alignment: Lawful Neutral (borderline coward) Stat Block: Commoner (PHB or Basic Rules) – Never fights, always hides.
DM Overview:
Harbin Wester is the cowardly, puffed-up bureaucrat of Phandalin. He holds the title of Townmaster, though few in town respect him—least of all the adventurers who come knocking. He never opens his door, preferring to speak through muffled yells, warped shutters, or the letter slot. Every interaction is an exercise in avoidance, evasion, and awkward public service.
He manages the Quest Board (reluctantly), and is the go-between for distributing rewards and accepting reports. He fears Cryovain, goblins, zombies, manticore feathers, strong accents, and most especially “adventurers with questions.”
Recurring Gag – The One-Gold Slot:
Harbin insists on paying rewards one gold piece at a time, slid meticulously under the door or through a mail slot. • He often counts them aloud as they come through: “One… Two… Oh drat, did that one roll away? Three…” • If the party tries to hurry him: “The sanctity of proper accounting cannot be rushed!”
Read-Aloud Example – Reward Pickup Scene:
The wooden door to the Townmaster’s Hall is closed tight, as always. A battered sign hangs slightly crooked: “Office Hours: Whenever I Feel Brave.” You hear rustling paper and a startled squeak from inside. A familiar voice calls out:
“Ah! You’ve returned! Brave souls, defenders of Phandalin! …You didn’t bring anything dangerous, did you?”
After a moment, a metal slot creaks open near the floor. One by one, gold coins begin to clink through—slowly. Painfully slowly.
“One… Two… You’re not peeking through the keyhole, are you? I—I have allergies!”
Quips & Voice Suggestions: • “The Townmaster is not currently available! Unless this is about paperwork!” • “Yes, yes, you’ve done marvelously. But please, take your terrifying dragon stories elsewhere.” • “You’ll find the payment… uh… under the door. Mind the splinter.” • “I was just about to come out! Just about. Very nearly.” • “If it helps, I have prepared a certificate of gratitude. It’s laminated!”
Personality & Motivation: • Visual Quirk: No one in town has seen Harbin in person for months. Even town meetings involve a drawn curtain and a shouting match. • Behavior: Paranoid, procedural, and peevishly self-important. He both fears adventurers and relies on them. • Motivation: Survive, keep his job, and avoid having to deal with anything “heroic.” • Secret Wish: Retire to Neverwinter and open a bakery that only serves scones.
DM Use & Hooks: • Comedic Relief NPC – Use Harbin as a contrast to brave adventurers. • Passive Quest Hub – Players may grow fond of his absurdity as they interact with the quest board. • Potential Twist: Harbin might secretly have information, if coaxed or tricked. Perhaps he’s seen strange letters, or been bribed by cultists without knowing. • Down the Line: Harbin may be replaced, or forced out of hiding, possibly by: • A town vote. • A direct crisis (e.g., Cryovain attacks Phandalin). • A heroic moment where he accidentally helps

npc.label: Linene Graywind
npc.name: Commoner [2024]
npc.text:
Location: Lionshield Coster, Phandalin Race/Class: Human commoner (noncombatant, but sharp and savvy) Faction Ties: Neutral with the Lords’ Alliance (potential contact if developed) Visual Trait: Wears a Lionshield-blue doublet over well-worn armor padding; short-cropped silver-streaked hair and a scar along her jawline from a bandit fight years ago. Voice/Quirk: Speaks plainly but with precision. She clicks her tongue when annoyed and keeps a crossbow leaned against the counter at all times. Quips: 1. “If you’re not here to trade or talk trouble, then you’re just here wasting both our time.” 2. “Every sword I sell has a story. Most of them end in blood.” 3. “Don’t bother lying to me—I’ve heard it all from men twice your size.” 4. “My coin’s good, my steel’s better, and my patience is razor-thin.” 5. “Dragons? No. Bandits? Every damn week. I’ll take the dragon.”
Role in the Adventure
Linene operates the Lionshield Coster, a merchant franchise known for shipping weapons and armor along the Sword Coast. She’s practical, no-nonsense, and always weighing risk versus reward. She primarily exists to: • Sell gear to players, especially martial weapons and light armor. • Reward characters who recover stolen Coster supplies from Cragmaw or other bandit groups (this hook is stronger in Lost Mine of Phandelver, but you can seed it in DoIP too). • Track rumors and trade disruptions caused by Cryovain’s reign of terror. • Offer leads on mercenary hires, missing caravans, or possible side work (especially if you want to transition to Tyranny of Dragons later).
Motivations & Hooks • Profit with Principle: Linene is business-minded but refuses to deal with known criminals or the Zhentarim. She’s shrewd, but not heartless. • Dragon Trouble: She’s keeping track of lost shipments and rumors about Cryovain. If the players help restore security, she’ll remember. • The Sword Coast’s Stability: Linene quietly believes the Lords’ Alliance isn’t doing enough. If you’re introducing factions, she might warm to the players as grassroots problem-solvers.
Exploration Interactions • Players might barter for gear, offer to escort caravans, or trade information about Cryovain and the region’s threats. • If the party recovers weapons marked with the Lionshield crest from bandits or monsters, she’ll offer a reward (up to 50 gp or a +1 weapon if you want to sweeten the pot)

npc.label: Elmar Barthen
npc.name: Commoner [2024]
npc.text:
Proprietor of Barthen’s Provisions Location: Barthen’s Provisions, eastern Phandalin
Visual Trait: A kindly human man in his early fifties, with wind-chapped cheeks, short brown hair streaked with gray, and hazel eyes that crinkle when he smiles. Always wears a thick leather apron and has callused hands from years of hauling crates.
Role in Town: Elmar owns the largest general goods store in Phandalin. Though not a combatant, he’s a pillar of support for local adventurers and settlers. He provides supplies, hears rumors from the road, and offers advice with a warm, steady presence.
Quips • “If you’re lookin’ to stock up before heading out, you’ve come to the right place.” • “I don’t sell weapons, but I can give you a biscuit and a reason to come home safe.” • “Phandalin’s seen worse. And we’ll see better—mark my words.” • “I miss that boy. Just a kid, barely more than a pup. Cryovain got him…” (trails off, then stiffens his jaw) “Go put that beast in the ground.”
Personality & Motivation • Temperament: Warm, grounded, and unfailingly patient. Treats adventurers like extended family, especially if they show kindness. • Backstory: Lost his young apprentice during Cryovain’s first attack. Doesn’t talk about it unless pushed, but it’s clear the grief sits close to the surface. • Motivations: • Keep his shop open as a lifeline for the town and adventurers. • Quietly supports the party’s efforts to take down Cryovain. • Offers discounted goods to those protecting Phandalin.
Services • Supplies: All basic adventuring gear from the PHB at standard prices. • Notable Items: Occasionally stocks potions of healing (if the town is restocked), warm cloaks, and rations from Triboar or Leilon. • Discounts: Offers 10–25% off to the party once they earn his trust by completing a quest or helping Phandalin

npc.label: Herbitha Finfine, Local Chef.
npc.name: Tortle
npc.text:
She's an all-baking, all-embroidering, all-worries midwestern Tortle Druid, based on my mom.
Race/Gender: Tortle Female Class/CR: Druid (CR 1, or use Druid Acolyte stat block as base) Location: Edge of Phandalin, in a tilted, mossy cottage patched with quilts and climbing ivy
Visual Traits: • Weathered green shell etched with embroidered patches, stitched in bright thread • Wide-brim straw hat with a plastic daisy on top • Wears a floral apron that smells like cinnamon and wet earth • Waddles slowly but talks real fast, hon
Voice/Quips (Midwest Mom Tortle): • “Ope, lemme just scoot past ya there.” • “I worry, y’know? This land’s got energy, bless its lil heart.” • “Don’t go skipping meals, dear—have a berry loaf, it’s fresh!” • “You see a circle of mushrooms, you turn around, hon. That’s not for us.” • “Have you spoken to your friends about your feelings lately? I’ve got tea.”
Wares & Offerings: • Herbal poultices and salves (+2 HP healing, 5gp each) • Foraged baked goods (lemonberry buns, apple acorn crisp, etc.) • Enchanted embroidery charms (minor buffs or narrative flavor items) • Can provide Goodberry, Speak with Animals, or Druidcraft upon request
Motivations: • Protect the natural balance near Phandalin from “riled-up roots and bad juju” • Make herself useful in town while not getting too involved (but she always does) • Uncover what’s disturbed the local plant spirits since Cryovain’s arrival
Minor Hooks: 1. Mushroom Circle Mystery: She’s noticed fey rings appearing more frequently near town. Something is stirring in the veil. 2. Baker’s Blessing: One of her cinnamon loaves is mysteriously linked to a charm of protection—why now? 3. Adabra’s Rivalry: Lighthearted friction with Adabra Gwynn: “I love her, bless her, but that gal doesn’t fold in the herbs proper.” 4. Embroidery of Memory: She’s stitching a dream she can’t explain—yellow flower, red string. She saw it in her sleep the same night Yote had his vision. 5. Shellbound Journal: She’s been recording omens from the wilds—strange winds, broken bird songs, and frost in summer.
How She Can Assist the Party: • Provides healing and baked goods between quests • Offers nature-based insights (cryptic but heartfelt) • Gives side quests involving fey, plants, or nature spirits • May reveal truths others miss (“That Halia gal? Her bread don’t rise right, if you catch my drift.”) • Could later become a conduit to fey or druidic power sources if things escalat

action.name: Shell Defense
action.text: The tortle withdraws into its shell. Until it emerges, it gains a +4 bonus to AC and has advantage on Strength and Constitution saving throws. While in its shell, the tortle is prone, its speed is 0 and can't increase, it has disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws, it can't take reactions, and the only action it can take is a bonus action to emerge.

Would sell out the group if it meant gold and dogs. • Combat Behavior: Hangs back, hurls insults, throws daggers

note.name: DM REFERENCE CARD: Stone-Cold Reavers
note.text:
Type: Rival Adventuring Gang Number: 4 Stat Block: Use the Veteran stat block (MM p350) for all Reavers. Adjust gear and damage to flavor. Alignment: Neutral Evil Factional Affiliation: None (Opportunists, but could be courted)
Tactics & Behavior • Combat: Brutal, direct, and disrespectful. Use terrain, flanking, and hit hard. Will flee if outmatched. • Social: Lie first, then threaten. Always looking for the edge—financial or moral. • Rival Tactic: Steal quests, claim rewards, take credit for other heroes’ work.
Members & Flavor
1. Syleen Wintermoon – The Brash Leader • Visual Trait: Long red ponytail, cracked scale armor, crooked grin. • Quips: 1. “You think you’re the heroes? That’s adorable.” 2. “First come, first paid.” 3. “We’ll save the town—right after we save our coin purse.” • Motivation: Profit and fame. Leads through sarcasm and swagger. • Combat Behavior: Strikes fast and taunts often.
2. Runa Vokdottir – The Enforcer • Visual Trait: Towering woman with frostbitten fingers, black braids, and a scarred cheek. • Quips: 1. “The sword’s not for show.” 2. “Weakness is nature’s way of saying goodbye.” • Motivation: Enjoys combat. Believes in strength and survival. • Combat Behavior: Frontline tank. Speaks little, hits hard.
3. Brakkis Elspaar – The Lazy Schemer • Visual Trait: Balding, barrel-bellied man with a wine-stained cloak and a belt of dice. • Quips: 1. “We doing this the easy way or the really easy way?” 2. “What if we don’t fight the monster and just say we did?” • Motivation: Comfort and retirement. Would sell out the group if it meant gold and dogs. • Combat Behavior: Hangs back, hurls insults, throws daggers.
4. Jabarl the Orc-Biter – The Brooding Muscle • Visual Trait: Shaved head, fur-lined cloak, knotted rope belt with orc tusks. • Quips: 1. “You talk too much.” 2. “I liked you better unconscious.” • Motivation: Fight and survival. Soft spot for animals. • Combat Behavior: Charges headlong, reckless but efficient.
Reputation in Phandalin • “Adventurers,” but seen as thugs by many. • Have collected a few bounties and rewards—often by deception or force. • Not trusted by Sister Garaele or Toblen Stonehill. • Harbin Wester is too intimidated (or ignorant) to push back

monster.label: Blimza the Barrelback
monster.name: Apprentice Wizard
monster.text: Race: Duergar | Role: Security & Testimonial Enforcer Visual: Thick arms, stony skin, covered in alchemical burns. Constantly chewing spicy roots. Quips: • “You open it, you own it.” • “You touch him, I squash you.

monster.label: Wizzleroot Nibblestem
monster.name: Apprentice Wizard
monster.text: Race: Rock Gnome | Class: Wild Magic Sorcerer Visual: Wispy white hair standing on end, oversized starry goggles, a purple robe covered in stitched-on potion labels. Quips: • “Side effects may include euphoria, vomiting, or existential dread!” • “Oh-ho! That wasn’t supposed to explode that violently.” • “You break it, you drink it!” Motivations: Sell potions, collect weird reagents, and find a buyer foolish enough to test his latest prototypes

note.name: Wizzle
note.text:
Accessing the Bazaar • The bazaar hovers between 30–60 feet in the air and teleports erratically every 2–3 days. • Customers are levitated one at a time via a magical lift circle at its base, activated by speaking the word: “Wizzlefizz!”
Key NPCs 1. Wizzleroot Nibblestem (he/him) Race: Rock Gnome | Class: Wild Magic Sorcerer Visual: Wispy white hair standing on end, oversized starry goggles, a purple robe covered in stitched-on potion labels. Quips: • “Side effects may include euphoria, vomiting, or existential dread!” • “Oh-ho! That wasn’t supposed to explode that violently.” • “You break it, you drink it!” Motivations: Sell potions, collect weird reagents, and find a buyer foolish enough to test his latest prototypes. 2. Blimza the Barrelback (she/her) Race: Duergar | Role: Security & Testimonial Enforcer Visual: Thick arms, stony skin, covered in alchemical burns. Constantly chewing spicy roots. Quips: • “You open it, you own it.” • “You touch him, I squash you.” 3. Candle (they/them) Race: Fire Genasi | Role: Potion Sommelier Visual: Glowing red eyes, soft voice, always wafting scents of potions before offering them. Quips: • “This one tastes like honey and dreams… or nightmares, depends on the taster.” • “Only a drop, love. The full dose is… transformative.”
Sample Potions for Sale
(Prices are wildly inconsistent, bartering encouraged) 1. Potion of Roachform (150 gp) • Effect: You transform into a roach for 1 hour. Cannot speak, but can crawl through 1-inch gaps. Reverts on death or dispel magic. • Hidden Effect: Addictive. First time is thrilling. Second time… necessary. 2. Fizzlepop Elixir (60 gp) • Effect: Gives you the ability to teleport up to 10 feet at will for 1 minute. Every use causes a small POP! sound and a 1d6 chance of swapping clothing color. 3. Wail of the Wyrmling (90 gp) • Effect: You breathe frost like a baby dragon. 15 ft. cone, 3d6 cold damage. Causes a sore throat for 24 hours. 4. Potion of Forgotten Names (50 gp) • Effect: You forget your own name for 1 hour. Immune to divination magic during this time. Can’t be magically tracked. • Bonus: Bards call this “performance fuel.” 5. Lustrous Hair Elixir (30 gp) • Effect: Your hair becomes preposterously long, luscious, and always blowing in wind. Permanent unless cut.
Hooks & Encounters 1. Tulie’s Whispers (Yote-specific) • A carved bone totem in a display case pulses with dream energy. Candle notices and says, “This… doesn’t belong to us, but it found its way here. Could be fate.” • Could lead to a new Quori-related sidequest. 2. Cryovain Bounty • Wizzleroot has a potion he claims is “Cryovain’s Bane”—a frothy blue draft that’s “guaranteed*” to help in dragon combat (*unproven, side effects include wing envy). 3. The Addicted Noble • A frantic noble is found on the edge of town begging for more Roachform. He claims it allows him to “sneak where the others can’t.” He may have seen something he shouldn’t have while in insect form… 4. Runaway Stall • A malfunctioning cart loaded with volatile potions detaches from the platform and crashes nearby. Time slows as the PCs race to defuse or contain the fallout

note.name: Intro Cutscene
note.text:
The sky hums—quiet at first, like a plucked harp string trembling in the clouds. A shimmer ripples across the air above you, bending light and wind. Then, with a sound somewhere between a thunderclap and a whoopee cushion, a ripple of magical energy bursts through the sky like a snapped curtain.
From nothing emerges something impossible: a massive, levitating object shaped like an upside-down wizard’s hat, its point bobbing lazily as it floats into view. The brim stretches nearly sixty feet across, with colorful patchwork stalls, swinging lanterns, and fluttering banners lashed to its edges by rope and spell alike.
A spiral of rainbow steam shoots from a copper pipe at the center, emitting a scent that’s equal parts cinnamon, sulfur, and… goat cheese? Sparks fly. Bells chime. One banner unfurls midair with a flourish and a magical voice echoes across the sky like a carnival barker announcing the end of days:
“WIZZLEROOT’S FLYING FIZZLE! HOME OF HICCUPING ELIXIRS, BEWITCHING BREWS, AND EXPERIMENTAL CONCOCTIONS PROBABLY LEGAL IN NEVERWINTER!”
A glowing rune flashes beneath the bazaar, revealing a floating disc—an arcane elevator—that slowly descends with a wet “pop” sound and hovers just above the ground. Painted in glittering blue letters is a simple word:
WIZZLEFIZZ.
The disc waits patiently, vibrating like an overexcited puppy, daring someone to step aboard

note.name: Phandalin
note.text:
A frontier town of old ruins, new hope, and frequent danger.
Phandalin – Summary for the DM • Population: ~40 residents and a handful of travelers • Tone: Scrappy and resilient. People are cautious but welcoming to heroes. • Backdrop: Built atop ruins of the original town, destroyed centuries ago. • Current Tension: Cryovain, a young white dragon, has been spotted near Icespire Peak. Townsfolk are frightened. Some stay quiet, others demand action.
Phandalin at a Glance (Key Locations & NPCs)
Townmaster’s Hall • Harbin Wester: Pudgy, paranoid bureaucrat. Posts bounties, avoids risk. • Use It For: Posting quests, hearing town gossip, introducing plot hooks.
Stonehill Inn • Toblen Stonehill: Warm-hearted innkeeper. Former city-dweller from Triboar. • Use It For: Gathering rumors, offering the party a place to stay (5 sp/night), light-hearted moments.
Shrine of Luck (Tymora) • Sister Garaele: Harper agent, calm and clever. Offers divine insight and secret missions. • Use It For: Divine guidance, Harper involvement, hidden agendas.
Barthen’s Provisions • Elmar Barthen: Friendly older merchant. Honest and talkative. • Use It For: Gear resupply, local rumors, delivery-based quest seeds.
Lionshield Coster • Linene Graywind: Stern and practical weapon merchant. • Use It For: Arms and armor, tense negotiations, offering help defending the town.
Miners’ Exchange • Halia Thornton: Ambitious and persuasive; Zhentarim-aligned. • Use It For: Mercenary jobs, shady side quests, moral dilemmas.
Phandalin Encounter Seeds
You can sprinkle these in between adventures or when the party wants to roam the town: • A farmer reports a cow frozen solid overnight—nothing else touched. • Children claim a strange pale man is hiding in the ruins at dusk. • A caravan from Neverwinter is late—very late. • A local blacksmith goes missing, and the forge is found cold. • Halia Thornton hires mercenaries with unknown goals. • Sister Garaele asks the party to escort her to a secret meeting outside town. • The tap house erupts into a bar fight when a Zhentarim spy is outed. • A drunk in the inn swears he saw the dragon land atop an old dwarven shrine.
Phandalin Rumors and Hooks
Give your players things to chase, true or not: • “I heard the dragon’s hoard is in the ruined dwarven mine.” • “The Sleeping Giant has a tunnel in the cellar—smuggler’s route, maybe.” • “Sister Garaele speaks to ghosts when no one’s around.” • “The old town well? They say it goes all the way to the Underdark.” • “Toblen’s boy saw kobolds with glowing collars out by the ridge.” • “The Lionshield Coster lost a whole shipment—no signs of tracks.”
Tone Tips: Running Phandalin • Play up the small town familiarity—everyone knows everyone else. • Locals are hopeful but stressed. Many remember the Redbrand occupation, and fear trouble rising again. • Cryovain’s presence has tightened the town’s nerves—some want to fight, others want to flee. • Offer moments of warmth: shared stew at the inn, kids chasing dogs, a dwarf carving mushrooms into toys.
Where Can the Party Stay? 1. Stonehill Inn – Comfortable rooms, meals, stories by the hearth. 2. Toblen’s Spare Barn – Offered free for “hero types” who don’t mind hay and mice. 3. Miners’ Exchange Bunkhouse – Hard beds, suspicious stares, and strong ale

note.name: Phandalin Tales (d20) Use Anywhere
note.text:
Phandalin Tales (d10 Table)
These rumors circulate around the Stonehill Inn, whispered over mugs of ale and exchanged beside flickering hearths.
d10 Tale 1 “A tower collapsed west of town the other night, and some say it was struck by lightning from a cloudless sky.” — The ruined Tower of Storms is a site of storm-worship and dire rituals. The beacon pulses with an eerie green light that lures ships to wreckage. 2 “A halfling prospecting near the mountains heard strange voices echoing from deep within the stone.” — A potential lead to the Dwarven Excavation, or perhaps something darker—an ancient spirit or slumbering elemental force. 3 “They say the Circle of Thunder glows during storms, and lightning dances between its stones.” — A hint at the anchorites of Talos and the ritual site where Gorthok the Thunder Boar might be summoned. 4 “A merchant passed through Conyberry claiming ogres had taken over an old shrine just south of town.” — A hook for the Shrine of Savras, now overrun with orcs and ogres displaced by Cryovain. The gold bell’s secret may still lie undiscovered. 5 “Grannoc, the mad druid, wandered into town muttering about ‘roots with teeth’ and ‘lightning in the blood.’ Then he vanished into the woods.” — A lead to the Woodland Manse, or possibly the Circle of Thunder if tied to the anchorites’ storm rituals. 6 “The gnomes of Gnomengarde have gone quiet. Some say they’re working on a flying machine; others say a shapechanger got in.” — A quirky yet dangerous opening for the Gnomengarde adventure, possibly involving paranoia or paranoia-inducing magic. 7 “A child claims to have seen a white dragon circling Icespire Peak, its breath freezing birds in midair.” — A chilling omen that directly foreshadows Cryovain, suitable as early or ongoing buildup. 8 “Falcon’s Hunting Lodge hasn’t sent word in weeks. Folks say the forest spirits have turned against them.” — A cue to investigate Falcon’s Lodge, where corruption and unnatural magic may be taking hold. 9 “Someone broke into the miners’ exchange—nothing stolen, just symbols carved into the floor, glowing like starlight.” — A hint at arcane interference, a potential connection to Selûne, or an optional quest tied to a PC’s backstory (e.g. Nsyldam or Yote). 10 “The sea near the cliffs glows green at night, and fishermen whisper of songs on the wind.” — A moody, mythic lead-in to the Tower of Storms and its harpies, wrecks, and the lingering power of Talos
“You didn’t hear it from me, but…”
1. “The dragon’s been seen roosting atop Icespire Peak.”
NPC: Toblen Stonehill, human innkeeper, wears a blacksmith’s apron over his barkeep’s garb—never gave up old habits. Note: True. Cryovain lairs there.
2. “Halia Thornton’s got a map to a dwarven vault under the town.”
NPC: Daran Edermath, half-elf orchard-keeper, silver hair in a warrior’s tail, sword calluses on both hands. Note: False… probably.
3. “The Shrine of Luck has started glowing after sundown.”
NPC: Sister Garaele, elf acolyte, violet robes and a silver star-pendant that vibrates softly when danger is near. Note: True, but it’s the faerzress increasing underground.
4. “There’s a tunnel under the Sleeping Giant. Smugglers used it once.”
NPC: Grista, dwarf barkeep, scar over her left brow and a chipped tankard always on her belt. Note: True, but the tunnel collapsed years ago.
5. “Linene keeps a magic sword under the counter. It hums.”
NPC: Linene Graywind, human merchant, sharp-eyed, with a jagged scar across one knuckle—duelist’s mark. Note: True. She doesn’t advertise it.
6. “The old town well is haunted. Voices echo from below.”
NPC: Pip Stonehill, human boy, missing front tooth, oversized boots he refuses to take off. Note: Mostly false—but the well does connect to older ruins.
7. “Barthen’s two assistants are actually twins raised by gnomes.”
NPC: Thistle, human teen, curly red hair and grease-stained gloves. Note: False. She made it up herself.
8. “The dragon froze a cow in the Alderleaf field and left it standing.”
NPC: Qelline Alderleaf, halfling farmer, sun-leathered skin, always chewing a sprig of grass. Note: True. It spooked her goats for days.
9. “The Miners’ Exchange is a front for Zhentarim spies.”
NPC: Halia Thornton, human guildmaster, red-lacquered fingernails and a cloak that always smells faintly of roses. Note: True. Halia recruits quietly.
10. “There’s a talking fox in the woods to the east.”
NPC: Carver, elf trapper, one-eyed with a feather charm braided into her hair. Note: False—though druids have been known to take animal form near Phandalin.
11. “A ghost sings lullabies near the Alderleaf well at night.”
NPC: Reed Dovetail, gnome mason, wears one earring made of carved driftwood. Note: Unknown. Locals swear it sounds like a mother’s voice.
12. “Sister Garaele’s pendant glows when liars speak.”
NPC: Karna, tiefling mercenary-for-hire, black scales flecked with red; always sharpening something. Note: False—but the pendant is holy and reactive to magic.
13. “Redbrand ghosts haunt the old manor. One calls out for Sildar.”
NPC: Sildar Hallwinter, human warrior, graying at the temples and walks with a limp he never speaks of. Note: Possibly true. The manor still gives him nightmares.
14. “The gnomes in Tinkleguard are making a dragon-slaying machine.”
NPC: Belwar, svirfneblin emissary, skin like stone and eyes too big for his face. Note: Mostly false, but the gnomes are inventing something… chaotic.
15. “The Sleeping Giant’s beer is cursed. You’ll dream of screaming.”
NPC: Toby Hardshell, human miner, missing three teeth and wears goggles even at night. Note: False. Grista just makes it strong and cheap.
16. “A half-orc named Skarn is burying something out in the orchard at night.”
NPC: Skarn, half-orc trapper, massive frame and a perpetual black eye. Note: True. It’s money—he doesn’t trust banks.
17. “Phandelver’s Pact isn’t just a legend. It was a deal with something else.”
NPC: Old Magda, human widow, wrapped in wool shawls, missing her left ear. Note: True. But the truth is buried… literally.
18. “Daran has a map to an ancient Moon Elf vault under the orchard.”
NPC: Daran Edermath, half-elf (repeated for relevance), with a blade hidden in his cane. Note: False… unless he forgot where he put it.
19. “A masked figure walks the hills at night, humming lullabies.”
NPC: Jalessa Orna, dwarf glassblower, arms like tree trunks and a burn scar on her left cheek. Note: Unconfirmed. Some think it’s a ghost. Some think it’s a bard with bad taste.
20. “Cryovain is hunting people, not treasure. It remembers faces.”
NPC: Harrow, drow exile, white hair braided tight, one gold tooth inscribed with a rune. Note: Unknown. He claims he saw it speak in dreams

note.name: Stonehill Inn
note.text:
Stonehill Inn
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
Warm lamplight spills through the windows of this modest, two-story stone-and-timber inn. A hand-painted sign swings gently above the door, etched with a hilltop beneath a rising sun.
Inside, the air smells of hearthfire, sourdough, and mushroom stew. A few travelers nurse mugs of ale while a young human boy clears empty plates. The tavern is clean, lived-in, and humming with quiet conversation.
A sturdy man behind the bar offers you a nod and a practiced, hopeful smile.
Primary NPC: Toblen Stonehill • Occupation: Innkeeper and owner of the Stonehill Inn • Race: Human • Age: Late 30s • Visual Trait: Thick brown beard with a single silver streak braided through it • Personality: Friendly, practical, protective of his family and townsfolk • Quip: “New in town? Welcome. Try the stew. If it doesn’t fill you, the ale’ll drown the rest.”
Background Info (for the DM):
Toblen is originally from Triboar, where life was harder and colder. He moved to Phandalin to raise a family somewhere quieter. He’s married to a woman named Trilena, and they have a young son, Pip, who often busses tables and eavesdrops on adventurers.
Toblen dislikes Harbin Wester (the cowardly townmaster), has no love for the Zhentarim, and remains on friendly terms with Sister Garaele. He keeps tabs on travelers and adventurers but doesn’t pry—unless something seems off.
Use This Location For: • Gathering rumors or quest leads • Introducing Toblen as a trustworthy local ally • Giving players a warm, safe place to rest (5 sp per night, meals included) • Letting NPCs deliver rumors or intrigue during dinner or drinks • Early hooks: Pip overhears things or wants to be an adventurer himself

note.name: Barthen’s Provisions
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
This long, single-story building is one of the largest in town, its beams reinforced with fresh wood and the scent of sawdust still lingering. The sign above the door shows a full backpack and a loaf of bread. Outside, a pair of young humans unload sacks of grain from a stubborn mule.
Inside, shelves are packed with trail gear, barrels of dry goods, crates of ironmongery, and glass jars filled with nails, buttons, and bits of brass.
A round-faced, rosy-cheeked man with a stained apron leans over a ledger, humming tunelessly until he sees you.
“Well now, you’re either hungry, lost, or about to walk into trouble. Which is it?”
NPC: Elmar Barthen • Race: Human • Age: Mid-50s • Visual Trait: Ink-stained fingers, spectacles always perched halfway down his nose • Personality: Warm, observant, dotes on adventurers like a favorite uncle • Quip: “If it fits in a pack or keeps you fed, I’ve got it. If it bites or blasts, that’s Linene’s department.”
Background (source-faithful):
Elmar is an honest and well-respected merchant. He doesn’t deal in weapons or armor, but he stocks virtually all adventuring gear found in the Player’s Handbook, up to 25 gp in value. He is concerned about the rising threat of Cryovain and is grateful to anyone helping protect the town.
He’s supported by two teenage helpers: • Ander: Wide-eyed, eager, always dropping things • Thistle: Sharper, suspicious of strangers, trying to act grown-up
Inventory Highlights (Sample Stock List)
(All standard PHB prices unless noted)
Travel & Trail Goods • Backpacks, bedrolls, mess kits, rations (1-day, 5 sp), waterskins • Torches, lanterns (hooded and bullseye), flasks of oil, tinderboxes • Rope (silk or hempen), pitons, hammers, grappling hooks • Caltrops (bag of 20), ball bearings, marbles • Climbing kits, fishing tackle, basic sewing kits
Food Supplies • Loaf of mushroom bread (2 cp) • Hard cheese wedge (1 sp) • Dried fruit bundle (5 sp) • Smoked rothé sausage (1 sp per link) • Small cask of ale (2 gp) • Large wheel of gnomish hard cheese (10 gp, “lasts a month, even if you don’t”)
Camping / Utility • Tent (2-person), cooking pots, firewood bundle • Chalk (various colors), ink, quills, parchment • Small mirror (5 gp), signal whistle, hourglass (if available, 25 gp)
Not for Sale • Weapons, armor, spell components (unless very basic) “You’ll want to talk to Linene over at the Lionshield Coster for anything with a blade.”
DM Tips: What Barthen Knows • Dragon sightings: “Heard the Cryo-thing was spotted over Umbrage Hill last week. Poor Adabra…” • Tinkleguard gnomes: “Odd bunch. Send foraged goods now and again. No word lately.” • Redbrand leftovers: “Don’t mention that name around Sister Garaele if you like being blessed.”
Using Barthen’s in Play • A quiet, safe place for players to resupply and hear town gossip • Barthen could ask a favor if the party becomes trusted: “Could you bring this parcel to Falcon’s lodge? It’s… fragile. And somewhat furry.” • He may reward dependable PCs with a discount or free item • Ander or Thistle might tag along on errands (if players allow it), adding light roleplay or comic relief

note.name: Lionshield Coster
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
A crisp, blue-shield emblem hangs over the doorway of this warehouse-like building—its paint freshly touched up, its shutters bolted open. Inside, the air smells of oiled leather, metal polish, and ink.
Shelves of well-made goods line the walls: coiled whips, bundled javelins, reinforced packs, and crates marked with the Lionshield crest. Behind the counter, a no-nonsense woman inspects a shipment manifest while a crossbow rests within arm’s reach.
She glances up just long enough to assess you, then says, dryly:
“You buying, selling, or causing problems?”
Primary NPC: Linene Graywind • Race: Human • Age: Early 40s • Visual Trait: A long scar across one knuckle; always wears her blue Lionshield vest over hardened leather • Personality: Blunt, practical, loyal to those who earn it • Quip: “Every blade’s got a story. Most of them end the same.”
Background Info (for the DM):
Linene is the Phandalin agent of the Lionshield Coster, a merchant company based in Yartar. She sells weapons, armor, and adventuring gear—and takes pride in fair dealing and high quality. She doesn’t tolerate thieves, drunkards, or Redbrand sympathizers.
She recently recovered a stolen shipment (intercepted near Cragmaw territory). She may reward adventurers who assist her with protecting future deliveries—or who report trouble on the roads.
She has military training and recognizes discipline in others. If the party earns her respect, she can become a valuable supplier or silent ally.
Inventory Highlights (PHB Prices Apply)
Weapons & Ammo • Longswords, shortswords, spears, maces • Longbows, shortbows, crossbows (light/heavy), darts • Arrows & bolts (1 gp per 20) • Throwing axes, daggers, javelins, quarterstaffs
Armor • Padded, leather, and studded leather armor • Chain shirts and chainmail • Shields (wood and steel variants)
Note: Anything heavier than chainmail must be special-ordered (arrives in 1d4+2 days).
Adventuring Supplies • Weapon polish, whetstones • Arrow repair kits • Scabbards and weapon loops • Quivers, crossbow cranks, bowstrings • “Monster Mark” paint vials (non-magical dye used to tag or mark slain creatures)
Use This Location For: • Letting the players resupply or upgrade gear • Having Linene offer militia-style contracts or paid jobs (e.g., escorting caravans, investigating bandits) • Showing lawful, grounded NPCs who don’t back down from threats • Hinting at wider commerce networks (Yartar, Triboar, Neverwinter)
Optional Rumor or Hook • Linene recently intercepted a coded letter hidden in a shipment—it’s in Thieves’ Cant. She doesn’t understand it, but offers it to trusted adventurers for “a discount and a favor.” • She suspects Halia Thornton is arming someone quietly—but she has no proof

note.name: Miner’s Exchange
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
Set against the rising slope at the edge of town, this sturdy stone building wears no sign—but the hammer-and-pick carved above the door speaks clearly. Its windows are narrow and shuttered, and a half-dozen heavy crates sit on the front porch under a tarp.
Inside, the walls are lined with ledgers, mining tools, and ore samples in labeled drawers. The air smells like dust, ink, and stone. Behind a broad desk stacked with documents, a poised woman in a deep green cloak looks up slowly.
“Adventurers,” she says, smiling like a chess player with one hand on the board. “Let’s talk opportunity.”
Primary NPC: Halia Thornton • Race: Human • Age: Late 30s • Visual Trait: Jet-black hair in a coiled bun, a silver ring shaped like a snake always on her left hand • Personality: Calculating, charismatic, confident; chooses words carefully • Quip: “There’s gold in the stone, and power in the knowing. Which are you after?”
Background Info (for the DM):
Halia Thornton is the guildmaster of the Phandalin Miners’ Exchange, where prospectors and miners bring raw ore to be weighed, logged, and paid for. It’s also a power base—Halia has connections to the Zhentarim, though she keeps her affiliation quiet.
She believes Phandalin needs strong leadership, and she doesn’t trust Harbin Wester to provide it. She may attempt to manipulate or recruit the party—especially if they show ruthless or pragmatic leanings.
Halia doesn’t deal in brute force. She offers influence, secrets, and gold.
Use This Location For: • Delivering morally gray quests or offers • Providing “legitimate” income for PCs willing to do grunt work (e.g., guarding caravans, clearing tunnels) • Introducing Zhentarim contacts or conflicts • Setting up political tension in Phandalin
Services / Functionality • Weighs and purchases ore, gems, rare stone (good place to cash in mining loot) • Sells mining gear (pickaxes, blasting powder, lanterns) • Offers contracts to those who protect trade routes or investigate tunnel collapses • May offer payment for information on rivals, including Harbin, Sister Garaele, or Linene
Optional Rumor or Hook • Halia asks the party to deliver a sealed letter to a contact near Butterskull Ranch. She doesn’t say what it contains. • A miner claims he saw Halia speaking to a shadowed figure in the woods behind her building. She denies everything

note.name: Shrine Of Luck
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
Tucked into a quiet corner of town is a humble open-air shrine built from smooth river stones and weathered wood. Carved into the stone archway above the altar is the smiling face of Tymora, goddess of good fortune.
Bundles of dried flowers, tiny tokens, and copper coins line the base of the altar. Faint blue light glimmers from within the cracks of the stone—whether from faith or magic, it’s unclear.
Kneeling in front of the altar is a slender elf in travel-worn robes, her hands folded in quiet prayer. She opens one eye as you approach and gives a half-smile.
“Careful. Fortune favors the bold, but she tests the reckless.”
Primary NPC: Sister Garaele • Race: Moon Elf • Age: Appears in her early 30s, but carries centuries of calm • Visual Trait: Silver hair braided with blue thread, and a crescent tattoo of Tymora on her left palm • Personality: Gentle, perceptive, speaks in quiet truths • Quip: “When fortune speaks, she often whispers. Listen closely.”
Background Info (for the DM):
Sister Garaele is a cleric of Tymora and a member of the Harpers, though she keeps her affiliation hidden unless trust is earned. She’s known in town as a healer, confidante, and keeper of quiet secrets.
She believes in protecting the innocent and quietly opposing tyranny. She may become a strong ally for morally inclined parties, or offer coded warnings to those walking a dangerous path.
She tends the shrine alone, but never seems afraid—even of the dragon.
Use This Location For: • Providing healing or divine spells (free for good deeds, otherwise 25–50 gp donations) • Quiet conversation away from the tavern bustle • Introducing the Harpers subtly • Receiving divine guidance, omens, or magical rumors • Low-magic moments of hope, faith, and mystery
Shrine Functions • Spells offered: cure wounds, lesser restoration, identify, augury (at her discretion) • Donations accepted, never demanded • Secret missions: If the party earns her trust, Garaele may offer a Harper-related quest (e.g., recovering a lost artifact or tracking a Zhentarim agent)
Optional Rumor or Hook • Garaele mentions unrest in the Wealdath, a forest far to the south, and asks if the party has heard anything unusual. • On quiet nights, the shrine glows blue from within—some say Tymora walks here in spirit. Others think something ancient stirs beneath the town

note.name: Townmaster’s Hall
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
This plain, boxy building sits at the heart of Phandalin like it’s trying not to be noticed. A peeling sign reads “Townmaster’s Hall,” and a bulletin board outside displays several weathered parchments stamped with official-looking seals.
The front door is unlocked, but the office beyond it is quiet—too quiet. A large oak door at the back of the room is shut tight, and from behind it, you hear the squeak of a chair, the thump of shuffling papers, and the unmistakable sound of a nervous man clearing his throat.
Then comes a voice—nasal, muffled, and just a bit high-pitched:
“Er, yes! Adventurers, splendid! Just take a look at the board, won’t you? All quite dangerous! But very important! Yes… carry on, then!
NPC: Harbin Wester • Race: Human • Visual Trait: Thick spectacles, wispy comb-over, and a shiny brass chain of office he polishes obsessively • Personality: Cowardly, officious, desperate for capable help but afraid to ask directly • Quip: “Very well then, brave adventurers! If you’d kindly take care of the dragon, or the undead, or… well, anything, really—that would be splendid.”
Official Quest Listings
Each quest appears as a parchment notice on the town bulletin board, written in Harbin’s shaky hand and signed with his wax seal.
Initial Tier Quests (Party Level 1–4)
1. Dwarven Excavation Quest • “Dwarves are excavating ruins in the mountains southwest of Phandalin. They need to be warned of the dragon and helped if trouble arises.” • Reward: 50 gp • Follow-Up: No direct follow-up, but may lead into Dragon Barrow Quest
2. Gnomengarde Quest • “A clan of reclusive rock gnomes in the mountains south of town may have inventions to help Phandalin. Offer them aid and request their assistance.” • Reward: 50 gp • Follow-Up: Completing this opens potential access to gnome-made magic items and alliances
3. Umbrage Hill Quest • “Adabra Gwynn, a midwife and alchemist at Umbrage Hill, must be warned of the dragon. If she refuses to leave, ensure she’s safe.” • Reward: 25 gp • Follow-Up: Completing this allows Adabra to assist the town and possibly provide potions in later quests
Second Tier Quests (Party Level 4–6)
(Unlocked once the party completes two initial quests)
4. Butterskull Ranch Quest • “An orc raiding party has attacked Butterskull Ranch. Travel there and ensure the safety of the rancher, Alfonse ‘Big Al’ Kalazorn.” • Reward: 100 gp • Follow-Up: May hint at orc movements relevant to later quests
5. Loggers’ Camp Quest • “A logging camp east of Phandalin hasn’t reported in. Check on the camp and ensure it’s not been attacked by the dragon or worse.” • Reward: 100 gp • Follow-Up: May lead into Woodland Manse Quest
6. Mountain’s Toe Gold Mine Quest • “The Mountain’s Toe mine needs protection from nearby threats and dragon sightings. Escort supplies and clear the area.” • Reward: 100 gp • Follow-Up: Leads directly into the Dragon Barrow Quest
Final Tier Quests (Party Level 6–7)
(Unlocked once the party completes two second-tier quests)
7. Axeholm Quest • “Axeholm, a ruined dwarven fortress, may serve as a defensible location against the dragon. Cleanse the site and secure it.” • Reward: 250 gp • Follow-Up: Unlocks Axeholm as a potential stronghold for the town
8. Dragon Barrow Quest • “A legendary sword, Dragon Slayer, lies buried in a barrow protected by undead. Retrieve it to aid in the defense against the dragon.” • Reward: 500 gp • Follow-Up: Crucial for the final battle against Cryovain
9. Woodland Manse Quest • “A cult tied to elemental evil occupies a ruined manse deep in the Neverwinter Wood. Defeat them and eliminate their influence.” • Reward: 250 gp • Follow-Up: May tie into future cultist activity or foreshadow other campaigns (like Princes of the Apocalypse)
10. Icespire Hold Quest (Final Confrontation) • “Cryovain, the white dragon, lairs atop Icespire Hold. Defeat the beast and secure the region once more.” • Reward: 1,000 gp • Follow-Up: Ends the main threat of the adventure. Phandalin hails the party as heroes.
DM Tips • Use Harbin’s nervous nature for comic relief or frustration—he’s terrified of danger but grateful for help • Posting the quests gradually builds a sense of pacing and choice • Harbin may offer “bonuses” (extra gold, town favor, or simple deeds of gratitude) for clearing out multiple threats in one trip • You can have NPCs request different quests first based on what matters to them (e.g., Garaele urging Umbrage Hill, Halia supporting the Loggers’ Camp)

note.name: The Stone Cold Reavers Steal Dwarven Excavation!
note.text:
1. Arrival at the Site • The Reavers show up loud and overconfident, weapons drawn. • They start barking orders at Dazlyn and Norbus without asking questions. • Runa threatens to “shut them in the sarcophagus if they keep whining.”
2. Exploration Style • They split up—terrible idea. • Brakkis wanders off, sits on a stone that happens to be the ochre jelly’s lair. • They engage it. Jabarl splits the jelly. Moaning. Cursing. Running. • They flee the ruins after torching half the interior and never figuring out the mystery of the dwarven gods or the shrine.
3. Convincing Harbin Wester • They drag a cracked dwarven helmet back as “proof.” • They scribble some dwarven-looking symbols onto parchment (clearly nonsense). • They fake a letter from “Dazlyn” saying, “Thanks, Reavers. You’re the real heroes.” • They hand it all under Harbin’s office door like a group of absolute grifters.
Read-Aloud Scene: The Reavers Claim Their Reward
Location: Outside the locked office door of the Townmaster’s Hall in Phandalin. It’s dusk. The Reavers are lined up like thugs at a vending machine, kneeling one at a time to collect their gold from under the slot in the door, while Harbin nervously verifies their story from the other side.
Read-Aloud Text:
The wooden floor creaks under heavy boots as four grimy, scarred adventurers lounge in front of the Townmaster’s Hall—each one taking turns at the barred door like it’s pay day at a butcher’s stall.
Behind the thick oaken slab, you hear the tremble of a man too scared to show his face.
“Er… and you’re sure the site is safe?” comes Harbin Wester’s voice—muffled, anxious, and nasally.
Syleen Wintermoon leans close to the slot and taps it with a knuckle. “Cleaned out. Nothing but old bones and empty rocks now. Orcs wouldn’t dare go near it after what we did.”
“We also, uh, recovered this…” Brakkis says, shoving a cracked dwarven helm through the slot. “Very dwarfy. Probably sacred. You’re welcome.”
Runa Vokdottir tosses in a stained note scrawled with blocky symbols and misspelled thanks: “Dazlen says we saved his short little beard.”
From behind the door, you hear the clink of coins. One by one, small leather pouches are pushed under the door. The Reavers crouch to collect them like wolves sniffing out marrow.
“That’s what I like about you, Harbin,” Jabarl grunts as he pockets his share. “You pay up and you don’t ask too many questions.”
“Y-you’re heroes! Yes, heroes! Let’s not… dwell,” Harbin stammers.
“Exactly,” Syleen smirks, flipping a coin up and catching it. “And we’re always available. For the right price.”
What This Sets Up for the PCs • When the party arrives at the site later, they find: • The dwarves still alive but furious and stranded. • Evidence of a half-assed expedition: charred ruins, slashed books, disrespectful graffiti. • The ochre jelly might still be lurking (or its split half), still dangerous. • In Phandalin, word spreads fast that the Reavers “already did the work.” • Harbin is smugly convinced he paid the right people. • The party now has to undo the damage, clear the actual threat, and win back credibility

note.name: Bounty Board
note.text:
· I saw you at the [insert name of local shop here]. My name is Bart, and I told you that I was leaving town in a couple of days. I changed my mind and would like to find you and take you to dinner. I’m staying at the [insert name of local inn here] if you’re interested.
· I’m looking for a hard-working farm hand. Must know how to ride a horse, round up cattle, and build fences, or be a quick learner. Pays 2 GP per tenday with room and board. For directions to the farm, talk with Gregory Stones at the [insert name of local inn here].
· I need some trees cut down, chopped up, and stacked. I’m getting too old for this. I can give you a warm place to stay, and three meals a day for as long as it takes. Talk to Manny Gusto at the [insert name of local tavern here]. I left my contact information with him.
· I woke up on the side of the road next to a large rock. My head was injured and now I can’t remember who I am. Please help me! My name is [“My name is” is scratched out.] Just call me “Jack” for now. If you can help, meet me outside of town on the [insert name of road nearby]. I’m camped out by that stupid rock. Apparently I have some coin. [If they take this quest, they can find his body. Bandits have taken his belongings, including the coin.]
· My eyesight is almost gone. I need someone to help me daily. I can pay 1 SP per day. You will be required to provide general care for me. You can have one of my rooms. Ask Mr. Smithson at the [insert name of local shop here] for more information. Written by Vern Smithson.
· I’m looking for someone who wants to spend five days per tenday picking and peelin apples. Must have stamina. Pays 2 SP per day. Inquire at the Rosebud Winery.
· Looking for someone to help clean up fish carcasses along the river bank. Pays 2 SP per day. If interested, ask for Steward Mick Moore at the [insert name of town hall here]. (Mick is in charge of city clean up.)
· Join our bird watching society, The Cheery Chirps. Come spend a couple hours a day with us if you enjoy watching a variety of birds in their natural habitat. We meet each day at noon near the [insert city entrance/gate here].
· Do you have young ones that want to learn how to play music? I will come to your home to teach the flute, lute, viol, and lyre. One hour lessons for 1 SP each. I am a professional. My name is Theresa and I play at the [insert name of tavern here] in the evenings.
· I’m looking to hire a couple of apprentices who want to learn how to build. I’m currently building a home [insert location here]. Ask for Calvin there. Pays at the end of each tenday.
· Need a translator? I fluently speak Orc, Goblin, and Giant. My fee depends on the amount of translation required. I can travel if needed, but I require that you provide my lodging and food if available. Leave your contact information with Char at the [insert name of tavern here].
· I am good with children, and can teach them to read and write. I will work with them three days per tenday for two hours each lesson, 5 CP per child. My name is Grace. Leave your contact info with Helga at the [insert name of inn here].
· I saw a dragon fly overhead a few days ago! It was immense, and red! I’m not seeing things, I don’t care what the city guards say! I saw it! Be ready to flee!
· I’m taking on an apprentice at the smithy. My former apprentice thinks he’s ready to run his own shop so he quit. He didn’t listen well anyway. I’m looking for someone who pays attention and has patience. I pay at the end of every tenday.
· I’m looking for strong backs to carry and load blocks. We work eight hours each day for five days per tenday. Pays well. Look for Adren Stoneshield at the quarry.
· I am giving swimming lessons at the [insert name of body of water here]. 4 CP per lesson. We meet each day two hours after sun rise. Ask for Matilda.
· I just bought some land and am starting a farm. I’m looking for someone with the knowledge to dig a well. We can discuss payment after I deem you’re qualified to do the job. Take the [insert name of road here] about ¾ of a mile outside of the city/town. You’ll see a barn being built on the right. My name is Herman.
· I can paint your family portrait. Be prepared to spend six hours with me. I take pride in my work. The cost is 5 SP per person in the portrait. I can paint family pets too! Let’s make memories together. I am usually set up at the [insert name of city/town market here]. My name is Vivian.
· Can you sing? Come join our acapella choir! We practice at the end of each tenday at the [insert name of temple here].
· Do you have arms? If so, you can work for me! I’m looking for someone to pick apples at my orchard. 1 SP per bushel. Come to the Happy Worm Orchard for more info. … Also, you must have legs. ("Also, you must have legs," appears to have been added later)
· I broke my arm and can’t afford a cleric to heal it, so it’s going to be a few weeks before I can get back to work. I will pay someone to help me around the house and pick up the slack on the farm. You will be taking care of my animals and keeping the barn straightened up and tidy. Free room and board for the duration, which is probably around 4 to 6 weeks. I’ll pay 2 SP per day. My name is Allan Toure. Directions on the other side. Bring this flier with you.
· If you live within the city walls, then this message is for you. Just because we live outside the city in what you call “The Slums”, we are people too, so stop looking at us like we’re diseased! Sure, we may not have the wealth that you have, but we’re not animals. We have families that we love, we laugh, we cry, we do everything you do. So next time you come traveling through our little neighborhood, think about that. (Anonymous)
· Are we not a civilized society? I am tired of picking up your scraps and waste in the road. There are trash bins for a reason! It isn’t hard to use them! Please help keep this town clean. – A Concerned Citizen.
I don’t know if you’ll see this but I have your blue cloak. You left it at [insert name of local tavern here] last night. Your perfume is still on it. It smells nice. I’ll be there the next three nights to give it back to you if you show up, and I hope you allow me to buy you a drink.

note.text: Geldor the Orc

trait.name: Archer
trait.text: A longbow or shortbow deals one extra die of its damage when Falcon hits with it (included in his longbow attack).

trait.name: Sharpshooter
trait.text: Falcon's ranged weapon attacks ignore half cover and three-quarters cover.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: Falcon makes three melee attacks or two ranged attacks.

action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d8 + 2) slashing damage, or 7 (1d10 + 2) slashing damage if used with two hands.

action.text: Ranged Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d8 + 2) piercing damage.

note.name: DM Overview
note.text:
Falcon’s Hunting Lodge is a secure wilderness sanctuary nestled deep within Neverwinter Wood. It serves as a neutral rest stop, quest hub, or even a siege set-piece depending on your campaign’s needs. Though not connected to any one quest, it is an ideal location for character downtime, gathering information, or planting narrative seeds related to the Woodland Manse, Cryovain’s rise, or Talos cult activity.
1. Purpose & Role in the Campaign • Safe Haven. A place for characters to rest, resupply, and regroup. • Quest Hook Anchor. Offers access to the Woodland Manse Quest, and hints about the Circle of Thunder, orc movements, and Cryovain’s growing influence. • Narrative Contrasts. A well-defended, civilized outpost surrounded by wild danger. Highlights the encroachment of Talos cultists into safe territory. • Character Showcase. Offers rich NPCs like Falcon, Corwin, and Pell, each bringing warmth, mystery, or gravitas to the setting.
2. Tone & Atmosphere • Rustic but Refined. Log palisades and stone walls surround cozy interiors, crackling hearths, oil lanterns, and mounted trophies. Think “frontier noble lodge” meets “grim hunting preserve.” • Subtle Tension. Orc heads mounted on walls suggest Falcon’s defiance, but hints of pending retaliation loom large, especially with Grannoc’s threat growing nearby.
3. Key Elements to Improvise • Hospitality Mechanics. How warmly do they treat guests? Does Falcon charge or offer freely? Falcon will not tolerate rowdiness or violence under his roof. • Narrative Rumors. Use Falcon’s knowledge and Corwin’s mutterings to provide: • Orc sightings • Anchorite rituals • The mystery of the overgrown manse • Weather omens tied to Talos • Quiet Bonds. Pell’s silence and perceptiveness make him a great observer for quiet character moments or secrets spotted from the shadows.
4. Major Encounter Options • Siege of the Lodge. The “Counterattack!” event after Woodland Manse can lead to a dramatic battle within these walls. You may need battlemaps or defend-the-stronghold mechanics. • Assassins or Spies. Talos cultists might infiltrate under false pretenses, trying to poison supplies, burn down the stable, or target Falcon. • Noble Guests. At your discretion, a pampered noble might arrive, requiring escort to Neverwinter—or bringing political trouble in their wake.
5. Falcon’s Attitude & Boundaries • Polite but No-Nonsense. He does not suffer fools or bullies. Keeps a wary eye on charismatic tricksters. • Will not leave the lodge. Emphatic about this. Says nobles might need him; real reason may be deeper (e.g., a vow, a secret, a hidden relic). • Gift Reactions. A bottle of wine (especially from Barthen’s) earns favor. Magical meat or rare monster parts earn interest.
6. Adventure Hooks • Boots of Elvenkind. Offered as a reward for clearing Woodland Manse. • Heirloom Rumors. Falcon mentions a friend lost a family ring near the ruins—bonus quest or lead. • Petunia’s Trail. Falcon might notice tracks of a prize cow wandering east, tying into Butterskull Ranch

note.name: Improv Kit
note.text:
Falcon’s Hunting Lodge – General Improv Kit
1. Tone and Atmosphere • Vibe: Solitary, rustic haven; a self-sufficient outpost at the edge of civilization. • Sensory: Pine smoke, roasting meat, crackling hearths; the scent of damp wood and beast-sweat; distant birdsong and the snap of bowstrings. • Emotional Palette: Peaceful but watchful. There’s a subtle tension beneath the surface—Falcon’s lone war on the orcs feels like a powder keg ready to blow.
2. Dynamic Uses for the Lodge • Refuge Between Quests: Safe rest point with downtime options (crafting, repairing gear, trading with Falcon). • Rumor Mill: Falcon, Corwin, or even Pell (through gestures) can seed local rumors or lore drops. • Political Tension: Nobles may arrive seeking Falcon’s services, stirring up drama, entitlements, or attracting danger. • Counterattack Base: Lodge becomes a fortified position against a looming assault (e.g. anchorite retaliation). • Moral Dilemma: Falcon’s orc-hunting obsession could spark questions about mercy vs vengeance.
3. Roleplaying Hooks • Falcon: • Offers cynical wisdom: “The forest doesn’t care who you are, only how well you bleed.” • Reacts calmly to threats unless orcs are involved—then becomes cold and decisive. • Obsessed with protecting the Lodge’s sanctity. “I’ve bled on these floors. Let no beast take them.” • Corwin: • Gruff and dry-humored. “You bring wine, I’ll warm your bones. You bring trouble, I’ll bury the bones.” • Unspoken tension with Falcon about his warpath. • Pell: • Mute, but sharp-eyed. Communicates through expressive gestures and drawn pictures. • Might slip players a sketch showing trouble approaching or something he’s seen in the woods.
4. Encounters and Happenings
Use these for spontaneous events while PCs are at or near the lodge: 1. Noon Guests: A pompous noble and retinue arrive seeking Falcon’s services, disdainful of “ruffians.” 2. Boar Trouble: A tusked dire boar, branded with Talos’ rune, slams through the outer fence at night. 3. Pell’s Discovery: Pell sketches blight footprints near the pens—Gulthias tree spawn may be near. 4. Lost Child: A half-starved child stumbles into the yard, chased by shadowy forest creatures. 5. Haunted Wood: At night, green witchlights flicker in the trees. Wisps try to lure Pell into the forest. 6. Corwin’s Warning: He finds an orc effigy nailed to a tree near the bridge—Talosites taunting Falcon.
5. Rumors at the Lodge (d6)
Roll or choose as needed: 1. “Heard tell of a druid grove ‘round here that moves with the seasons. Might explain the vanishing game.” 2. “That stone manse? It’s cursed. Heard the ivy screams when you cut it.” 3. “Falcon weren’t always alone. He had a sister once. Vanished into the forest after some quarrel.” 4. “Something’s been howling near the river—too deep for wolves. Too smart, too.” 5. “You didn’t hear it from me, but Pell can speak. He just won’t.” 6. “Corwin keeps his coin in a hollow log in the stables. Says he doesn’t trust ‘southern gold.’

note.name: Falcon The Hunter (F11 Or F13)
note.text:
Location: F13 (Bedroom) or F11 (Dining & Trophy Hall) Race/Gender: Human Male Class/CR: Veteran Visual Trait: Towering height (6’6”), cold blue eyes, fur-lined cloak, and a scar across the bridge of his nose. Voice/Quips: • “Nothing in these woods scares me, and nothing should scare you either.” • “You’re welcome to stay, just don’t touch my wine.” • “Orcs? I shoot ‘em before they get close enough to stink.” Motivations: • Maintain the lodge as a safe, self-reliant bastion in the wild. • Protect Neverwinter nobles (for coin, rarely affection). • Eliminate orcs and other threats to “his” forest. Daily Activities:
1. Morning: Patrols the grounds with Baatorius. 2. Noon: Practices archery at hidden woodland targets. 3. Afternoon: Prepares meat in the trophy hall or inspects the tower. 4. Evening: Hosts guests at F11 for food, drink, and tall tales. 5. Night: Sleeps lightly with a loaded crossbow next to his bed

note.name: Corwin The Cook (F8 Or F9)
note.text:
Location: F8 (Bedroom), F9 (Kitchen), or roaming Race/Gender: Human Male (Elderly) Class/CR: Commoner Visual Trait: Balding with wispy white hair, hunched frame, and an apron that always smells faintly of garlic and pipe smoke. Voice/Quips: • “More stew? Of course. The secret’s nutmeg. Don’t tell Falcon.” • “Been cooking for ten years longer than you’ve been breathing, pup.” • “Falcon’s temper’s a candle wick… long, but flammable.” Motivations: • Keep everyone fed, warm, and away from trouble. • Keep Falcon alive, despite himself. • Protect Pell like a surrogate grandson. Daily Activities:
1. Morning: Prepares breakfast and inventory in pantry (F10). 2. Noon: Tends to chores, washes linens in river, scolds Pell lovingly. 3. Afternoon: Repairs gear, whittles wooden spoons, tends fire in F8. 4. Evening: Prepares and serves dinner; eats in silence. 5. Night: Sleeps light, mutters names from his past

note.name: Pell The Stablehand (Roaming)
note.text:
Location: F7 (Bedroom), F4 (Stables), F5 (Storage), or outdoors Race/Gender: Human Male Child (12 years old, mute) Class/CR: Commoner Visual Trait: Big hazel eyes, cropped black hair, silent presence. Often communicates via nods and carved wooden symbols. Voice/Quips: (Mute – communicates via gestures or scratched chalkboard messages) • Nods with quiet purpose, uses carved animal tokens for emotions (boar = danger, falcon = Falcon nearby, heart = thanks). Motivations: • Protect the animals; especially Baatorius, the stallion. • Help Falcon and Corwin however he can. • Prove his courage in a silent world. Daily Activities:
1. Morning: Feeds pigs, goats, chickens in animal pens. 2. Noon: Brushes Baatorius, mends tack, polishes hooves. 3. Afternoon: Observes visitors quietly, assists in smithy (F6). 4. Evening: Watches sunset from the tower (F16), then eats with Corwin. 5. Night: Sleeps in a cot next to his wooden animal carvings

note.name: Baatorius The Horse
note.text:
Type: Warhorse (Unique Mount) Location: Usually in the westernmost stall (F4 – Stables) Visual Trait: Storm-gray coat with a single white streak down his snout, intelligent eyes, battle-notched ear Temperament: Calm, hyper-aware, loyal only to Falcon Voice/Quips (through flavor or Falcon): • (Snorts and stamps when strangers approach.) • “He only bites or kicks when he doesn’t like someone. He’s usually right.” – Falcon • “Smartest beast I’ve ever known. Saved my life more times than I’ll admit.” – Corwin
Stat Block: Use Warhorse (MM p. 340) with the following adjustments: • AC 12 (natural armor) • HP 22 (3d10 + 6) • Speed 60 ft. • Passive Perception 12 • Special Trait: • Feral Loyalty. Baatorius can sense Falcon’s distress at any range within 1 mile. If Falcon is dying or in mortal peril, Baatorius becomes agitated and neighs loudly unless silenced magically.
Motivations: • Stay near Falcon unless commanded otherwise • Avoid unnecessary noise or strangers • Will only allow PCs to approach or ride if Falcon permits it
Behavioral Tags: • Alert: Often the first to detect unseen threats in the area • Reserved: Avoids touch unless familiar • Proud: Carries himself with presence—never dirty or skittis

note.name: Arrival/Gate
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
A light fog curls through the forest floor as you crest a mossy ridge and glimpse a fortified compound nestled in a clearing across a narrow river. A newly built stone bridge crosses the water, leading to a ten-foot-high palisade of mossy logs. Inside, you can just make out the peaked gables of a two-story stone-and-wood lodge and the square silhouette of a gray tower lined with battlements. Chickens cluck softly beyond the walls, and smoke curls from a chimney—warm, familiar, and welcome.
Mounted beside a solid oaken gate is a small iron bell with a frayed rope hanging from its clapper.
DM Notes: First Impressions & Setup 1. Approach Options • If characters approach cautiously or quietly, they may remain unnoticed (DC 13 Stealth group check to sneak up). • If they ring the bell or shout, proceed with interaction. 2. Initial NPC Placement • Corwin (human commoner) is in the kitchen (area F9), peeling potatoes and drinking weak ale. • Pell (mute stablehand, 12) is sweeping the stables (area F4) and tending Baatorius, Falcon’s horse. • Falcon is in his bedroom (area F13) sharpening arrows and sipping wine by the fire.
NPC Encounter: Corwin at the Gate
If the bell is rung or the characters call out:
The scrape of a heavy bar precedes the creak of the gate, and an elderly man in a stained apron peers out, a brow cocked with mild annoyance. One eye is cloudy with age, the other keen as ever.
“If you’re here to steal eggs or bring trouble, best keep walking. If not… state your business.”
Corwin’s Attitude: Wary but not hostile. He warms quickly to courtesy and wine.
Dialogue Hooks: • “Falcon don’t much care for visitors unannounced, but I’ll let him know.” • “Stable’s there. Pell’ll see to your beast, don’t mind his silence—he’s sharper than he looks.”
NPC Movements and Hospitality
Once trust is earned: 1. Pell emerges from F4 and leads animals to the stable. He nods respectfully but says nothing. 2. Corwin shows the party to guest house (F3), encourages them to drop their gear. 3. He then leads them to the dining hall (F11) where a fire is lit and wine is offered. 4. Falcon appears from F13, relaxed and curious, with a skin of strong wine and a heavy hunting knife at his belt

note.name: F1. Stone Bridge
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
A newly constructed stone bridge spans the slow, mossy river. Its edges are cleanly mortared, and the flagstones are wide and even—clearly the work of a practiced mason. You hear the soft gurgle of water below and the distant cluck of chickens beyond the palisade.
DM Notes 1. Dimensions: 5 feet wide, 20 feet long; sturdy enough to bear a wagon. 2. Scenery: • The river is shallow (3–4 ft deep), easy to ford elsewhere if needed. • Morning mist often clings to the river, lending the area an eerie calm. 3. Noise: • Footsteps echo faintly on the bridge. • Characters might catch hints of life inside: clattering dishes, a fire crackling. 4. Tactical Use: • Defensible choke point if attacked. • Falcon or Corwin may destroy a plank to disable it temporarily (DC 20 to repair)

note.name: F2. Gatehouse
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The oaken gate bears iron bands and heavy hinges, flanked by moss-covered stone walls. Mounted beside it is a tarnished iron bell with a short rope dangling like a beckoning finger. Just beyond the door, you hear faint footsteps on timber and the creak of wood as someone stirs inside.
DM Notes 1. Structure: • Ground floor has a ladder to a trapdoor leading to the rooftop (12 ft up). • Roof has iron railings, and a flagpole bearing Falcon’s silver falcon on black. 2. NPCs: • Corwin responds to the bell or voices, peering through a peephole. • If suspicious, he may ask a few probing questions before unlatching the door. 3. Combat Use: • Good vantage point in a siege or counterattack. • Arrow slits provide three-quarters cover; roof is good for scouts

note.name: F3. Guesthouse
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The scent of straw and wool greets you as the heavy door creaks open. Inside, thick blankets and soft pillows rest atop nine well-kept cots arranged in tidy rows. Lanterns hang from hooks above, and a stack of fresh firewood rests in the corner, ready for the hearth.
DM Notes 1. Capacity: • Sleeps up to nine comfortably. Falcon rarely has more than a few guests. • Blankets are woolen, locally made and warm. 2. Comfort Level: • Rustic but clean—adventurers accustomed to sleeping on rocks will find it luxurious. • Fireplace available (lit by Corwin if guests arrive late). 3. Items of Note: • A small wooden chest at the back contains spare candles, towels, and soap. • Pell checks in silently to fetch anything the guests might need. 4. Quirks: • Small rune is carved in the back post of cot #7—“Rest is earned” in Dwarvish. • Some guests leave carved initials in the rafters (with permission)

note.name: F4. Stables
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The scent of straw, leather, and horseflesh fills this long stable, its rafters low and shadowed. A gray stallion flicks his ears in the westernmost stall, watching you with calm intelligence. Empty stalls line the rest of the building, though each is clean, well-swept, and stocked with hay.
DM Notes 1.
