Occupants: • Baatorius, Falcon’s war-trained gray stallion, resides here. • Obeys only Falcon or Pell. • Will not allow strangers to mount him unless Falcon gives a command. • Pell, the mute stablehand, is often found grooming Baatorius or sweeping the floors. He communicates with gestures and looks to Corwin or Falcon for cues. 2. Stables Capacity: • Eight stalls total; currently seven are empty and available. • Water troughs, tack hooks, and feed bins in each stall. 3. Notes: • Falcon has carved a warding glyph above Baatorius’s stall (non-magical): a falcon eye symbol with three notches beneath it. • Characters can board their own mounts here freely. • If left alone with Pell, kind PCs may earn his trust. He offers them a simple carved wooden horse as a token of thanks

note.name: F5. Storage
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
A simple wooden door creaks open to reveal a cool, dark room filled with sacks of oats, tools for grooming and shoeing horses, and neatly coiled harnesses and bridles. Leather polish and hay mingle in the air, grounding the space in rustic familiarity.
DM Notes 1. Contents: • Saddle soap, halters, bridles, leather armor scraps, boot polish, hay forks. • Several coils of rope (50 ft hemp), small wheelbarrow, and two empty feed barrels. 2. Interesting Finds: • Falcon’s old trail saddle, masterfully made, hangs from a central post. It’s worn but exquisite craftsmanship. • A tin of “Corwin’s Hoof Wax” (he made it himself—it smells of rosemary). 3. Utility: • Characters may repair light armor or prepare gear here. • A character proficient in leatherworker’s tools could craft simple gear or patch armor. • DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check finds a pouch with 8 gp wedged behind a shelf, forgotten during last winter’s rush

note.name: F6. Smithy
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
An open-sided lean-to stands against the stable’s far wall, blackened with soot. An anvil sits on a thick stump next to a stone forge now cold. Hanging from hooks are horseshoes, tongs, and hammers. Scratches in the flagstones below speak of years of use.
DM Notes 1. Purpose: • Primarily used for repairing tack and shoeing horses. • Adventurers may use it to repair weapons or armor (non-magical). • No current blacksmith resides here, but Falcon has basic smithing knowledge. 2. Tools Available: • Smith’s tools (worn but functional). • Bellows, two hammers, tongs, punch, wire brush. 3. Special Interaction: • If a character takes time (2 hours), they can restore 1 point of armor’s AC loss or forge horseshoes or simple metal items. • Characters proficient with smith’s tools gain advantage on checks made here. 4. Hidden Find: • DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) to spot a small hidden drawer beneath the anvil block containing an old iron ring with a symbol of a tree burned into it (non-magical, from Falcon’s youth—possibly used as a narrative hook)

note.name: F7. Pell’s Bedroom
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
This small room smells faintly of wood polish and animal fur. A tidy cot is pressed against the wall, beside which stands a wooden crate filled with small carvings of birds, horses, and forest animals. A shelf holds a bundle of charcoal sticks and a smoothed board where a few stick-figure scenes are etched in faint lines.
DM Notes 1. Occupant: • Pell, the mute 12-year-old stablehand. Sleeps here. Always rises before dawn. • He’s careful and neat—room is clean despite its humble furnishings. 2. Details & Interactions: • Pell communicates through gestures and scribbles on his charcoal board. • He whittles small animal carvings—might gift one to a kind PC. • Characters who spend time with him (or succeed a DC 12 Insight check) learn he fears thunder and sleeps with a stuffed animal—a worn owl toy named “Rattles.” 3. Narrative Hook: • If danger arises at the lodge (e.g., Counterattack!), Pell hides beneath his bed unless a PC calms him

note.name: F8. Corwin’s Bedroom
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
A warm amber glow spills from a hearth set in the back wall of this modest room. The air smells of pipeweed and thyme. A plain bed is covered in patchwork quilts, and beside it stands a desk cluttered with folded linens, small jars of herbs, and a long-handled spoon resting across an open journal.
DM Notes 1. Occupant: • Corwin, the grizzled human cook (noncombatant), rests here when not preparing meals or tending to guests. • He is world-weary, perceptive, and kind but doesn’t abide fools. 2. Details: • A strong scent of herbs, tobacco, and stewing broth hangs in the air. • His journal contains musings, food recipes, and cautious notes about Falcon’s trophy wall (“Mark my words, this will bring trouble”). • DC 14 Intelligence (Investigation) reveals a rolled-up map tucked in his desk—a hunter’s sketch of nearby woodland terrain including a hidden spring (useful for survival/downtime scenes). 3. Roleplaying: • Corwin might share quiet wisdom with PCs: “Never trust a silent forest,” or “Every feast is followed by ashes.

note.name: F9. Kitchen
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
This long, low-ceilinged room carries the rich aromas of baking bread, roasting meat, and herb-laced stew. Hanging pots clatter faintly on hooks overhead, and an old iron stove smolders with warm coals. Bundles of dried herbs and onions hang from the rafters, swaying gently with the draft.
DM Notes 1. Features: • Cooking hearth, preparation tables, cupboards full of dried and fresh goods, and a stone sink with spring-fed water. • Lanterns hang on hooks; always lit at dusk by Corwin. 2. Corwin’s Domain: • Characters are welcome here but warned, “Stay out of the way, or stay useful.” • If asked, Corwin prepares excellent meals—providing inspiration to characters who spend a long rest at the lodge and share a meal with him. 3. Treasure/Story Element: • Hidden under a floorboard (DC 13 Perception) is a small wooden box containing a dried rose—a keepsake from Corwin’s lost lover, possibly used in personal quests or emotional RP. 4. Optional Flavor Table – What’s Cooking Today? Roll a d4 or choose: • 1. Venison stew with wild garlic and mushrooms • 2. Spit-roasted pheasant with sweet roots • 3. Braised rabbit with cider gravy • 4. Thick loaves of walnut bread with honey

note.name: F10. Pantry
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
Wooden shelves line the walls of this cold, dry chamber. Barrels, sacks, and clay jars are stacked neatly, the scents of flour, smoked meats, pickled vegetables, and strong ale mingling in the air. A few hooks on the ceiling dangle bundles of garlic and sprigs of rosemary.
DM Notes 1. Contents: • Barrels of salted pork, sacks of flour and oats, pickled root vegetables, dry cheeses, casks of ale, and preserved fruit. • Enough provisions to sustain a dozen people for two months. 2. Exploration Detail: • DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation) reveals a marked barrel—branded with the crest of a noble house in Neverwinter (potential future plot hook or faction tie-in). 3. Narrative Hook: • Corwin checks the pantry every morning. If theft occurs, he suspects guests before Falcon does, possibly creating tension

note.name: F11. Dining And Trophy Hall
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
This high-ceilinged chamber radiates warmth and primal pride. A long oak dining table occupies the center, surrounded by tall-backed chairs carved with antler motifs. The walls are hung with fur pelts and trophies—stag antlers, bear skulls, and the severed heads of orcs mounted like grim sentinels. Above, a gallery ringed by wooden railing displays even more hunting prizes, bathed in golden lamplight from twin iron chandeliers.
DM Notes 1. Atmosphere: • A roaring fire crackles in a wide hearth. The scent of roasted meat and pipe smoke lingers. • The upper gallery (accessible by stairs in F13) displays rare trophies: a manticore spike, a shattered bugbear helm, and a preserved griffon claw. 2. Falcon’s Presence: • If not in F13, Falcon is here, drinking, cleaning his hunting knives, or discussing monster sightings. • If this is the party’s first visit, Corwin brings them here before fetching Falcon. 3. Roleplay Tips for Falcon: • “These heads send a message. Orcs aren’t welcome here.” • “Help yourself to the fire and the drink. And don’t mind Corwin—he grumbles, but he keeps the place alive.” 4. Exploration Hook: • DC 13 Wisdom (Insight) or a conversation with Corwin reveals Falcon’s growing paranoia: He watches the forest with increasing intensity, half-expecting retribution for the trophies he displays

note.name: F12. Deluxe Guest Bedroom
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
This well-appointed room smells of cedar and lavender. A four-poster bed with a down-stuffed mattress dominates the chamber. On the nightstand sit a ceramic washbasin and a sealed box of fragrant pipeweed. Furred rugs and velvet curtains add a touch of luxury beneath the rustic timber beams.
DM Notes 1. For Rent: • Available for 10 gp per night. Free to PCs with Falcon’s trust (DM discretion). • Impeccably clean. Room contains a small locked chest (empty unless used by PCs), and a guest book filled with the names and coats of arms of noble visitors. 2. Story Hook: • DC 14 Intelligence (History) check reveals a name in the guest book that matches one found on an item or note elsewhere in your campaign—tie-in potential. • PCs might find a forgotten personal item left behind—a signet ring, a bloodstained letter, a carved hair comb—leading to a new thread. 3. Rest Benefit: • If a character rests here for 8 hours and enjoys a meal with Falcon, they gain inspiration

note.name: F13. Falcon’s Bedroom
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
Falcon’s quarters are lived-in and cluttered, yet oddly comforting. The walls are hung with hunting maps, curling scrolls, and weapons of various make—some dwarven, others elven. A wide bed is strewn with fur blankets, and the desk is covered in scattered correspondence, many marked with noble seals.
DM Notes 1. Occupant: • Falcon is often found here sharpening weapons, reading, or resting with a bottle of wine. • Keeps his personal bow (a finely crafted longbow of elven make) mounted above the desk. 2. Contents: • Letters from nobles, maps with orc and anchorite sightings, and a few marked locations like Circle of Thunder, Woodland Manse, and Old Owl Well. • A large key ring hangs from a hook near the door (unlocks pantry, gatehouse, and tower roof). 3. Roleplay Tips: • “If you want to survive in these woods, trust your instincts and sharpen your steel.” • “The forest doesn’t forgive. And neither do the things that slink through it.

note.name: F14. Tower Basement
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
A narrow stone staircase spirals down into a low-ceilinged chamber with packed dirt floors and rough stone walls. Wooden shelves line one wall, holding clay jars, barrels, and crates stacked high. A tang of earth and root vegetables hangs in the air.
DM Notes 1. Contents: • Cold storage for perishables: smoked hams, root vegetables, salted fish, wine jugs, and blocks of ice packed in straw. • Hidden beneath a false-bottom barrel (DC 14 Intelligence [Investigation] to detect) is Falcon’s emergency stash: a pouch with 75 gp, a silver-plated dagger, and a healing potion in a wrapped cloth. 2. NPC Use: • Pell sometimes sneaks down here for quiet or to sleep in the cool air during summer. 3. Ambience: • The air is damp and still. Mice scurry in the shadows. If the players are here during a storm, rainwater trickles down the staircase in rivulets. 4. Potential Encounter Hook: • A clever assassin or spy (should you need a future plot thread) could hide among the crates. This room provides natural hiding spots for stealth-based scenes

note.name: F15. Tower Guard Post
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
This quiet chamber is stark and functional. Arrow slits are carved into the stone walls at chest height, offering a commanding view of the palisade and the forest beyond. A rack of spears and a barrel of water sit in the corner. Dust coats everything.
DM Notes 1. Historical Use: • Once used to defend the lodge against bandits and monsters. Now rarely visited except by Falcon during security sweeps. 2. Usage: • Falcon sometimes stations a visiting ally or trusted NPC here if threats in the woods increase. 3. Exploration: • PCs who spend time watching from the slits can spot movement in the forest (DC 14 Wisdom [Perception])—be it deer, patrols of orcs, or shadowy shapes in Talos-aligned rituals. 4. Tactical Note: • Excellent location to stage a last stand or prep an ambush if PCs expect a counterattack from the manse or Cryovain’s agents

note.name: F16. Tower Roof
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
This open rooftop stands thirty feet above the ground, offering a sweeping view of the river, palisade, and surrounding woods. Stone battlements circle the roof, and a thick wooden door leads to the stairwell below. A weathered iron brazier stands at the center, its bowl filled with old ashes.
DM Notes 1. Visibility: • Ideal for spotting smoke plumes or unnatural lights from the Woodland Manse, Circle of Thunder, or other distant forest activity. • At night, the moonlight bathes the forest in silver. On a clear day, PCs can spot Falcon’s game trails. 2. Brazier Use: • Can be lit to signal trouble to Falcon’s allies in the woods (though they may take hours to respond or simply flee). 3. Falcon’s Use: • Occasionally climbs here to stargaze, pray to the Huntress (Mielikki), or drink in solitude. 4. Exploration Hook: • Hidden beneath a loose stone in the parapet (DC 15 Wisdom [Perception]) is a rusted whistle—a gift from Pell, made from bone, with a barely legible etching: “So you’re never alone.

note.name: Description
note.text: The wounded manticore threatens Adabra, who refuses to retreat. The creature can be reasoned with, scared off, or fought. It may mention being driven from the mountains by a greater dragon, hinting at Cryovain’s growing presence.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 213, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 60

trait.name: Tail Spike Regrowth
trait.text: The manticore has twenty-four tail spikes. Used spikes regrow when the manticore finishes a long rest.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The manticore makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws or three with its tail spikes.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8+3) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6+3) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail Spike
action.text: Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, range 100/200 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8+3) piercing damage.

note.name: Overview
note.text:
Level Range: Tier 1 (balanced for level 3 or lower) Tone: Isolated, tense, slightly whimsical with a hint of wild danger Core Themes: • Small-scale heroism and moral choice • The fragility of safety in frontier regions • A living world disrupted by Cryovain’s arrival
Adventure Summary
Umbrage Hill is a quiet herbalist’s outpost disrupted by the wild influence of Cryovain the white dragon. As the characters arrive, they encounter a manticore attacking the windmill, seeking meat or treasure. The encounter is an opportunity for combat, negotiation, or clever distraction. Regardless of outcome, the apothecary Adabra Gwynn is key to future healing resources and offers a reward for help.
This location establishes the dragon’s influence beyond Phandalin and introduces the tone of vulnerability that pervades the region.
Location Lore • Hill’s Name: Named for a forgotten dwarven feud—two clans fought a bloody battle here. • Cairns: Now only remnants remain—bare stone markers under the open sky. • Windmill: A hundred-year-old structure repurposed by a Chauntean herbalist. Solid stone, weather-worn, surrounded by an iron fence.
Important NPC
Adabra Gwynn – Midwife, Apothecary, Devotee of Chauntea • Visual Trait: Loose silver hair tied with dried herbs; wears patchwork robes with grass-stained hems. • Quips: 1. “Chauntea grant me strength—again?!” 2. “I’ve got tinctures, teas, and trouble—take your pick.” 3. “That thing better not have scratched my drying rack.” • Motivation: Protect her home and keep healing others—refuses to abandon Umbrage Hill despite danger. • Daily Activity: Harvesting herbs in the morning, brewing in the afternoon, praying at dusk. • Game Role: Sells healing potions (up to 6), offers quest resolution note for Harbin Wester.
Encounters & Resolution
Manticore Encounter • Creature: 1 Manticore (MM p213) • Trigger: Already attacking the front door upon arrival. • Player Options: 1. Fight it – Straightforward combat. 2. Negotiate – It will leave if given 25 gp worth of treasure or a few pounds of meat. 3. Distraction or creative solution – Roleplay or spell-based solutions allowed. • If allowed to escape: May return later with a mate, complicating future travel or local quests.
Rewards & Quest Completion • Quest Goal: Ask Adabra for a written note confirming she’s alive and well (turn in to Harbin Wester). • Reward: 1 free Potion of Healing, additional available for 50 gp each (up to 6 in stock). • Hook Potential: • Players may feel compelled to help fortify her defenses. • Cryovain’s threat feels immediate and personal.
Location Breakdown
U1. Dwarven Cairns – Windswept piles of rocks, long forgotten. A quiet memorial to lost history. U2. Ruins of a House – Just a collapsed fireplace remains. Possible camping spot or memory point. U3. Ground Floor of Windmill – Adabra’s work area: mortar, pestle, drying herbs, medicinal books. U4. Adabra’s Quarters – Modest bedroom and prayer nook to Chauntea. U5. Guest Loft – One bed and old adventuring gear (nothing magical, mostly sentimental)

note.name: Arrival
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The trail winds upward through dry grass and thistle until the silhouette of an old windmill rises against the blue-grey sky. Perched on the slope of the hill, the squat, circular stone building stands behind a low iron fence, its vanes turning slowly in the wind like lazy sentinels. But peace is shattered by the pounding of claws against stone—
A massive winged beast snarls at the front door, its barbed tail lashing like a whip. Rust-colored fur bristles across its lion-like body, and blood trickles down one flank where jagged wounds ooze between broken spines. It slams its claws again, shouting:
“Come out, little windwitch! I hunger still, and pain makes my temper sharp!”
From a shuttered second-story window, a woman’s face appears—gray-haired, wide-eyed. She waves frantically and shouts:
“A little help?! Before I become manticore mulch?!”
DM Notes:
Dimensions & Visibility: • The windmill stands ~20 feet tall at its peak, with a ~10-foot-high iron fence surrounding a 40-foot circular yard. • The manticore is at the front door (area U3), visible from 100 feet out. • The terrain up the hill is exposed, so the party is likely seen unless stealthy.
Manticore Adjustments (Custom Flavor): • Name: Harthor the Riddling Hunger • HP: Slightly reduced to reflect injury (e.g., ~50–60 HP). • Motivation: • Wants to survive and feast. • Is deeply frustrated and wounded—driven here by Cryovain, now injured and alone. • Will lash out but is capable of thought and parley.
Tactics: • If the party approaches cautiously, Harthor growls a riddle challenge, his attempt at “mercy” before mauling. • If a player engages in the riddle or tries diplomacy, it buys time. • If healed with magic or given 1d4 potions of healing, he pauses, suspicious but swayed.
Harthor’s Riddle (Optional Prompt):
“What walks on four legs at dawn, two at midday, and three at dusk?” (Answer: A human – crawling, walking, using a cane.)
If answered correctly: He narrows his eyes and snarls, “Wisdom in a small form… curious.” If answered wrong: “Then riddle-meat you’ll be!” and he attacks.
Negotiation Option:
If offered healing or potions, Harthor snarls suspiciously but listens:
Quip: • “You offer kindness to a killer? Are you fools… or tacticians?” • “I have tasted pain, cold, and dragon-fire. If your war is with Cryovain, perhaps I still have fangs to offer.”
If swayed: • Harthor agrees to help in a future battle against Cryovain, retreating to nurse his wounds and await word. • He leaves with a howl that echoes across the valley, a grim promise of aid

note.name: U1 – Exterior Approach
note.text:
Stone mounds marking the forgotten bones of a dwarven feud.
Read-Aloud Text:
To the west of the windmill, scattered among the tall grass and thistlebrush, lie six low cairns—simple piles of weather-worn stone, each about four feet across and knee-high. Lichen coats their surfaces like flaky green runes, and the wind whistles softly as it passes over them. A faint scent of dry earth and old iron lingers here.
The ground feels solemn—quiet, but not empty.
DM Notes: • These cairns mark the graves of dwarves who perished in a battle centuries ago between two rival clans. • The stonework is crude but enduring. A successful DC 12 Intelligence (History) or DC 10 Wisdom (Religion) check identifies them as funerary cairns of traditional dwarven design. • Any dwarven character or someone fluent in Dwarvish can make out faded clan symbols—now barely visible—suggesting a once-proud lineage lost to time.
Optional Hook: • A successful DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check reveals that one cairn has been disturbed—possibly scavenged by a tomb raider or monster. • Beneath a loose stone, the party may find an old dwarven amulet depicting Moradin’s anvil, cracked and tarnished (worth 10 gp to a collector or dwarf)

note.name: U2 – Windmill Exterior
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Near the base of the hill sits the blackened shell of a long-abandoned stone cottage. Only a fireplace and the lower third of the walls remain standing—surrounded by tumbled masonry and choking weeds. Ashen wood crumbles underfoot, and the scent of smoke still seems to cling faintly to the stones, as if the fire happened yesterday instead of decades ago.
DM Notes: • This ruined house predates the windmill and may have belonged to an early settler, apothecary, or one of the dwarves’ descendants. • No treasure remains, but a successful DC 12 Wisdom (Survival) check reveals claw marks on the stones—evidence that Harthor or other beasts may have once sheltered here.
Exploration Detail: • In one corner of the hearth is a small iron box, fire-warped and sealed by rust. With effort or tools (DC 14 Strength check to pry open), it contains: • A silver charm of Chauntea, shaped like a sheaf of wheat (25 gp), • A small prayer scroll, water-damaged but still legible in parts

note.name: U3 – Main Room
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The thick wooden door swings open to reveal a circular stone chamber roughly 20 feet across. The air is heavy with the scents of lavender, dried chamomile, and the acrid tang of crushed sulfur. Shelves line the curved walls, crammed with jars of dried herbs, animal skulls, hanging moss, and curious seedpods. In the center, a massive millstone dominates the room, its grooves dusted with flecks of vibrant green. A mortar and pestle the size of a cauldron rests nearby, still wet with a pungent paste.
A spiral staircase, narrow and steep, hugs the wall to the right, climbing to the upper floors.
DM Notes: • This floor serves as Adabra’s workshop, where she grinds herbs, prepares poultices, and infuses healing potions. • Characters with proficiency in Herbalism Kit or Nature (DC 12) recognize the quality and variety of reagents. • Searching the shelves yields: • 1 dose of antitoxin • 2 common potion ingredients (e.g., ground ghostcap mushroom, ashblossom petals) • Healer’s balm (acts as one use of the Healer feat or Spare the Dying once

note.name: U4 – Herb Storage
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The staircase leads to a modest living space carved into the windmill’s second level, roughly 18 feet in diameter. A simple cot tucked beneath a window is layered in patchwork quilts. Dried bundles of lavender hang from ceiling beams, swaying gently in the draft. A small writing desk is cluttered with notes, open vials, and a sketch of a flowering plant labeled “Moonbriar.” Against the wall, a shrine of Chauntea has been assembled from a bundle of wheat, a tarnished copper bowl, and a clay statuette of the grain mother.
DM Notes: • Adabra’s space is peaceful, practical, and clearly lived-in. She spends most of her time here when not working. • Characters inspecting the shrine and offering a prayer may gain a fleeting sense of serenity; a Cleric or Druid of Chauntea might receive a minor omen (a warm wind or vision of ripe grain). • The notes on her desk include: • An unfinished letter to Harbin Wester refusing to return to Phandalin (“I serve better here than cowering behind town walls.”) • A herbalist’s recipe for a potion of healing (DC 14 Intelligence check to copy

note.name: U5 – Rooftop / Landing Spot
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
At the top of the narrow stairwell is a drafty loft beneath the cone-shaped roof of the windmill. The room is triangular in cross-section, about 15 feet wide, and smells of dust and dried herbs. A thin bedroll is laid out beside a shelf stacked with folded blankets, bottles of liniment, and empty potion vials. One wooden beam has several notches carved into it—perhaps a calendar, perhaps something more personal.
A small round window frames the western horizon, where the Sword Mountains cast long shadows across the grassland below.
DM Notes: • This loft functions as a sickroom or guest chamber—Adabra has treated the wounded here before. • Characters choosing to rest here benefit from a calming aura; a long rest here restores 1 additional hit die. • Searching the loft turns up: • An unused healing potion (forgotten under a blanket) • A diary page referencing nightmares Adabra has had recently—dreams of “icy wings above the valley” and “red eyes in a winter storm.” Foreshadowing of Cryovain or possible Cult of the Dragon hints

note.name: NPC – Adabra Gwynn
note.text:
A middle-aged human woman with white-streaked dark hair tied in a herb-scented braid. She wears layered green robes, stained from years of potion-making. She is stubborn and highly independent, refusing to leave Umbrage Hill even under threat.
Visual Trait: Streak of purple dye in her braid from crushed bellroot. Quip: 'I didn’t distill ghost pepper salve just to be run off by a flying lion.'

note.name: NPC – Injured Manticore
note.text:
A battered manticore with a torn wing membrane and patches of frostbite. Possibly driven from the mountains by Cryovain, it is desperate, hungry, and considers the windmill’s potions its salvation.
Visual Trait: Scarred snout with an icicle-shaped claw mark across its left eye. Quip: 'I bleed... and you brew. Heal me, or feed me.'

note.name: Wrapping Up
note.text:
Quest Resolution • Quest Goal: Ensure Adabra Gwynn’s safety and encourage her return to Phandalin. • Outcome: Adabra refuses to leave her windmill, believing her healing work is more valuable here. However, she agrees to write a note to Harbin Wester confirming her well-being. • The party can return to Phandalin’s Townmaster’s Hall to complete the quest by delivering the note. • Reward from Adabra: One potion of healing per party, not per character. She may offer additional potions for 50 gp each, as long as she has stock.
Additional Outcomes • If the Manticore is Defeated: • Adabra is deeply grateful. Her future dialogue with the party becomes warmer and more personal. • The area is safe for use as a retreat point or sanctuary in the future. • If the Manticore is Healed or Bribed: • The manticore flies off, vowing to return the favor… if the party honors their word. • Future Hook: The manticore (or its mate) may appear later to assist in the battle against Cryovain—particularly if they’re promised healing, meat, or a share of treasure.
Future Use • Potion Supplier: Adabra can be revisited between quests for healing potions (limited supply). • Informant or Ally: She may be a voice of wisdom regarding nature, dreams, or Chauntea’s teachings. • Potential Rescue Target: If the manticore returns with allies or if Cryovain’s reign worsens, Umbrage Hill may come under threat again—offering a future side quest or dramatic rescue opportunity.
Harbin Wester Interaction (Quest Turn-In) • Harbin refuses to open his door. If the party slides the note under it: • He muffles a “Very good! Thank you!” and rewards the party with 25 gp, unless the Reavers have already stolen the reward (see below). • Optional Rival Hook: If the Stone-Cold Reavers get here first, they might forge a note and claim the reward, forcing the party to deal with Harbin’s confusion and the Reavers’ smug taunts.
Narrative Beat to Emphasize • This is the first moment the players encounter a greater consequence of Cryovain’s arrival—the manticore is displaced, Adabra is in danger, and even remote areas aren’t safe. Use this to subtly remind players that things are escalating across the Sword Coast

npc.label: Joybell
npc.name: Joybell
npc.text: Joybell • Role: Kitchen overseer (T4) • Look: Wears a soot-streaked apron and a scorched chef’s hat with a feather sticking out • Quip: “Bread not burn today. Not like yesterday. Or the day before.. or- check oven! Check oven!”

npc.label: Dimble
npc.name: Dimble
npc.text: • Role: Mushroom oil extractor (T4) • Look: Has thick goggles smeared with fungus juice and a mushroom-oil stain shaped like a heart on his vest • Quip: “Red squish makes fire juice. You drink? No! You die! Fun!”

npc.label: Panana
npc.name: Panana
npc.text: Panana • Role: Dough kneader (T4) • Look: Wild hair tied with twine, sleeves always rolled up, arms dusted in green flour • Quip: “Knead! Press! Smack dough like it owes you mushrooms!”

npc.label: Uppendown
npc.name: Uppendown
npc.text: Role: Bread sculptor (T4) • Look: Wears a monocle and carries a tiny chisel and brush for shaping loaves • Quip: “Each loaf… a masterpiece. The crust must whisper when cracked.

npc.label: Tervaround
npc.name: Tervaround
npc.text: Role: Wine fermenter (T4) • Look: Always balancing precariously on a stool, with purple mushroom stains up to her elbows • Quip: “Purple goes in the barrel, not in mouth! Not again! No more purple dreams!

npc.label: Fibblestib
npc.name: Fibblestib
npc.text: Fibblestib • Role: Inventor (T11) • Look: Puffy white hair sticking out at wild angles; carries blueprints rolled into a sword belt • Quip: “Sanity ray! Zap-zap! Brain fixed, crown straight!

npc.label: Dabbledob
npc.name: Dabbledob
npc.text: Dabbledob • Role: Inventor (T11) • Look: Wears a harness of tools and a shoulder-slung clipboard labeled “Stabilize Everything” • Quip: “No zaps. Just straps. Straitjacket better than brain boom!

npc.label: Facktorè
npc.name: Facktorè
npc.text: Facktoré • Role: Turret inventor (T7) • Look: Pale goggles over wild eyes, sitting in a rotating chair of crossbows • Quip: “Welcome! Time to spin and test! Hope you duck good!

npc.label: Ulla
npc.name: Ulla
npc.text: Ulla • Role: Guard (T9) • Look: Wears a dented pot as a helmet with “SHAPES BAD” scratched into it • Quip: “Say your name. Say it backwards. Real gnomes can do that!

npc.label: Pog
npc.name: Pog
npc.text: Pog • Role: Guard (T9) • Look: Holds a crossbow upside down; wears mismatched boots • Quip: “No changers! No rug people! I bite first—ask later!

npc.label: King Korboz
npc.name: King Korboz
npc.text: King Korboz • Role: Paranoid king (T15) • Look: Wears a jagged scrap-metal crown and carries a glue-dissolving flask • Quip: “It’s here. It’s here! Took Bip, then chair. Chair still here… why chair still here?!

npc.label: King Gnerkli
npc.name: King Gnerkli
npc.text: King Korboz • Role: Paranoid king (T15) • Look: Wears a jagged scrap-metal crown and carries a glue-dissolving flask • Quip: “It’s here. It’s here! Took Bip, then chair. Chair still here… why chair still here?!

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Tasha's Cauldron of Everything p. 167

trait.name: False Appearance (Object Form Only)
trait.text: While the mimic remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary object.

trait.name: Spider Climb
trait.text: The mimic can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 1 piercing damage plus 2 (1d4) acid damage.

action.name: Shape-Shift
action.text: The mimic polymorphs into an object or back into its true, amorphous form. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 220, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 60

trait.name: Shapechanger
trait.text: The mimic can use its action to polymorph into an object or back into its true, amorphous form. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Adhesive (Object Form Only)
trait.text: The mimic adheres to anything that touches it. A Huge or smaller creature adhered to the mimic is also grappled by it (escape DC 13). Ability checks made to escape this grapple have disadvantage.

trait.name: False Appearance (Object Form Only)
trait.text: While the mimic remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary object.

trait.name: Grappler
trait.text: The mimic has advantage on attack rolls against any creature grappled by it.

action.name: Pseudopod
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8+3) bludgeoning damage. If the mimic is in object form, the target is subjected to its Adhesive trait.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8+3) piercing damage plus 4 (1d8) acid damage.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Tasha's Cauldron of Everything p. 167

trait.name: False Appearance (Object Form Only)
trait.text: While the mimic remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary object.

trait.name: Spider Climb
trait.text: The mimic can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 1 piercing damage plus 2 (1d4) acid damage.

action.name: Shape-Shift
action.text: The mimic polymorphs into an object or back into its true, amorphous form. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

item.name: Clockwork Amulet
item.text:
This copper amulet contains tiny interlocking gears and is powered by magic from Mechanus, a plane of clockwork predictability. A creature that puts an ear to the amulet can hear faint ticking and whirring noises coming from within. When you make an attack roll while wearing the amulet, you can forgo rolling the d20 to get a 10 on the die. Once used, this property can't be used again until the next dawn.
Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything p. 137

item.name: Pole of Collapsing
item.text:
While holding this 10-foot pole, you can use an action to speak a command word and cause it to collapse into a 1-foot-long rod, for ease of storage. The pole's weight doesn't change. You can use an action to speak a different command word and cause the rod to revert to a pole; however, the rod will elongate only as far as the surrounding space allows.
Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything p. 138

item.name: Hat of Wizardry
item.text:
This antiquated, cone-shaped hat is adorned with gold crescent moons and stars. While you are wearing it, you gain the following benefits: You can use the hat as a spellcasting focus for your wizard spells. You can try to cast a cantrip that you don't know. The cantrip must be on the wizard spell list, and you must make a DC 10 Intelligence (Arcana) check. If the check succeeds, you cast the spell. If the check fails, so does the spell, and the action used to cast the spell is wasted. In either case, you can't use this property again until you finish a long rest.
Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything p. 137

item.name: Wand of Pyrotechnics
item.text:
This wand has 7 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 of its charges and create a harmless burst of multicolored light at a point you can see up to 60 feet away. The burst of light is accompanied by a crackling noise that can be heard up to 300 feet away. The light is as bright as a torch flame but lasts only a second. The wand regains 1d6 + 1 expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the wand's last charge, roll a d20. On a 1, the wand erupts in a harmless pyrotechnic display and is destroyed.
Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything p. 140

note.name: Gnomengarde Bounty
note.text:
Quest Name: Gnomengarde Quest Where Posted: Townmaster’s Hall bounty board in Phandalin Who Posts It: Townmaster Harbin Wester Bounty Text (paraphrased from the adventure):
“A clan of reclusive rock gnomes lives in a small network of caves in the mountains to the south. The gnomes of Gnomengarde have the magical inventions Phandalin needs to defend itself. Find out if they’ll help. If they do, get them to send aid. If not, try to convince them or at least find out why.”
Reward: 50 gp upon successful return with gnome aid or a full report Complication: • The gnomes are paranoid due to recent disappearances • A mimic has infiltrated their lair, causing fear and chaos • The party must earn the gnomes’ trust, deal with the mimic, and calm King Korboz’s paranoia

note.name: T1. Misty Pool and Mushroom Islands
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
Mist drapes the chamber like a silken veil. A shallow, glassy pool stretches before you, glowing faintly with a shimmering green-blue hue. Two low islets rise from the water, each covered in towering mushrooms—red, green, and violet—glowing like fungal lanterns.
The air hums with unseen magic. You feel it—not just see or hear it—but feel it, thrumming gently behind your ribs.
Some of the mushroom stalks twitch slightly, as if breathing. You could swear the mist just whispered something. Maybe it’s the waterfall. Maybe it’s not.
Gnomish Quip (if a gnome is present or watching):
“Don’t eat the purple one. Makes dreams too loud. Red’s okay. Oil fire boom fun. Green? Bread. Always bread.”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This cavern holds the mystical heart of Tinkleguard. A 3-foot-deep pool surrounds two islands of magically grown mushrooms. The mist is perpetual, created by the nearby waterfall in area T2 and kept thick by enchantments from the enclave’s founders.
The mushrooms are: • Red – Produces a slick oil used in lanterns and devices • Green – Ground into flour for rich, herbal “green bread” • Purple – Crushed and fermented into potent mushroom wine
The islands themselves are enchanted, acting as a subtle ley node that fuels much of the odd magical interference in the area. It’s this wild magic that causes many of the strange inventions and accidents around Tinkleguard.
The mushrooms radiate a faint magical aura if detect magic is used—primarily transmutation with a hint of wild magic residue.
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Bioluminescent mushroom stalks sway slightly in still air; mist coils around them like dancing spirits • Sound: The low crash of water, subtle popping from the mushrooms’ gills • Smell: Earthy, damp, spiced with fungal sweetness • Touch: Cool air clings to your skin; the mist leaves a faint tingling sensation • Taste: Metallic tang of wild magic; the air is thick like soup on the tongue
Optional Encounter Seed
If you want to foreshadow danger, you might add: • A mushroom cap has a large bite taken out of it. • One of the island stones is slightly melted or clawed. • A half-sunk gnomish tool belt lies in the pool, tangled in mushroom roots

note.name: T2. Waterfall and Rope Bridge
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
The roar hits you first—like a living wall of thunder. Mist sprays out in great white plumes from a mighty waterfall plunging sixty feet into darkness below. Carved stone ledges rise twenty feet on either side of a mist-choked gorge, and spanning it: a rope bridge.
Thirty-five feet of wet, sagging wood and twine—frayed in places, shivering in others. The middle droops low, hanging just fifteen feet above the churning pool below. A single lantern swings from a hook halfway across, its light strobing in the rising fog like a blinking eye.
The whole bridge groans at the mere sight of you.
Gnomish Quip (whispered from the mist):
“Bridge tricky. Likes to dance. Don’t jump. No crab ride! Crabs tangle. They scream.”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
The waterfall is both a natural marvel and a magical amplifier for the energies coursing through Tinkleguard. Its constant roar fills the chamber and partially obscures the 35-foot rope bridge, which connects two raised ledges carved into the stone. • The bridge is difficult terrain due to its sagging center and slick, misty ropes. • If a creature falls or jumps, the water 15 feet below cushions the fall—no damage taken. • The barrel crab constructs from T6 cannot cross the bridge without becoming hopelessly entangled.
The bridge itself: • AC 11, 30 HP • Immune to poison and psychic damage • Shows signs of strain—sections have clearly been patched with different types of rope and vines.
The mist here is heavy—any ranged attacks beyond 10 feet suffer disadvantage unless magical sight is used.
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Rushing waterfall obscures the far side; ropes sway and glisten in the mist • Sound: Overwhelming, echoing roar of falling water; your own voice sounds miles away • Smell: Fresh and sharp, like split granite in a storm • Touch: Everything is wet—ropes, boots, even your teeth feel damp • Taste: Cold, stony mineral wash; the waterfall’s mist almost stings your tongue
Hazard Notes
Crossing the bridge during combat or in haste may require: • DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) to maintain footing if moving faster than half speed • Falling results in being swept a few feet downstream, unless caught or supported
Optional Drama Beat
A loose gnome-made device dangles from a hook under the bridge. Retrievable with mage hand or risky climbing, it’s: • A glowspore flare that provides radiant light for 1 minute, then explodes with harmless sparks (can be used later to distract a paranoid gnome

note.name: T3. Dining Hollow
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
The stone tunnel opens into a low-ceilinged grotto, shaped more by hands than water. The chamber is lined with gnome-sized tables, all arranged neatly—too neatly. Chairs sit slightly off-angle. One has tipped and never been righted.
A stout wooden cabinet leans against the far wall, its doors closed but a spoon jutting from the corner like a tongue. A faint draft whispers through the room, curling beneath your collar and rustling something unseen.
It smells like old bread and something just a little… acidic.
Gnomish Quip (if observed, even echoing):
“Friend sat there. Then poof. Chair hungry. Spoon laughed. Don’t sit. Never sit!”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This is where the gnomes of Tinkleguard once gathered to eat and talk and argue over mushrooms. Now it’s eerily quiet. The space is clean, but untouched in a way that screams of absence. • Contains several Small-sized tables and chairs • A cabinet on the east wall holds gnome-sized tin dishware and utensils • There are no gnomes present, but one chair has been knocked over (and not put back) • The air carries faint traces of mushroom stew—long gone cold • Paranoia and grief have settled here like dust
This room is a prime spot for characters to: • Grow suspicious of the mimic (which may be in T8) • Realize someone left in a hurry—or didn’t leave at all
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Tables perfectly arranged, plates still stacked, one chair out of place • Sound: Every sound you make echoes too long—no other life stirs • Smell: Dry bread, faintly sour wine, the metallic sting of old panic • Touch: Smooth stone, faint warmth where sunlight never reaches • Taste: Faint oiliness, as if breathing in the memory of food
Optional Clue • A tiny gnomish fork lies half-under a chair. • One prong is bent inward, and the tip coated in a sticky, colorless slime • Clues characters in to the mimic threat, or that something snatched someone mid-meal
DM Note:
The mimic is not here unless you decide to move it from T8. If you want to spook the party: • Have a chair shift slightly when no one is near it • Let one of them sit and hear a faint gurgle beneath them—harmless… this time

note.name: T4. The Kitchen
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
Warmth hits you like a puff of fresh bread. This chamber is narrow and steamy, packed wall to wall with rope-and-pulley cooking contraptions. Gears clatter. A pair of tongs flings itself into a pot. Rolling pins march like soldiers across dough.
Five gnomes hustle about the room, arguing with their tools and each other. Each of them is half-buried in mushrooms, flour, or steam. None of them stop when you enter—though a few eyes flick your way before snapping back to their culinary chaos.
“If you touch that bread, I will stab you with a ladle,” one of them mutters.
Gnomish Quip Chorus (overlapping):
“Outsiders! Don’t touch anything. Especially that. Or that. Or her.” “You like cooking? You cook? You look cookable—HA!” “One of you’s a chair. I know it.”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This is Tinkleguard’s main kitchen, customized with Small-sized furnishings and cluttered with bizarre but functional inventions—rope-and-gear bread rollers, steam-powered fermenters, and oil presses rigged to squeeze mushrooms with unnatural precision.
Each of the five gnome recluses here is preoccupied with their work and won’t leave the kitchen, but they’ll engage in frantic, distracted conversation. They all avoid talking about the missing gnomes or King Korboz’s paranoia, instead directing visitors to the inventors in T11.
NPC Cast of Cooks
Joybell (female gnome) • Role: Stove wrangler • Current Action: Stoking the fire of a hot iron stove with a long-handled poker • Visual Trait: Singed white hair tied in a fungus-patterned scarf • Personality: Stern, unflinching, takes kitchen discipline very seriously • Need: For you to stay out of her kitchen • Quip: “Touch the poker, and I’ll baste your fingers.”
She stands by the iron stove near the east wall, feeding thick mushroom logs into the flames with the grim intensity of a blacksmith.
Dimble (male gnome) • Role: Mushroom oil press operator • Current Action: Using a complex press-like contraption to extract oil from a red mushroom, filtering it into small flasks • Visual Trait: Thick goggles smeared with red oil; one strap broken and tied with twine • Personality: Precise, mechanical, speaks in muttered equations • Need: Recognition for his flawless oil extraction ratios • Quip: “Red cap in, red oil out. That’s alchemical harmony. You wouldn’t understand.”
Dimble doesn’t look up when addressed—his full focus is on adjusting sprockets and pulleys for perfect pressure.
Panana (female gnome) • Role: Bread dough prep • Current Action: Standing atop a low table while operating a mechanical rolling pin, kneading green bread dough made from mushroom flour • Visual Trait: Two missing fingers on one hand, replaced with jointed brass nubs • Personality: Loud, chipper, constantly singing off-key • Need: Company. Hates silence more than chaos • Quip: “Bread should sing! And scream! And rise like revolution!”
She hums to the dough while occasionally slapping it for “motivation.”
Uppendown (male gnome) • Role: Bread sculptor • Current Action: Forming the dough into loaves, sculpting each one meticulously as if entering a baking competition only he knows about • Visual Trait: A pair of monocles on a rotating brass armature—clicks between them while shaping loaves • Personality: Arrogant artisan; believes bread is art • Need: Adoration. Craves compliments on his work • Quip: “Each loaf is a sculpture of agony. Of triumph. Of… delicious despair.”
He pauses after each loaf to admire it from different angles and nod gravely.
Tervaround (female gnome) • Role: Mushroom wine fermenter • Current Action: Stuffing a massive purple mushroom into a barrel, standing precariously on a stool to reach • Visual Trait: Patchy hair dyed unevenly purple, one eye constantly twitching • Personality: Nervous, conspiratorial, whispers to the barrels • Need: Safety. She suspects the mimic is still here • Quip: “Purple’s watching. I pour it in, it looks back. One day, it’ll drink me.”
She looks over her shoulder between every mushroom drop, eyeing the wine barrels like they might blink
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Steaming counters, clanking pulleys, loaves in weird shapes • Sound: Gear clicks, bubbling pots, overlapping muttering • Smell: Rich green bread, roasted red mushroom oil, sharp purple wine ferment • Touch: Heat from the stove, sticky dough, warm metal • Taste: The air is savory, spicy, sour—and slightly smoky
Optional Clue or Hook
A basket of bread bears a strange indentation—something large and toothy took a bite, but the gnomes refuse to speak about it.
If pressed, Tervaround mutters:
“Big teeth. Not mine. Not bread’s. Barrel teeth. Chair teeth.”

note.name: T5. Pantry
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
The corridor gives way to a cramped stone chamber stacked to the ceiling with crates and shelves. Green loaves of mushroom bread are wrapped in waxed paper and piled like bricks. Fungal jerky dangles from hooks. One barrel leaks purple brine across the floor.
The air is heavy, dense with preserved rot and something faintly… chemical. You get the uneasy sense that something recently slithered out of here. Or back in.
Gnomish Quip (if a gnome saw you enter):
“You hungry? Take bread. Not that one. That one bit back.” “Crate nine’s cursed. Bread keeps rearranging itself.”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This pantry is packed to bursting with preserved foodstuffs collected and prepared by the gnomes. The majority are: • Loaves of green mushroom bread • Jars of pickled cap stems and stalks • Dried fungal jerky strips • Kegs of mushroom brine
Some of the crates have been disturbed—pried open not with hands or tools, but with brute force. A few have strange, wet scratch marks on the lids, and the floor near the wall has a trail of slick residue like a slug the size of a horse made a hasty exit.
There are no gnomes here. It’s a dead-silent storehouse. Too silent.
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Stacked crates, fungus-slick walls, some loaves missing large chunks • Sound: Muffled thump (a crate settling? something moving deeper?) • Smell: Pickled mushroom, dry earth, and something sour-sweet and wrong • Touch: Crates damp with brine, one is slimy underneath • Taste: The air has a pickled tang, but bitter mold clings at the back of your throat
Optional Clue • A crate in the back is missing its lid entirely. Inside: a crumpled gnome apron, soaked in wine and streaked with mucus-like goo. No blood. • A DC 12 Survival check reveals drag marks leading toward T8 (Mimic and Mushroom Wine)
Player Tension Tool
If you want to up the paranoia, let a crate lid shift by itself. When investigated—nothing. But the smell inside is warm. Like breath.

note.name: T6. Barrel Crabs
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
This chamber hums faintly with the ticking of dormant machinery. Two enormous contraptions sit parked in alcoves, each one shaped like a crab—if a crab were made of barrels, rivets, and bad ideas.
Six articulated legs curl under each shell. Forward-facing pincer claws twitch once… then settle still. A hatch on top creaks slightly open, revealing a padded leather seat and a dashboard of tangled levers.
One of the crabs lets out a hiss, like a sigh of disappointment.
Gnomish Quip (if they’re seen climbing in):
“You ride? You drive? You crash. Everyone crashes.” “Crabs strong. Crabs dumb. Don’t let crab love you—it hugs too hard.”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
Two gnome-built contraptions rest in this otherwise empty chamber: • Each resembles a crab with a barrel-shaped shell, six metal legs, and forward-facing pincer claws. • A top hatch opens to reveal a single Small-sized cockpit, complete with levers, gears, and a padded seat. Medium creatures can squeeze in uncomfortably.
Each Barrel Crab: • AC 15, 30 HP, STR 10 • Immune to poison and psychic damage • Cannot breathe underwater or survive high pressure (they are not airtight) • Movement: Scuttles at 15 ft. speed • Attack: • Claws (Melee Weapon Attack): +2 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. • Hit: 5 (2d4) piercing damage, and the target is grappled (escape DC 10)
While inside, a creature gains: • Total cover from outside attacks • Ability to use an action to move or attack with the claws • Only one function per turn (move or attack)
The machines are too wide to cross the rope bridge in T2. Attempting to do so results in them becoming tangled and potentially falling into the stream below.
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Metal exoskeletons glint with rust and oil • Sound: Clocks tick within the crabs; a low skkkrrr of pressurized steam • Smell: Oil, grease, and faint sulfur • Touch: Metal is warm to the touch; the inside smells like nervous gnome sweat • Taste: Air is heavy with iron and rubber—bitter and artificial
Optional Detail • One crab has a nameplate welded on: “Snippy” • The other’s has been burned off, but scratched beneath it in chalk: “Heard whispers. Bad crab now. Do not trust.”
Player Engagement Hook
If a character climbs in: • The crab jerks forward once on its own, even if unpowered • From within the hatch, they spot something scuttling under a nearby crate—gone when investigated.

note.name: T7. Auto loading Crossbow Platform
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
This chamber clanks, whirs, and hums with pent-up energy. In its center stands a massive, bolted-down contraption: a rotating platform armed with four heavy crossbows, their strings pulled taut.
Above the weaponry sits a tall, absurd chair outfitted with pedals, levers, and one cracked teacup bolted to the armrest. Sitting in the chair is a wide-eyed gnome in a patched leather coat, one foot resting on a dangling gear chain, the other twitching with anticipation.
Her head jerks toward you as you enter. “FIELD TEST. INITIATING.”
Gnomish Quip (Facktoré, immediately):
“Are you hostile? Don’t answer. Let’s assume yes.” “Spin, shoot, reload, repeat! This is science!!”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This room houses the autocrossbow turret platform, an invention of Facktoré, one of Tinkleguard’s more “single-minded” residents. The entire device is a Large object that: • AC 13, 45 HP • Immune to poison and psychic damage • Every 10 HP lost disables one of the four autoloading crossbows
Mounted crossbows: • Each makes a Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, range 50/200 ft., one target Hit: 5 (1d10) piercing damage • Each has 20 bolts when combat begins
A creature in the chair (Facktoré or a player): • May use an action to: • Spin the device 360 degrees counterclockwise • Fire up to two crossbows, aiming in any direction
The platform makes a grinding metal shriek when it rotates, echoing through the complex like an alarm bell.
Facktoré – NPC Summary • Visual Trait: Tattered leather apron stitched with copper wire; goggles permanently fogged; one mechanical hand • Personality: Obsessed, tunnel-visioned, unpredictable genius • Need: Recognition and validation for her “perfect” invention • Quip: “System ready. You’re the test. We’ll fix the bugs later—assuming you survive!”
Behavior: • Facktoré attacks intruders immediately, assuming they’re spies or shapeshifters • Ceases fire only if: • Reduced to 0 HP • The platform is disabled or destroyed • The party calms her with a successful DC 13 Charisma (Persuasion or Performance) check • After calming down, she becomes chatty and erratic, offering wild ideas about shapechangers, living chairs, and combat muffins
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Crossbows gleam with tension; mechanical chair twitching with readiness • Sound: Clicks, clanks, the buzz of tensioned string and shifting gears • Smell: Iron, gunpowder, singed oil • Touch: Warm chair leather; static from frayed wiring • Taste: Dry metal and gnome breath
Optional Discovery
On a shelf behind the turret: • A small, cracked crystal labeled “TARGET ACQUISITION STONE – EXPERIMENTAL” • Can be used as an improvised alarm (buzzes when someone enters line of sight) • Facktoré doesn’t even remember making it

note.name: T8. Mimic(?) And Mushroom Wine
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
The air is thick here—warmer, wetter, sour. Twelve massive barrels sit snugly in alcoves carved into the walls, their tops sealed with dark wood and pinned with brass braces. Some bear taps and drip slowly into pails below.
Fungus creeps along the walls. One of the barrels has a faint pulse, like a heartbeat. Another groans—just wood settling… you hope.
The scent of fermented mushroom is overpowering, cloying, and almost sweet enough to cover the reek of something alive.
Gnomish Quip (from Tervaround, if she’s followed the party here):
“One’s not a barrel. I know it. I watched it… swallow Quippy’s arm. Barrels don’t burp like that.”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This chamber contains twelve forty-gallon barrels, most of them full of fermented purple mushroom wine. • Barrels are set into alcoves and braced with wood • South alcove barrels are tapped, two are half-full, two nearly empty • North and east alcoves hold eight untapped, full barrels • One of these eight is a mimic, lying in wait
Mimic Behavior: • The mimic has learned patience, preying on isolated gnomes • When attacked or sufficiently disturbed (e.g., poking, trying to move it), it reveals its form • If the players get clever and use detect magic, it does not register (mimics aren’t inherently magical) • If characters attempt to move a barrel: choose whether to reveal it or roll 1d8 to determine the mimic’s position
Mimic – Stat Block Snapshot • AC: 12 | HP: 58 • Shapechanger | Adhesive | False Appearance (Object) • Pseudopod (Melee): +5 to hit, 1d8+3 bludgeoning + 1d8 acid • Engulfs and grapples (Escape DC 13)
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Barrels glisten with dampness, some bloated as if overfull • Sound: Dripping wine… and a slow, wet rasp from somewhere behind a barrel • Smell: Sweet and putrid—purple wine over rot • Touch: Barrel staves are warm, slightly pulsing—one is sticky • Taste: Vinegar-sour air coats your tongue with something bitter and wrong
Optional Clue
Players investigating the barrels can notice: • One is warm to the touch when the others are cool • Gnomish footprints leading to it—none leading away • A bit of torn gnome robe stuck between barrel and wall • A half-full mug of wine still warm on the floor nearby
Optional Gnome Corpse Discovery (Grim Clue)
If you want to raise the stakes: • A barrel tap is torn out • Inside, remnants of gnome-sized bones and hair float in thick purple sludge • A cork is embedded with bite marks
This is where players realize the paranoia is real, and King Korboz might not be as mad as he seems

note.name: T9. Gnome Guard Post
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
Mist hangs heavy in this cave, stirred only by your breath and the faint splash of water against stone. A slick, natural ramp curves up to a ledge ten feet above. There, two gnomes crouch behind a crooked barricade made from scrap metal, pipe segments, and broken chair legs.
One raises a rusty crossbow. The other squints at you, lips trembling. They shout together—overlapping.
“WHO GOES THERE?!”
“…Might be chairs. Might be changers. Speak truth or we poke you full’a bolts!”
Gnomish Quips (Ulla & Pog, overlapping and erratic):
“Not real. Not real. One of you’s not real.” “You got teeth where you shouldn’t? Let me see your tongue!” “Only real ones know the Muffin Code! …Wait. Do we have one?”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This mist-dampened cave serves as a defensive post for Tinkleguard. A 10-foot-high ledge overlooks the lower floor and can be: • Reached via the curving tunnel to the east, or • Climbed directly with a successful DC 12 Strength (Athletics) check on the slick stone wall
Atop the ledge are two paranoid gnome guards:
NPCs
Ulla (female gnome) • Visual Trait: Missing three fingers on one hand, wears a fingerless glove stuffed with spoons • Personality: Suspicious, humorless, militant • Need: Proof that you’re not shapeshifters • Quip: “Real folks sweat. Chairs don’t sweat. You sweating yet?”
Pog (male gnome) • Visual Trait: Missing an eye; his socket is filled with a smooth purple bead • Personality: Nervous echo, always defers to Ulla • Need: To not screw this up again • Quip: “I just do what Ulla says. Even if she is a chair.”
Encounters / Social Options
Their orders are clear: “Attack shapechangers on sight.” Since anyone might be one, they’re jumpy and aggressive.
To avoid a fight, a character must succeed on one of the following: • DC 10 Charisma (Deception): “We’ve been invited by the kings.” • DC 10 Charisma (Intimidation): “Hurt us, and Tinkleguard gets wiped off the map.” • DC 10 Charisma (Persuasion): “Shapechangers wouldn’t walk in so loudly… or wear this hat.”
On a success: They lower their crossbows but continue to watch the party like hawks. On a failure: They attack. (1 round of warning yells, then fire from above.)
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Mist curling along the floor, shadows flickering on the ledge • Sound: Quiet except for whispered arguments and creaking crossbows • Smell: Oiled wood, stale sweat, tension • Touch: Damp cave floor, the weight of eyes watching from above • Taste: Bitter air—fear-salted
Optional Discovery • A rusted grappling hook lies discarded behind the ledge—snapped rope still attached. The cut marks on the rope look… chewed

note.name: T10. Spinning Blades
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
You step into swirling mist—cool, quiet… and then you hear it.
A faint whir… no, two. Twin devices sit in the misty eastern half of the room. Each resembles a waist-high turnstile, but instead of bars, they’re rigged with long, razor-thin blades that spin like buzz saws.
The northern spinner rotates counterclockwise. The southern one whirls clockwise.
Between them is only a narrow strip of safe stone and a lever on the far side. It’s brass. It’s big. It’s very much out of reach.
Gnomish Quips (disembodied or later explanation from inventors):
“It was for… slicing bread! Big bread! Bad bread!” “Mage hand. Mage hand! That’s what it’s for! What? You don’t have mage hand?” “One time it sliced a changeling in half! Or maybe a coat rack. Still counts!”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This area is lightly obscured by mist from the waterfall. The eastern section holds two rapidly spinning bladed turnstiles—lethal gnome-made security devices. • The northern turnstile spins counterclockwise • The southern turnstile spins clockwise • A brass lever is located in the south wall of the western portion, set to “down”
Trap Mechanics: • Any creature entering or starting their turn in the eastern part of the room while the blades spin must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking: • 18 (4d8) slashing damage on a fail • Half as much on success • Pulling the lever (up) causes the blades to stop spinning
Bypassing It the Gnome Way: • The gnomes normally use the mage hand cantrip from the eastern doorway to flip the lever without stepping inside
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Blades flash in the mist like teeth; reflections scatter across the wet floor • Sound: Whrrr-clack-whrrr, like an angry music box on overdrive • Smell: Burnt oil and iron • Touch: Wind from the blades tugs at your cloak’s edge; stone beneath your feet vibrates • Taste: Air like metal shavings—bitter and dangerous
Optional Clues or Features • A gnomish boot, too small for a PC, lies in the corner—sliced cleanly at the toe • There’s a char mark on the wall, where someone once tried shocking grasp to jam the gears. It didn’t end well.
Tension Builder Tip
As players discuss the trap, have the southern spinner speed up slightly and emit a screech like metal on bone. No mechanical effect—just flavor that says: it’s ready

note.name: T11. Inventors Workshop
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
The tunnel opens into a cluttered stone chamber filled with tables, scrolls, workbenches, and half-built devices that hiss, spark, or softly hum. The air is thick with the smell of singed paper and ozone.
Atop a short ledge, two gnomes argue furiously in Gnomish—hands flailing, gears bouncing from their pockets.
“Sanity ray!” one shouts, slamming a copper rod on a table. “Straitjacket!” the other retorts, wielding a bundle of straps and tiny buckles like a warbanner.
They freeze mid-bicker when they spot you—then speak in eerie unison:
“Are you here to help fix the kings?”
Gnomish Quips (Fibblestib & Dabbledob):
Fibblestib: “We need a zap. One good zap. Clears the brain like mushroom vodka!” Dabbledob: “Zaps don’t cure madness! They cause it! Straps! Straps are safe!” Both: “Unless you’re a shapeshifter. Then… dissection!”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This is the brainstem of Tinkleguard—the workshop of its two most brilliant (and unbalanced) inventors: Fibblestib and Dabbledob. The room is filled with: • Half-completed gadgets, most of them broken, smoking, or nonsensical • Tinker’s tools, scribbled blueprints, coils, and a shared spellbook on a pedestal • A 10-foot-high ledge overlooks the main floor (where the inventors usually perch)
NPCs
Fibblestib (male gnome) • Visual Trait: A metal coil worn as a monocle; zaps occasionally when he blinks • Personality: Dreamy, excitable, chaotic engineer • Need: Build something that cures King Korboz’s madness (with lightning) • Quip: “Madness is just… ungrounded brilliance! Zap it into place!”
Dabbledob (female gnome) • Visual Trait: A leather apron covered in tiny straps, buckles, and three useless belts • Personality: Blunt, skeptical, hyper-logical • Need: Contain King Korboz’s madness with physical means • Quip: “If it can’t scream, it can’t break things. Simple.”
Together, they: • Are more concerned about fixing the kings than the missing gnomes • Offer magical rewards if players can help calm or “cure” the kings • Constantly bicker, but are brilliant in their own right
Magical Item Hook
If the party aids them or earns their trust, they offer one of their prototypes: • See “Gnome-Made Magic Items” in the adventure, or invent something new and wild
Spellbook on the Pedestal
Entitled Magick of Tinkleguard (in Common and Gnomish), it contains: • Burning hands, detect magic, identify, mage armor, magic missile, shield, sleep
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Scrolls and scribbles everywhere; a corkboard of nonsense equations • Sound: Buzzing gears, scribbled muttering, intermittent laughter • Smell: Ink, ozone, and fungal glue • Touch: Everything zaps or sticks or smokes when touched • Taste: Air filled with static—like licking a lightning rod
Optional Encounter
If the players present a calming spell, item, or strategy: • Fibblestib attempts to build a sanity ray 2.0 • Dabbledob starts strapping it to a helmet before they agree what it does
Success earns party favor, plus treasure access (see T13)

note.name: T12. Gnome Domiciles
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
The smell of warm stone and mushroom soap greets you as you step into a long, low chamber. Faint ash from old campfires dusts the floor, and quiet breaths echo from four shallow caves off the main room.
Each nook holds tiny wooden cots crammed together like sardines in a can. Eight gnomes sleep here—peacefully, for now. One snores. One sleep-talks. One drools into a sock.
It’s cozy. It’s quiet. It feels… borrowed from better times.
Gnomish Quips (if one wakes up groggily):
“Mmrph… I wasn’t drooling, it’s soup… zzz.” “You smell like chairs. Chair-changers. Shifters! Wait—dream. Just a dream.” “Five more minutes! Unless you’re breakfast. Are you breakfast?”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This area functions as the shared sleeping quarters for the reclusive gnomes of Tinkleguard. It includes: • Four side chambers, each fitted with five Small-sized cots • Eight rock gnomes are currently asleep (two per side cave): • Caramip, Jabby, Nyx, Quippy (female) • Anverth, Delebean, Pallabar, Zook (male)
None of the sleeping gnomes are hostile unless attacked. They: • Avoid talking about the missing gnomes or recent events • Suggest visitors speak with Fibblestib and Dabbledob (T11) if questioned
Optional: If the players make too much noise, one or two gnomes awaken and may: • React with fear (“Chairs!”) • Sleep-cast minor illusion (harmless but spooky) • Attempt to hide under beds or throw shoes
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Neatly arranged cots, mushroom-stitched quilts, tiny shelves with carved trinkets • Sound: Gentle snoring, the occasional sleepy mumble, one phantom fart • Smell: Soap, moss, and well-worn wool • Touch: The air is warm, blankets soft, stone floor gently radiates heat • Taste: Mushrooms… and gnome sweat (regrettably)
Optional Clue • One cot is empty but undisturbed, neatly made—no dust • A half-eaten roll lies beneath it, hardened, with one perfect mimic tooth embedded
Flavor Tip
This area is a tonal contrast to the chaos elsewhere. If played right, it can: • Offer brief peace before the final confrontation • Remind players of the gnomes’ innocence and vulnerability • Let you drop hints about mimic feeding patterns, vanishing cots, or strange sleepwalking

note.name: T13. Treasury
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
The scent of rust and dust strikes first. This room is piled wall to wall with tangled contraptions, broken gizmos, warped gears, twisted metal rods, cracked lenses, and a few things that probably never worked in the first place.
The only lighting comes from a half-broken lamp strapped to the wall with belt leather. A spring-powered boot taps on the floor with no one in it. Somewhere in the back, something goes ping… and then nothing.
This is where the genius comes to rest—and rot.
Gnomish Quip (if guided here by Fibblestib or Dabbledob):
“Treasure! Or trash. Or both! We forget.” “Found the time-freezer here once. Froze time. For four seconds. Melted a bird.” “Don’t touch anything that hums or weeps.”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This locked chamber serves as storage for gnome scrap, spare parts, and failed inventions. Only Fibblestib and Dabbledob carry the keys.
The room is full of: • Nonfunctional gnomish machines, like boot-launchers, gear umbrellas, and one silent music box that opens backward • Loose gears, coils, and bits of twisted brass • Crates labeled in scribbled Gnomish (“NOT DANGEROUS,” “PROBABLY FINE,” “ASK FIRST”)
Treasure (if investigated)
With effort or magic, the following can be found among the scrap:
With detect magic: • Clockwork Amulet – Steady your strikes with mechanical precision • Pole of Collapsing – Compact climbing or whacking tool; fun-sized for sneaky jobs
Without magic:
Each item takes 1 hour of sifting and investigation to uncover. Use DC 15 Investigation checks to speed up the process
These are rewards Fibblestib and Dabbledob are happy to part with—assuming the players have helped them or shown usefulness
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: A scrapyard of parts and glittering junk under low flickering light • Sound: Constant soft ticking, the whir of one gear that won’t stop spinning • Smell: Dust, brass polish, scorched paper • Touch: Metal is cold or uncomfortably warm; everything feels slightly greasy • Taste: The air has a dry, coin-like tang
Optional Surprise • A broken-looking clockwork spider reactivates for 6 seconds, scuttling in circles before exploding with confetti • On the wall is a faded gnome diagram: a plan for something called a “Gelatinous Cube Repeller” with a note: “does not work.

note.name: T14. Throne Room
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
Twin thrones sit atop a low stone dais at the far end of the chamber. They’re built not from gold or stone, but from welded pipe, shattered gearwork, and scavenged metal plates—all bolted into squat, oddly angled seats built for gnomes.
One throne’s seat is crooked. The other is scorched. Neither is occupied.
A strange silence hangs in the room. Dust has begun to settle—thickly. This place hasn’t seen its kings in days.
Gnomish Quip (from a cautious gnome entering behind the party):
“Kings used to argue here. Loud. Funny. Now… no laughs. Just chairs. Empty chairs.” “Korboz don’t come no more. Not since he said the throne talked back.”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This chamber once hosted the kings of Tinkleguard: Korboz and Gnerkli, now both holed up in T15, refusing to leave.
At the center of the room: • A stone dais raised just two feet • Two thrones, each uniquely decorated: • Korboz’s is built from twisted scrap and copper pipes • Gnerkli’s is patchworked with felt, brass buttons, and a cracked music box lid as a headrest • Between them, a small metal table once used for tea, now overturned
Along the north wall is a secret door, known only to the kings, which leads to T15 (their private quarters). The party may detect this door with: • Passive Perception 15+ • DC 12 Investigation • Guidance from the kings (if they speak to them first)
No guards remain here—just dust, silence, and the lingering aura of stress.
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Twin thrones—dusty, crooked, scorched. A throne room without rulers • Sound: Just your breath and the low ticking of a nearby machine left on • Smell: Rust, cloth mold, and tea long dried into the stone • Touch: Throne arms feel slightly warm… as if recently vacated • Taste: Air heavy with tension and unspoken arguments
Optional Details • Scratched into the floor beneath Korboz’s throne: “The chair wasn’t the mimic… but it lied anyway.” • One of the armrests has been ripped open, exposing hollow space inside—just large enough to hide something dangerous (or scared

note.name: T15. Gnome Kings Bedroom
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (for players):
The door is locked, but you hear movement inside—soft scraping, followed by frantic whispering. As you knock or call out, a voice croaks through the wood:
“It’s still out there. I saw it. It wore a face—it wore MY face.”
The door shakes slightly, as if someone is pressed up against it. Another, quieter voice adds from within:
“We’re fine. We’re safe. Please don’t make him unlock the door. He glued me to the chair again.”
Gnomish Quips (from behind the door):
Korboz: “You’re not real. You’re not you. Where’s your tongue?! SHOW ME YOUR TONGUE!” Gnerkli: “It’s Tuesday. We’re supposed to have stew. This is not stew.” Korboz: “Stew is dead! The stew was a mimic!”
Room Overview (Enhanced Source Content):
This is the private chamber of King Korboz and King Gnerkli, who have barricaded themselves inside. The main door is locked, and only the kings have keys. However: • There is a secret passage from T14, which the kings forgot about • The players can enter via that passage or: • Convince Korboz to unlock the door (DC 12 Charisma [Persuasion]) • Use magic or force (but risk escalating Korboz’s paranoia)
Inside the Room: • Korboz paces in circles, twitching, clutching a flask of glue solvent • Gnerkli sits, glued to a chair, calm but slightly dazed • The room is well-appointed: thick blankets, tiny wardrobes, strange paintings of mushrooms with royal faces
Korboz won’t calm down until: • He is convinced the shapechanger is dead (whether or not the mimic was actually killed) • This requires a DC 12 Charisma (Persuasion) check and/or good roleplay • If the players lie about killing the mimic, a DC 14 Deception check works as well
NPCs
King Korboz (paranoid ruler) • Visual Trait: Jagged metal crown welded from fork tines and a soup ladle • Personality: Frenzied, frightened, occasionally brilliant • Need: Safety. Absolute, unquestionable proof the mimic is gone • Quip: “It took their shape. Then their seat. Now it waits for ME.”
King Gnerkli (glued king) • Visual Trait: Patchwork cloak stitched with sock yarn and gnome scout badges • Personality: Chill. Resolute. Slightly wine-numbed • Need: To calm Korboz and get out of this glue • Quip: “I could solve all this if I could just… stand up. Maybe tomorrow.”
Treasure (under the bed): • A small chest, unlocked, containing: • Hat of Wizardry • Wand of Pyrotechnics (fully charged)
These can be discovered: • By searching the room (obvious if they look under the bed) • Or given as a reward from the kings if peace is restored
Sensory Snapshot • Sight: Cozy mess—blankets tangled, scrolls scattered, glue on everything • Sound: Muffled muttering, pacing footsteps, the occasional wet “squelch” from Gnerkli’s chair • Smell: Mushroom stew long gone cold, solvent fumes, fear • Touch: Warm stone floor, sticky patches from failed glue traps • Taste: Bitter tension, sharp glue in the air
Closing Notes / Resolution:
Once Korboz is convinced: • He’ll calm down and restore some order to Tinkleguard • The kings may offer rewards, vital information, or future aid • The gnomes slowly reemerge from their hiding places
And just like that, the enclave breathes again

note.name: Wrapping Up
note.text:
Gnomengarde is a roleplay-rich dungeon crawl with mystery, whimsy, and a touch of horror. It’s an ideal low-level adventure that rewards players who investigate, show empathy, and solve problems creatively.
To wrap up the adventure, the characters should: • Identify and deal with the mimic terrorizing the gnomes. • Convince or restore King Korboz’s sanity, either with proof or persuasion. • Earn the trust of Fibblestib and Dabbledob to receive magical rewards. • Optionally retrieve a magic item for Townmaster Harbin Wester to complete the Gnomengarde quest.
Depending on the outcome, the gnomes of Gnomengarde might become valuable allies in the region—or remain reclusive and mistrustful of outsiders.
Read-Aloud Conclusion (for Players)
The last echoes of danger fade into the mist, the roar of the waterfall now gentle instead of ominous. Gnomes peek out from tunnels and alcoves, hope glimmering behind spectacles and soot-smudged faces. King Korboz—once gripped by madness—clutches Gnerkli’s hand with trembling fingers, clarity returning to his wide, tearful eyes.
Fibblestib and Dabbledob scurry toward you, their arms loaded with strange devices, blinking lights, and sputtering contraptions. “Thank you,” they say in unison, “for bringing balance back to our home.”
In the distance, mushroom lanterns flicker like stars in the fog. Gnomengarde is safe—for now.
Quest Completion Criteria
Objective Outcome Mimic is found and destroyed (or forced to leave) Restores peace; grants Korboz clarity. King Korboz is calmed or convinced of safety Rewards unlocked; gnome kings are grateful. Fibblestib and Dabbledob are consulted Enables access to magical rewards. A magic item is returned to Harbin Wester Townmaster pays 50 gp for a Hat of Wizardry.
Player Rewards
If the party completes the main objectives: • Clockwork Amulet (G13) • Pole of Collapsing (G13) • Wand of Pyrotechnics (G15, from King Gnerkli) • Hat of Wizardry (G15, from King Korboz) • Spellbook (G11 – “Magick of Gnomengarde,” if kept) • 50 gp (Optional reward from Harbin Wester)
If the players didn’t obtain all items but saved the kings or dealt with the mimic, allow the gnomes to gift or offer trade for one remaining item based on roleplay.
