Ongoing Connections & Threads • The mimic may have whispered clues before dying—or fled, potentially returning later. • The gnomes may offer future magical support, minor inventions, or information. • Gnomengarde’s Wild Magic could spark lingering effects, especially if the PCs cast spells while inside. • The gnome kings may become quirky recurring allies, especially in regional matters or when Talos-related threats arise

npc.label: Dazlyn Grayshard
npc.name: Dwarven Worker
npc.text:
Gold Dwarf Prospector — Honest, anxious, practical
Visual Trait • Bushy red eyebrows that twitch when he’s agitated • Wears a soot-smudged leather vest and carries a pickaxe with a cracked haft
Personality • Forthright and honest to a fault • Nervous around danger but committed to his work • More scholarly than Norbus—he actually wants to catalog ruins, not just loot them
Motivations & Needs • Wants to excavate safely, without being turned into jelly • Seeks recognition for discovering a dwarven site tied to ancient faith • Fears that staying too long will result in divine punishment from Abbathor
Voice/Quip Examples
“I told Norbus it was cursed. You see bones melt like butter and still go back?” “We could map it, write it down, let some priests look at it—then dig.”
Norbus Ironrune
Shield Dwarf Prospector — Gruff, proud, impatient
Visual Trait • Long gray mustache braided with copper wire • Constantly polishes one of his beard rings when annoyed
Personality • Blunt, defensive, and dismissive of caution • Resents anything that slows down the dig • Has zero patience for superstition or monsters he can’t hit with a hammer
Motivations & Needs • Obsessed with finding something valuable—gold, artifacts, gems • Wants to prove he was right to keep digging • Sees Dazlyn as too cautious, but respects him deep down
Voice/Quip Examples
“We didn’t haul rock for three moons just to walk away empty.” “If it bleeds—or oozes—I’ll break it.”

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Infernal Machine Rebuild p. 15

trait.name: Dark Devotion
trait.text: The worker has advantage on saving throws against being charmed or frightened.

action.name: Scimitar
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. 4 (1d6 + 1) slashing damage.

npc.label: Norbus Ironrune
npc.name: Dwarven Worker
npc.text:
Shield Dwarf Prospector — Gruff, Proud, Impatient
Visual Trait • Braided gray mustache threaded with rune-etched copper rings • Wears a cracked miner’s helmet he refuses to replace (“It’s seen things, just like me.”) • Carries a heavy iron hammer slung across his back, head worn from overuse
Personality • Blunt, skeptical, and stubborn—he trusts in stone, not stories • Hates delays and “nonsense magic”—especially anything religious • Believes most problems can be solved with force or grit • Looks down on scholars but quietly respects people who prove themselves
Motivations & Needs • Wants treasure, plain and simple—gold, gems, lost dwarven artifacts • Determined to reclaim dwarven ruins for personal gain and pride • Refuses to abandon the excavation unless it means total collapse or death • Secretly feels inferior to smarter dwarves like Dazlyn, and compensates by being louder and angrier
Voice/Quip Examples
“We didn’t tunnel halfway into a mountain to run from a puddle.” “You can keep the history. I’ll take the valuables.” “If the gods had wanted us to pray, they wouldn’t’ve given us pickaxes.”
In Roleplay • Often contradicts Dazlyn even when he agrees with him • If the players act cautiously, he mocks them; if they’re bold, he grumbles admiration • Will never back down from a fight unless someone drags him away
Sample Scene (post-jelly): “Well. That’s handled. So—altar’s still there, right? That means there’s something worth dying over. Come on, we’ll split it. Seventy-thirty.

monster.conditionImmune: blinded, charmed, deafened, exhaustion, frightened, prone

trait.name: Source

trait.name: Amorphous
trait.text: The jelly can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Spider Climb
trait.text: The jelly can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Pseudopod
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (2d6+2) bludgeoning damage plus 3 (1d6) acid damage.

reaction.name: Split
reaction.text: When a jelly that is Medium or larger is subjected to lightning or slashing damage, it splits into two new jellies if it has at least 10 hit points. Each new jelly has hit points equal to half the original jelly's, rounded down. New jellies are one size smaller than the original jelly.

An opaque mottled deep blue gemstone worth 10 gp.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide, page 134

item.name: 10 GP - Banded Agate
item.text:
A translucent striped brown, blue, white, or red gemstone worth 10 gp.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide, page 134

item.text:
An opaque black gemstone worth 10 gp.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide, page 134

item.text:
A transparent pale blue gemstone worth 10 gp.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide, page 134

An opaque light blue-green gemstone worth 10 gp.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide, page 134

item.name: Holy Symbol Of Abbathor
item.text:
Holy Symbol of Abbathor: • A tiny jeweled dagger on a silver chain • Decorated with Dwarvish runes: “Greed is good” • Value: 50 gp • Could be of interest to collectors, dwarves, or cultist
A cleric or paladin can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus, using it in place of any material components which do not list a cost. To use the symbol in this way, the caster must hold it in hand, wear it visibly, or bear it on a shield.
Source: Player's Handbook, page 151

item.name: Studded Leather Armor
item.text:
2 sets of leather armor, red-dyed and decorated with Abbathor iconography • Fully usable, but may raise eyebrows in certain company • Value: ~25 gp each, or as standard armo
Made from tough but flexible leather, studded leather is reinforced with close-set rivets or spikes.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 144

item.name: Sending Stones
item.text:
Sending stones come in pairs, with each smooth stone carved to match the other so the pairing is easily recognized. While you touch one stone, you can use an action to cast the sending spell from it. The target is the bearer of the other stone. If no creature bears the other stone, you know that fact as soon as you use the stone and don't cast the spell. Once sending is cast through the stones, they can't be used again until the next dawn. If one of the stones in a pair is destroyed, the other one becomes nonmagical.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 199

item.name: Spell Scroll (Detect Magic)
item.text: A spell scroll bears the words of a single spell, written in a mystical cipher. If the spell is on your class’s spell list, you can use an action to read the scroll and cast its spell without having to provide any of the spell’s components. Otherwise, the scroll is unintelligible. If the spell is on your class’s spell list but of a higher level than you can normally cast, you must make an ability check using your spellcasting ability to determine whether you cast it successfully. The DC equals 10 + the spell’s level. On a failed check, the spell disappears from the scroll with no other effect. Once the spell is cast, the words on the scroll fade, and the scroll itself crumbles to dust. The level of the spell on the scroll determines the spell’s saving throw DC and attack bonus, as well as the scroll’s rarity, as shown in the Spell Scroll table. A wizard spell on a spell scroll can be copied just as spells in spellbooks can be copied. When a spell is copied from a spell scroll, the copier must succeed on an Intelligence (Arcana) check with a DC equal to 10 + the spell’s level. If the check succeeds, the spell is successfully copied. Whether the check succeeds or fails, the spell scroll is destroyed.

note.name: Overview
note.text:
What’s Going On?
Two dwarven brothers—Dazlyn Grayshard and Norbus Ironrune—are excavating the ruins of a fallen dwarven temple dedicated to Abbathor, the dwarven god of greed. They’re hoping to reclaim it for scholarly purposes, but they’ve run into trouble: • Traps, collapsing ruins, and undead • A cursed altar to Abbathor causing spiritual unrest • The dwarves are at odds about how to proceed
Key Themes • Ancient dwarven ruin • Greed and divine corruption • Undead guardians • Two bickering dwarves in over their heads
Location Summary • Located in the foothills of the Sword Mountains • Formerly a temple to Abbathor, desecrated and left in ruin • Contains collapsed hallways, dust-choked chambers, and skeletal undead • Features a cursed altar that emits a subtle aura of malevolence
Major NPCs
Dazlyn Grayshard • Race: Gold Dwarf • Visual Trait: Bushy red eyebrows that twitch when annoyed • Personality: Cautious, reasonable, wants to leave • Quip: “I told Norbus it was cursed. You don’t get that many skeletons by accident.”
Norbus Ironrune • Race: Shield Dwarf • Visual Trait: Long gray mustache tied into beard rings • Personality: Stubborn, proud, wants to finish the job • Quip: “It’s just bones and bad luck! There’s still gold down here—I can smell it.”
Encounters • Undead skeletons guarding the ruins (likely from cursed temple magic) • Environmental hazards: cave-ins, crumbling architecture • Optional trap or cursed item near the altar of Abbathor • Possible divine encounter or omen from a dwarven deity, if a cleric or dwarf is present
Resolution Options • Help the dwarves clear the ruins and stabilize the site • Convince them to seal the place and leave • Destroy or sanctify the altar to lift the curse (holy water or dispel magic) • Report findings back to Harbin Wester for full reward

note.name: E1. Canyon
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
Weatherworn stone stairs lead up to a rough escarpment, where the shattered facade of an ancient dwarven temple is half-buried in rubble. Thick vines and dry grass grow between the cracks in the flagstones, and a pair of mossy statues—each depicting a grim-faced dwarf—stand lopsided beside the threshold.
Chunks of carved stone litter the steps, and the wind howls mournfully through the cracked archway. A few deep boot prints in the dust suggest someone has passed through recently… or is still inside.
At a Glance (Sensory Snapshot) • Sight: Collapsed stonework, broken statues, symbols partially eroded by time • Sound: Wind whistling through the arch, distant birdcalls, an occasional ominous creak from within • Smell: Dust, dried moss, old ash • Touch: The stone is cool and brittle, crumbling slightly under pressure • Taste: Dry grit on the wind—like licking stone and iron
DM Notes • The temple was once dedicated to Abbathor, the dwarven god of greed. His iconography (twisted coins, snarling dwarves, clutching hands) is visible here, but cracked or defaced. • Dazlyn and Norbus may be heard deeper inside arguing (if the party listens carefully): “It’s cursed, Norbus!” — “Then curse the gold too, but I’m not leaving empty-handed!” • The entrance is unstable. If a PC succeeds on a DC 12 Wisdom (Perception) check, they notice cracks in the arch above. Disturbing the entrance (loud noises, heavy blows) may trigger a small collapse trap: • Trap Effect: All creatures within 10 feet make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take 2d6 bludgeoning damage from falling debris.
Optional Encounter (if needed)
To increase tension or delay their entry: • A skeleton scout wanders near the entrance, eyes glowing faintly with divine malice • A divine omen may be offered to dwarf characters or clerics—perhaps a feeling of being watched, or a sudden chill as they step inside

note.name: E2. Ruined Settlement
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
Beyond the broken gate, the path widens into the remains of a long-buried settlement. Rubble piles mark the outlines of stone buildings, most of them collapsed into shapeless heaps. Jagged walls stand like broken teeth under the shadow of the mountains. At the far end, a stone well sits choked with debris. The whole place is eerily quiet, the silence broken only by the occasional moan of wind through the canyon.
Ash marks and crushed bones are scattered among the stones—long dead, and recently disturbed.
At a Glance (Sensory Snapshot) • Sight: Sunlight gleaming off broken walls, deep shadows between collapsed buildings, outlines of ancient dwarven structures • Sound: Whispers of wind, distant rockfall, shifting gravel underfoot • Smell: Dry dust, old ash, faint iron tang of bone and rusted metal • Touch: Crumbling masonry, brittle bones, stones warm from sun but sharp-edged • Taste: Dust on the air, gritty and stale
Room Function (DM Notes)
This was once a dwarven mining outpost or temple village, now collapsed due to a divine-induced avalanche. It served as the living quarters and working area for priests and acolytes before the temple (E3+) behind it. • The settlement has been fully ransacked. Nothing of value remains here. • The well is clogged with stone and unfit for use. • Dazlyn and Norbus have already cleared most of the rubble to reach the temple but keep campfires here during the evening (signs of recent activity).
Exploration Notes
Characters searching the ruins may find: • Crushed dwarf bones beneath collapsed walls (no loot, but may indicate divine wrath to a cleric) • Signs of recent campfires and bootprints (Dazlyn and Norbus’s) • Faint symbols of Abbathor carved into ruined stone—closed hands, snarling dwarven faces, coin pouches with fangs • One wall contains a half-buried, cracked relief of Abbathor hoarding gemstones under a mountain. It’s been chipped and defaced.
If the party searches thoroughly (10+ minutes), they find a carved Dwarvish phrase in crumbling script: “In his greed, the god cast down the faithful.” Insight or Religion check (DC 13) reveals this may hint at divine punishment for unworthy sacrifices.
• A low tremor might hint at deeper instability in the site—or supernatural unrest • A character who sleeps here without protection may receive a dream (or nightmare) from Abbathor, demanding tribute

note.name: E3. Courtyard And Temple Facade
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
A ten-foot-high stone wall, partially collapsed, separates the ruined settlement from a wide courtyard beyond. Three large piles of rubble mark where the dwarves have excavated. Hewn directly into the canyon’s back wall looms a thirty-foot-high stone facade—weathered and cracked.
A wide stair rises to a broad stone platform before an open, ten-foot-high doorway. Life-sized granite statues of cloaked dwarves flank the entrance, their faces twisted into devilish grins now softened by age and erosion.
From behind one of the rubble piles, you hear the sound of crinkling rations… and low, muttering voices in thick Dwarvish.
Norbus (gruff, defensive): “I told you, Dazlyn, it ain’t cursed—it’s just jelly! Sticky, angry jelly. That’s all!”
Dazlyn (frustrated, worried): “It dropped from the ceiling, Norbus. It melted through a ten-pound pickaxe like butter on a forgeplate!”
Norbus: “Aye, and what did you do? Ran squealin’ like a kobold on fire! This temple’s full o’ secrets—we found it, and I’m not givin’ it up.”
Dazlyn: “Abbathor crushed this place for greed, Norbus! You think he’s not watchin’? You wanna end up a puddle of bones and beard hair?”
Norbus (grumbles): *“You just want to run back to Phandalin and sell rocks to Harbin Wester. Well, I want to dig. And if the jelly eats me—at least I’ll be rich digesta!”
Dazlyn (under his breath): “More like lunch for a slime god…
At a Glance (Sensory Snapshot) • Sight: Broad stair, towering entrance, two eerie dwarf statues with chipped faces and sinister grins • Sound: Wind pushing through the canyon, faint clatter of tools, grumbling dwarves behind rubble • Smell: Dry stone, old soot, faint trace of iron (blood or rust) • Touch: The facade is rough, cold, and cracked; the rubble is unstable but walkable • Taste: Bitter dust in the air, like old ash and crushed coins
NPCs: Dazlyn & Norbus
When the party calls out or walks closer, the dwarves emerge from behind a rubble mound, munching on dried mushrooms and rothé jerky.
Dazlyn Grayshard • Race: Gold Dwarf • Visual Trait: Bushy red eyebrows so thick they cast their own shadows • Personality: Forthright, honest, a little anxious • Quip: “Ah, strangers! You here to help, or here to loot? Either way—mind the jelly.” • Need: Wants the temple cleared, feels it’s cursed. Will leave if pushed.
Norbus Ironrune • Race: Shield Dwarf • Visual Trait: Braided gray mustache with rune-carved beard rings • Personality: Gruff, proud, paranoid about losing their claim • Quip: “We found it, we clear it. Unless you want to help… and share.” • Need: Desperately wants to reclaim the temple and prove it profitable.
They argue constantly but trust each other. They’ve explored just far enough to disturb the ochre jellies inside the temple, and now refuse to go further.
What the Dwarves Offer • They have a pair of sending stones (magic items) • If warned about the dragon, they thank the party and offer: “Clear out the temple for us. Kill the jellies. We’ll give you the stones—and a share of anything valuable we find.” • If the party helps, they’ll split all future finds and even offer their trust as allies in Phandalin or beyond
These stones become a handy tool for split-party play or long-distance communication—especially useful if you plan to link into Tyranny of Dragons later.
Temple Entrance (DM Notes) • The statues flanking the entrance depict cloaked dwarves with greedy grins—likely representations of Abbathor, dwarven god of greed • Anyone proficient in Religion (DC 12) recognizes this temple’s religious iconography as morally suspect • A DC 13 Investigation reveals bloodstains near the steps—drag marks from something (or someone) being pulled inside…
Optional Embellishments • Dazlyn confides: “I swear I heard whispering in there. Like… promises. Gold in the walls. Jewels in the eyes. I think it’s the stone talking.” • Norbus mutters: “If the jelly doesn’t eat ya, the temple will. But I’ll be damned if I walk away without seeing the altar.

note.name: E4. Dusty Foyer
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
The temple’s interior is a tunnel of gloom. You step into a chamber choked with dust and scattered rubble. The faint scent of old incense clings to the air—sweet and acrid, like burnt copper and rotting parchment.
Two sets of heavy stone double doors stand open, each pinned to the floor with iron spikes. Crumbled alcoves mark where statuary or relics may have once stood, now empty.
To the north, what must have been a secret door yawns open, revealing a narrow chamber filled wall-to-wall with collapsed stone.
At a Glance (Sensory Snapshot) • Sight: Dust motes hang in slanted light; jagged rubble piles choke the corners; the shadows seem heavier than they should be • Sound: Stillness broken only by your footsteps and distant echoes deeper in the temple • Smell: Stale air, mildew, and a faint metallic tang of blood or rust • Touch: The stone underfoot is smooth but coated in grime; the air is cool and heavy • Taste: Dry grit hangs in the air—almost bitter
DM Notes
This foyer once served as a ritual preparation chamber or vestibule for dwarves entering the temple proper. • The double doors to the east lead into E5: Temple Proper • The northern wall holds a secret passage, discovered by Dazlyn and Norbus, now open to reveal a collapsed tunnel • Iron spikes hold the temple doors open—they were hammered in by the dwarves to prevent being sealed inside again
Exploration Features • Spiked Doors: Can be closed with effort. Removing the spikes takes 1 minute with tools or a DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check • Collapsed Room (North): This was once a hidden chamber—now impassable. Nothing of value remains inside, but it hints at more hidden architecture • A DC 13 Religion check reveals the faint carvings along the eastern doorframes to be prayers to Abbathor: “Greed is glory. Want without shame. Take what is owed, and more besides.”
Optional Details for Immersion • A chilled draft flows unnaturally from under the temple doors, though there’s no open air source • Characters with divine magic may feel a prickling sense of unease, as if something is watching
Optional Flavor Event: As the party crosses the foyer, a tiny tremor shakes the dust from the ceiling, causing it to rain down like a slow hourglass. The quake is brief—but the altar room beyond (E5) awaits.
Hook for Tension
If the players pause here, you might whisper something more subtle:
You feel as though the room is remembering you. Not watching—just waiting.

note.name: E5. Temple
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
The heavy stone doors open into a grand, rectangular chamber hewn entirely from dark, veined stone. Massive pillars line the hall, rising to a ten-foot-high ceiling shrouded in shadow. Dust carpets the floor in thick waves, undisturbed except for the occasional trail… or stain.
At the far end stands a broad limestone altar, streaked with old, dried blood. A faint shimmer glistens on its surface, like oil in water. Behind it, a jagged fissure in the wall reveals a dark cavity.
The room is deathly silent—until a pebble from the ceiling clatters on the floor.
At a Glance (Sensory Snapshot) • Sight: Tall pillars, altar stained and cracked, strange glistening sheen in places, and unnatural darkness in corners • Sound: Occasional plip… plip… of unseen liquid; faint squelch of shifting ooze; your own breath, loud in the stillness • Smell: Stale blood, moldy stone, acidic tang like rust and vinegar • Touch: Air is clammy and tense, like entering a crypt • Taste: Metallic, like biting your tongue in a silent church
What’s Really Here
Two ochre jellies, remnants of Abbathor’s divine wrath. The priests once sacrificed blood and gemstones here; when Abbathor was displeased, he collapsed the temple and twisted the priests into oozing abominations. • One jelly clings to the ceiling above the altar, waiting to drop • A second jelly (if the party includes 2+ characters) clings to the southern wall, nearly invisible among the shadowed stone
Jellies attack only when the party nears the altar or disturbs the room.
Combat Encounter: Ochre Jellies (1–2) • Stats: Use Ochre Jelly stat block (Monster Manual or Basic Rules) • Tactics: • They ambush—one drops from above, the other slithers forward silently • They split if hit with slashing or lightning damage (DM discretion) • If overwhelmed, they try to retreat into wall cracks
Environmental Use: • A collapsing pillar or altar trap could be triggered if the party slams into the architecture during combat • Pillars provide half cover or obstacles during battle
Secrets & Treasure
Hidden Cavity – The Secret Door • One of the center stone pillars contains a secret door (DC 15 Wisdom [Perception] to find) • Inside: a narrow cavity packed with ancient dwarf skulls, symbols of failed greed • At the bottom is a stone coffer, unlocked, containing: • 15 gemstones, each worth 10 gp • The coffer is carved with the phrase (in Dwarvish): “We took, and were taken.”
Religious and Narrative Flavor
The Altar • Old bloodstains and dusted-over gemstone fragments mark this as a sacrificial site • Divine casters who examine the altar with a DC 13 Religion check identify: • The altar was used to sacrifice both treasure and blood to Abbathor • Failing to meet his expectations provoked his wrath
Foreshadowing • Players may start to understand the deeper themes of greed, divine punishment, and transformation • A dwarf or cleric may feel a divine unease here—Abbathor’s presence is lingering
If the Party Wins… • The dwarves (Dazlyn and Norbus) will be thrilled if told the jellies are dead • They offer the Sending Stones as promised • They suggest returning to search the rest of the temple, now safer (which opens up E6–E11)
Optional Details • As the last jelly dies, a low groan rumbles through the temple. Is it just settling stone… or something deeper? • If players disturb the bones in the secret cache, they may experience a brief flash of shared memory—an image of dwarves clawing at the stone as the avalanche buried them alive

note.name: E6. Partially Collapsed Room
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
This chamber is filled with rubble and broken stone, the result of a ceiling collapse that sheared through the room at a brutal angle. Piles of debris nearly reach the ceiling, and shattered remains of stone furnishings jut out like broken ribs.
One side of the room appears untouched—three smooth stone walls and part of the ceiling remain intact—but it’s eerily silent, like sound dies in the dust here.
At a Glance (Sensory Snapshot) • Sight: Heavy collapse piles, faint carvings half-buried, dead air • Sound: Muffled footsteps, falling dust, occasional deep creaks in the stone • Smell: Chalky rubble, ancient ash, and a whisper of long-dead incense • Touch: Dry stone powder clings to hands and armor; the rubble is sharp-edged • Taste: Metallic, stale, and choking if stirred
Room Function (DM Notes)
This room was likely once an office, scriptorium, or ritual prep area—but now it’s mostly destroyed. One wall may bear the faint outlines of a mosaic or engraved relief now too eroded to decipher.
There is nothing of value here, but the scene can serve to: • Convey a sense of the temple’s violent destruction • Evoke Abbathor’s punishment for failed greed • Create quiet, grim pacing between more dangerous or magical chambers
Characters that examine the collapse with a DC 12 Investigation check notice that the falling stone crushed someone or something, though any remains have long since turned to dust. A DC 15 Religion or History check reveals that Abbathor has a history of punishing temples whose offerings are insufficient.
Optional Embellishments (Flavor or Hooks) • Clerics or dwarves may feel spiritually chilled in this room, as if something was judged and erased • A lingering trace of divine magic (faint necrotic aura) may be sensed with detect magic, tied to the lingering divine wrath of Abbathor • If you’re using dreams or divine omens, this room might trigger a short flashback or echoing voice that says something like: “The vault was sealed. The greedy consumed. Let it lie.

note.name: E7. Secret Tunnel
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
Behind a carefully disguised stone seam lies a cramped tunnel, choked with dust and half-filled with collapsed rubble. The ceiling presses close—barely six feet high—and the floor slopes subtly downward.
The air is thick and still, and faint puddles of sticky liquid mark the stones ahead. Something wet shifts in the shadows.
Then you hear it—a faint slurp, like syrup being dragged across stone.
At a Glance (Sensory Snapshot) • Sight: Narrow walls, damp streaks of glistening ooze, cramped shadows • Sound: Muffled squelching, party members’ breathing, distant trickles • Smell: Rotting mold, acidic slime, stagnant air • Touch: Slimy residue along the floor and walls; the air clings to skin • Taste: Acrid, sour air—like copper and vinegar
DM Notes
This tunnel was once a priest’s passage—used to access areas of the temple discreetly—but has since collapsed and become a nesting ground for another ochre jelly, twisted remnant of Abbathor’s cursed priests.
The secret door can be discovered from either end: • From the temple (E5), it may be found with a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) or DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check if players inspect the eastern wall • From the collapsed side (E6 or E10), it cannot be opened unless the players return via E5 or E9
Encounter: Ochre Jelly (1) • The jelly lurks in the rubble at the south end of the tunnel, lying flat and still • It attacks only when a PC is alone, wounded, or distracted • Its attack may be ambush-style, with advantage on its first strike from stealth (DC 13 to notice in time)
Tactics: • The jelly attempts to corner a PC in the tight space • Fire and slashing damage risk splitting it • Retreat is difficult—tunnel is only 5 feet wide, allowing single-file movement (use this to build claustrophobic tension)
Environmental Features • Difficult terrain: The entire tunnel is filled with uneven rubble, broken bricks, and slime • A successful DC 12 Survival check identifies that the jelly has been feeding—perhaps on old bones, perhaps something else…
Optional Detail – Temple Whisper
To add more mystique:
When a divine character (cleric, paladin, dwarf) steps into the tunnel, they briefly hear a whisper in their native tongue: “Crawling greed still waits. You will join it, or leave it starved.”
Loot • No treasure here—just danger • However, if the jelly is destroyed and the party searches its lair, they may find: • A dwarven signet ring (worth 25 gp) belonging to a long-dead priest • A scrap of red leather with gold stitching, once a priest’s vestment (worthless, but may identify former temple roles

note.name: E8. Priests Bedchamber
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
This chamber opens into a quiet hall lined with the remnants of sleeping quarters. Three stone bedframes, sturdy but cracked, stand against the eastern wall. Whatever once cushioned them has long since rotted away.
Faint carvings adorn the walls above each bed—dwarven runes almost too worn to read. The air feels thick, still, and reverent… or resentful. Something watches here, but nothing moves.
At a Glance (Sensory Snapshot) • Sight: Empty stone bedframes, wall carvings, layers of fine dust, scattered stone shards • Sound: Distant echoes, the party’s own footsteps, unsettling quiet • Smell: Dry air, faint ash, and mold lingering in the cracks • Touch: Cold stone surfaces, brittle fragments of carved bedding, dry grit • Taste: The air is dry as parchment—tasteless but dry enough to rasp the throat
DM Notes
This was the private sleeping chamber for the temple’s priesthood. While unguarded and untrapped, it resonates with religious memory and quiet sorrow. The dwarves who once lived here were transformed into ochre jellies as punishment from Abbathor. • No threats reside here—only dust and echoes. • A DC 12 Religion check reveals the runes are prayers to Abbathor, each personalized for a different priest: • “Let gold guide my hands.” • “Take what shines, and leave the rest.” • “I give you greed, that I may receive power.”
These can hint at the twisted religious values of the temple, and how far its clergy had fallen into corruption.
Search Results (if players examine the room) • Nothing of monetary value remains, but the following can be found: • A small obsidian token (nonmagical) with a clenched hand etched into it—symbol of Abbathor • A scrap of red leather cloth, once ceremonial, now too dry-rotted to salvage • Faint scrape marks near the beds—perhaps where a chest once sat, now long gone
Optional Details & Flavor Hooks • If a character spends time praying here or uses detect magic, they might sense a lingering necrotic residue in the stone—like a stain on the soul of the place • A dwarf or cleric might receive a dreamlike flash or whispered voice: “The faithful slept, but never woke. Their hunger outlived them.” • One bedframe bears a chiseled name: “Thradek Goldblood”—perhaps a priest now twisted into a jelly in E5 or E7
Mood and Purpose
This room reinforces: • The corrupted devotion of Abbathor’s followers • The quiet tragedy of a doomed temple • The sense that divine wrath lingers, even in forgotten place

note.name: E9. Vestry
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
This narrow stone chamber is hushed and still, the silence broken only by the soft scrape of your own footsteps. A shallow font protrudes from the southwest wall—cracked, long dry, and darkly stained. Its basin is carved with concentric coin shapes, now barely visible beneath grime.
Opposite the font, a tall stone wardrobe leans slightly forward, its heavy doors closed but crooked on rusted hinges. Mold creeps along its base where it meets the floor.
The air is thick, stagnant, and sour—as if whatever was once sacred here has long since curdled.
At a Glance (Sensory Snapshot) • Sight: Empty walls, dry font with dark stains, wardrobe standing like a forgotten tomb • Sound: Muffled, as though the room absorbs sound—only footsteps echo faintly • Smell: Moldy stone, old leather, and a faint tang of iron • Touch: The font is pitted and cold; the wardrobe’s surface is damp and slick • Taste: Dust and coppery air cling to the tongue like blood at the back of the throat
Room Function (DM Notes)
This was the priests’ dressing chamber, where ceremonial vestments were donned before conducting rituals. While the sanctity of the space has faded, a few functional remnants endure. • The wardrobe is closed. A character must open it manually, which causes the rusted hinges to groan (loud enough to alert nearby creatures, if any remain) • Inside are two sets of ceremonial red leather armor, still intact: • Embossed with Abbathor’s symbol: a clenched fist over a hoard of coins • Well-preserved due to magical or divine treatment • Can be worn as standard leather armor, though gaudy and dyed blood-red
Treasure • 2 sets of leather armor, beautifully crafted and functional (non-magical) • Each set could fetch 25 gp to the right collector or devout (or attract the wrong kind of attention)
Optional: If a player wears the armor and speaks Dwarvish or succeeds on a DC 12 Religion check, they feel a momentary pulse of dark approval—like being noticed.
Investigation Opportunities • The stone font is cracked and long dry. A DC 12 Religion check reveals it was used to anoint priests with liquid gold or sacrificial blood, depending on the ritual • Carvings in the font read (in Dwarvish): “Greed cleanses all. Enter adorned.” • A small silver coin, now blackened, is fused to the bottom of the basin—a final offering
Atmosphere and Purpose • This chamber adds depth to the cultural practices of Abbathor’s clergy • The armor offers useful loot, but can also carry narrative weight: • Does wearing it mark the party in some way? • Will others recognize the symbol? • Is it a sign of disrespect or curiosity?

note.name: E10. Partially Collapsed Room
note.text:
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
This chamber is half-swallowed by its own ceiling. A mound of fallen stone fills the southern side of the room, forcing you to step carefully across a jagged field of rubble. Slabs of masonry lean against the far wall like toppled gravestones.
Half-buried beneath the collapse lies a motionless skeleton, pinned beneath the rubble. Its rust-colored leather robes have faded and torn, revealing a glint of silver at its throat.
At a Glance (Sensory Snapshot) • Sight: Jagged collapse, broken bones tangled in red rags, glimmering silver in the dust • Sound: Faint scrape of shifting rubble underfoot, distant creaks of settling stone • Smell: Old leather, mildew, powdered stone • Touch: Rubble shifts under pressure—unstable in places; bones crumble at a touch • Taste: Grit and dry mold linger in the back of the throat
Room Function (DM Notes)
This room was a private study or ritual space—now crushed by the same divine earthquake that ruined the rest of the temple. The body belonged to one of Abbathor’s priests, crushed instantly. • The skeleton is inert, no threat here • Its robes match those from E9, indicating its priestly status • This is a good moment for somber tone, reflection, or a grim reminder of the consequences of greed
Treasure • Around the skeleton’s neck hangs a jeweled holy symbol of Abbathor: • A tiny dagger, hilt shaped like a grasping hand, set with small garnets • Hangs on a silver chain • Inlaid Dwarvish runes read: “Greed is good.” • Value: 50 gp to collectors, dwarves, or cultists of Abbathor • May radiate faint necrotic magic (non-functional, thematic only)
Optional Twist: If a divine caster holds the symbol, they hear a brief echo in Dwarvish: “Take. Keep. Grow.”—the mantra of Abbathor
Checks and Interactions • DC 12 Religion: Identifies this as a blessing token, worn by higher-ranking Abbathor clergy • DC 13 History: Reveals Abbathor’s followers sometimes fought over these symbols, believing them to physically channel divine favor • Search Check (DC 10): Finds a small, rusted dagger tucked under the skeleton’s robes (worthless, but ceremonial)
Optional Embellishments • The ceiling creaks ominously but remains stable—unless the party tries to excavate too aggressively • If the holy symbol is taken, a single coin drops from the ceiling, inexplicably—striking stone with a clear clink
Mood and Purpose • This room quietly reinforces the fatal price of ambition • The holy symbol gives a tangible tie to Abbathor’s influence • A reflective moment before the final, dramatic chamber (E11)

note.name: E11. Hall Of Greed
note.text:
To access this room, the rubble to the entry must be cleared. One character would take 40 hours.
Read-Aloud Box (for players):
After hours of clearing rubble—stone by stone—you finally break through into a sealed, untouched chamber. It’s a low, wide room, almost a vault, and the air inside is thick and cold like an unopened tomb.
Two alcoves are carved into opposite walls. One to the north holds a squat stone statue of a dwarf with short horns curling from his forehead, his face twisted in greedy joy. His thick stone fingers clutch a single, glowing green gem.
The southern alcove holds only rubble—whatever was there shattered beyond recognition. The room is utterly silent, as if even sound fears to echo here.
At a Glance (Sensory Snapshot) • Sight: Dull green light glinting off the statue’s gem, broken stone in southern alcove, dust swirling in slow spirals • Sound: Deafening stillness; heartbeat and breath seem too loud • Smell: Cold, dry air with a faint undertone of copper and old stone • Touch: The air is thick and oppressive—like pressure on your chest • Taste: Bitter, electric sharpness—like biting into a coin
Room Access (DM Notes) • This chamber is sealed behind rubble, requiring 40 hours of work by one character, or less if multiple PCs assist • The rubble was part of Abbathor’s divine punishment, sealing greed away with destruction
Key Features and Encounter
Northern Alcove – Statue and Gem Trap • The statue is of Abbathor in his corrupted form—his eyes bulging with avarice, his smile hungry • The glowing green gem appears magical, tempting… and valuable
The gem is an illusion. If any creature touches or tries to take the gem, it crumbles to fine green dust, and the statue explodes.
Trap – Exploding Statue • Trigger: Touching or disturbing the gem • Effect: Statue detonates in a blast of razor-sharp stone shards • All creatures within 10 feet must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw: • On a fail: 22 (4d10) piercing damage • On a success: Half damage • The explosion leaves only dust and rubble behind—no gem, no treasure
Optional Flavor: A single whisper echoes in the minds of those affected: “You took… and were taken.”
Southern Alcove – Shattered Statue • Once a twin to the northern statue, it was destroyed in the divine quake • The rubble is worthless, though a DC 13 Religion check suggests it may have once held a real offering—perhaps one that Abbathor rejected
Mood and Meaning • This is the final judgment of the temple—greed punished, not rewarded • It reinforces Abbathor’s domain: temptation, corruption, and divine disappointment • It offers a moment for players to reflect on what’s worth pursuing—not every treasure is real
Optional Rewards
To offer something tangible for smart play or to soften the trap’s blow: • If a character investigates the statue first (DC 13 Investigation), they might detect faint hairline fractures or a heat shimmer suggesting instability • A DC 15 Arcana or Religion check before touching it reveals the gem radiates false aura magic—an illusion masking something dangerous
Optional Treasure (for wise or cautious players)
Hidden in the base of the shattered southern statue (DC 15 Investigation), you may include: • A scroll of shield (or another minor spell) • A single platinum coin, melted to the stone (worth 10 gp, but hard to retrieve) • A hidden inscription: “Greed grants nothing but the grave.”
Conclusion and Exit • The players have now cleared the temple and faced its final test • If Dazlyn and Norbus were waiting outside, they greet the party with awe and gratitude, offering the Sending Stones and possibly more:
Norbus (gruff, impressed): “You went in. You came back. Whole, even. Well… mostly.”
Dazlyn (wide-eyed): “What’d you find? …No, never mind. I don’t want to know. Just—thank you.”

note.name: Kobold Encounter: Servants Of The Ice Tyrant
note.text:
When It Happens • After the party clears the temple and returns to Dazlyn and Norbus • Can occur as they rest, pack up, or begin descending the canyon • Ideal for characters around level 2–3
Setup: Kobold Advance Party
Just as the dwarves finish congratulating the party—and possibly offering the sending stones—a distant chittering sound echoes through the canyon. Small, hunched shapes slip from behind boulders, eyes gleaming yellow in the dusk.
“The ice-king comes,” one of them hisses, brandishing a spear tipped in jagged bone. “We mark his claim in stone and blood!”
Enemies (suggested stats) • 3–6 Kobolds (MM, CR 1/8) • 1 Kobold Dragonshield (Volo’s Guide to Monsters or use a reflavored Guard with pack tactics) • Optional: 1 Winged Kobold who flies above, dropping small rocks and shouting threats in Draconic
Tactics: • Kobolds stay in cover, use pack tactics, and try to overwhelm one target • The dragonshield fights honorably but panics if Cryovain is insulted • If half the kobolds fall, the rest flee into the wilds, shouting: “Cryovain will freeze you for this!”
Motivations and Clues
These kobolds serve Cryovain—not out of loyalty, but fear and awe. They believe he is a chosen avatar of Tiamat (even if he isn’t), and they’re sent ahead to scout and sabotage humanoid strongholds.
What the kobolds say: • “This land belongs to the sky-fang!” • “Cryovain will build his throne here!” • “You cannot stop the white tyrant! The Cold Queen gave him wings!”
Optional: One kobold carries a crude pendant—a five-headed dragon symbol (Tiamat), carved from bone and scorched with frost. It suggests cult influence is spreading.
Treasure / Clues • Tiamat token or a map fragment showing Cryovain’s “claimed territory” • A scorched banner or carved slate reading (in Draconic): “This canyon belongs to the Cold King.” • Optional: A battered piece of parchment with five claw marks, scrawled in multiple clawed hands: “Prepare the fireblood cave. He descends soon.”
Dazlyn & Norbus Reactions • Dazlyn is alarmed: “They’re organizing now? Kobolds with banners? That’s… bad.” • Norbus is furious: “We mine, we dig, we die—because of lizards? No more!”
They may offer the party first claim on any treasure from future digs, or offer to report this to Neverwinter.
Campaign Bridge Use • The party may now be aware that Cryovain has followers, not just random attacks • This encounter hints that the cult’s influence or propaganda is reaching even lowly creatures • Great moment to pivot into Dragon Barrow, Woodland Manse, or even Tyranny of Dragons with kobolds or cultists acting as messengers or scout

note.name: Wrapping Up
note.text:
The Dwarven Excavation is a grim, atmospheric site with a strong sense of dwarven history and a lingering divine curse. The ruins of the temple to Abbathor, the dwarven god of greed, whisper of betrayal and punishment, while the ochre jellies and structural instability keep things dangerous even for careful explorers.
This quest pivots from a simple dragon-warning errand into a dungeon delve full of traps, secrets, and character-driven reward opportunities.
Assuming the adventurers: • Warned Dazlyn and Norbus about Cryovain • Destroyed the ochre jellies and explored the temple • Survived the surprise kobold attack
…then they’ve earned the dwarves’ gratitude, magical treasure, and potentially a powerful regional alliance.
Read-Aloud Conclusion (for Players)
The canyon settles into uneasy silence as the last echoes of battle fade—kobold blood steaming on cracked stones, the scent of dust and old greed still thick in the air. Dazlyn wipes grime from his brow and exhales deeply.
“By the forge… you did it.”
Norbus, ever-cautious, scans the canyon walls one last time before stepping forward with a pair of polished stones. “Take these. You’ve done more than we could’ve asked. Abbathor’s hunger lingers, but… this place has a future now.”
Behind them, the shattered temple doors creak in the wind. Inside, the altar stands quiet at last.
Quest Completion Summary
Objective Outcome Warn Dazlyn and Norbus about Cryovain Quest complete. Dwarves offer gratitude and potential future alliance. Clear the temple of jellies and threats Party earns the sending stones and any treasure found inside. Survive kobold ambush Highlights Cryovain’s regional threat; optional clue-bearing bodies may hint at future plans. Search temple thoroughly Characters may recover 150 gp in gemstones (E5), a holy symbol worth 50 gp (E10), and avoid the exploding statue trap (E11).
Player Rewards
If the party clears the temple and completes the encounter: • Pair of Sending Stones (reward from Dazlyn and Norbus) • 15 × 10 gp gemstones (E5 hidden coffer) • Holy Symbol of Abbathor (E10, 50 gp) • XP or milestone level-up based on party progress • Optional: If you added Cryovain-sent kobolds, one could carry a chill-clawed token, insignia, or claw-scratched map fragment foreshadowing Cryovain’s lair or his territorial dominance.
Let me know if you’d like a [Game Master 5 XML] export of these rewards!
Dazlyn and Norbus’ Future Role
If the party earns their trust: • The dwarves become allies in Phandalin’s defense or trade networks. • They might share information on lost dwarven sites, ancient magic, or Cryovain sightings. • Dazlyn is upbeat and honest—he may over-share. • Norbus is grumpy, skeptical, but deeply loyal once his trust is earned.
NPC Quips: • Dazlyn: “You lot might not have beards, but you’ve got stones.” • Norbus: “Next time I see a jelly, I’m putting salt in my boots.”
Ongoing Threads • The statue trap in E11 might be magical in nature, a final curse of Abbathor, and worth revisiting later. • The kobolds could have carried a message crystal or insignia from Cryovain’s forces—hinting at his growing influence in the mountains. • The sending stones provide an ongoing link to the dwarves. Consider using them for a later call-for-aid, lore drop, or emotional scene

npc.label: Big Al Kalazorn
npc.name: Commoner
npc.text:
Big Al Kalazorn
Retired Sheriff of Triboar, Ranch Owner Race: Human | Gender: Male | Alignment: Lawful Good Class Equivalent: Veteran (MM p.350) – currently wounded and unarmed
Appearance: A broad-shouldered man with a weathered face, bushy white sideburns, and a jagged scar across one ear. He wears a dusty duster coat, and his silver sheriff’s badge is still pinned proudly to his chest—even in captivity.
Voice: Gruff but fatherly, with a slow cowboy drawl.
Quirk / Visual Trait: Always chews on a toothpick or piece of wheat straw. His boots still shine like he’s on patrol.
Quip:
“I didn’t survive bandits, rust monsters, and two ex-wives just to die in a cellar tied to a chair.”
HP: 9 (currently injured) AC: 11 (no armor), 16 in mithral chain mail Speed: 30 ft. Abilities: STR 16, DEX 13, CON 14, INT 10, WIS 11, CHA 10 Saving Throws: STR +5, CON +4 Skills: Intimidation +2, Survival +3 Attacks: • Longsword (if given): +5 to hit, 1d8+3 slashing • Heavy Crossbow (if found): +3 to hit, 1d10 piercing
Motivations: • Reclaim his ranch or die trying. • Keep Petunia the cow safe—“She’s family, plain and simple.” • Reward anyone who helps restore order or bring down the orcs.
Reward Offers: • Mithral chain mail (found in B6) • 65 gp + gratitude and a lifelong ally • Local rumors or past lawman intel (could be used in future quests)
If Petunia Is Found:
“That’s my girl! She’s worth more to me than all the gold in Triboar.
Upon rescue (groggy):
“Y’all took your sweet time. I was just startin’ to like the cellar décor.”
On seeing his ranch trashed:
“Well I’ll be hog-tied and frostbit… them orcs sure know how to wreck a homestead.”
About Petunia the cow:
“That cow’s smarter’n most mayors I’ve met, and better company than all of ’em.”
Offering thanks:
“I don’t got a medal or nothin’, but you got my word and what’s left of my good whiskey.”
If joining a fight:
“Lemme at those tusk-faced varmints—I ain’t done swingin’ just yet.”
Talking about his past:
“Used to be a lawman in Triboar. These days I settle for butter and peace… mostly butter.”
Regarding the mithral armor:
“Kept that for a rainy day. Well, looks like we’re in the damn monsoon.”
While limping with a weapon:
“I might be slower, but I hit like a horse with a grudge.”
If someone tries to flirt with him:
“Honey, I’m flattered, but I’m old enough to be your lore entry.”
After everything calms down:
“Ain’t nothin’ a hot bath, a cold drink, and a live cow can’t fix.

trait.text: Monster Manual p. 345, Lost Laboratory of Kwalish p. 38, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 55

action.name: Club
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +2 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 2 (1d4) bludgeoning damage.

monster.label: Orc 9
monster.name: Orc
monster.text: Behavior: They’re drunk on Big Al’s ale, scattered around the farmhouse (rooms B1–B9), and not expecting a fight. They’ll fight to the death once engaged
