item.name: Mithral Chain Shirt
item.text:
Mithral is a light, flexible metal. A mithral chain shirt or breastplate can be worn under normal clothes. If the armor normally imposes disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks or has a Strength requirement, the mithral version of the armor doesn't.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 182

item.name: Gold (gp)
item.text:
Common coins come in several different denominations based on the relative worth of the metal from which they are made. The three most common coins are the gold piece (gp), the silver piece (sp), and the copper piece (cp). With one gold piece, a character can buy a belt pouch, 50 feet of good rope, or a goat. A skilled (but not exceptional) artisan can earn one gold piece a day. The gold piece is the standard unit of measure for wealth, even if the coin itself is not commonly used. When merchants discuss deals that involve goods or services worth hundreds or thousands of gold pieces, the transactions don't usually involve the exchange of individual coins. Rather, the gold piece is a standard measure of value, and the actual exchange is in gold bars, letters of credit, or valuable goods. One gold piece is worth ten silver pieces, the most prevalent coin among commoners. A silver piece buys a laborer's work for a day, a flask of lamp oil, or a night's rest in a poor inn. One silver piece is worth ten copper pieces, which are common among laborers and beggars. A single copper piece buys a candle, a torch, or a piece of chalk. In addition, unusual coins made of other precious metals sometimes appear in treasure hoards. The electrum piece (ep) and the platinum piece (pp) originate from fallen empires and lost kingdoms, and they sometimes arouse suspicion and skepticism when used in transactions. An electrum piece is worth five silver pieces, and a platinum piece is worth ten gold pieces. A standard coin weighs about a third of an ounce, so fifty coins weigh a pound.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 143

note.name: Overview
note.text:
Read-Aloud: As you crest a low hill, the scent of scorched wood and wildflowers mingles on the breeze. Nestled in the shallow valley below, Butterskull Ranch sprawls across lush pastures and golden cornfields. A once-thriving estate now lies wounded—its barn and smithy reduced to blackened skeletons. Beyond them, a two-story log farmhouse sits quiet beside a murky pond, its windows open like tired eyes watching the road. Pigs meander through the ruined fields, unbothered. And between the house and the ruins, you see them—bodies strewn in the dirt, buzzing with flies, watched only by crows.
DM Info: • The attack happened about a tenday ago. • The orcs have no reason to expect adventurers and are overconfident. • Big Al is bound and bloodied in the cellar (B10), but alive. • Petunia the cow, Al’s prized dairy cow, is grazing somewhere in the countryside and may be recovered. • The players can negotiate with Big Al, discover his mithral armor, and earn gold in the office. • Party size will determine the number of orcs: 3 × number of characters (not counting sidekicks)

note.name: Petunia the Cow
note.text: Petunia is found in a field between Conyberry and the ranch. She wears a cowbell and has a 'BAK' brand. She’s calm and follows gentle characters anywhere. Big Al will offer his mithral armor as reward for returning her safely.

note.name: Horses in Conyberry
note.text:
Read Aloud:
The forest thins briefly, revealing the blackened bones of a ruined village. Charred beams and crumbled stone foundations jut like broken teeth from the soft earth. Wind whistles mournfully through the husks of homes, carrying the faint scent of old ash and moss. In the village square, near an old dry well, three unsaddled horses graze nervously amid the silence.
DM Info:
Conyberry was once a peaceful village nestled along the Triboar Trail, but it was abandoned decades ago after a series of monster raids—first by orcs, then undead from the nearby ruins of Agatha’s lair. The place is utterly lifeless now, save for the sounds of wind and insects. Nature has begun reclaiming the ruins, though the air here is strangely still, as if holding its breath.
Sensory Details: • Sight: Collapsed rooftops, singed stone walls, moss-covered cobblestones. • Sound: Whistling wind, buzzing flies, distant bird calls. • Smell: Damp wood, scorched earth, faint animal musk from the horses. • Feel: A lingering chill, despite the season.
Exploration Opportunities: • A DC 10 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals that the three grazing horses are branded with the letters “BAK” (Big Al Kalazorn). • A DC 15 Wisdom (Animal Handling) check is required to calm and ride one of the horses without spooking it. • If spooked, the horses bolt but can be tracked with a DC 12 Survival check per mile. • Searching the ruins reveals: • Charcoal-scrawled symbols of Talos on one burned home wall (suggests future threats). • A rotted journal page clinging to a stone wall, half-legible, describing a “terrible cry from the woods.”
DM Guidance: • This encounter functions as atmospheric setup and a light reward (free mounts). • If the party is cautious or respectful, the horses may become companions for the journey. • You can optionally include Petunia the Cow nearby in a separate clearing (see Butterskull Ranch text). • Consider letting a PC sense that something still watches these ruins—a foreshadowing for anchorites, undead, or the Harpers.
Optional Rumor (if the party camps here):
A whispered voice in the night (illusion or trick of the wind) says: “Beware the roots that writhe… the storm that breathes…

note.name: Arrival And Exterior
note.text:
Read-Aloud: Butterskull Ranch sprawls behind a sagging wooden fence. Charred beams rise from the ruins of a barn and smithy, skeletal against the sky. Two orc corpses rot in the dirt beside five dead ranch hands. Flies buzz thick as smoke.
DM Info: • The bodies have no treasure. • Pigs wander freely and are non-hostile. • A successful DC 12 Wisdom (Survival) check spots orc footprints leading to and from the farmhouse.
Exploration Hooks: • DC 14 Investigation reveals discarded weapons with the mark of Icespire Hold’s orc tribes. • One pig has a crude orcish sigil burned into its flank—possible link to a known warband

note.name: NPC – Alfonse 'Big Al' Kalazorn
note.text:
Visual Trait: Deep voice and a stiff right leg from an old wound. Quip: 'Ain’t no orc gonna steal my cows and my butter.'
Retired Sheriff of Triboar, Ranch Owner Race: Human | Gender: Male | Alignment: Lawful Good Class Equivalent: Veteran (MM p.350) – currently wounded and unarmed
Appearance: A broad-shouldered man with a weathered face, bushy white sideburns, and a jagged scar across one ear. He wears a dusty duster coat, and his silver sheriff’s badge is still pinned proudly to his chest—even in captivity.
Voice: Gruff but fatherly, with a slow cowboy drawl.
Quirk / Visual Trait: Always chews on a toothpick or piece of wheat straw. His boots still shine like he’s on patrol.
Quip:
“I didn’t survive bandits, rust monsters, and two ex-wives just to die in a cellar tied to a chair.”
HP: 9 (currently injured) AC: 11 (no armor), 16 in mithral chain mail Speed: 30 ft. Abilities: STR 16, DEX 13, CON 14, INT 10, WIS 11, CHA 10 Saving Throws: STR +5, CON +4 Skills: Intimidation +2, Survival +3 Attacks: • Longsword (if given): +5 to hit, 1d8+3 slashing • Heavy Crossbow (if found): +3 to hit, 1d10 piercing
Motivations: • Reclaim his ranch or die trying. • Keep Petunia the cow safe—“She’s family, plain and simple.” • Reward anyone who helps restore order or bring down the orcs.
Reward Offers: • Mithral chain mail (found in B6) • 65 gp + gratitude and a lifelong ally • Local rumors or past lawman intel (could be used in future quests)
If Petunia Is Found:
“That’s my girl! She’s worth more to me than all the gold in Triboar.

note.name: B1 – Kitchen
note.text:
Read-Aloud: The scent of sour milk and spilled ale hangs heavy in the air. Pots dangle from ceiling hooks above a long counter, and a large butter churn stands beside a skull-shaped wooden mold stained with yellow.
DM Info: • This is where butter skulls were made. • One orc is passed out drunk here, unless combat has already begun elsewhere.
Exploration Finds: • DC 10 Perception reveals a hidden jug of fresh buttermilk and a wooden spoon carved with initials “BAK.” • The butter skull mold is a fun, thematic memento worth 2 gp to a merchant in Phandalin

note.name: B2 – Empty Foyer
note.text:
Read-Aloud: The entry is bare but for muddy bootprints and blood smears. A wooden staircase groans with every breeze, leading up into shadow.
DM Info: • A bottleneck point during combat. • Characters can hear drunken orc laughter above (from B5) with a DC 10 Perception check

note.name: B3 – Dining Room
note.text:
Read-Aloud: The long room reeks of stale meat and spilled beer. Two battered trestle tables sit crookedly beneath walls decorated with cattle skulls, one of which now wears an orcish helm like a cruel joke.
DM Info: • One or two orcs are likely playing dice or eating here. • The skull decor unnerves the orcs, who mock it to mask their unease.
Exploration Finds: • DC 12 Investigation uncovers a splintered table leg carved into a makeshift club. • The orc helm is functional but rusted and reeking

note.name: B4 – Downstairs Closet
note.text:
Read-Aloud: This narrow closet holds chipped ceramic plates and pewter spoons stacked neatly on crooked shelves. The air smells of old soap and dust.
DM Info: • Nothing of value, but PCs hiding here gain advantage on Stealth checks

note.name: B5 – Common Room
note.text:
Read-Aloud: Shredded cards and toppled Dragonchess pieces litter the floor. Padded chairs, now defiled by muddy boots and spilled ale, crowd the center of the room. Graffiti in orcish scrawls across the hearth: “BAK BURNS.”
DM Info: • Two or three orcs lounge here if undisturbed. • The game pieces are carved from bone and worth 10 gp total to a collector

note.name: B6 – Big Al's Bedroom
note.text:
Read-Aloud: This room once held pride and peace. A four-poster bed with thick woolen quilts dominates the space, and the walls display framed paintings of rolling fields beneath bright skies. A cedar wardrobe stands near the bed, its door slightly ajar.
DM Info: • DC 15 Perception reveals the hidden compartment in the wardrobe. • Inside is the mithral chain mail (counts as light armor for stealth purposes).
Exploration Hook: • A letter tucked into the paintings is addressed to “Sheriff Kalazorn” from Triboar’s mayor, asking him to return “for one last roundup.

note.name: B7 – Ranch Hands’ Bedrooms
note.text:
Read-Aloud: The modest rooms hold bunk beds and footlockers. The air is still and musty. Faded bandanas and worn boots remain neatly placed—hauntingly undisturbed.
DM Info: • Two rooms, each with simple belongings and bunk beds. • DC 12 Medicine can determine that the occupants likely died defending Big Al
Exploration Finds: • A lucky coin in one footlocker, pressed with Tymora’s face (10 gp value)

note.name: B8 – Big Al’s Office
note.text:
Read-Aloud: Stacks of yellowed parchment and thick ledgers clutter a sturdy oak desk. A broken quill lies beside a half-filled mug of cold tea. A stuffed boar’s head hangs askew on the back wall.
DM Info: • The coin sack is hidden under the paper clutter (65 gp, 145 sp, 220 cp). • The ledgers show Big Al sold butter skulls as far as Waterdeep.
NPC Hook: • If asked, Al later mentions he once investigated a smuggling ring in Waterdeep—and suspects some butter shipments were used to move illicit potions

note.name: B9 – Upstairs Closet
note.text:
Read-Aloud: This cramped closet smells of vinegar and pine. A mop, broom, and bucket rest in a corner, all slightly damp.
DM Info: • No treasure. • Could be used to ambush or hide

note.name: B10 – Cold Storage Cellar
note.text:
Read-Aloud: A trapdoor groans open to reveal stairs descending into cool darkness. Below, shelves line the walls, holding waxed butter skulls arranged with unnerving precision. In the center of the room, a large man sits slumped and bound to a chair, a burlap sack over his head.
DM Info: • This is Alfonse “Big Al” Kalazorn, former sheriff of Triboar. • Human veteran, currently at 9 HP. • Grizzled, with white stubble and one ear missing. • Visual Trait: Wears a sheriff’s badge even in retirement. • Quip: “I didn’t survive bandits, rust monsters, and two ex-wives just to die in a cellar tied to a chair.” • DC 10 Persuasion/Intimidation to convince him to flee to Phandalin. • He’ll gladly join a fight if given armor or a weapon. • He’ll reward the players with his mithral armor and additional gifts if Petunia is returned

note.name: Wrapping Up
note.text:
After liberating the ranch and rescuing Big Al Kalazorn from the cellar, the party has the opportunity to finish the quest in a number of satisfying ways depending on their choices:
1. Completing the Quest Goals
The party has fulfilled the main objectives of the Butterskull Ranch quest if: 1. They have freed Big Al from captivity in the cold storage cellar (B10). 2. They have cleared the ranch house of orc invaders. 3. They have either: a. Convinced Big Al to return to Phandalin (DC 10 Charisma [Persuasion or Intimidation]), or b. Supported Big Al’s decision to remain and defend his land.
2. Bonus Goal – Finding Petunia the Cow
Big Al offers a splendid reward for returning Petunia, his beloved and profitable cow. • If the party found Petunia during their journey, Big Al is overjoyed and gifts them the mithral chain mail from his bedroom (B6). • If they didn’t find her, he asks them to search. For each hour spent searching: • Roll a d6. On a 6, Petunia is found. • If mounted, the party finds her on a 5 or 6.
Petunia is unbothered by the chaos, calm in nature, and will follow the party peacefully.
3. Loot and Rewards Summary
Characters can acquire the following items and treasure during or after the adventure: 1. Mithral Chain Mail • Hidden in Big Al’s wardrobe (B6). • Given as a reward for returning Petunia. 2. Coin Pouch • 65 gp, 145 sp, and 220 cp found in Big Al’s office (B8). 3. Optional: Riding Horses • If tamed in Conyberry, the branded horses (BAK) serve as temporary mounts or saleable livestock.
4. Ongoing Relationships
If the party helps Big Al and treats him well: • Big Al becomes an ally of the party, willing to offer shelter, food, and a friendly face in times of need. • He may become a recurring character in the campaign, especially if you plan to revisit Conyberry or nearby locations.
5. Optional Follow-Ups and Hooks
You can keep the story flowing from here with these potential leads: 1. Big Al’s Gratitude • He might refer the party to fellow ranchers or merchants who need help. 2. Resettling the Ranch • Orcs and bandits might return. Big Al might hire the players to help establish a new defense. 3. Petunia’s Protection • Cryovain or his minions may target livestock again—Petunia could be in danger, making her a funny but meaningful “escort” NPC. 4. Lead into Shrine of Savras • Big Al may mention travelers speaking of visions, fate, or a ruined shrine to the south

npc.label: Boar
npc.name: Anchorite of Talos
npc.text: TELLS THE PLAYERS ABOUT CIRCLE OF THUNDER

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 51

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting
trait.text:
The anchorite's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save DC 12). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
3/day: thunderwave (2d8 damage) 1/day each: augury, bless, lightning bolt (8d6 damage), revivify

trait.name: Shapechanger
trait.text: The anchorite can use its action to polymorph into a boar or back into its true form, which is humanoid. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

action.name: Clawed Gauntlet (Humanoid Form Only)
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d4 + 3) slashing damage.

action.name: Tusk (Boar Form Only)
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) slashing damage.

spell.name: Thunderwave
spell.text:
A wave of thunderous force sweeps out from you. Each creature in a 15-foot cube originating from you must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 2d8 thunder damage and is pushed 10 feet away from you. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed.
In addition, unsecured objects that are completely within the area of effect are automatically pushed 10 feet away from you by the spell's effect, and the spell emits a thunderous boom audible out to 300 feet.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Augury
spell.materials: specially marked sticks, bones, or similar tokens worth at least 25 gp
spell.text:
By casting gem-inlaid sticks, rolling dragon bones, laying out ornate cards, or employing some other divining tool, you receive an omen from an otherworldly entity about the results of a specific course of action that you plan to take within the next 30 minutes. The DM chooses from the following possible omens.
• Weal, for good results
• Woe, for bad results
• Weal and woe, for both good and bad results
• Nothing, for results that aren't especially good or bad
The spell doesn't take into account any possible circumstances that might change the outcome, such as the casting of additional spells or the loss or gain of a companion.
If you cast the spell two or more times before completing your next long rest, there is a cumulative 25 percent chance for each casting after the first that you get a random reading. The DM makes this roll in secret.

spell.name: Bless
spell.materials: a sprinkling of holy water
spell.text:
You bless up to three creatures of your choice within range. Whenever a target makes an attack roll or a saving throw before the spell ends, the target can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the attack roll or saving throw.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Lightning Bolt
spell.materials: a bit of fur and a rod of amber, crystal, or glass
spell.text:
A stroke of lightning forming a line of 100 feet long and 5 feet wide blasts out from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 8d6 lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The lightning ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot above 3rd.

spell.name: Revivify
spell.materials: diamonds worth 300 gp, which the spell consumes
spell.text: You touch a creature that has died within the last minute. That creature returns to life with 1 hit point. This spell can't return to life a creature that has died of old age, nor can it restore any missing body parts.

npc.label: Tibor Wester, Brother of Harbin Wester
npc.name: Commoner
npc.text:
Visual Trait: Wears a moth-eaten green vest over a fine white shirt, dirtied and wrinkled from hiding. His beard is half-shaved, as if he panicked halfway through grooming and gave up.
Quip: “Don’t suppose you brought more than courage and questions, did ya?”
Roleplay Notes: • Cowardly and opportunistic. • Has no love for his brother Harbin but appreciates the lifeline Phandalin provides. • Will sign anything that gets him out of danger
Tibor Wester – NPC Quips 1. “I swear, I’m just here to file logs, not fight monsters!” 2. “Did you bring the supplies? And—uh—preferably a sword? Or a cleric?” 3. “If it’s not in the ledger, it’s not my problem.” 4. “You have no idea how much I hate nature. I should’ve gone into dry goods.” 5. “They didn’t say anything about giant bugs in the job description!” 6. “Please don’t break the door down—it’s the only thing keeping me alive!” 7. “If I die out here, tell my brother Harbin he still owes me five gold.” 8. “I might’ve screamed… once. Or twice. You try not screaming when the ground explodes!” 9. “Listen, I didn’t see the anchorites leave the totem. But I felt it. In my spine.” 10. “Okay, okay, fine! I’ll sign the paper. But if an ankheg eats me while I’m writing, it’s on you!

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 345, Lost Laboratory of Kwalish p. 38, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 55

action.name: Club
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +2 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 2 (1d4) bludgeoning damage.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 21, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 51

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 (2d6+3) slashing damage plus 3 (1d6) acid damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is grappled (escape DC 13). Until this grapple ends, the ankheg can bite only the grappled creature and has advantage on attack rolls to do so.

action.name: Acid Spray (Recharge 6)
action.text: The ankheg spits acid in a line that is 30 ft. long and 5 ft. wide, provided that it has no creature grappled. Each creature in that line must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 (3d6) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 21, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 51

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 (2d6+3) slashing damage plus 3 (1d6) acid damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is grappled (escape DC 13). Until this grapple ends, the ankheg can bite only the grappled creature and has advantage on attack rolls to do so.

action.name: Acid Spray (Recharge 6)
action.text: The ankheg spits acid in a line that is 30 ft. long and 5 ft. wide, provided that it has no creature grappled. Each creature in that line must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 (3d6) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

item.name: 250 GP - Silver necklace with a gemstone pendant
item.text:
This art object is worth 250 gp.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide, page 135

note.name: Overview
note.text:
Summary
The Loggers’ Camp quest is a tense wilderness mystery with sudden bursts of terror. The players are tasked with delivering much-needed supplies to the camp and getting a signature from Tibor Wester to confirm delivery. Upon arrival, they discover a massacre—dozens of loggers killed, the camp silent, and burrowing ankhegs hiding just below the surface.
A Talos-worshiping druidic cult (the Anchorites) has planted a cursed totem in the camp to attract ankhegs as retribution for the destruction of Neverwinter Wood. The party must survive ambushes, locate and neutralize the totem, and convince Tibor to sign for the supplies—preferably before the ankhegs eat him too.
Tone & Pacing • Start light with Vincent the ox and the delivery—play up the wilderness travel and Barthen’s charming preparation. • Shift to eerie once they reach the quiet woods. Use silence, broken equipment, and subtle signs of violence. • Snap into horror with sudden ankheg eruptions, screaming acid-soaked death, and an unhelpful, cowardly NPC.
Build tension with delayed reveals and reward clever players who scout ahead, notice tremors, or investigate instead of charging in.
Main NPCs • Tibor Wester – Human commoner. Craven, paranoid, hiding in his office. • Visual Trait: Red nose and sweat-stained collar, reeks of old ale and sawdust. • Quip: “I didn’t sign up to be eaten! I just wanted to sell wood, gods damn it!” • Vincent the Ox – Technically an NPC. Loyal, stubborn, and blessedly normal. • Returns to Barthen if abandoned. Players might get attached.
Enemies • Ankhegs – Ambush predators drawn by the Talos totem. • Hide underground, sense tremors (tremorsense), and use acid spray. • Only surface when characters step into marked zones. • Anchorite of Talos (Optional Foreshadowing) • Drethna, shapeshifted into a boar, might be encountered en route (see A Boar-ing Encounter). • If spared, she warns Woodland Manse. If killed, it delays their retaliation.
Treasure • L3 (Tibor’s Office): • If convinced or rescued, Tibor gives a signed receipt (quest item) and may provide useful tools (ropes, axes, etc.). • Totem (L2): • Destroying it prevents more ankheg attacks—wise players will realize it’s the cause. • Roleplay Reward: • Players might earn favor from Falcon, Barthen, or Phandalin if they deliver the goods and solve the crisis professionally.
Adventure Hooks • Harbin sends the party to deliver goods via Barthen’s Provisions. • A bottle of wine given to Falcon along the way can lead to Falcon’s Hunting Lodge. • Discovery of the Talos totem connects directly to the Woodland Manse arc.
Tips for Running It • Drop subtle signs of ankheg burrowing before they attack—shifting dirt, tremors, strange footprints. • Use Tibor for dark humor—he’s annoying, but not evil. He might try to bribe or beg the party to lie for him. • Reward nonviolent solutions—careful scouting, sneaking, and breaking the totem avoid most of the danger. • Keep it short and tight—this quest should wrap up in 1–2 sessions depending on how deep they explore

note.name: NPC Tibor Wester
note.text:
Visual Trait: Wears a moth-eaten green vest over a fine white shirt, dirtied and wrinkled from hiding. His beard is half-shaved, as if he panicked halfway through grooming and gave up.
Quip: “Don’t suppose you brought more than courage and questions, did ya?”
Roleplay Notes: • Cowardly and opportunistic. • Has no love for his brother Harbin but appreciates the lifeline Phandalin provides. • Will sign anything that gets him out of danger

note.name: Quest Card And Preparations
note.text:
Quest: Loggers’ Camp
Quest Giver: Harbin Wester (Townmaster of Phandalin) Level Range: 2–4 Reward: 100 gp upon return with signed receipt
Description: “My half-brother, Tibor Wester, oversees a logging camp deep in Neverwinter Wood. He’s late with his latest delivery and I’m worried. Take these provisions to the camp and make sure Tibor signs for them. You’ll need to pick up the supplies from Barthen’s Provisions first. And bring back my ox and cart when you’re done!”
Objectives: • Deliver the crates to the camp safely • Get Tibor Wester’s signature • Survive whatever’s troubling the camp • Return the ox (“Vincent”) and cart to Barthe

note.name: Travel to Loggers' Camp
note.text: The camp lies 50 miles north of Phandalin. It takes two days' travel on foot with a long rest halfway. Navigate Neverwinter Wood with DC 10 Wisdom (Survival) each hex; failure wastes 1d4 miles. Players may rest at Falcon’s Lodge en route.

note.name: A Boar-ing Encounter
note.text:
Location: Neverwinter Wood, early into the journey to Loggers’ Camp
Read-Aloud:
The air thickens beneath the canopy of Neverwinter Wood. Shafts of light pierce through gnarled boughs, illuminating motes of dust that drift like fireflies. The forest is quiet—not peacefully so, but tense, as if holding its breath.
Then, sixty feet ahead, a wild boar lumbers into a small clearing. Its bristled fur gleams with damp earth, and its small black eyes fix on you with strange, almost human wariness.
The boar does not flee. It just… watches.
DM Notes: • Creature: The boar is Burtolli, a female anchorite of Talos in wild shape. She is suspicious but non-hostile unless provoked. Tells the players ABOUT CIRCLE OF THUNDER. • DC 15 Wisdom (Insight) reveals that the boar is unusually still and more aware than most animals. • Passive Perception ≥ 14 or DC 15 Arcana/Nature check reveals faint magical energy—suggesting druidic shapeshifting. • Burtolli attacks only in self-defense. If the characters fight her and she survives, she transforms mid-combat into her anchorite form, letting out a shriek of lightning before vanishing into the trees.
Exploration Hooks: • Characters may try to approach or communicate with the boar. • DC 15 Animal Handling earns a moment of curiosity—Burtolli may grunt or tilt her head, but ultimately bolts. • If they bypass or ignore her, she flees deeper into the forest to warn the anchorites at Woodland Manse.
Foreshadowing Rumors (Optional):
You may allow characters to connect this encounter to rumors in Phandalin: • “Storm cultists out in the woods—folks say they become the beasts they summon.” • “A hunter said a boar looked right at him and smiled. Just turned and vanished.”
Possible Outcomes: • Combat Ensues: Burtolli calls down lightning (via Thunderwave or Wrath of Talos) and tries to flee once reduced to half HP. • Boar Escapes: She reaches the manse by nightfall and warns Grannoc, who doubles their perimeter defenses. • Captured/Interrogated: Burrolli shifts back and warns them cryptically: “You cut trees. Talos cuts deeper. Storm is coming… and it remembers your names.

note.name: Arrival at the Camp
note.text:
Read Aloud:
A hush hangs over the forest like a held breath. The air smells of pine, damp earth, and ash. As you break through the tree line, you find yourself on a low, sandy embankment overlooking a camp stretched along the riverbank. Tents sag silently in the wind. A half-collapsed chimney slouches beside torn-down cabins. Nearby, a lopsided wooden shack leans under the weight of logs stacked against its wall. There are no voices. No movement. Just silence—and the unsettling sense that something beneath the earth is listening.
DM Info: • The party arrives to a seemingly abandoned camp. • Three ankhegs lie in ambush (L3 and L6); each erupts based on trigger conditions. • The loggers are dead; Tibor Wester hides in the tool shack. • A cursed totem in the ruined chimney (L2) draws the ankhegs. • The totem can be destroyed to avoid future combat.

note.name: L1 – Cabins on the Rocks
note.text:
Read Aloud:
A stony outcrop juts from the shoreline, where two ruined cabins cling to the escarpment like old memories. The frames are long burned out, the roofs collapsed inward, but the chimneys still rise like solemn sentries. No signs of life—nor movement—just the low whisper of the river lapping below.
DM Info: • This area is safe from ankheg eruptions. • Characters may use this location for a short rest. • Possible clue: a broken campfire ring shows someone tried to make a last stand here (DC 10 Investigation reveals orc arrows embedded in nearby logs)

note.name: L2 – Old Cabin and Chimney
note.text:
Read Aloud:
All that remains of this cabin is a crumbling stone foundation and a chimney, half-swallowed by ivy. Bits of scorched wood jut out from the earth like ribs. The smell of old blood lingers faintly.
Totem Description: A cluster of blood-dipped stick figures tied with human hair, each scratched with crude lightning symbols.
Discoveries: • Totem: DC 15 Religion check reveals it’s a Talos curse designed to attract nature’s wrath. • Destruction: If burned, smashed, or buried in salt, it breaks the enchantment and any ankhegs not yet encountered burrow away

note.name: L3 – Office and Tool Storage
note.text:
Read Aloud (Main Room):
The structure creaks as you push open the warped door. The smell of old sweat and sawdust hits you. Logging tools—axes, rusted saws, frayed harnesses—are piled carelessly. A low moaning creak rises as something shifts beneath the floorboards.
Trigger: The first character who crosses the floor triggers the ankheg eruption. The creature bursts through in a spray of dirt and rotted wood, attacking immediately.
Read Aloud (Office):
Behind a poorly barricaded door, you hear a scraping, then a voice: “Who’s there? You with the beasties or the paymasters?”
Tibor Roleplay Tip: He peeks out only after hearing his name. If the characters deliver the supplies or mention his brother Harbin, he opens up—nervously

note.name: L4 – River Dock
note.text:
Read Aloud:
Weathered boards stretch into the river, slick with moss. Empty moorings sway gently in the current, the ropes snapping softly in the breeze. It’s clear no boats have come for some time.
Exploration Finds: • A fishing pole missing its hook. • A single boot half-submerged in mud. • A soggy ledger tucked in a waterproof oilskin with the names of dead workers crossed off one by one

note.name: L5 – North Camp
note.text:
Read Aloud:
A circle of blackened stones marks the remains of a campfire. The surrounding tents have collapsed, their canvas rotted and partially dissolved. The air smells faintly of acid, and strange furrows scar the sand—like something massive tunneled through.
Exploration Clues: • DC 10 Investigation: Tells of creatures dragged into the sand. • DC 15 Nature: Recognizes signs of ankheg activity—acid burns and underground attacks

note.name: L6 – South Camp
note.text:
Read Aloud:
You step cautiously into a second ring of abandoned tents. The silence is thicker here—like the ground itself is holding its breath. Then, a vibration. A low chitter. The ground erupts beneath your feet.
Combat: • Three ankhegs burst out when a creature steps near their marked eruption points. • Tents here are torn and melted. Bits of armor and bone are half-swallowed by sand.
Treasure: • DC 13 Investigation in the wreckage reveals a melted steel belt buckle engraved with the symbol of Neverwinter. • DC 12 Survival to harvest ankheg acid sac (worth 25 gp to apothecaries or alchemists

note.name: Wrapping Up
note.text:
Once the characters have delivered the supplies and resolved the threat of the ankhegs, they can claim success—though the scene is less a triumphant rescue and more a grim reckoning with the cost of failure, cowardice, and unnatural interference.
1. Completing the Quest Goals
The party successfully completes the Loggers’ Camp quest if: 1. They deliver the two crates of supplies to Tibor Wester. 2. They rescue Tibor from the barricaded office (L3) and get his signature acknowledging receipt of the goods. 3. They survive or neutralize the ankheg threat. • This can include: • Defeating the ankhegs in L3 and L6. • Destroying the Talos totem hidden in L2, which causes any remaining ankhegs to lose interest and leave.
2. Tibor Wester’s Reaction
Tibor is: • Cowardly, selfish, and has no sense of duty beyond survival. • Grateful enough to sign the manifest and confirm delivery, but shows no heroism or leadership. • Lies about his courage to others later, claiming he “held the line” until help arrived.
He offers: • No treasure or reward, but may hint that his half-brother Harbin Wester will compensate the party for their troubles.
3. Roleplaying Fallout and Reactions
The party may take a variety of follow-up actions based on their moral alignment or temperament: 1. Interrogate or shame Tibor for abandoning his workers. This can create tension with Harbin Wester later. 2. Destroy the totem to prevent further attacks from Talos-worshippers. 3. Recover evidence of the attack for reporting: • The melted tents (L5, L6). • Drag marks and acid burns. • Totem tied to storm cult activity.
4. Potential Rewards and Finds
There is no formal treasure here, but the party might reasonably acquire: 1. Recovered supplies from the abandoned tents (ropes, mess kits, logging tools). 2. Insight into the anchorites of Talos, especially if they recognize the totem in L2 and connect it to the Woodland Manse. 3. Recognition back in Phandalin, if they deliver the signed manifest and report on the threat they faced.
5. Follow-Up Options and Adventure Hooks 1. Return to Phandalin to report success to Harbin Wester and Barthen. 2. Pursue the anchorite threat, tracing the totem’s origin to the Woodland Manse (if they haven’t already). 3. Investigate other attacks along the river or nearby woods, especially if the boar encounter was nonviolent and unresolved. 4. Expose Tibor to Harbin if the party is angry about his cowardice. This could change political dynamics in Phandalin.
6. Optional Epilogue Scene (DM Prompt)
If you’d like to close the session cinematically, consider a final moment:
The sun sets over the ruined camp as Tibor signs the parchment with a shaking hand. Behind him, the shattered tents flutter in the breeze, stained with acid and blood. A thin line of disturbed soil snakes away into the trees—one last trace of the horrors below

npc.label: Don Jon Raskin
npc.name: Commoner
npc.text:
Visual Trait
A sun-leathered man with a long salt-and-pepper mustache and thick muttonchops, clad in a tattered leather duster, fur-lined boots, and a green bandana tied jauntily around his neck. He smells faintly of pickled fish and whiskey.
Quips & Voice Style • “Y’know, back when I wrestled a giant octopus off the coast of Mintarn—this here’s nothin’.” • “Well butter my boots and call me breakfast, this place is worse than a gorgon’s outhouse.” • “I’ve wrangled whalers tougher than this mine. These rats ain’t seen nothin’ yet.” • “You hear that? That’s the sound of profit cryin’ for help.”
Speech Style: Fast-talking, overconfident, colorful, and folksy. He loves telling stories no one asked for.
Personality • Overconfident: Thinks he’s the protagonist of every story. • Blustery but good-hearted: He won’t abandon allies and is loyal to a fault. • Tactical cowardice: He’ll avoid danger if he doesn’t have backup, despite bragging otherwise. • Secretly lonely: Enjoys adventuring because it gives him a captive audience.
Background
Don-Jon has worn a dozen hats over the years—miner, whaler, trader, fur trapper, caravan guard, and one-time “mayor” of a failed frontier town. He was recently hired by a consortium in Neverwinter to take charge of Mountain’s Toe and boost output, but the infestation of wererats has thrown a pickaxe in his plans.
Role in the Adventure • Serves as the quest-giver escort for Mountain’s Toe. • Pushes the party to deal with the wererats directly. • If left alone, tries to negotiate peace—but fails and is likely infected or imprisoned. • If brought to safety and the mine is cleared, he becomes a reliable contact for future mining endeavors or favors from Neverwinter merchants

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 345, Lost Laboratory of Kwalish p. 38, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 55

action.name: Club
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +2 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 2 (1d4) bludgeoning damage.

npc.label: Zeleen Varnaster
npc.name: Wererat
npc.immune: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered
npc.text:
Zeleen Varnaster (Wererat Leader) • Female wererat in human form (until combat) • Scheming, sarcastic, speaks with polite contempt • Visual Trait: Gold hoop earrings and a pale pink scarf tied at the wrist • Quip: “It’s not our fault the dwarves were allergic to progress.
Race: Wererat Role: Leader of the Whiskered Gang Location: M4 — Wererat Den Form: Initially appears in human form—calm, composed, and a little too friendly.
Visual Traits • Sharp, angular features with pale, almost translucent skin • Pale pink silk scarf wrapped around her wrist (scented faintly of lilac) • Gold hoop earrings, scuffed and mismatched • Clean, calloused hands—odd for a “miner”
Voice and Mannerisms • Speaks slowly and precisely, like someone choosing her words very carefully • Smiles with only the corners of her mouth—never shows her teeth • Watches everyone with measured interest, tapping her scarf’s knot when thinking • Occasionally scratches behind her ear absentmindedly when agitated
Motivations • Primary Goal: Maintain control of the mine and expand her gang’s foothold in the region • Secondary Goal: Use diplomacy and deceit to avoid a costly fight • Hidden Agenda: If ousted, plans to flee to the Shrine of Savras or cause trouble in Phandalin later • Does NOT want: An outright war with adventurers who might be more trouble than they’re worth
Tactics & Approach • Clever Manipulator: Zeleen knows how to play both sides. She may offer a false bargain, suggesting her gang will leave if the characters “deal with” the orcs at the Shrine of Savras. • Social Encounters: If the party seems diplomatic, she’ll lean into the façade of reason: • “This mine’s no shrine—it’s just shelter. You think anyone else deserves it more than we do?” • Intimidation or Threats: She’ll pretend to back down, promising to leave, only to double-cross later. • Combat: If diplomacy fails, she transforms mid-sentence—coiling into hybrid form—and orders her gang to “take out their knees.”
Quips & Quotes • “Now now, let’s not resort to screaming and steel—we’re all civilized, aren’t we?” • “We found this place fair and square—after someone else died trying to keep it.” • “Careful, friend. It’s a slippery slope from savior to slaughterer.” • “Tell Harbin Wester we’re the least of his worries.” • “We’re not vermin. We’re survivors. We just bite harder than most.”
How to Use Zeleen in Play • As a Moral Test: Zeleen tempts characters to resolve the situation without bloodshed—but her lies test the party’s insight and values. • As a Recurring Villain: If she escapes, she could spread lycanthropy, start rumors in Phandalin, or join a larger faction (e.g., Zhentarim or local thieves’ guild). • As a Twisted Ally: Under duress, she might turn against worse foes or offer information for personal gain

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 209, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 64

trait.name: Shapechanger
trait.text: The wererat can use its action to polymorph into a rat-humanoid hybrid or into a giant rat, or back into its true form, which is humanoid. Its statistics, other than its size, are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Keen Smell
trait.text: The wererat has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Multiattack (Humanoid or Hybrid Form Only)
action.text: The wererat makes two attacks, only one of which can be a bite.

action.name: Bite (Rat or Hybrid Form Only).
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d4+2) piercing damage. If the target is a humanoid, it must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or be cursed with wererat lycanthropy.

action.name: Shortsword (Humanoid or Hybrid Form Only)
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6+2) piercing damage.

action.name: Hand Crossbow (Humanoid or Hybrid Form Only)
action.text: Ranged Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6+2) piercing damage.

monster.name: Dwarven Worker
