item.name: Goggles of Night
item.text:
While wearing these dark lenses, you have darkvision out to a range of 60 feet. If you already have darkvision. wearing the goggles increases its range by 60 feet.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 172

item.name: Gold Ore
item.text: This mining object is worth 10gp

note.name: D6 Clues
note.text: d6,Discovery 1,A torn parchment wedged in a crack near the mine entrance reads: “The Shrine is lost. They came in darkness, and now we flee. –V” (Hint at Shrine of Savras, former wererat lair.) 2,Graffiti on a wall, written in Dwarvish: “Gold’s worth nothing to a corpse.” Scratched beneath it in Common: “Z.V. doesn’t bleed. Don’t trust her.” 3,A chunk of gold ore is embedded with a strange glyph not native to this region. A DC 13 Arcana or History check reveals it’s from an ancient Netherese mining technique—this mine may sit atop something older. 4,A half-chewed journal page in the rats’ den mentions: “We saw it again last night. The thing on the ceiling with no eyes. It watches.” (A frightened note about the carrion crawler in M11.) 5,A miner’s pick broken at the shaft is marked with a blackened handprint. A DC 12 Religion check links it to Shar, the Mistress of the Night—possibly indicating a deeper darkness stirring below the mine. 6,A set of footprints (barefoot, clawed) lead into a sealed-off tunnel with collapsed support beams. At the end, scrawled in Undercommon: “We burrow to survive, but they come for us still. –Gnash” (Could connect to Underdark tunnels or future threats.)

note.name: Overview
note.text:
Read Aloud (Arrival):
Hidden among snow-kissed boulders at the base of a craggy peak, a tunnel mouth yawns beneath a wooden plank carved with the words “Mountain’s Toe.” The wind howls faintly through the pass, rattling frost-bitten pine branches and sending up gusts of gold-flecked dust from the rock. A scent of wet stone and old iron wafts out of the tunnel’s depths. There’s no sign of miners… no welcome party.
DM Info: • What’s Going On: The mine has been quietly overrun by the Whiskered Gang, a group of cunning and unscrupulous wererats led by Zeleen Varnaster. They pose as friendly mine workers at first but are waiting for an opportunity to expand their influence or ambush the party. Meanwhile, five dwarven miners remain in hiding, refusing to yield the mine to “filthy rats.” • Quest Trigger: The party escorts the boastful Don-Jon Raskin to take over as overseer. Upon discovering the wererats, Raskin expects the party to “clear ‘em out like a good boil on a bad day.” If they don’t, he will attempt to bargain on his own and may become infected with lycanthropy or even converted to their gang. • Enemies to Prep: • Wererats (M1, M4) in human and hybrid form • Giant Rats (M4, M13) • Carrion Crawler (M11) • Optional: add a low-CR spirit or minor construct in the overseer’s ruined office (M10) as a bonus surprise or clue. • Key NPCs: • Don-Jon Raskin – Brash, loud-mouthed prospector with white mutton chops and a rattling laugh. Quip: “Gold’s where the rats ain’t, I always say!” • Zeleen Varnaster – Ambitious wererat with a hunched posture and silver-streaked braids. Visual quirk: she keeps an elegant boot dagger visibly strapped to her thigh. Quip: “Business is about adaptation… and we adapt well.” • Dwarven Miners (M14–15) – Gruff and starving, armed with tools and spite. • Gronkel Stonepick: Eye patch, hates the taste of cheese. “I’d rather chew gravel than share a tunnel with ratfolk.” • Treasure: • Goggles of Night (M4) • 10 gold ore chunks (10 gp each) • Modest coin pouch (82 sp, 450 cp) • Plentiful mining tools and rations for party resupply (M3, M5, M8) • Tension Hooks & Exploration: • Clues that something is amiss (stabbed body in M9, false friendliness, dead orcs outside) • The wererats claim they’ll leave if the party clears the orcs at the Shrine of Savras—this is a lie. • Dwarves may aid the party if convinced or offered safety (RP encounter). • The Carrion Crawler is a surprise danger that could block a retreat route. • Tone to Run With: Think Appalachian prospector horror meets verminous coup. The mine’s eerie quiet, gold-veined tunnels, and rusted tools should contrast with the sly charisma of the wererats and the chaos that could explode at any moment

note.name: Roleplaying Don-Jon Raskin
note.text:
Don-Jon Raskin
Role: Quest NPC (Escort) Race: Human Type: Commoner (with custom flair) Alignment: Lawful Good Quest Involvement: Mountain’s Toe Gold Mine Location: Stonehill Inn, Phandalin (starting location)
Description (For the DM):
Don-Jon Raskin is a boisterous, seasoned frontiersman with a booming voice and boundless confidence. He’s wide-shouldered and weathered by the wilds—his beard a tangled nest of gray shot through with gold, his travel-stained coat held together with brass buttons and blind optimism. His boots are scuffed, his belt carries both a wineskin and a broken compass “for old times’ sake,” and he smells faintly of pine tar and pipe smoke.
Despite his swagger, Don-Jon’s heart is in the right place. He sees himself as a mentor to “you young adventurin’ types” and peppers his speech with outrageous stories that may or may not be true. He’s unarmed but unafraid, and expects the world to sort itself out in time—especially if someone like him is in charge.
Visual Trait: • A once-white fur-lined coat, now patched with four different kinds of leather. • Gold tooth that flashes when he grins (which is often).
Quips and Catchphrases: • “Back when I was runnin’ a post up by Icewind Dale, I wrestled a dire wolf for the last cup of coffee.” • “I once traded a barrel of salted eels for a magic ring. Turns out it only makes toast. Still got it.” • “This ol’ mine don’t scare me. I’ve fought off frost giants, fussy investors, and worse—divorces.” • “If we see any trouble, just stand behind me. I make an excellent distraction.”
Behavior & Roleplaying Tips (DM Use): • Chatty, overconfident, but respectful of bravery. • Never stops telling tall tales, especially if asked anything mundane. • Will never fight—he sees himself as a “foreman,” not a “frontliner.” • Will boast and bluff to appear brave, but if cornered, he freezes up or hides.
Quest Role: • Must be escorted safely to the Mountain’s Toe Gold Mine, 15 miles northeast of Phandalin. • If delivered safely, he helps reveal that wererats have taken over the mine. • If left to negotiate alone, he is quickly turned into a wererat himself. • After reaching the mine, he encourages the party to clear it out or negotiate with the Whiskered Gang.
Stat Block:
Use Commoner stat block (Player’s Handbook, or DMG) with the following twist: • HP: 9 (as a nod to his grizzled toughness) • No combat abilities, but advantage on Charisma (Deception) checks when telling tall tales. • Flaw: “I assume everyone wants to hear my stories. Even in battle. Especially in battle.”
Adventure Tip (for the DM):
Don-Jon is great comic relief and an emotional anchor. Let players grow fond of him—then give them the dilemma of protecting him or seeing him fall to the wererats. If turned, he may later return as a tragic (or hilarious) recurring foe—“Don-Jon the Bite!

note.name: Travel to the Mine
note.text: The mine lies 15 miles northeast of Phandalin, near the Sword Mountains. The journey can be completed in a day with no random encounters expected. Sensory Note: Cold winds sweep down from the peaks, carrying the scent of pine and iron-rich dust.

note.name: Dead Orcs Encounter
note.text:
Location: 5 miles outside Mountain’s Toe Gold Mine Trigger: Happens automatically en route to the mine CR: None (narrative & investigation)
Read Aloud:
The air turns colder as your boots crunch across the rocky path. A low ridge looms to your right, framed by jagged peaks scraping a brooding, gray sky.
About ninety feet ahead, something breaks the stillness—bodies, strewn like broken puppets across the earth. Six of them, broad and brutish, their weapons scattered like the aftermath of a failed last stand.
Don-Jon Raskin squints ahead, then lets out a low whistle.
“Well, ain’t that something. Looks like someone—or something—saved us some trouble.”
DM Notes: • These six orc corpses (from Cryovain’s earlier attack) are sprawled on icy ground, half-frozen, their hide armor stiff with rime. Their greataxes and javelins lie nearby, coated in frost. • A DC 12 Wisdom (Medicine) check reveals they died from intense cold—frozen to death by Cryovain’s breath roughly three days ago. • If the players don’t identify the cause, Don-Jon suggests: “Dragon work, no doubt. White breath—cold and cruel. Poor bastards.”
Sensory Details: • Smell: Bitter cold mixed with the faint iron tang of old blood. • Sight: Frostbite-blackened flesh, weapons frozen into clawed hands. One corpse has ice crystals curling from its nostrils. • Sound: Wind whistles through cracks in the rocks. Ravens circle overhead but keep their distance.
Exploration & Loot: • Each orc carries a rusty greataxe and 1d4 javelins. These weapons are mundane but serviceable. • A DC 14 Intelligence (Investigation) check uncovers a folded scrap of orcish parchment tucked into a belt pouch on one of the bodies. It shows a crude hand-drawn map pointing toward Icespire Hold with a single word in Orcish: “Claimed.” • Optional: You may include a broken bone pendant carved in the shape of a boar’s tusk, possibly hinting at anchorite ties or an old tribal link.
Optional Encounter Hook: • If you want tension, have the scent of blood draw a mountain lion or carrion crawler nearby. • Alternatively, use this moment to foreshadow Cryovain’s recent flight path, perhaps with gouged claw marks in the ridge wall or a patch of wing-disturbed snow

note.name: Arrival at the Mine
note.text:
Location: Tunnel mouth at the base of the Sword Mountains Trigger: Upon approaching the mine at the end of travel CR: None (setup scene)
Read Aloud:
Hidden beneath frost-tipped pines and low brush, the mouth of a tunnel yawns at the foot of a snow-draped mountain.
A crooked wooden sign hangs above the entrance, creaking slightly in the wind. Carved into it in faded Common: “Mountain’s Toe.”
The air here is sharp with the bite of cold iron. A light snow falls in fits, clinging to the rocky slope. No smoke, no voices, no distant hammering—just quiet.
Don-Jon Raskin adjusts his pack, clears his throat, and mutters:
“Well, reckon this is it. Sure don’t smell like gold yet…”
DM Notes: • Don-Jon has never been here before and carries no map or layout of the mine. • This is a great moment to pause for a long rest, discuss tactics, or allow the party to prep spells or gear. • From this point forward, the party can be ambushed, overhear wererat chatter, or begin exploring freely.
Sensory Cues: • Smell: Earthy loam and faint rot mixed with metallic tang from deeper within the tunnel. • Sound: Wind hissing through trees, the occasional distant clatter of falling stone from somewhere within the mine. • Sight: The tunnel is framed by weathered timbers, reinforced in places with rope bindings. Lanterns hang cold and unlit.
Environment & Travel Impact: • Temperatures here are just below freezing. Characters not dressed for cold might begin making Constitution saving throws if exposed for long durations. • If the party is loud, you can hint that something inside the mine stirs faintly, as if hearing them.
Exploration Hook:
If the party inspects the sign or entry: • A DC 12 Investigation or Survival check notes several humanoid tracks, ratlike paw prints, and a single set of heavy bootprints (Don-Jon’s predecessor?) that vanish near the entrance

note.name: M1. Guard Post
note.text:
Location Type: Mine Entrance Cavern Occupants: 2 Wererat Guards (hybrid form) CR: Moderate (social or combat)
Read Aloud:
The tunnel opens into a rough-hewn cavern braced with wooden beams, its stone walls veined with glimmers of gold ore. Lanterns dangle cold and empty from the ceiling hooks, swaying gently in the cave’s breathless stillness.
Then—movement.
Two figures step from the shadows at the far end. They’re humanoid, but wrong—snouted, whiskered, hunched and wiry, with fur-matted skin and gleaming yellow eyes. Each clutches a short blade crusted with dried blood.
One raises a clawed hand and growls,
“You here to work… or to die?”
DM Info: • These are two female wererats in hybrid form, stationed to intercept intruders and act as gatekeepers to the mine. • They don’t attack immediately unless provoked. Their primary goal is to maintain the illusion of control and funnel intruders toward Zeleen Varnaster (M4). • If the party mentions Don-Jon Raskin or claims to be new laborers, the wererats offer to “escort them to the overseer.” • The wererats won’t give names, but one is called “Skitters” by her companion.
NPC Traits – Wererat Guards • Skitters: Wears a cracked miner’s helmet over one ear. She squints often, even in darkness. • Quip: “Don’t talk much, but I bite plenty.” • Grelda: Missing several front teeth, speaks with a lisp and raspy chuckle. • Quip: “New meat’s always twitchy. Hope you don’t squeal too loud.”
Combat Notes: • If attacked, the wererats retreat toward M4 while fighting, calling for backup. • In hybrid form, they resist nonmagical damage (except from silvered weapons). • If overwhelmed, one tries to flee, possibly alerting more guards deeper in.
Exploration & Clues: • DC 13 Perception Check: Scratches in the rock floor form crude tally marks—perhaps counting victims or days. • DC 15 Insight Check: The wererats are tense and overacting their roles as mine guards. They seem unsure how to deal with actual authority.
Treasure: • None in this room, but each wererat carries a rusty dagger and 1d6 silver pieces in a pouch tied to their belt

note.name: M2. Wooden Posts
note.text:
Location Type: Tunnel Storage Alcove Occupants: None CR: N/A (non-combat area)
Read Aloud:
This narrow alcove opens up just enough to break the monotony of the main tunnel. Leaning in uneven rows against the rocky walls are dozens of thick wooden posts—some snapped at the ends, others splintered with old tool marks.
The air here smells faintly of dry timber and dust, tinged with the scent of old sweat and iron nails. A discarded hammer lies half-buried in loose gravel near the entrance.
DM Info: • This is a maintenance supply zone, used to shore up tunnels with wooden supports. • There’s nothing actively dangerous here, but it can clue the players into the mine’s previous operation and the level of abandonment. • Posts are heavy but moveable—can be used as makeshift barricades or props.
Exploration & Interactions: • DC 10 Investigation: Discover a buried set of chalk markings on the wall: arrows pointing toward different tunnels, faded with age. • DC 12 Survival: Notice drag marks near the posts—likely from recent wererat activity moving heavy equipment

note.name: M3. Crates and Casks
note.text:
Location Type: Storage Room Occupants: None CR: N/A (non-combat area)
Read Aloud:
Crates and casks are stacked three high along the rough stone walls of this storage cave. Most bear faded stencils reading “M.T.G.M.” and several have been pried open. The room smells of sawdust and stale air, with the occasional creak as wood shifts in the cool subterranean draft.
One cask near the far wall has burst open, spilling a trickle of dry black powder across the floor—long since spoiled or useless.
DM Info: • This is a leftover supply room from when the mine was fully operational. • Though it appears looted, some hidden items remain if players search thoroughly. • The empty crates are mostly damaged—some crushed under collapsed ceiling beams.
Exploration & Finds: • DC 10 Investigation: Find a crowbar wedged behind a crate. • DC 13 Perception: Hear faint scratching from a hidden rat behind the casks—it flees deeper into the mine, possibly alerting wererats. • DC 15 Investigation: Discover a false bottom in one crate revealing: • A small, forgotten leather pouch with 6 gp and a smooth river stone carved with a spiral (no magic, but symbolic of dwarven prosperity).
Treasure: • Crowbar • 6 gp in hidden pouch • Spiral-carved river stone (can be sold to a dwarf for 10 gp or used as leverage with miners in M14–15

note.name: Roleplaying Zeleen
note.text:
Race: Wererat Role: Leader of the Whiskered Gang Location: M4 — Wererat Den Form: Initially appears in human form—calm, composed, and a little too friendly.
Visual Traits • Sharp, angular features with pale, almost translucent skin • Pale pink silk scarf wrapped around her wrist (scented faintly of lilac) • Gold hoop earrings, scuffed and mismatched • Clean, calloused hands—odd for a “miner”
Voice and Mannerisms • Speaks slowly and precisely, like someone choosing her words very carefully • Smiles with only the corners of her mouth—never shows her teeth • Watches everyone with measured interest, tapping her scarf’s knot when thinking • Occasionally scratches behind her ear absentmindedly when agitated
Motivations • Primary Goal: Maintain control of the mine and expand her gang’s foothold in the region • Secondary Goal: Use diplomacy and deceit to avoid a costly fight • Hidden Agenda: If ousted, plans to flee to the Shrine of Savras or cause trouble in Phandalin later • Does NOT want: An outright war with adventurers who might be more trouble than they’re worth
Tactics & Approach • Clever Manipulator: Zeleen knows how to play both sides. She may offer a false bargain, suggesting her gang will leave if the characters “deal with” the orcs at the Shrine of Savras. • Social Encounters: If the party seems diplomatic, she’ll lean into the façade of reason: • “This mine’s no shrine—it’s just shelter. You think anyone else deserves it more than we do?” • Intimidation or Threats: She’ll pretend to back down, promising to leave, only to double-cross later. • Combat: If diplomacy fails, she transforms mid-sentence—coiling into hybrid form—and orders her gang to “take out their knees.”
Quips & Quotes • “Now now, let’s not resort to screaming and steel—we’re all civilized, aren’t we?” • “We found this place fair and square—after someone else died trying to keep it.” • “Careful, friend. It’s a slippery slope from savior to slaughterer.” • “Tell Harbin Wester we’re the least of his worries.” • “We’re not vermin. We’re survivors. We just bite harder than most.”
How to Use Zeleen in Play • As a Moral Test: Zeleen tempts characters to resolve the situation without bloodshed—but her lies test the party’s insight and values. • As a Recurring Villain: If she escapes, she could spread lycanthropy, start rumors in Phandalin, or join a larger faction (e.g., Zhentarim or local thieves’ guild). • As a Twisted Ally: Under duress, she might turn against worse foes or offer information for personal gain

note.name: M4. Wererat Den
note.text:
Location Type: Occupied Den / Social or Combat Encounter Occupants: Zeleen Varnaster (wererat leader), wererat gang (1 per party member + Don-Jon), 4 giant rats CR: Moderate to Deadly depending on party level and diplomacy
Read Aloud:
This wide cavern opens before you like the hollow chest of a sleeping beast. The walls are scarred by pick marks, with cracked wooden beams holding up the ceiling. A dozen mining tools—shovels, pickaxes, wheelbarrows—lie abandoned across the floor.
In the shadows, figures move: some shaped like people, others unmistakably rats the size of dogs. Their eyes glitter in the lamplight.
A stern woman with silver-shot hair steps forward. She wears dusty miner’s clothes belted tight at the waist with a gleaming dagger. Her smile is thin.
“So. The owners finally sent someone. We hoped they’d forgotten about this place.”
DM Info:
This cavern is the heart of the Whiskered Gang’s operation. The wererats pose as tolerant squatters but are planning to fully claim the mine. • Zeleen Varnaster, female wererat leader in human form • Wererats (Human Form): One per PC + Don-Jon • 4 Giant Rats in northeast tunnel, lounging or scavenging • Zeleen prefers to talk first, only attacking if slighted or threatened • The wererats will lie about leaving if the orcs at the Shrine of Savras are cleared—they have no intention of relocating
Zeleen Varnaster – Quick NPC Card: • Visual Trait: Iron-gray braid down her back, one side of her face is scarred with old claw marks • Quip: “We don’t need trouble—just space to dig and breathe. Is that too much to ask?” • Tactics: • Starts in human form unless threatened • Transforms only if a fight begins or things go badly • Wererats fight as a swarm, protecting Zeleen • Giant rats only join if combat lasts more than 2 rounds
Exploration & Interactions: • DC 12 Insight: Zeleen’s tone belies distrust; her talk of negotiation is stalling for advantage. • DC 14 Persuasion: Convince her to let the party leave safely if things get tense. • Intimidation can escalate quickly—wererats will not surrender easily unless Zeleen dies. • DC 15 Investigation or Perception: Spot a half-buried stash under a collapsed tunnel support.
Treasure:
Hidden beneath the debris in the southwest corner (under broken crates): • 10 chunks of raw gold ore (10 gp each) • 82 silver pieces, 450 copper pieces • Goggles of Night tucked in a padded cloth sack (worn by a wererat before the mine takeover)
If identified, the goggles allow the wearer to see in darkness up to 60 feet—extremely useful for non-darkvision party members.
Don-Jon’s Reaction:
“No-good, stinkin’ whisker-bellied squatters. You mark my words—they’ll chew through every board and gold vein before the week’s out.”
If players back down or leave the wererats alone, Don-Jon will grumble and either: • Attempt to rally help later • Get bitten offscreen and show up in Phandalin infected or turned (DM’s discretion

note.name: M5. Storeroom
note.text:
Type: Supply Cave Creatures: None Threat Level: None Treasure: Supplies (not valuable), potential rationing clue
Read Aloud:
The air in this chamber is dry and stifling, heavy with the smell of old grain and mildew. Neatly stacked in the center are crates marked with fading mining company sigils, and several thick casks are lashed together with coarse rope. Rodent droppings and claw marks mar the sides of a few containers.
DM Info:
This room contains survivable provisions: • 12 crates of dry foodstuffs (hardtack, dried fruit, lentils) • 9 casks of water (some partially drained) • Signs of recent access suggest both dwarves and wererats have used this supply • No valuable treasure, but players might appreciate salvaging extra supplies
Exploration Hooks: • DC 10 Investigation reveals two broken water casks, chewed open from the side (evidence of rat or giant rat interference). • DC 13 Survival: The rations here could stretch for another week if supplemented with foraging or outside supply runs. • Optional Clue: A hastily written tally sheet (in Dwarvish) near a crate suggests someone tried to ration supplies for six people, likely the hidden dwarf miners in area M14–15

note.name: M6. Sleeping Quarters
note.text:
Type: Abandoned Bunkroom Creatures: None Threat Level: None Treasure: Minor personal effects
Read Aloud:
Rows of wooden cots line this narrow cavern, their blankets haphazardly rumpled as if the occupants left in a hurry. A lantern swings slightly from a ceiling hook, its oil long depleted. Scattered between the beds are cracked mugs, scuffed boots, and the odd glint of spilled coins or misplaced tools.
DM Info:
This was a shared bunkroom for miners, now abandoned. • Bedding shows signs of sudden departure—blankets tossed, boots left behind • One cot is partially slashed open, and there are tiny blood spatters on the floor beneath it • The air carries a faint scent of rat musk and old sweat
Exploration Hooks: • DC 10 Perception: Under one cot is a small wooden dice box carved with a dwarven clan symbol—contents missing. • DC 13 Investigation: A pair of boots has a concealed heel with 4 gp tucked inside. • Optional Rumor Hook: A scrawled message under one bedframe reads in Common: “Zeleen promised peace. Liars wear faces like ours.

note.name: M7. Gold Storage
note.text:
Read-Aloud: A narrow corridor opens into a roughly carved chamber that smells faintly of sweat and dust. Against the back wall sits a wide wooden bin, its interior smeared with traces of gold dust. Two wheelbarrows lean against a stack of old crates nearby, their iron rims chipped and worn with use.
DM Notes: This chamber once served as the primary drop-off point for ore-bearing carts. Now, it’s eerily quiet—empty of both treasure and miners. Footprints crisscross the floor, some booted and others distinctly rat-like, suggesting both wererat and human activity. A few mining tools—worn picks, shovels, and gloves—are scattered about, along with broken boards from discarded crates.
Exploration Opportunities: • Investigation (DC 10): Reveals a smudged tally board detailing recent gold extractions. The most recent entries are signed “Z.V.” (Zeleen Varnaster). • Hidden Find (DC 15 Perception): A crack beneath the gold bin contains a half-eaten hardtack biscuit and a small gold nugget worth 15 gp—likely dropped by a careless wererat

note.name: M8. Equipment Storage
note.text:
Read-Aloud: This side room smells faintly of oil and rust. Stacked neatly along the stone walls are racks of pickaxes, shovels, sledgehammers, and wheeled carts. A pair of thick leather gloves lies abandoned on the floor, next to a smashed lantern.
DM Notes: Despite the clutter, the room is mostly organized—evidence that the miners maintained it before the wererat incursion. Now, the tools are idle, though the gang occasionally sneaks in to make it look like business continues.
Exploration Opportunities: • Usefulness: Adventurers can freely take mining tools or repurpose the wheelbarrows. • DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation): A hidden panel beneath a rack of tools conceals a faded symbol of the Emerald Enclave, carved by a miner who once served them. It’s an old prayer for strength and protection underground. • DC 10 Religion: Identifies a lucky token hanging on a peg—a small pendant engraved with Chauntea’s symbol, likely left behind by a pious worker

note.name: M9. Dead End
note.text:
Read-Aloud: This tunnel narrows as it slopes gently downward before abruptly ending in a jagged wall of collapsed stone. A rank smell of blood and decay lingers in the still air. Slumped against the rock is the withered corpse of a human miner, his fingers curled around the handle of a rusted pickaxe.
DM Notes: The miner was stabbed by a wererat weeks ago after uncovering a small, promising gold vein and refusing to share it. His killer left him here, and his body has been gnawed by rats. This somber spot hints at the betrayal festering beneath the Whiskered Gang’s truce. • Inspection (DC 12 Medicine): Reveals stab wounds too precise for a mining accident—confirming the attack was deliberate. • Clue (DC 10 Investigation): A smear of dried blood leads back up the tunnel, suggesting the miner tried to crawl away. • Treasure: Inside the miner’s vest is a note tucked in an oilskin pouch, never delivered: “Zeleen is not who she says she is. Watch the shadows in the southwest den. —F.” Also found is a silver coin pressed with the symbol of Lathander, worn smooth from years of handling—a keepsake of hope

note.name: M10. Overseer's Office
note.text:
Read-Aloud: The wooden door creaks open to reveal a small, ransacked office. A desk has been shoved roughly to one side, its drawers open and papers strewn across the floor. A single cot lies overturned beside an empty chest. Faint claw marks mar the walls, and a broken oil lamp stains the floor with a dark, pungent smear.
DM Notes: This was once the domain of the previous overseer, who fled after the wererats invaded. Zeleen Varnaster likely tore the place apart looking for valuables or incriminating documents. The wererats haven’t bothered restoring order, using the space instead as a dumping ground for broken gear.
Exploration Opportunities: • DC 10 Investigation: Unearths a satchel stuffed into the bottom of the empty chest. Inside: a cracked ledger, two gold teeth, and an unsigned contract between the Neverwinter Mining Consortium and a Harper intermediary—proof of distant Harper interest in the mine’s security. • DC 12 Arcana: The lamp oil mixed with rat fur triggers faint transmutation traces—Zeleen may have been experimenting with partial shapeshifting magic here. • Treasure: Hidden in the desk leg’s hollow (DC 14 Perception) is a vial of Dust of Dryness—a minor magical item originally gifted to the overseer by a grateful dwarven supplier

note.name: M11. Carrion Crawler
note.text:
Read-Aloud: A sharp, metallic stench wafts from the tunnel ahead. The air grows damp and foul, and pale smears of slime streak across the stone walls. Above, the shadows conceal movement—a grotesque, many-legged creature clings to the ceiling, its tentacles twitching hungrily.
DM Notes: A carrion crawler has made this high, narrow tunnel its lair. Drawn by the scent of death from previous mine skirmishes, it slithered in from the wilderness and now guards the upper pass like a grotesque sentinel. It waits halfway along the tunnel, poised above where the narrow ceiling dips. • Creature Behavior: The crawler prefers to ambush. It attacks only if a creature gets within 10 feet or if it’s disturbed by loud noise. • Vertical Path: The tunnel’s north exit climbs 20 feet up a jagged incline. Characters may scale the slope with a successful DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check. Failure results in a fall and 1d6 bludgeoning damage. • Light: Dim natural light filters in from the upper entrance, casting the tunnel in flickering shadows—perfect cover for the lurking crawler. • Clue: The south door leading into this tunnel is heavily scratched and battered. A successful DC 12 Intelligence (Nature) check reveals the marks as carrion crawler tentacle gouges.
Tactical Note: If the party enters from below, describe the echo of their footsteps and the cold slime dripping from above just before the attack. If they come from the upper slope, allow a DC 14 Perception check to spot the crawler before combat begins.
Treasure: Hidden in a niche near the upper end of the tunnel (DC 13 Investigation) is the skeletal hand of a long-dead scout clutching a cracked Harper badge and a potion of healing (2d4 + 2 HP)

note.name: M12. Sleeping Quarters
note.text:
Read-Aloud: This chamber smells faintly of oil and unwashed bodies. Six wooden cots line the walls in orderly rows, each covered with threadbare wool blankets. A few boots and dented helmets are scattered across the stone floor. One cot has been slashed open, its stuffing leaking like spilled grain.
DM Notes: These were the original miners’ quarters. The wererats have claimed them but rarely use them, preferring to sleep near the central den (M4). The state of disrepair shows that this section has been ignored for some time.
Exploration Opportunities: • DC 10 Investigation: One cot has a journal hidden in the mattress, scrawled in Dwarvish. The entries describe the onset of tension in the mine, mentions of “shifting shadows,” and suspicions that not all miners were human. • DC 12 Religion: A small wooden holy symbol of Chauntea (goddess of agriculture and toil) is tucked under one pillow—a sign of quiet faith clung to during darker times. • DC 13 Perception: One blanket, when shaken out, rustles oddly. Sewn into the hem is a tiny velvet pouch containing 1d6 moonstones (50 gp each), likely stashed by a fearful miner who never returned

note.name: M13. Rat-Infested Cave
note.text:
Read-Aloud: A sour stench clings to the stagnant air. The door creaks open to reveal a dark, narrow chamber riddled with gnawed bones, shredded sacks, and piles of refuse. Red eyes glint from the shadows, followed by the sudden, twitching movement of sleek bodies.
DM Notes: This area is infested with five giant rats. They were once trained by the wererats but have become increasingly feral, feeding on scraps and carrion. They immediately attack any intruders out of territorial instinct. • Ambush Setup: The rats lurk in refuse piles, granting them half cover until they strike. Unless a character succeeds on a DC 14 Perception check, the rats get a surprise round. • Sound: A faint squeaking and scratching might be heard from this room while passing (DC 10 Perception). • Visual Detail: One of the refuse piles holds what appears to be a gnawed boot—still attached to a severed foot, half-covered in slime.
Exploration Opportunities: • Searching the refuse (DC 13 Investigation) reveals: • A rusted dagger with a Harper insignia etched into the hilt. • A silver locket containing a miniature painted portrait of a dwarven woman (worth 25 gp). • A bloody mining logbook detailing warnings from a dwarf named Braum Stoneshield about “rat-eyed men.

note.name: M14–M15. Miners' Retreat
note.text:
Read-Aloud (approaching the door): From beyond the door, you hear muffled voices in Dwarvish—low, tense, and grumbling. The smell of soot and stale food wafts through the cracks. One voice barks a warning: “You open that door, you best not be a rat.”
Read-Aloud (entering): Inside, a modest chamber glows with the flicker of an oil lamp. Five dwarves—grimy, tired, and heavily bearded—stand ready with pickaxes and makeshift spears. Bedrolls, ration tins, and scattered supplies cover the stone floor.
DM Notes: These two chambers serve as a hidden refuge for five dwarf miners (use commoner stat blocks). They speak both Common and Dwarvish, and they’re desperate, proud, and stubborn. • Mood & Tension: The dwarves don’t trust easily. Their leader, Gilda Stoneshield, is fierce-eyed with a braided silver beard and an old Emerald Enclave charm around her neck (she’s a former sympathizer). • They refuse to surrender the mine and have vowed to “outlast the whiskered devils.” They are unaware of Zeleen’s full numbers or duplicity. • The dwarves are starving, but they won’t leave unless offered direct help or a clear plan of retaliation against the wererats.
Exploration Interactions: • Diplomacy or Faction Recognition: • A character who invokes the Emerald Enclave, Harpers, or speaks Dwarvish with respectful tone gains advantage on Persuasion checks. • A successful DC 12 Charisma (Persuasion) check convinces Gilda to share tactical insights about wererat movement and numbers. • Food Offering: If the party shares food or leads them to the storeroom (M5), they become friendlier and may aid in minor ways.
Flavor Details: • Gilda’s Quip: “If you’re here to evict rats, bless ya. If you’re here to trade cheese, get out.” • One dwarf, named Thurn, scribbles bad poetry in charcoal on the wall. One stanza reads: “Ten graves dug, ten friends gone, The rats crawl in, we hold ‘til dawn.”
Names: Gilda Stoneshield, Brokk Ironbite, Dannik Stoutarm, Norra Emberbrew, and Thurn

note.name: M16. Graveyard
note.text:
Read-Aloud: You step into an open cavern where the air feels still—unnaturally so. A ring of shallow graves marks the ground, each mound crowned with a miner’s pick thrust into the earth like a crude headstone. No names, no carvings. Just the solemn steel of the tools they once wielded.
A faint, metallic tang lingers in the cold air, as if the mountain remembers blood.
DM Notes: This solemn chamber holds the resting place of ten fallen miners—victims of the wererat invasion. The graveyard was made hastily and without ceremony, but with a miner’s reverence. Each grave has a pickaxe planted upright, some bent or rusted, others clean and polished. • Emotionally Charged Space: The dwarves in areas M14–15 speak of this chamber with hushed tones. Gilda Stoneshield refers to it as “the circle of the fallen.” • Divine Magic & Reverence: • A character casting detect magic senses a faint, lingering aura of necromancy, not harmful but residual—left from a failed ritual attempt to raise one of the fallen. Zeleen may have tried and failed to turn a body. • Clerics or followers of Moradin, Selûne, or Kelemvor may feel a subtle pull to offer prayer here. Doing so grants inspiration to one party member as the souls of the dead approve. • Burial Clue: A successful DC 13 Investigation check uncovers that one pickaxe has a carved rune near the hilt. It reads in Dwarvish: “Tharum of Clan Axebright – may your spark guide the gold.”
Exploration Opportunities: • DC 15 Religion or History Check: Identifies the grave marker style as traditional to Neverwinter mining guilds. • Offering Ritual: Spending 10 minutes to consecrate the space with a prayer or a symbolic token (e.g. a coin, a candle, a poem) calms the spirits, preventing any future necrotic effects from rituals cast here. • Optional Hook: • If your players enjoy deeper lore, one grave (Tharum’s) holds an amulet of Moradin, a simple holy symbol that grants the wearer a once-per-day Bless spell (DM’s discretion if you’d like to include it). • Alternatively, the spirit of Tharum may appear in a dream or a commune-style vision later, warning of Zeleen’s future plans.
Optional Quip (from a dwarf or Don-Jon):
“No names. Just steel and silence. That’s how miners mark their own.” —Gilda Stoneshiel

note.name: Wrapping Up
note.text:
1. Quest Objectives Review
Original Quest Goal: Escort Don-Jon Raskin safely to the mine and deal with the threat (unbeknownst to the PCs, the Whiskered Gang of wererats).
Player Choices May Include: • Fighting and defeating the wererats (including Zeleen). • Negotiating a truce or evacuation. • Discovering the dwarf miners and siding with them. • Leaving Don-Jon to handle it himself (possibly resulting in him being turned into a wererat). • Driving off or slaying the carrion crawler in the upper tunnel.
2. Outcomes & Resolution Options
A. Wererats Defeated • Don-Jon declares the mine safe and begins organizing the remaining dwarf miners. • He insists the party takes a cut of the gold ore found in M4. • Zeleen’s body may contain a personal token (necklace, journal, or a Zhentarim contact scroll if you want to link to bigger factions). • The dwarves celebrate, and a minor NPC may offer a rumor or future hook (e.g., “Some of these rats mentioned a shrine near Conyberry…”).
B. Peaceful Resolution / Truce • Zeleen feigns agreement, but her promises are dubious. She might send spies after the party later. • Don-Jon is frustrated but honors the party’s decision if they insist. • You can foreshadow future betrayal or factional consequences (e.g., Emerald Enclave hearing about “pestilence left to fester”). • Party still receives some treasure and the 100gp reward.
C. Don-Jon Turned • If the party leaves Don-Jon and he’s turned, they might later hear strange rumors from returning miners: • “He’s never seen in the daylight anymore.” • “The mine’s production suddenly increased, but no one ever comes out.” • Could lead to a return quest to investigate and purge the mine, now filled with more wererats and dark experiments
3. Follow-Up Hooks • Zeleen’s revenge (if she escaped or the party let her go). • Shrine of Savras mentioned by the wererats. • Faction fallout: If the party allowed the wererats to remain, local factions (Emerald Enclave, Harpers) may object. • Rumors of Cryovain continue to swirl

npc.label: Vyldara
npc.name: Banshee
npc.resist: acid, fire, lightning, thunder; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks
npc.conditionImmune: charmed, exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained
npc.text:
Quip (Upon sighting intruders): “They left me. Sealed me in. And now— you have come to share their fate!”
Backstory: Vyldara was a moon elf ambassador who sought to spark rebellion among the dwarves of Axeholm, hoping to turn their fortress to her cause. When her manipulations were uncovered, she was imprisoned, left to await elven emissaries. But impatience turned to violence—she murdered her guards and was cut down by dwarven axes. Her spirit lingered in torment, rising as a banshee to haunt the fortress, consumed by betrayal and wrath.
Motivations: Vyldara sees the living as violators of her unquiet tomb. She seeks revenge against the dwarves who imprisoned and killed her, and despises adventurers who dare tread her halls. She won’t leave Axeholm—but she will destroy any who trespass within it

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 23, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 52

trait.name: Detect Life
trait.text: The banshee can magically sense the presence of living creatures up to 5 miles away. She knows the general direction they're in but not their exact locations.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
trait.text: The banshee can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. She takes 5 (1d10) force damage if she ends her turn inside an object.

action.name: Corrupting Touch
action.text: Melee Spell Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 12 (3d6+2) necrotic damage.

action.name: Horrifying Visage
action.text: Each non-undead creature within 60 ft. of the banshee that can see her must succeed on a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened for 1 minute. A frightened target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if the banshee is within line of sight, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to the banshee's Horrifying Visage for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Wail (1/Day)
action.text: The banshee releases a mournful wail, provided that she isn't in sunlight. This wail has no effect on constructs and undead. All other creatures within 30 ft. of her that can hear her must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature drops to 0 hit points. On a success, a creature takes 10 (3d6) psychic damage. The woeful banshee is a spiteful creature formed from the spirit of a female elf. Its face is wreathed in a wild tangle of hair, its body clad in wispy rags that flutter and stream around it.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 284, Lost Laboratory of Kwalish p. 48, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 63

action.name: Blood Drain
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 5 (1d4+3) piercing damage, and the stirge attaches to the target. While attached, the stirge doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of the stirge's turns, the target loses 5 (1d4+3) hit points due to blood loss. The stirge can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement. It does so after it drains 10 hit points of blood from the target or the target dies. A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the stirge.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 328, Player's Handbook p. 306, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 58

trait.name: Spider Climb
trait.text: The spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Web Sense
trait.text: While in contact with a web, the spider knows the exact location of any other creature in contact with the same web.

trait.name: Web Walker
trait.text: The spider ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 7 (1d8+3) piercing damage, and the target must make a DC 11 Constitution saving throw, taking 9 (2d8) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the poison damage reduces the target to 0 hit points, the target is stable but poisoned for 1 hour, even after regaining hit points, and is paralyzed while poisoned in this way.

action.name: Web (Recharge 5-6)
action.text: Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, range 30/60 ft., one creature. Hit: The target is restrained by webbing. As an action, the restrained target can make a DC 12 Strength check, bursting the webbing on a success. The webbing can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 10; hp 5; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage).

item.name: Gold ring Opens A29 Vault
item.text: Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 135

item.name: Holy Symbol (Moradin)
item.text:
A holy symbol is a representation of a god or pantheon
A cleric or paladin can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus, using it in place of any material components which do not list a cost. To use the symbol in this way, the caster must hold it in hand, wear it visibly, or bear it on a shield.
Source: Player's Handbook, page 151

item.name: Potion of healing
item.text: A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains 2d4 + 2 hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.

item.name: Shield
item.text:
A shield is made from wood or metal and is carried in one hand. Wielding a shield increases your Armor Class by 2. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 144

item.name: Dread Helm
item.text:
This fearsome steel helm makes your eyes glow red while you wear it.
Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything p. 137

item.name: Gauntlets of Ogre Power
item.text:
Your Strength score is 19 while you wear these gauntlets. They have no effect on you if your Strength is 19 or higher without them.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 171

note.name: Overview
note.text:
Adventure Tier: Designed for characters of 4th level, though clever and cautious 3rd-level adventurers can survive. Suitable for heroes who’ve proven themselves and now face something darker, older, and more haunted than before.
Tone & Theme: Axeholm is a claustrophobic dwarven fortress steeped in grief, undeath, and divine abandonment. There are no living enemies here—only lingering pain, restless spirits, and a banshee’s unfulfilled anguish. This is an eerie delve into history, faith, and the cost of pride.
Summary for DM Quick Reference: • Background: Once a proud dwarven citadel, Axeholm was sealed a century ago after a plague drove its inhabitants to madness and undeath. The surviving dwarves locked the gates and left it to rot. Now, its halls are haunted by the spirits of those who died in confusion, fear, or rage. The banshee Vyldara, a fallen war priestess of Shar (formerly a devout of Selûne), still mourns the silence of her goddess. • Goal: Provide the adventurers with a fortified base (once cleansed), and foreshadow the deeper, divine conflicts affecting Faerûn’s spiritual balance. Encourage themes of light vs shadow, memory vs oblivion, and sacrifice. • How to Run It: • Emphasize atmosphere: flickering torchlight, cold echoing halls, whispers in Dwarvish no one understands. • Use haunting flashbacks: spectral scenes of dwarves arguing, priests weeping at altars, or empty suits of armor turning their heads. • Let the players interact with the past: faint echoes, scrawled notes, a shrine to Selûne long since dark.
Key Factions & Forces
Undead Spirits: • Specters of dwarves slain in confusion and fear. • Poltergeists throwing suits of armor at intruders. • Haunted armor still marching in endless patrol.
Vyldara the Banshee: • Former priestess of Selûne, turned to Shar in despair when her prayers went unanswered. • Lair: The Sanctum of Mourning, a once-sacred chamber defiled by her transformation. • Motivation: Longs for peace but is blinded by grief and shame. May be calmed by a Selûnite relic, prayer, or a character’s presence (especially Nsyldam).
Echoes & Remnants: • Dwarven shrines to Moradin, Clangeddin, and Berronar Truesilver stand abandoned, weeping with salt-streaks in the stone. • Ghostly arguments play in silence across certain chambers, visible but not audible—until a character succeeds on a Wisdom (Religion) or Arcana check.
What to Prep:
Monsters: • 4–6 Specters (individually or in pairs). • 2 Animated Armors, possibly enhanced with cold or necrotic effects. • 1 Banshee (Vyldara). • 1–2 Poltergeists or Wraiths (optional). • Possible Undead Dwarven Warriors (reskinned skeletons or wights).
Magic/Important Treasure: • Selûnite Moonstone Icon (calms Vyldara for one turn or dispels one specter with radiant light). • +1 Dwarven War Axe, formerly belonging to the fortress commander. • Blessed Water Basin – can be used to turn undead for one encounter. • Commander’s Logbook – contains tactical history and a possible lead on another dwarven ruin. • Gem-encrusted Lockbox – trapped, but contains 150 gp in varied coins and 3 art objects (worth 50 gp each).
Notable NPCs (Ghostly or Flashback)
Vyldara Vrenn, the Banshee • Visual: Flowing silvery hair that turns to smoke at the ends. Hollow eyes that flicker between Selûne’s soft blue and Shar’s violet shadow. • Quip: “She would not answer me. So I screamed—and only the dark replied.”
Commander Bolgrin Ironsoul (flashback or vision) • Visual: Missing an eye, wears a shattered breastplate. • Quip: “We seal it behind us. We do not speak of what we did.”
Ties to the Party • Nsyldam: Vyldara’s fall mirrors Nsyldam’s struggle. Her presence or prayer may provoke a reaction, dialogue, or even a test of faith. • Yote: Might sense Quori influence here—spirits murmuring messages twisted by grief and darkness. • Cromwell: May uncover journal entries about betrayal or exile tied to fortress politics. • Riverine: Ghostly dwarves might acknowledge her as “disciplined like we were.” One may call her “Shield Sister.”

note.name: Arrival
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Thrust from the base of a brooding, storm-washed mountain rises the gray maw of Axeholm. Dark and silent, a fifteen-foot-wide tunnel leads inward, flanked by forty-foot bulwarks of seamless stone. An iron portcullis—corroded by time and rain—hangs like a jaw of rusted teeth, barring entry. Arrow slits stare down like hollow eyes, empty and watching. There is no sound but the distant wind and the slow, mournful drip of water from stone.
DM Notes: • The fortress looks abandoned, but tension lingers in the air—a deep, unsettling stillness, as if the mountain holds its breath. • The portcullis is too heavy to lift unaided. Its bars are narrow, too close even for Small characters to squeeze through. • A Small character can, however, squeeze through an arrow slit into A2 or A3 with a successful DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. • The winches inside A2 and A3 can raise the gate 5 feet per DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check. • Alternatively, with a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check, characters can spot accessible chimneys leading to A21 and A23. • Scaling the mountain requires a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check. Characters with climbing gear gain advantage. • Chimneys are tight but passable. Failing a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check while descending means a 20-foot fall (2d6 bludgeoning damage).
Exploration Hooks: • Ash and wind have eroded carvings near the entry—a long-forgotten inscription barely legible: “In honor and stone, we endure.” • The rusted bars of the portcullis are cool to the touch but emit a strange hum if pressed with a holy symbol of Moradin. • A successful DC 13 Intelligence (History or Religion) check recalls Axeholm was once a stronghold of Moradin-worshipping dwarves who mysteriously vanished

note.name: A1 – Outer Gauntlet
note.text:
You step into a darkened corridor of carved stone. The walls rise up like canyon faces, lined with narrow arrow slits, and the ceiling is littered with soot-stained holes—murder holes where hot oil once poured. The air is thick with ancient dust and the scent of iron and rot. Ahead, a pair of sturdy oak double doors bars further entry, their iron bands rusted but strong.
DM Notes: • The murder holes above are nonfunctional but ominous. • The double doors to the south are barred shut from the inside. Characters can break them down, which takes: • 1 hour for one character, or less time with more characters assisting. • Smashing through the doors alerts all dwarf ghouls in the fortress, which gather in A4 (Mustering Hall). • The initial undead encounter here includes: • 3 dwarf ghouls plus 3 regular ghouls per party member (excluding sidekicks). • This is a major threshold fight—if these ghouls are killed, the fortress is clear of further ghoul threats.
Tactical Notes: • The narrowness of the space may lead players to creative tactics (spells through arrow slits, covering retreat, etc.). • Dwarf ghouls use rusted axes, and still wear scraps of their old clan armor.
Exploration Interactions: • Scattered bones and claw marks on the stone hint at a past siege that ended in horror. • A cracked dwarven helmet, its faceplate crushed inward, sits near one slit. Inside is a petrified strip of beard braid—clearly once ceremonial

note.name: A2 – Western Bulwark
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Dim light filters in through narrow arrow slits carved in the fortress’s thick stone walls. Seven massive ballistas, silent sentinels of a forgotten age, point outward, their bolts coated in dust. A heavy iron winch sits embedded in the wall, its gears rusted and stiff with age. A stone staircase hugs the wall to the north, curling upward into shadow.
DM Notes: • The ballistas are dwarven in design, each built to defend the gate with deadly precision. Each has five bolts left, but the mechanisms creak loudly when aimed. • The winch mechanism controls the portcullis in area A1. A character must succeed on a DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check to crank it upward by 5 feet per success. Two successful checks fully open the portcullis. • The staircase leads to A22 (Upper Bastion).
Exploration Finds: • One ballista still has a bolt loaded and ready. A character succeeding on a DC 13 Investigation check notices that the bolt is etched with dwarven runes meaning “To Break the Storm.” This was a ceremonial bolt used to fire during festivals honoring Moradin

note.name: A3 – Eastern Bulwark
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
A twin to the western bulwark, this room holds seven massive ballistas aimed out through narrow arrow slits. The room smells of old oil and stale stone. A single winch, half-sunken into the floor and wall, clings to its iron chains like a sentinel long at rest. A staircase climbs toward a darkened upper floor.
DM Notes: • Mechanically identical to A2. This winch also controls the portcullis in area A1; either winch can operate it. • The stairway leads to A23 (West Upper Barracks).
Exploration Finds: • Characters who examine the walls notice scratched carvings: dwarven names. These were the names of the ballista teams once stationed here. One inscription reads, “Last fire, for Axeholm.

note.name: A4 – Mustering Hall
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Dust chokes the air of this vast chamber. A vaulted ceiling soars forty feet above, held aloft by four thick pillars etched with faded dwarven battle scenes. Heavy double doors stand on each wall beyond the entry. Arrow slits pierce the upper north and south walls, and a balcony juts from the eastern wall twenty feet up, its edge crumbled with age.
DM Notes: • This is the central hub of the lower fortress. • If the party bashed open the entry doors in A1, the gathered dwarf ghouls (3 base + 3 per party member) are waiting here to ambush them. • If combat begins here, the sound echoes up the halls, alerting any undead in A14, A19, or A26 within 1d4 rounds unless silenced or concealed. • The balcony above connects to A25, and stairs from A22 also descend into this space.
Exploration Finds: • Dust trails on the ground show where bodies were dragged recently—likely by ghouls. A DC 14 Survival check reveals the claw marks and shuffling drag lines typical of undead movement. • One of the pillars has a recess with a prayer carved into it: “Moradin, strike down the cursed breath that haunts this hall.”
A5. West Hall
Read-Aloud Text:
The corridor reeks of rot. Broken bits of armor litter the ground—dented helms, sundered gauntlets, and blades dulled by age and blood. Gnawed bones lie scattered like discarded kindling. You sense the stench of something not long dead. A hiss slithers out from the dark ahead.
DM Notes: • This hall contains one ghoul per party member. They are hidden among the debris and launch an ambush if characters are not being stealthy. • The ghouls will attempt to cut off retreat and fight savagely unless turned or frightened.
Exploration Finds: • A dwarf skeleton holds a cracked drinking horn with the name “Thurgan Stonebind” engraved. Inside is a shriveled parchment: “May I rest in Moradin’s forge.” • A successful DC 12 Religion check reveals Thurgan was once a known defender of Axeholm

note.name: A5 – West Hall
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The corridor reeks of rot. Broken bits of armor litter the ground—dented helms, sundered gauntlets, and blades dulled by age and blood. Gnawed bones lie scattered like discarded kindling. You sense the stench of something not long dead. A hiss slithers out from the dark ahead.
DM Notes: • This hall contains one ghoul per party member. They are hidden among the debris and launch an ambush if characters are not being stealthy. • The ghouls will attempt to cut off retreat and fight savagely unless turned or frightened.
Exploration Finds: • A dwarf skeleton holds a cracked drinking horn with the name “Thurgan Stonebind” engraved. Inside is a shriveled parchment: “May I rest in Moradin’s forge.” • A successful DC 12 Religion check reveals Thurgan was once a known defender of Axeholm

note.name: A6 – Armory
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The heavy door creaks as it opens into a long, narrow chamber. Rows of empty stone racks line the walls, each one chiseled with craftsmanship worthy of dwarven pride. Mannequins carved from oak stand silently, their arms outstretched like forgotten sentinels, but their armor is long gone. Iron hooks dangle from the walls where shields once hung, and a faint impression of soot and polish still marks the floor.
DM Notes: • The dwarves stripped the armory clean before fleeing Axeholm. • There is no combat encounter here, but the room offers a stark reminder of how swiftly a place of strength can become barren. • Characters inspecting the racks with a DC 10 Investigation check can note that the weapons were removed methodically, not in a panic.
Exploration Finds: • A secret compartment in one rack (DC 15 Perception) contains a rusted but serviceable dwarven whetstone engraved with the words “Bite true, Oathkeeper.” It grants advantage on one use of the mending spell or smith’s tools to repair a blade. • A faded parchment tucked behind a hook reads in Dwarvish: “For our children’s blades, may they never be needed.

note.name: A7 – Main Barracks
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
A sour draft wafts through this vast, silent hall. Dozens of wooden cots lie abandoned in rows, the straw within them moldering or torn. Tattered blankets cling to frames like cobwebs, and two cold fireplaces stand dark and soot-choked at either end of the room. The air smells faintly of mildew and regret. Deep grooves in the floor mark where footlockers once stood, long since taken.
DM Notes: • This space was the sleeping quarters for the fortress garrison. • No enemies lurk here, but this area can build tension through sensory detail and the lingering presence of the past. • The fireplaces rise 120 feet through the mountain but are now clogged with rubble.
Exploration Finds: • One cot still bears a carved nameplate at its foot: “Sergeant Krun Draghorn”. Tucked beneath the mattress (DC 13 Investigation) is a carved wooden holy symbol of Clangeddin Silverbeard—a dwarven deity of war. • A moldy journal (illegible without comprehend languages or mending) contains passages reflecting fear of the banshee’s presence and uncertainty over the fortress’s future

note.name: A8 – Privies
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
A narrow passage leads to a cramped chamber behind thick woolen curtains, now torn and yellowed with age. The acrid stench of rot lingers faintly in the air. Behind the curtains, you find crude wooden benches set above long-forgotten chutes descending into darkness.
DM Notes: • Three individual privies, unused for decades. • Nothing of value or danger resides here unless the party insists on an extremely thorough search.
Exploration Finds (Optional Flavor): • One character with a particularly high passive Perception may notice a rat skull or gnawed finger bone stuck between floorboards. • A DC 15 Survival check reveals the chutes descend toward the eastern tunnels (just east of A10), though they are too narrow for any creature larger than Tiny to descend safely

note.name: A9 – Smithy (Stirge)
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Two massive hearths line the far wall, their stones blackened with years of soot. A pair of heavy anvils stand sentinel before them, rusted but resolute. Hammers, tongs, and broken tongs litter the ground. The hearth to the south groans faintly as a fluttering sound echoes from within its shadowed chimney.
DM Notes: • A single stirge lurks high up in the southernmost chimney (200 feet tall). • If anyone shines a light into the hearth or investigates loudly, the stirge panics and attacks the nearest creature.
Combat: • The stirge is not aggressive unless provoked, and it flees after being injured unless cornered. • Creative players may scare it off or trap it with spells or stealth.
Exploration Finds: • Beneath the southern anvil is a small smith’s mark carved into the floor—an old dwarven rune for “Endure.” • A DC 12 Arcana or History check reveals this smithy once produced armor for Axeholm’s elite

note.name: A10 – Tool Storage
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
This rectangular room smells faintly of iron and oil. Long wooden racks line the walls, their pegs burdened with smithing tools—hammers, rasps, chisels, and pliers—each showing signs of wear but still serviceable. Dust thickens the air, disturbed only by your presence.
DM Notes: • The tools are dull with age but functionally intact. • There are no enemies or traps here. • If the party has a smith or someone proficient in smith’s tools, this room offers crafting opportunities.
Exploration Finds: • A DC 14 Investigation check reveals a pair of artificer’s tongs hidden behind a loose stone (worth 10 gp to a craftsman or enchanter). • A tiny engraving of Mystra’s symbol (a starburst) lies on the underside of one tool. This implies one of the smiths here once served a magical patron or worked on enchanted arms

note.name: A11 – Inner Gauntlet
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The corridor ahead is narrow and silent, hemmed in by walls of seamless stone. Four arrow slits—two on each side—are carved into the stone at chest height, allowing a commanding view of the passage. Dust lies thick on the floor, and old boot prints—some humanoid, some not—are frozen in it like ghosts of the past.
DM Notes: • This is a defensive bottleneck leading into A14, the Throne Room. • The arrow slits once allowed defenders to rain death on invaders, but the guard posts behind them (A12 and A13) are now quiet. • If the ghouls from A14 or A26 are still alive and hear movement in this hall, they might position themselves to ambush characters from multiple sides.
Exploration Finds: • A DC 13 Perception check spots a dried smear of blood trailing beneath one slit—possibly from a ghoul clawing its way through. • Characters who listen carefully (DC 10 Perception) may hear faint skittering from the east (A13) or distant snarling

note.name: A12 – West Guard Post
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
You enter a narrow chamber with two enormous ballistas positioned behind arrow slits in the east wall. The weapons, now coated in dust, still bear carved runes of Moradin along their frames. Five thick, iron-tipped bolts lie stacked beside each machine. Dust covers the floor, but it’s undisturbed—no signs of motion or recent life.
DM Notes: • This post is defensively positioned to guard the inner hall. • The ballistas are in good condition and usable. If characters set up an ambush here, allow for clever use of the ballistas. • If combat erupts nearby, characters stationed here gain three-quarters cover from the slits.
Ballista Stats (reminder): • Ranged Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, range 120/480 ft., one target. • Hit: 16 (3d10) piercing damage. • Requires 3 actions (1 to load, 1 to aim, 1 to fire); a team of characters can split this up over turns.
Exploration Finds: • A DC 12 History or Religion check identifies the Moradin script as a blessing: “Strike true, in the Father’s name.” • A hidden drawer inside the weapon rack (DC 14 Investigation) contains an old dwarven maintenance kit (oil, stone polish, rag, chisel) worth 5 gp and sacred to dwarven artisans

note.name: A13 – East Guard Post
note.text:
Read Aloud:
Broken armor lies scattered across the cold stone floor of this watchroom. A dull gleam reflects off a rusted battleaxe, and gnawed bones peek from beneath torn chainmail. Two long-dormant ballistas face outward through narrow arrow slits in the west wall, coated in a fine veil of dust. The silence here feels thick—as if it were waiting.
DM Notes: • This guard post once served as a final defense against attackers breaching the outer gauntlet (A1). It is now the site of a grim battle long past. • Evidence of struggle: The remains are those of two dwarf guards who were cornered and killed by ghouls. Bits of armor, rusted weapons, and shattered shields remain. • Ballistas: Two operational ballistas (each loaded with 5 bolts) point west through slits into area A1. They are usable with three actions per shot (load, aim, fire). • Exploration Hooks: • A successful DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check reveals a rusty iron locket beneath a shattered helm. Inside is a miniature sketch of a dwarven child and the inscription “Thrain, wait for me.” (Flavor only, or potential connection to future NPCs or lore). • A DC 12 Wisdom (Perception) check notices faint scratch marks along the stone leading to the fireplace—evidence that one guard tried to flee or climb

note.name: A14 – Throne Room
note.text:
Read Aloud:
The stench of death thickens as you enter this wide, dust-choked hall. Pillars of pale stone rise to the dark ceiling like silent sentinels, casting long shadows in the gloom. At the far end, an alcove frames a raised limestone throne, its armrests shaped like angular dwarven gauntlets. Flanking it are two statues of stern dwarf warriors carved from black granite. A wide, soot-blackened fireplace yawns behind the throne, its interior stained with age and sorrow. Something feels wrong here. A sense of presence—hungry, watching, close.
DM Notes: • The throne room was once Axeholm’s heart, where the castellan ruled and heard petitions. Now, it is a haunt of foul undeath. • Ghoul of the Castellan: Hiding behind the throne is the undead dwarf castellan, now a ghoul with 40 HP and a pungent rotting stench. • A DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals the ghoul’s presence before it attacks. • If the throne is approached or inspected, the ghoul lets out a shriek and attacks. • This shriek alerts the ghouls in A26, who climb down through the chimney and join the fight after the first round of combat. This group includes two soot-covered ghouls plus one per PC (not counting sidekicks). They act on the same initiative count as the castellan. • Treasure: • The castellan wears a gold signet ring bearing the Axeholm crest—a dwarven gauntlet clutching a handaxe. It’s worth 5 gp and unlocks the secret chest in area A29. • One of the castellan’s boots contains a folded note in Dwarvish (DC 10 Intelligence check to read): “Vyldara will bring ruin. This place must be sealed.” • Exploration Hooks: • A player who sits on the throne hears a distant wail echo through the halls—Vyldara’s banshee shriek faintly reverberating from the upper halls. No mechanical effect, but a flavorful omen. • A DC 14 Religion check reveals the throne room once hosted sacred ceremonies honoring Moradin, now defiled by undeath

note.name: A15 – Dining Room
note.text:
Read Aloud:
The stale scent of mildew and ancient smoke lingers in this long stone hall. A 15-foot stone dining table, carved with interlocking runes and flanked by two weathered wooden benches, dominates the space. Hanging above the table, two iron chandeliers sway gently from unseen drafts, their melted candle stubs long since gone cold. To the north, a soot-stained fireplace yawns open, its stonework cracked with age. Beyond the table, tucked in an alcove to the east, you see a rough-hewn pit descending into darkness. The bones of small animals lie at the edge, gnawed and mold-covered, tossed here like refuse.
DM Notes:
This was once the mess hall for Axeholm’s garrison. The table and benches are dwarf-sized—heavy, practical, and built to last. Now, the room is quiet save for the occasional drip of moisture or creak of distant stone. • The Pit (Alcove Feature): • Descends 60 feet straight down into a refuse shaft used by the dwarves to dispose of bones and food waste. • Characters can climb up or down using abundant footholds and wall notches with a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check. • At the bottom is a pile of bones, tattered scraps of dwarven linen, and rusty utensils. The detritus is harmless, but players may fear otherwise. A great place to inject a moment of tension or horror (e.g., a bone snapping underfoot suddenly). • Optional Find: • A DC 14 Intelligence (Investigation) check at the bottom reveals a small silver fork etched with a moon rune—a personal item from Vyldara’s last meal, kept as a relic by a curious dwarf. Could act as a token to anchor Vyldara in a memory, providing a possible tool for peaceful resolution or distraction. • Exploration Hook: • One player might notice scratches on the table where someone attempted to carve a message—“Forgive her… we left too late.” The letters are shallow and incomplete, but offer a glimpse into the dwarves’ regret about imprisoning Vyldara rather than trusting diplomacy.
Atmospheric Elements: • Sound: The wind howls faintly down the chimney, sometimes sounding like a low, mournful cry. • Light: If players have no magical light source, this room is steeped in darkness except for dim light from nearby hallways. • Smell: Earthy rot mixed with soot and iron. A very faint floral trace lingers near the pit—possibly remnants of dried herbs once used to mask kitchen odors

note.name: A16 – Kitchen
note.text:
Read Aloud:
Dust hangs thick in the air of this stone-walled kitchen, the scent of rusted iron and decay clinging to the stillness. Long-cold metal stoves and stone sinks line the walls, while rows of tarnished pots and dented kettles dangle from iron hooks. A faucet carved like a dwarven face protrudes from the back wall above a deep basin. From it, a steady drip of steaming water plinks into the stone sink below, each drop echoing like a heartbeat in the silence.
DM Notes:
This was the beating heart of the fortress’s daily life—now still, but eerily intact. It evokes the suddenness of Axeholm’s fall.
Notable Features: • Hot Water Faucet: • Turning the faucet causes naturally heated water (via underground spring) to flow into the sink, still functional due to dwarven engineering. • This can be a moment of relief—or rising unease—depending on tone. • Optional twist: The sudden gurgling as the pipe activates may echo unnervingly down adjacent halls, possibly drawing unwanted attention (like a nearby ghoul). • Cooking Utensils & Equipment: • Old but functional, these include: • Meat cleavers (potential improvised weapons). • Stone spice jars labeled in Dwarvish (all empty). • A carved rolling pin with Moradin’s sigil (harmless, but symbolically powerful for dwarves). • A character who succeeds on a DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) check while searching the shelves discovers a sealed clay jar tucked behind old cookware. Inside is a chunk of lard infused with herbs—long since spoiled, but oddly still fragrant (perhaps preserved by minor dwarven magic). • Optional Exploration Find: • DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation): A crumpled kitchen ledger tucked under a butcher block records the final meal served—just days before Axeholm was abandoned. A note in the margin reads: “Guest requested elven tea again. No one trusts her.” (Refers to Vyldara, and a sign of growing unrest before her imprisonment.)
Tension Opportunities: • Sound Trap: A loose iron ladle suddenly falls from its hook and clatters to the floor. Echoes ring out down the halls—perhaps a cue for: • Nearby ghouls in A17 or A14 to stir and investigate. • Characters to pause and wonder who else might be listening. • Omen of Haunting: The basin mirror-like surface may momentarily show a reflection of someone not present—a flicker of Vyldara’s spectral form, watching from behind. Harmless, but unsettling.

note.name: A17 – East Hall in Ruins
note.text:
Read Aloud:
The hallway ahead is choked with debris—cracked flagstones, splintered beams, and fallen chunks of stone litter the passage. A faint, acrid stench creeps from the shadows ahead, growing stronger with every step. Bits of rusted armor and scattered bones peek out from under the rubble, whispering of something violent long past. The air here feels heavier, like it’s watching you.
DM Notes:
This area reflects the physical scars of the earthquake and the emotional tension of what lies beyond. The destruction makes travel slow and hints at the ghoul den (A19) nearby.
Features: • Difficult Terrain: The eastern half of the hallway is strewn with rubble. Movement is halved unless players clear debris (takes 10 minutes per 10 feet cleared). • Corpse Signs: A successful DC 13 Wisdom (Medicine) check reveals that at least three dwarves died here from slashing wounds—likely from clawed hands, not blades. Their bones are gnawed, their armor torn. • Stench Increases: Characters with a passive Perception 13 or higher notice that the smell of rot intensifies with every step toward A19. This can serve as a subtle warning of the ghoul nest just beyond.
Exploration Clues & Tension: • DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation): A hidden insignia carved into the wall—a dwarven prayer to Moradin, smeared with blood. Someone tried to consecrate the hall before death. Finding this grants inspiration to any dwarf or follower of Moradin. • Subtle Movement: A stone shifts behind the players. Perhaps a rat. Or something watching. If you want to increase pressure, a ghoul from A19 could begin creeping forward to scout (you decide if it attacks). • Spiritual Echo: For flavor, a character attuned to the divine or undead may feel a chill pass through them, as if Vyldara’s sorrow or anger stirs in response to their presence.
Summary Table:
Feature Detail Terrain Difficult due to rubble Threats Connects directly to A19 (ghoul den) Exploration Finds Prayer carved in blood, gnawed dwarven remains Tension Tools Rising stench, ominous noises, ghostly chills Checks DC 13 Medicine (cause of death), DC 15 Investigation (hidden prayer

note.name: A18 – Empty Room
note.text:
Cleared by the dwarves—emptiness breeds unease.
Read Aloud:
This square room lies eerily still, its stone walls bare and its flagstone floor untouched by anything more recent than a thick coat of dust. The air is stagnant, and your footsteps echo louder than expected—as if something long silenced now listens.
DM Notes: • Nothing remains—this room was thoroughly cleared before the dwarves fled Axeholm. • That said, the emptiness itself is unsettling, especially after the debris and bones in the hall.
Exploration Opportunities: • DC 12 Wisdom (Perception): Characters hear a distant, low hiss or snarl—a foreshadowing of the ghouls in A19. The sound reverberates strangely in this room, raising tension. • Optional Flavor – “Echo of Memory”: If you want to play into a haunting atmosphere: A character who lingers alone may briefly hear the scrape of stone on stone, or a whisper in Dwarvish: “Hold the line…” (Pure flavor—no mechanical effect, just unsettling mood.

note.name: A19 – Ghoul Den
note.text:
Read Aloud:
The stench of rot and decay becomes overpowering as you approach. The arched doorway hangs open, the wood shattered inward, and the stone floor within is slick with grime and scattered with gnawed bones. Crude claw marks rake the walls where once-carved dwarven rituals remain—figures holding censers and holy icons now scarred and desecrated. And from the darkness beyond… the sound of hissing breath and shuffling limbs.
DM Notes:
This was once a shrine to Moradin, now corrupted into a den of ghouls.
Combat Encounter: • Enemies: • 1 ghoul + 1 per party member (excluding sidekicks) • These ghouls hiss, snarl, and scrabble hungrily at the floor as the players enter. • They pursue fleeing prey into other rooms if needed. • Tactics: • Ghouls lurk in shadow, ambush-style, using the bones for partial cover. • They focus on weaker or wounded characters first.
After Combat – Exploration:
Once the ghouls are slain, characters can explore freely.
Read Aloud (Post-Battle):
The ghouls’ snarls fade into silence. The sickly stench clings to the air. Amid the scattered bones and ruined masonry, something still glimmers—a flash of platinum beneath the rubble, and a small box buried in the silt.
Treasure: • Platinum Amulet of Moradin (holy symbol): • A thin but sturdy gold chain with a platinum hammer-and-anvil amulet. • Any dwarf recognizes this immediately; others can identify it with a DC 10 Intelligence (Religion) check. • Might grant inspiration if used in prayer or ceremony later. • Steel Coffer: • Weight: 5 lb • Packed with silt. Inside: • Potion of Superior Healing • (Give the card or description to the player upon identification.)
Clues & Roleplay Hooks: • Religion Check (DC 13): Identifies this room as once a dedicated place of healing and spiritual protection. Desecrating it would have been deeply taboo. • Mystic Whisper (Optional Flavor): When the amulet is lifted from the silt, a soft wind brushes past—a blessing or a warning? • Party Connection Opportunity: If any PC has ties to Moradin, dwarves, or temples, this shrine can become a moment of reverence or recommitment

note.name: A20 – Narrow Tunnel
note.text:
Read Aloud:
A tight, rough-hewn passageway veers downward here—barely wide enough to crawl through. The tunnel is 2 feet wide, 5 feet high, and 60 feet long, its walls scraped by claw marks and smeared with a dried, brown crust that might once have been blood. The air is close and stale, filled with the scent of mildew and rot.
DM Notes:
This tunnel was dug by ghouls as a secret connection between the upper and lower levels of the fortress. It’s barely passable and very claustrophobic. • Traveling Through It: • Medium creatures must squeeze through—half movement speed, disadvantage on attack rolls and Dexterity saving throws. • Small characters can pass more easily, though still uncomfortable. • The walls and ceiling groan faintly with weight. Consider adding tension by describing loose pebbles shifting or faint skittering sounds just out of sight.
Optional Encounter: • If you want to raise the stakes, place a swarm of insects or a single ghoul in the far end, lurching toward them in tight quarters.
Exploration Finds: • DC 13 Intelligence (Nature or Survival): The claw marks are recent. One ghoul might still be using this passage—suggesting an active patrol route. • DC 15 Wisdom (Perception): Small bits of chewed cloth or a gnawed bone splinter hint that this was also used to drag prey between lairs

note.name: A21 – East Upper Barracks
note.text:
Read Aloud:
The door creaks open to reveal a room of shattered furnishings, the remains of a once orderly barracks. Splintered cots, toppled chairs, and busted footlockers lie scattered about, while a cold blackened fireplace sits on the eastern wall. A gust of damp mountain air rolls down from the chimney, carrying with it the scent of soot, ash, and the open sky.
