DM Notes: • This room was destroyed during the ghouls’ rampage, but its chimney remains open. • The chimney leads to the exterior and provides an entry/exit path per the arrival text.
Traversal: • The chimney is 20 feet tall. • DC 10 Strength (Athletics) to climb due to easy handholds. • Using gear gives advantage.
This chimney is one of two viable entry points into Axeholm for PCs who scouted alternate entrances.
Exploration Finds: • DC 12 Wisdom (Perception): • A half-burned boot inside the hearth, as if someone once tried to climb down but failed. • There’s a scorch mark on the inside wall where a fire flared up violently. • DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation): • Under one cot is a carved wooden amulet shaped like a dwarven hammer, once a good luck charm. Worth 2 gp but valuable to dwarves.
Tension Elements: • The wind moans occasionally through the chimney, sounding disturbingly like a sigh or distant whisper. • If the banshee is still active, her wails might echo faintly, unsettling those inside

note.name: A22 – Upper Bastion (Spiders)
note.text:
Read Aloud:
You step into a broad stone chamber, once a stronghold of Axeholm’s upper guard. Arrow slits along the north wall let in shafts of cold light or moonlight, depending on the hour, casting long, silver-blue shadows across the stone. Thick webs cling to the high ceiling and pillars—tangles of glistening silk that flutter with the slightest draft. Lined against a trench in the floor are three blackened cauldrons, once used to pour hot oil on invaders below. Something skitters in the dark. Then stillness. Watching.
DM Notes:
This was once a key defensive hall overseeing area A1 (the outer gauntlet). The upper bastion was overtaken by giant spiders, nesting in the southern shadows, among the ruined furnishings and webbing.
Creatures: • 3 giant spiders, plus 1 additional for each PC in the party (excluding sidekicks). • They linger in ambush, clinging to ceilings and walls. • They strike only when the group is vulnerable or begins exploring the south half of the chamber.
Features: • Arrow Slits: Face both north (mountainside) and south (into A4). • Two Fireplaces: Blackened and cold, previously used to heat cauldrons of oil. • Stone Trenches: Lead from the cauldrons to narrow slits in the floor that open into area A4 below. • Stairways: One descends west to area A2, the other east to A3.
Exploration Finds: • DC 13 Intelligence (History or Investigation): • The cauldrons were built with dwarven runes of protection—they once shimmered with fire magic when filled. • The runes are inert now, but a skilled mage might reactivate them. • DC 15 Wisdom (Perception): • Hidden in a collapsed crate near the south wall is a partially intact dwarven helmet, inscribed with the crest of Axeholm (1 gp, sentimental to dwarves). • DC 16 Survival (Spider Clues): • Sticky egg sacs line a corner—one is beginning to twitch.
Tension Clues: • The webs are fresh. • Characters who use fire may ignite a burst of webs, causing a sudden blaze (Dex save DC 12 to avoid 1d6 fire damage)

note.name: A23 – West Upper Barracks
note.text:
Read Aloud:
This dusty room smells faintly of burnt ash and aged leather. Cots, tables, and footlockers remain intact—everything still, abandoned. On the west wall, above a blackened fireplace, hangs a steel shield, polished by time but still bearing the proud crest of Axeholm: A dwarven gauntlet clutching a handaxe.
DM Notes:
This was the upper barracks for a proud dwarven unit. They likely perished or fled before the banshee’s screams overtook this part of the fortress.
Features: • Steel Shield: Nonmagical, but finely made. Worth 10 gp to a collector or 20 gp to a dwarf patriot or noble house. • Chimney Access: The fireplace connects to an accessible 20-foot chimney, which opens to the outside (entry route, see Arrival section).
Exploration: • DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation): • Inside a footlocker: a sealed envelope addressed to a “Captain Drun”, bearing a coded map of Axeholm patrol routes (player clue or historical detail). • If deciphered, it provides advantage on navigating A4, A5, and A11 (once per location). • DC 15 Wisdom (Insight): • This place wasn’t abandoned in chaos—items are packed away, suggesting a controlled retreat rather than slaughter.
Tension Boosters: • If the banshee still haunts the fortress, faint whispers swirl in the corners of this room—memories trapped in stone. • One cot has an indentation as if someone was just sitting on it… but there’s no one there

note.name: A24 – Haunted Hall
note.text:
Read Aloud:
The hall is choked with dust and silence, broken only by a soft, ever-present moan—so faint it might be your mind playing tricks. Ahead, a ghostly figure drifts through the stale air. Her silver hair sways in an invisible wind, veiling much of her face, which glows with the pale sheen of moonlight through mist. Her form flickers—a tattered gown of ancient silk, spectral arms ending in clawed fingers that trail sorrow like fog. Then her head lifts, and she screams— “GET OUT OF MY HOUSE!”
Overview: • Vyldara is the ancient spirit of a moon elf ambassador unjustly imprisoned and violently slain by the dwarves of Axeholm. • She is not an aimless haunt—she is full of rage, grief, and a belief that justice was never served. • She detects all living creatures with her Detect Life trait the moment they enter the area.
How to Play Vyldara the Banshee
Tone and Voice: • Speak in echoing, broken phrases with flickers of lucidity. • Let emotion guide her—rage, betrayal, and desperation. • Sprinkle in whispers of her past: “They chained me… in stone and shadow…” “I brought peace… they brought blades…”
Tactics: • Round 1: She uses Horrifying Visage—attempting to paralyze or terrify the intruders. • Round 2: She uses Wail—a devastating shriek meant to drive all life out of her sanctum. • She retreats through the closed door into A27, passing effortlessly through walls. There, she makes her final stand.
If the party parleys (rare), Vyldara demands: • Justice. She believes the dwarves must be punished. • Release. A cleric may attempt to put her to rest with calm emotions or greater restoration—or a ritual at Moradin’s shrine using her name and the amulet from A19.
Combat Stats (PHB/MM standard banshee): • AC: 12 • HP: 58 • Speed: 0 ft., fly 40 ft. (hover) • Notable Abilities: • Horrifying Visage: Wisdom save or frightened for 1 minute. • Wail: Once per day. All creatures within 30 ft. make a Con save or drop to 0 HP (or half damage on save).
Atmospheric Effects: • The air drops 15 degrees as soon as she appears. • Light sources flicker, turn blue, or dim. • Shadows stretch against the light, like they’re being pulled by sorrow.
Roleplay Hooks (Optional): • Elf characters may feel a kinship or hear her last thoughts in Elvish. • Characters who visited A19 (former shrine) may reference it to gain advantage on Persuasion to delay her attack. • Vyldara recognizes Selûne as a goddess of truth and might briefly hesitate if invoked in faith.
Exploration and Clues • DC 12 History or Religion: Recognizes Vyldara as a moon elf ambassador from ancient records or teachings of Selûne. • DC 15 Insight: Notices that she is more sad than violent—her fury is born of betrayal. • Casting Speak with Dead or Speak with Spirits in A27 may offer visions of her final moments.
Climactic Tension Options: • As the battle begins, the cries of dead dwarves echo faintly from other halls—ghouls stirred by the banshee’s fury. • If Vyldara is defeated in A27, a pulse of moonlight fills the chamber—and then silence, eternal and cold

note.name: A25 – Upper East Hall and Balcony
note.text:
Read Aloud:
Rubble clogs much of the corridor ahead—fallen stone and fractured beams heaped like broken bones. Beyond, faint rays of moonlight spill through arrow slits and cracks in the ceiling, casting thin beams across the floor like spears of silver.
At the far end, a pair of stout stone doors hang half-open, revealing a narrow balcony that overlooks a dark, silent hall far below.
Details: • This hallway was part of the fortress’s upper command level. • The partial collapse makes the eastern half difficult terrain (halves movement). • The balcony beyond the doors overlooks the Mustering Hall (A4) from 20 feet above. • The balcony has no railing, just a sheer drop—perfect for a tense moment or a vertical ambush.
Exploration Opportunities: • DC 12 Investigation reveals a shattered signal horn buried in the rubble—once used to warn of enemy approaches. • DC 14 Perception at the balcony reveals faint signs of motion below—perhaps a ghoul waiting silently near the shadows of A4.
Tension Hook:
If the party made noise in A14 or A24, the ghouls in A26 may be alerted early and begin climbing toward the fireplace chimney—giving players a sense of being watched or stalked

note.name: A26 – Ghoul Bath
note.text:
Read Aloud:
A cold, fungal stink hangs thick in the air as you enter the room. In the center stands a carved stone tub, its edges black with age. The tub is filled not with water, but with a heap of gnawed, broken dwarven bones, still slick with rot.
Above it, a faucet juts from the wall—dripping slowly, unnaturally, hot water into the mess below. A hiss of steam curls from the foul slurry. Something… moves within.
Creatures: • Two ghouls plus one per party member (excluding sidekicks) lurk within or behind the tub. • They crawl in and out of this room through a 2-foot-wide hole in the east wall that connects to the chimney behind A14’s fireplace. • If the ghouls in A14 were slain, these ghouls are more feral, driven to madness by isolation.
Combat Notes: • The hot water faucet can be turned to scald a creature in the tub. • As an action, a character can turn the faucet wide open. The tub fills with steam and boiling water over 2 rounds, forcing all creatures in the tub to make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or take 2d6 fire damage per round. • Characters can lure ghouls into this trap with clever bait or illusions.
Exploration Finds: • DC 15 Medicine reveals that many of the bones belong to non-combatants—possibly dwarven children and elders. • The faucet is still connected to a magical geothermal channel, and could be repurposed as a heat source or linked to a purification ritual.
Tension Hooks: • The bones in the tub are arranged in circles, as if the ghouls were ritualistically nesting or performing some instinctive pattern—a sign of dark intelligence. • One of the bones bears a claw-scratched symbol of Shar, goddess of darkness and loss. This may be connected to Vyldara’s corruption—or the ghouls’ hunger born of cursed shadow

note.name: A27 – Banshee’s Bedchamber
note.text:
Read Aloud:
The heavy stone door opens with a low groan, revealing a chamber cloaked in shadow and dust. Cobwebs hang like torn silk from the rafters, and the air is colder here—unnaturally cold, as if the room itself still mourns.
A four-poster bed, now sagging and moth-eaten, stands at the center, its gauzy canopy torn and fluttering in an unseen wind. A delicate vanity of elven make lies shattered in the corner, its broken mirror reflecting a warped moonlit gleam.
There is no sign of the banshee, but her grief clings to the walls like frost.
DM Notes: • This was Vyldara’s chamber before her imprisonment and death. The dwarves had set it aside for diplomatic guests—and then turned it into a gilded prison. • The room is suffused with sorrow, a psychic echo of her despair. • If the banshee retreated here from A24 (Haunted Hall), she is found floating above the bed, whispering to herself in Elvish or undercommon phrases. • Her aura here is magnified: all Charisma-based skill checks made against her are made with disadvantage, unless the speaker shares her elven heritage or invokes Selûne, Mystra, or Sehanine Moonbow (elven moon deity).
Roleplaying Vyldara (If She Survives A24): • She’s resentful, vengeful, but not mindless. • Attempts to parley can succeed, but only if the characters show genuine remorse, understanding, or offer a sacred rite (see below). • She speaks in poetry and memory, saying things like: • “They locked me in velvet and stone. They fed me fear and drank my words.” • “They built walls to keep out war—but war was already inside them.” • “My voice was peace. Their axes knew only silence.”
Combat: • If the banshee is confronted here after already fighting in A24, she is weakened (start at half HP). • If she uses Wail in this confined space, allow characters advantage on the saving throw if they previously used divination, protective magic, or invoked a moon deity. • If she is destroyed here, her final cry is not a scream—but a sigh, as the shadows unravel around her and vanish into a cold breeze.
Alternate Ending – A Peaceful Passing (Optional):
If characters speak to Vyldara with compassion, and especially if: • An elf or half-elf offers her words of mourning • They speak her name and tell her she is remembered • They promise to carry her memory to her people
…Then her soul can be laid to rest.
She lowers from the air, her pale form shedding tears of starlight. “At last… I am seen,” she whispers. And then, like a candle, she is gone.
Reward for Compassion: If the party frees her this way: • Her spirit blesses the room. A character who rests here gains 1 Inspiration and has their next death saving throw made with advantage. • Vyldara’s Echo: Once per long rest, a character who mourned her may cast Dissonant Whispers (1st-level) as a bonus action. The voice is hers.
Exploration Finds: • DC 13 Investigation (Vanity): Among the shattered contents lies an ornate silver comb, shaped like a crescent moon and inlaid with amethyst. Worth 50 gp, or 150 gp to a moon elf or Harper collector. • DC 15 Religion (Bedside): Tucked inside the bed’s frame is a small moonstone icon of Sehanine Moonbow, goddess of mysteries and the full moon. Worth little in gold—but sacred to elves. Holding it during a short rest allows an elf or half-elf to remove one level of exhaustion or gain inspiration.
Tension Hook:
If the party killed Vyldara in rage or carelessness, the ghost of a dwarven priest may appear later in the dungeon—condemning them for failing to uphold Selûne’s mercy or Moradin’s justice. Consequences could follow

note.name: A28 – Castellan’s Bedchamber
note.text:
Read Aloud:
The air here is thick with dust and neglect. A stone-framed bed sits at the center, draped in a moldy blanket and surrounded by overturned stools, cracked mugs, and the splintered remnants of a once-proud desk. A soot-stained fireplace yawns in the south wall, its chimney blackened and crumbling at the edges.
From somewhere inside the chimney comes a faint skittering sound—sharp and wet, like claws tapping stone.
DM Notes: • This chamber belonged to the castellan of Axeholm—the last dwarf to remain after the fortress was sealed. His loyalty cost him everything, and his soul lingers as the ghoul hidden in Area A14. • The fireplace chimney is infested with stirges (1 per party member including sidekicks). These blood-hungry creatures burst out and attack if: • A character searches the fireplace • A loud noise is made in the room • Anyone starts a fire or casts light in the hearth
Secret Door: • A hidden vault lies beyond the fireplace. • A DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check while inspecting the hearth reveals handprints in the soot, too clean and deliberate to be random. • Pushing on the back wall reveals a secret stone door that swings open silently, revealing Area A29 – The Vault.
If the castellan’s signet ring (found on his ghoul in A14) is held near the soot, it glows faintly—evidence of dwarven runes reacting to the ancestral crest.
Tension Hook:
As the characters open the vault, they may hear the wind outside howl like a voice—Vyldara’s echo, or something older, whispering:
“You dig too deep for ghosts…

note.name: A29 – Secret Vault
note.text:
Read Aloud:
The hidden chamber is a cold stone cell, silent but for the echo of your footsteps. Empty but for a single item:
Against the far wall sits an iron chest with clawed feet and a heavy lid. Its lock bears a circular indentation, like a seal… no keyhole, no hinges. Above it is a tiny engraved sigil: a handaxe clutched in a dwarven gauntlet—the symbol of Axeholm.
DM Notes: • This secret vault contains relics sealed away by the castellan before the evacuation—one meant to protect, one to intimidate. • The chest is locked by design. The indentation matches the castellan’s signet ring (see Area A14). Placing the ring into the indentation unseals the chest.
Other Entry Options: • DC 20 Dexterity (Thieves’ Tools) to pick the mechanism • Knock spell or similar magic • Forcing it open triggers a faint pulse of necrotic energy (each creature in a 10-ft radius must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution save or take 4 (1d8) necrotic damage and feel the chill of Axeholm’s legacy)
Treasure:
Inside the iron chest, the characters find: • Dread Helm (Uncommon Wondrous Item) A blackened iron helm that causes the wearer’s eyes to glow red while worn. Purely cosmetic but intimidating. When donned, the helm hums with a faint echo of dwarven battle hymns. • Gauntlets of Ogre Power (Uncommon Wondrous Item) When worn, the wearer’s Strength becomes 19 unless already higher. Forged for dwarves in the days of giant wars, these gauntlets still carry the heat of ancestral fury.
Flair: The gauntlets are engraved with dwarven script: “Strength is the spine of honor.”
Optional Lore Discovery: • DC 14 History (Dwarf Heritage): A character recognizes that this vault style was used during times of war, hidden from both enemy and kin—meant to keep Axeholm’s pride safe until dwarves could return. • If Vyldara’s spirit was laid to rest peacefully, a faint silver shimmer clings to the gauntlets—a blessing of resistance (necrotic) for the next 24 hours

note.name: A30 – Privies
note.text:
Read Aloud:
Rusty chain mail curtains hang from iron rods, concealing a pair of alcoves tucked against the far wall. The air here is stale and carries the sharp tang of old decay mixed with mildew.
Inside each alcove rests a cracked wooden bench, its surface worn by time, with a circular hole cut through. The chutes beneath drop into silent, unknowable depths.
DM Notes: • These privies were used by Axeholm’s soldiers and residents before the fortress was abandoned. • The chainmail curtains offer eerie ambiance—semi-rigid and clinking softly in even the faintest draft. • The chutes descend vertically for hundreds of feet, passing just east of Area A10 (Tool Storage).
Exploration & Interactions: • A character shining a light or dropping a pebble into the shaft hears no bottom—just a long silence followed by a distant splash or clink. • DC 12 Wisdom (Perception): A faint breeze occasionally flows up the shaft—not natural airflow, but perhaps stirred by something still lurking far below.
Optional Discoveries: • DC 15 Investigation (searching behind or beneath the bench): • One privy’s floor panel is slightly loose. Beneath it is a small leather pouch stashed long ago by a dwarf hiding contraband before evacuation: • Contents: • 13 gp in older Dwarvish-minted coins • A tiny silver earring shaped like a warhammer (worth 25 gp) • A slip of parchment with a half-finished prayer to Moradin, smeared with dried blood
“Bless the forge that birthed me, and the stone that…” — the rest is blotted out
Tension Hook: • If a character sticks their head or arm into the chute for more than a moment, they feel a sudden chill from the darkness below. This has no mechanical effect—but suggest that something remembers…
Forgotten Realms Flavor: • Moradin, the Dwarffather, is often invoked in these quiet, humble places. Each privy bears an etched rune in the stone floor—a symbol of cleansing or purification, worn nearly smooth by time. • If a dwarf character pauses here and reflects or offers a whispered prayer, they may gain inspiration at the DM’s discretion

note.name: NPC – Vyldara the Banshee
note.text: **Name**: Vyldara, Banshee of Axeholm **Race**: Undead (Elf Spirit) **Visual Trait**: Tangled silver hair and translucent tattered robes **Quip**: “They abandoned me… now I wail for all eternity!” **Motivation**: Driven mad by betrayal and her own violent end, Vyldara sees all intruders as would-be executioners.

note.name: Moradin - Deity
note.text:
The Soul Forger, the Dwarffather, the All-Father Greater Deity (Lawful Good)
Domains: Forge, Knowledge, War Symbol: A hammer and anvil Worshipers: Dwarves, smiths, artisans, stonecutters, architects Favored Weapon: Warhammer
Overview: Moradin is the chief deity of the dwarves, revered as the creator of their race. He is the embodiment of dwarven virtues: strength, craftsmanship, honor, and tradition. According to myth, Moradin forged the first dwarves from stone and metal at the heart of the world and breathed life into them with fire and divine purpose.
He encourages innovation through creation, discipline through labor, and defense of the dwarven people and their strongholds. His forges burn eternally in his celestial realm, and his clerics are respected both as warriors and artisans.
Tenets of Faith: • Honor your clan and your ancestors. • Create with care and pride. • Defend your home from those who would defile it. • Temper strength with wisdom, and action with patience. • Forge your path with purpose and courage.
Common Saying: “Strike true, as Moradin guides your hand.

note.name: Wrapping Up
note.text:
Once the party has scoured the fortress of undead horrors, silenced the elven banshee, and claimed the treasures of the dwarves, Axeholm is theirs to reclaim—or to leave behind, its legacy of sorrow finally put to rest.
1. Quest Completion
The Axeholm quest is complete when: 1. All hostile creatures are defeated or driven out, including: • The ghouls scattered across both upper and lower halls. • The giant spiders nesting in the upper bastion (A22). • The banshee Vyldara, whose rage haunts the central halls (A24–A27). 2. The characters explore or secure most of the fortress, including its: • Outer and inner gauntlets (A1, A11) • Throne room (A14) and banshee’s lair (A27) • Secret vault and treasure cache (A29)
2. Narrative Closure
Axeholm offers a satisfying narrative arc if treated not only as a dungeon crawl, but as the unraveling of a tragic dwarven downfall. Emphasize the emotional and historical beats: • Vyldara’s story is one of betrayal, justice, and vengeance. Whether the characters show her mercy, try to speak with her, or destroy her without a word, her death marks the end of a haunted chapter in dwarven history. • The ghouls, once dwarves, are victims twisted by Abbathor’s cruelty and the banshee’s lingering hatred. • The emptiness of Axeholm lingers long after the final enemy falls. Dust, bones, and silence remain.
3. Treasures and Rewards
Characters who explore thoroughly can claim the following significant treasures: 1. Castellan’s Signet Ring (A14) – A golden ring worth 5 gp that unlocks the vault in A29. 2. Vault Treasure (A29): • Dread Helm – A fearsome cosmetic magic item. • Gauntlets of Ogre Power – A powerful item that boosts Strength to 19. 3. Holy Symbol of Moradin (A19) – A platinum amulet on a gold chain, sacred to dwarves, worth 250 gp. 4. Potion of Superior Healing (A19) – Found in a hidden coffer packed with silt. 5. Optional Armorer’s Tools and ballista gear – Functional dwarven tools (A6, A10) or siege weaponry (A2, A3, A12, A13), if the party seeks to fortify or repurpose the fortress.
4. Consequences and Future Use
Once cleared, Axeholm becomes a stronghold with the following options: 1. Safe Haven – With time and labor, the party could turn it into a base of operations. 2. Faction Interest – The dwarves of Mithral Hall, Gauntlgrym, or even the Harpers might show interest in reclaiming or consecrating the site. 3. Darkness Returns? – If Vyldara is not properly laid to rest or her spirit lingers, Axeholm could once again fall into cursed shadow.
5. Optional Epilogue Scene (DM Prompt)
To close the session with a flourish, use a narrative beat:
The wail of the banshee dies in the halls. You stand beneath the carved stone of the throne, the banner of Axeholm long-rotted on the wall behind you. The fortress is still again. But as the echoes fade and the final ghoul crumbles into dust, the silence feels heavy—not victorious, but solemn. The mountain remembers

monster.label: Will-o'-Wisp
monster.name: Will-o'-Wisp
monster.resist: acid, cold, fire, necrotic, thunder; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks
monster.conditionImmune: exhaustion, grappled, paralyzed, poisoned, prone, restrained, unconscious
monster.languages: the languages it knew in life

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 301, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 63

trait.name: Consume Life
trait.text: As a bonus action, the will-o'-wisp can target one creature it can see within 5 ft. of it that has 0 hit points and is still alive. The target must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw against this magic or die. If the target dies, the will-o'-wisp regains 10 (3d6) hit points.

trait.name: Ephemeral
trait.text: The will-o'-wisp can't wear or carry anything.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
trait.text: The will-o'-wisp can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 (1d10) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Variable Illumination
trait.text: The will-o'-wisp sheds bright light in a 5- to 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional number of ft. equal to the chosen radius. The will-o'-wisp can alter the radius as a bonus action.

action.name: Shock
action.text: Melee Spell Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 9 (2d8) lightning damage.

action.name: Invisibility
action.text: The will-o'-wisp and its light magically become invisible until it attacks or uses its Consume Life trait, or until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell).

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 273

action.name: Hooves
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d6+4) bludgeoning damage.

monster.label: Invisible Stalker
monster.name: Invisible Stalker
monster.resist: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks
monster.conditionImmune: exhaustion, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained, unconscious
monster.languages: Auran, understands Common but doesn't speak it

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 192, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 59

trait.name: Invisibility
trait.text: The stalker is invisible.

trait.name: Faultless Tracker
trait.text: The stalker is given a quarry by its summoner. The stalker knows the direction and distance to its quarry as long as the two of them are on the same plane of existence. The stalker also knows the location of its summoner.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The stalker makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 (2d6+3) bludgeoning damage.

item.name: Instrument of Illusions
item.text:
While you are playing this musical instrument, you can create harmless, illusory visual effects within a 5-foot-radius sphere centered on the instrument. If you are a bard, the radius increases to 15 feet. Sample visual effects include luminous musical notes, a spectral dancer, butterflies, and gently falling snow. The magical effects have neither substance nor sound, and they are obviously illusory. The effects end when you stop playing.
Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything p. 137

item.name: Necklace of Fireballs
item.text:
This necklace has 1d6+3 beads hanging from it. You can use an action to detach a bead and throw it up to 6 feet away. When it reaches the end of its trajectory, the bead detonates as a 3rd-level fireball spell (save DC 15). You can hurl multiple beads, or even the whole necklace, as one action. When you do so, increase the level of the fireball by 1 for each bead beyond the first.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 182

item.name: Dragon Slayer Longsword
item.text:
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When you hit a dragon with this weapon, the dragon takes an extra 3d6 damage of the weapon's type. For the purpose of this weapon, "dragon" refers to any creature with the dragon type, including dragon turtles and wyverns.
Versatile: This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property — the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.
Proficiency: martial, longsword
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 166

note.name: Overview
note.text:
Summary
Dragon Barrow is a haunted, earth-packed tomb built atop the grave of the green dragon Azdraka and those who helped slay it, including the noble Lady Tanamere Alagondar. Set in the windswept hills northwest of Phandalin, the barrow contains crumbling sepulchers, spectral guardians, and the fabled Dragon Slayer longsword, resting atop the fallen wyrm’s skull.
This is a location driven more by atmosphere, traps, and curiosity than by combat—until the guardian appears. This allows you to build tension with light, sound, and signs of ancient death.
Quest Goal
Retrieve the Dragon Slayer longsword buried with Lady Alagondar in the barrow.
What’s Going On Here? • Over a century ago, Lady Alagondar led a band of adventurers against the green dragon Azdraka, killing it but dying in the battle. • As per her will, she, her allies, and the dragon’s bones were buried in a dragon-shaped mound built at the site of the battle. • Restless undead, decaying traps, and a summoned guardian (invisible stalker) protect the tomb from looters. • A displaced centaur druid named Xanth watches the area and offers lore, as well as a lead to the Circle of Thunder, should you want to pivot to that location after the barrow.
Key NPCs • Xanth the Centaur (Optional) • A gentle, wary druid displaced by orcs. • Offers guidance, rumors, and a plot hook for the Circle of Thunder. • Visual Trait: Bark-like patterning along his flanks, like runes grown from the forest. • Quip: “Storm and stone—we leave the barrow be. The dead there remember.”
Monsters to Prepare 1. 3 Will-o’-Wisps (D2) • Lure characters toward pit traps with eerie lights. 2. 1 Skeletal Warhorse (D4) • Non-hostile unless attacked. Can bond with a PC. 3. 1 Invisible Stalker (D8) • Appears only if the Dragon Slayer is taken. Attacks until it is returned or it is slain.
Hazards & Traps 1. Concealed Pit Traps (D3) • Hidden spiked pits beneath decaying wood and dirt. 2. Tunnel Collapse Trap (D5) • Pressure plate that triggers a deadly cave-in. 3. Acid Sarcophagi (D6) • False tombs that spew corrosive dust. 4. Sarcophagus Lifting: DC 20 Strength (Athletics)
Treasure 1. Dragon Slayer (D8) – Main quest reward 2. Lute of Illusions (D7) – From the bard’s sarcophagus 3. Necklace of Fireballs (D7) – From the wizard’s sarcophagus
Atmospheric Tone & Sensory Details • Scenery: Windswept hill, storm-wracked skies, pale stone “spikes” jutting like bones. • Sounds: Hollow wind over grass, spectral whispers in narrow tunnels, the faint tink of armor when no one’s near. • Smells: Damp earth, long-decayed remains, faint tang of something wrong in the air. • Light: None within the barrow. At night, ghostly lights float above the hilltop (will-o’-wisps).
Tension and Pacing Tips • Play up the mystery and desecration. Tombs are meant to be still—but something isn’t. • The players should feel like trespassers, not heroes. Until the sword is in hand, no threat feels immediate—but the threat builds. • When the invisible stalker appears, make it sudden: unnatural wind, snuffed torches, whispered breath on the neck. • Drop hints of Lady Alagondar’s nobility and Azdraka’s monstrous size through murals, inscriptions, or charred claw marks

note.name: Location Background
note.text:
DM Notes
Historical Context • Tanamere Alagondar was a noble scion of Neverwinter, part of the Alagondar bloodline that once ruled the city. She lived more than a century ago during a time of great unrest along the Sword Coast. • A formidable knight and adventurer, Tanamere led two adventuring parties against Azdraka, an ancient green dragon who terrorized the High Road, preying on travelers and razing settlements between Neverwinter Wood and the coast.
The Battle • The final clash occurred amid the grassy hills northwest of Phandalin. Tanamere and her allies brought down the dragon in a fierce battle, but she perished in the process. • Per her dying wish, she was buried within the barrow, alongside: • Her loyal squire • The bones of Azdraka • And the companions who fell in the battle—a bard, a wizard, a cleric, and a fighter
The Barrow • The burial mound was built to resemble the dragon’s form—a final poetic gesture. Its shape can be discerned from the hilltop with a successful DC 10 Insight check. • Ten pale stones arc from the top of the mound like vertebrae or talons—these form both a monument and a camouflage for the barrow’s entrances. • This construction is sacred ground, though time and nature have eroded its memory.
Symbolism & Lore Hooks • Tanamere is a symbol of selfless sacrifice and noble duty, themes that can resonate with PCs devoted to justice, redemption, or old oaths. • The Alagondar legacy may intrigue characters from Neverwinter or those familiar with the city’s fractured history—Tanamere’s name may still carry quiet weight among bards or historians. • The fact that the dragon’s remains were buried with her suggests a spiritual or poetic philosophy—possibly an offering of peace, or a final gesture to tame the terror she defeated.
Exploration Opportunities • Lore checks (History or Religion, DC 12–15) could recall Tanamere’s story or details about the dragon wars along the Sword Coast. • Selûne’s faithful or Harpers might view the site as hallowed ground or a historical landmark worth preserving. • Haunting whispers, drifting lights, or subtle signs of the dragon’s essence lingering in the soil can foreshadow supernatural disturbances within

note.name: NPC: Xanth the Centaur
note.text:
Displaced Druid of the Hills
Type: NPC Ally (use Centaur stat block, Monster Manual, or Basic Rules) Alignment: Neutral Good Affiliation: None (Sympathetic to the Emerald Enclave) Challenge: 2 (700 XP) – if combat is forced (not recommended)
Visual Description
A towering centaur with wind-worn skin and moss-threaded braids, Xanth’s equine flanks are marked with natural patterns that resemble runes—like bark or stone. His eyes shimmer with the green of sun-dappled canopies, but there’s a wariness to him, the kind that only comes from seeing one’s home razed and magic turned cruel.
Notable Feature: His hooves crackle with druidic glyphs when he’s angry or invoking the wilds’ will.
Quips & Dialogue Hooks • “Storm and stone—we leave the barrow be. The dead there remember.” • “The forest breathes heavier now. Talos rides the thunder, and his anchorites spill blood into the roots.” • “I saw the witchlights dancing above the hilltop. I do not go where the spirits cry.” • “If you’ve steel for the dead, I won’t stop you. But if you’ve kindness for the living, I’ll ask a favor.”
Roleplaying Xanth • Tone: Calm, poetic, observant—he speaks like a naturalist mystic with an old soul. • Purpose: To warn the party about Dragon Barrow, provide information, and offer a side quest to the Circle of Thunder (should they follow it). • Motivations: • Defend the balance of the hills and woods. • Evade the orcs and Talos-worshiping anchorites who drove him from Neverwinter Wood. • Watch over the barrow from a respectful distance.
Interaction Tips • He will not enter the barrow under any circumstances. • He offers to guide the characters to the Circle of Thunder—but only if they seem just or seek to rid the land of evil. • Xanth responds kindly to Emerald Enclave members or druids, and may share extra lore with a nature-oriented PC.
Optional Lore He Shares • Lady Alagondar’s tomb was built with honor—but time breeds unrest, even among the dead. • Azdraka’s skull is said to whisper on stormy nights. • The will-o’-wisps only hover when someone’s fate is near. The barrow chooses its own intruders

note.name: Hooking Circle Of Thunder
note.text:
Narrative Thread from Xanth
As the party approaches or departs Dragon Barrow, Xanth the centaur may reiterate or expand on the ominous signs he’s witnessed nearby:
“The lights over the hill are not the worst thing in these lands… The spirits here are restless, yes, but something darker has taken root in the wood. Spell-twisted orcs. Half-bloods of ruin. They chant to something old beneath the trees.”
Xanth describes the Circle of Thunder, an ancient ring of standing stones deep in Neverwinter Wood, now overtaken by half-orc spellcasters and their beast-cloaked rituals. He believes the arcane corruption there is what stirs the undead in the barrow—something unnatural is thinning the veil between the living and the dead.
Hook Opportunities
You can introduce the Circle of Thunder before, during, or after Dragon Barrow: • Before the barrow: Xanth warns the party and offers to guide them after their current task. • During: The wisps or stalker may whisper fragmented visions—“circle of stones… dark blood, fire sky…” • After: Removing the Dragon Slayer sword might weaken a magical ward, allowing corruption to spread—fueling urgency to address it.
Lore Connection
The Circle of Thunder and Dragon Barrow can be linked by magic and legacy: • Theory: Long ago, the standing stones were a spiritual node used by druids and elves to honor elemental balance. Tanamere’s burial here was partially chosen for its geomantic proximity—the hill lies within the influence of the circle’s leyline. • The orc spellcasters now twist that energy, raising restless spirits, empowering will-o’-wisps, and disturbing sanctified tombs. • Selûne’s faithful or divine PCs may sense a fractured lunar current, as if moonlight can no longer reach this corner of the forest cleanly.
Xanth as a Guide • Xanth offers to escort the party to the Circle of Thunder once they are ready. He will: • Travel with them cautiously • Wait at the edge of the corrupted circle, unwilling to enter unless desperate • Use Xanth to reveal lore, warn of what’s ahead, or drop cryptic lines: “The stones don’t hum anymore. They scream. Something’s listening from beneath.”
Thematic Continuity • Dragon Barrow = death, legacy, haunted ground • Circle of Thunder = living corruption, primal imbalance, spiritual desecration Together, they represent two ends of the same spiritual wound—the dead disturbed by those who twist life.
Mechanical Connection (Optional)
If you want to add mechanical depth: • While the Circle remains active, undead in Dragon Barrow are empowered (e.g., will-o’-wisps get max HP or recharge abilities) • If the stalker in D8 is destroyed but the Circle remains active, a new spirit might rise in time, creating a recurring enemy • Destroying the Circle’s ritual node could provide divine cleansing—banishing lingering malice from Tanamere’s tomb.

note.name: Travel To The Barrow
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
You leave the rough roads behind as the hills rise like sleeping giants before you. The air turns sharp and salt-kissed, a cold wind blowing in from the Sword Coast. Rain spatters the horizon in drifting curtains, and black-winged shapes—crows, perhaps—circle distant stones on the ridgeline. The earth feels old here. Buried stories beneath every step.
DM Notes
Distance & Travel Time • The barrow lies approximately 40 miles northwest of Phandalin, between the High Road and the edge of Neverwinter Wood. • Travel pace: • 24 miles/day on foot with normal pace. • Expect two days of travel, requiring one long rest in the wilderness.
Terrain & Conditions • The route traverses rolling hills and open grassland—a lonely, wind-scoured landscape dotted with ancient standing stones and forgotten cairns. • Cold coastal wind blows inland throughout, bringing intermittent drizzle or heavy rain. Consider Constitution saves or exhaustion checks for extended exposure without shelter (optional, if running grittier survival rules). • Visibility can shift with the rain and fog. Use this for atmospheric tension or to hint at something unnatural—ghost lights, draconic shapes in the clouds, etc.
Optional Travel Encounters (Day or Night)
Use these if you want to add flavor, tension, or divert the party’s path: • Haunted Light (Night): A will-o’-wisp flickers on a distant hilltop, only to vanish when approached. It echoes the ones guarding the barrow. • Marauding Orcs: A splinter group of orcs from the Neverwinter Wood, armed with crude black-fletched arrows. Could foreshadow Xanth’s warnings or link to the Circle of Thunder. • Weather Challenge: A night of fierce rain forces the party to find shelter. Perhaps they stumble across an old, collapsed watchtower or druid circle half-buried in moss. • Ghostly Echo: On a moonless night, a spectral rider is seen galloping silently across the hills—an omen of Tanamere’s restless steed.
Environmental Descriptions (for flavor along the way) • A twisted, lightning-blasted tree juts from a hill like a skeletal hand. • Bones of a long-dead beast, picked clean, lie exposed to the wind. • The scent of wet soil and brine hangs heavy in the air. • A circle of stones—once a ritual site, now forgotten—echoes with faint whispers at dusk.
Hooks & Clues • If any PC communes with nature, casts divination magic, or prays for insight, you can foreshadow: • “Beware the breathless wind beneath the hill.” • “The sword waits, but so too does the shadow left behind.” • Characters who succeed on a DC 13 Survival or History check might recognize landmarks mentioned in old tales of Tanamere’s last battle, anchoring them in the landscape

note.name: Arrival
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The hills part to reveal a lone rise, thirty feet high and unnaturally still. Atop the mound, ten towering stones arc like bleached talons clawing at the dark sky—weatherworn and silent. The grass around them is flattened in rings, as though something vast once coiled and died here. Thunder murmurs in the west, and the air smells of salt, wet earth, and something older still—stone, decay, and ancient magic.
DM Notes
First Impressions • As the party comes within view of the barrow, emphasize: • The unnatural flatness of the hilltop • The bone-white stones protruding like draconic spines or claws • The sudden quiet of the surroundings—birds avoid the place
Barrow Shape Clue • If a character climbs the hill and spends time surveying the area, they can make a DC 10 Wisdom (Insight) check: • Success: They realize the barrow resembles a dragon’s shape, with the white stones forming a stylized spinal ridge. • This clue can create dramatic tension or allow perceptive PCs to “feel” the weight of the story before they even enter.
Supernatural Phenomena • At night, the will-o’-wisps (from area D2) emerge using Incorporeal Movement and hover above the mound, appearing as flickering green-blue witchlights. • These lights: • Attempt to lure travelers closer • May cause Insight or Arcana checks (DC 12) to guess their nature • Retreat and turn invisible if characters approach or investigate too closely
Environmental Sensory Details • Wind swirls in odd patterns near the hill’s summit—whispers beneath the gusts. • The stones feel warm to the touch despite the cold air. • A faint line of disturbed earth, as if something once slithered from the base of the mound, disappears into the grass.
Exploration Hooks • Religion or History check (DC 13): May recall references to burial mounds patterned after dragons in ancient Neverwinter rites—considered both honorific and protective, meant to keep the spirit of the slain beast bound to the earth. • Druid or Ranger PCs may detect that wildlife avoids the barrow unnaturally. • The presence of undead or ghostly magic may be felt by paladins or clerics using Divine Sense or Detect Magic, centered faintly beneath the mound

note.name: D1. Secret Entrance
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
Among the jagged stones atop the hill, one stands subtly askew—its base shadowed, its curve less graceful than the others. The ground beneath it slopes slightly, the grass thinner, the soil dry despite the rain. As you draw close, a breeze seems to slip from the earth itself, carrying a faint scent of dust and age. Something sleeps beneath this stone, sealed by time and silence.
DM Notes
Locating the Entrance • One of the white stones atop the hill is a disguised stone plug concealing a narrow spiral stair. • Searching the hilltop and examining the base of the stones reveals the entrance with a DC 10 Wisdom (Perception) check. • On a success, characters notice a 2-foot-wide gap beneath the stone, and cool air flowing from below.
Opening the Entrance • The plug-like stone can be toppled with one of the following methods: • DC 19 Strength (Athletics) check with ropes lashed around the top of the stone. • Success: The stone topples with a grinding, thunderous crash and reveals the spiral stair. • Knock spell: Immediately causes the stone to shudder and tip over unnaturally, cracking the earth around it. • Destructive force (e.g., shatter spell or brute smashing) is possible but may: • Alert the wisps below • Cause the stair to partially collapse (optional tension element)
Revealed Passage • Beneath the toppled stone is a 2-foot-wide spiral staircase of ancient flagstones, descending 30 feet into darkness. • The descent is tight, claustrophobic, and devoid of light. The air grows still and cloyingly stale after just a few steps. • Characters must squeeze to descend, especially if wearing bulky armor or carrying large packs.
Sensory Details • The stairwell smells of rot, stone, and long-buried bone. • The walls feel damp and close—like the earth is reclaiming every step. • Footfalls echo faintly below, but no sound returns from the depths.
Exploration Hooks & Cautions • This is the only entrance listed in the module, but you could allow clever PCs to: • Discover an alternate vent or crawlspace with Nature or Survival checks (DC 17+), leading to D5 or D6 for a stealthy infiltration. • Players using Detect Magic may sense a faint necromantic aura below, growing stronger as they descend. • Passive Perception 13+ might hear the soft hum of will-o’-wisps ahead—like insect wings made of light

note.name: D2. Will-o’-Wisps
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The spiral stair descends into narrow, earthen tunnels where the air turns thick with age and silence. Roots coil through the ceiling like veins beneath skin. Then—light. Faint glimmers dance just ahead, hovering above the ground like fireflies, soft and beckoning. The moment you shift your stance, the lights dart silently back, deeper into the dark.
Then one vanishes. And another. And the third… waits.
DM Notes
Room Overview • This is the entry hall of the barrow’s interior—a tight, low tunnel carved from packed earth, damp with condensation and reeking of stale death. • The spiral stair from D1 empties into this room. • Three will-o’-wisps haunt this area and use it as a trap zone, cooperating to lure intruders into the pit traps in area D3.
Will-o’-Wisps – Behavior & Tactics • Start invisible. They become visible when they: • Hear the party descending the stairs • Detect light sources or sound from above • When visible, they illuminate and float toward the concealed pits just beyond (D3), acting like curious or ghostly lights. • If a PC falls into a pit, the wisp near that trap: • Turns violent, zapping the prone target. • If reduced to 7 hit points or fewer, it turns invisible and retreats, possibly deeper into the barrow or into a pit to wait.
Tactics Tip: Play them like malevolent puzzle pieces. One wisp flickers ahead, another veers left, drawing the party apart. They never speak, only hover and pulse like dying stars.
Combat Stats (pg. Monster Manual or Appendix) • AC 19, HP 22 • Incorporeal Movement, Lightning damage, and resistance to nonmagical damage • Immune to exhaustion, grappled, paralyzed, prone, restrained, unconscious • Excellent hit-and-run skirmishers. Use advantageous terrain like pit traps or tight tunnels.
Sensory Descriptions • The air here is colder than above—still, but somehow aware. • The walls of the tunnel glisten with moisture and tiny bone fragments pressed into the dirt. • A low hum pulses at the edge of hearing—like breath held too long. • When wisps illuminate: pale blue light spills across the mud, catching on ancient weapon hilts and long-dead claw marks in the walls.
Exploration Hooks • Arcana or Religion check (DC 13): PCs may know that will-o’-wisps are spirits bound by malice or tragedy, often created near cursed sites or battlefields. • If a PC has divine senses or magic active, they may detect undead presence, and possibly Tanamere’s will resisting the corruption from deeper below.
Tension Builder • If the party lingers, a wisp might imitate torchlight near a distant tunnel, then vanish when approached. • Their silence is unnerving. They emit no sound, and their disappearance is instant—as if they were never there at all

note.name: D3. Concealed Pit Traps
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The tunnel narrows slightly as you move forward, the footing soft and treacherous. A faint scent of rust and rot hangs in the still air. Ahead, the flickering lights vanish behind a bend. But the ground… something about it feels wrong. Uneven. Too quiet. The silence sharpens into warning.
DM Notes
Trap Layout • The corridor here contains three concealed pit traps, each one: • 5 feet wide • 10 feet deep • Lined with rusty, upturned swords at the bottom
Detection & Avoidance • A creature using a pole, staff, or similar tool to prod ahead can detect a pit with a DC 10 Wisdom (Perception) check. • Characters relying solely on vision may not notice the traps—the covering is made from rotted wooden planks buried under a thin crust of dirt, appearing as undisturbed ground.
Trigger & Effect • Any creature that steps on a pit trap: • Automatically falls into the pit • Takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage • Is impaled by 1d4 rusty swords, each dealing 1d6 piercing damage • The creature lands prone and may be attacked by the will-o’-wisp stationed nearby (D2) on the following initiative count.
Tactical Use by Will-o’-Wisps • Each wisp from D2 is tied thematically and tactically to one of the pits. • If a creature falls in, that wisp attacks immediately, then uses its Incorporeal Movement to phase in and out of the pit as needed. • If the PCs fall into more than one pit, you can split the wisps to divide the party and increase tension.
Environmental Descriptions • The dirt here is unusually smooth… as if freshly packed. • You notice broken strands of grass and wood at odd angles along the edge of the corridor walls. • If a pit is triggered: • The ground gives way with a sickening crack, followed by the dull clatter of metal and a choked cry.
Exploration & Player Ingenuity • Creative players might: • Pour water or sand across the ground to test for hollows • Cast Find Traps, Detect Magic (for wisp proximity), or even Shape Earth to clear the terrain • Encourage clever, slow-paced exploration by rewarding detection and caution.
Optional Variants & Enhancements • For extra danger or cinematic flair: • One sword is magical—perhaps faintly glowing, or etched with a forgotten sigil (useless, but hinting at older conflicts). • A rotting corpse lies in one of the pits, long dead, armor rusted through—but clutching a sealed scroll case or broken holy symbol of Lathander. • Add a clue scratched into the wall above a pit, warning future explorers: “Light lies. Step lightly.

note.name: D4. Skeletal Surprise
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The tunnel opens into a shallow, domed chamber. Tangled roots hang from the ceiling like withered tendrils. In a southern alcove lies a collapsed mass of bones—shattered ribs, a broken skull, and the crumbling remnants of barding and leather straps. The smell of old rot lingers faintly, as if the air still remembers a heartbeat.
Then, a low creak. The bones begin to stir.
DM Notes
The Steed Awakens • The remains belong to Lady Tanamere Alagondar’s loyal warhorse, buried with her in death. • When a creature approaches within 5 feet, the bones reassemble into a skeletal horse with a creaking snap of joints and grinding bone. • The animation is not hostile unless attacked.
Stat Block: Use a Riding Horse stat block with the Undead type and vulnerability to bludgeoning damage (optional).
• AC 10, HP 13, Speed 60 ft., no special undead powers.
Roleplay Opportunity • The skeletal horse is docile and calm, its spirit apparently tethered more by duty than malice. • If a character attempts to mount, feed, or speak gently to it, the steed bonds to them for the rest of the dungeon. • Use this to reward PCs with a moment of reverence or awe. • It could respond favorably to PCs aligned with Selûne, noble goals, or who show respect for Tanamere’s legacy. • A successful DC 13 Animal Handling check or a gentle moment of reverence is enough to earn its loyalty.
Flavorful Steed Behavior • Though it does not breathe, its head turns toward sounds with eerie alertness. • Its hooves never quite touch the ground—they leave no prints. • When struck by light, its bones glint faintly with celestial silver, as if sanctified long ago.
Exploration & Symbolism • This steed represents loyalty beyond death—a powerful visual symbol of Tanamere’s legacy. • Clerics, paladins, or anyone with divine magic may sense a calm aura around the creature—a stark contrast to the wisps’ malice.
Optional Mechanics • The steed can carry one rider and obey basic commands. • If attacked or mistreated, it crumbles into dust, releasing a faint whinny that echoes unnaturally. • If brought to D8 (Tanamere’s tomb), the horse may kneel beside her sarcophagus, then fall still—its duty fulfilled.
Hooks & Enhancements • In future sessions, the bonded PC might dream of riding through moonlit fields beside a silver-armored woman on a living horse. • The steed’s undead nature could attract unwanted attention from druids, clerics, or ghost-sensitive NPCs. • The horse could be laid to rest properly at a shrine to Selûne, granting favor or a one-time blessing

note.name: D5. Narrow Tunnel
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The passage ahead narrows to a jagged seam in the earth, no wider than a coffin’s width. Damp soil walls press in tightly, roots threading through like veins in old skin. The air here is heavy—close. Every breath feels muffled, like the hill itself is swallowing sound.
DM Notes
Tunnel Description • This winding 2-foot-wide tunnel is barely large enough for Small or Medium creatures to squeeze through. • Movement through the tunnel is halved. • No room to fight effectively; attacks are at disadvantage, and spellcasting may require a concentration check at DM discretion. • It’s pitch dark—no light, and no air movement.
Trap Mechanism • At the midpoint is a 5-foot-long pressure plate hidden beneath 2 inches of loose earth. • DC 10 Wisdom (Perception) to detect with a pole or careful examination • Characters not prodding ahead will likely miss it
Trigger Effect:
• The walls collapse inward, burying all creatures currently in the tunnel: • Buried creatures are blinded, restrained, and have total cover • Begin to suffocate once they run out of breath • See Suffocation rules in the PHB (typically 1 + Con modifier minutes)
Escaping or Rescuing:
• A creature outside the collapse can use an action to dig: • Each action opens a 5-foot-deep section of tunnel • Once a buried creature’s space is cleared, they are no longer restrained • It takes 1 round per section dug (unless using magic or tools)
Sensory Descriptions • Earth presses tight against armor, weapons scrape the walls, and every movement feels like trespassing inside a buried lung. • Just before the collapse, a low groan pulses through the soil—like something ancient shifting in its sleep.
Tension-Building Suggestions • Consider a faint ghostly whisper just before the trap is triggered: • “You shouldn’t be here.” • Let players hear a faint crack of roots breaking, or loose pebbles skittering, as a warning if they’re being cautious.
Player Ingenuity • Druidic magic like Mold Earth or Shape Stone can bypass or reveal the trap • Rogues or engineers may propose anchoring ropes or spikes in case of collapse • Use this as a claustrophobic horror moment, particularly if the skeletal horse from D4 cannot follow—emphasize isolation
Optional Encounter • If a character is trapped and isolated, you might foreshadow Tanamere’s lingering spirit or have a single wisp manifest near the mouth of the tunnel, choosing to watch… and wait

note.name: D6. False Tomb
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
Two stone sarcophagi rest in shallow alcoves carved into the south wall. Dust coats them thickly, and pale streaks of mineral runoff trace tears across their lids. The air in this chamber bites with a faint chemical tang—like old vinegar and burnt stone. Something about this space feels too still… as if waiting.
DM Notes
Tomb Trap Mechanics • Each of the two sarcophagi is sealed and carved from solid granite (see Catacomb Features for lid stats). • When a lid is opened: • A cloud of corrosive dust bursts forth • The cloud fills a 10 ft. x 10 ft. area directly north of the sarcophagus
Trap Effect:
• All creatures in the cloud must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw: • On a failed save: take 14 (4d6) acid damage • On a success: take half damage • After detonation, the cloud disperses instantly
Contents • Nothing of value lies within either sarcophagus—only fragments of shattered bones and rusted debris. • This is an intentional decoy tomb, possibly placed to mislead looters or protect the sanctity of the true resting place.
Sensory & Symbolic Flavor • The dust burns the nostrils, acidic and sharp like ancient alchemy gone sour. • On the inside of one lid, a series of tiny scratch marks—fingernail-sized—hint at an ominous past. • PCs may feel this chamber was meant to punish greed, contrasting the nobility of Tanamere’s actual resting place.
Optional Enhancements • A successful DC 13 Religion or Arcana check could suggest the trap was magically preserved or set by Tanamere’s companions as a deterrent. • A Detect Magic spell shows faint traces of evocation magic, dissipating rapidly

note.name: D7. Adventurers' Sepulcher
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The scent of age deepens in this quiet chamber. Four sarcophagi line the alcoves—each sealed, each marked with a simple glyph: a harp, a hammer, a sunburst, and a flame. Dust motes drift in the stale air like faded memories. Something sacred lingers here—not hostile, but heavy. Honored dead.
DM Notes
Layout & Lore • This chamber holds the remains of the four adventurers who perished fighting Azdraka: • A bard, a cleric, a fighter, and a wizard • Their tombs are quiet and untrapped, carved into the earth like forgotten promises.
Optional Lore Check (DC 14 History):
• The glyphs represent their roles—Harp (bard), Hammer (fighter), Sunburst (cleric of Lathander or Amaunator), Flame (evoker or elemental mage). • Knowledge of their sacrifice can offer a moment of reflection or inspire Selûnite PCs who value duty and sacrifice.
Treasure • Northwest Sarcophagus (Bard): • Contains a Lute of Illusions • A beautiful, warped-string instrument with silver inlays and a faint, echoing hum • Southeast Sarcophagus (Wizard): • Contains a Necklace of Fireballs • Coiled among the wizard’s brittle ribs like a snake of embers
You may hand out item cards or refer players to Magic Item Listings in the Essentials Kit or your core books.
Exploration Hooks • If a PC speaks aloud in reverence or prays over the tombs, the dust briefly swirls—like a breath drawn and released. • Paladins or clerics using Divine Sense detect no evil, only a lingering trace of grace and valor.
Sensory Additions • Soft glimmers of residual magic pulse faintly beneath the lids—like sparks sleeping under ash. • When a sarcophagus is opened respectfully, there is no creak or groan. Only silence

note.name: D8. Dragon Slayer
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The air grows colder as you descend into the final chamber. The tunnel opens into a long earthen hall, its walls fused with something massive—ribs. Enormous dragon bones arc overhead, embedded in the soil like ancient rafters. At the far end, a great skull rests in eternal stillness, its jaws parted in a final scream.
Set gently atop the skull is a longsword. Its hilt is wrapped in faded blue leather, its blade clean despite the centuries. Two sarcophagi flank the chamber, their lids simple, unadorned. The silence here feels sacred.
DM Notes
Room Overview • This is the heart of the barrow, and the resting place of: • Lady Tanamere Alagondar, noble knight of Neverwinter • Her faithful squire • And the remains of Azdraka, the green dragon she helped slay • The bones of Azdraka are fused into the very walls—his skull placed intentionally in the center of the chamber, beneath the sword
Optional Insight (DC 12): A PC may recognize the poetic placement: the blade of the dragon slayer resting atop the source of its triumph—not as a trophy, but as a vigil.
Treasure: Dragon Slayer Sword • A +1 dragon slayer longsword lies atop Azdraka’s skull • When drawn: • The blade gives off a faint shimmer, as if reflecting unseen starlight • If held aloft, it resonates with a low chime like a struck bell • Refer to the Magic Items Listing or provide item card
Guardian Encounter: Invisible Stalker • As soon as a character touches or lifts the sword, a summoned invisible stalker manifests and attacks • The stalker cannot be reasoned with and fights until the sword is returned or it is destroyed • Its goal is to prevent the desecration of Tanamere’s resting place—not to kill for pleasure • Use standard stats (MM); remember it attacks with advantage due to invisibility
Optional Flare: When summoned, the wind in the chamber shifts violently—the stalker’s form appearing only as swirling dust and ash. A voice, not its own, echoes once: “Only the worthy may bear the blade.”
Tactical Terrain Notes • The tight chamber makes flanking difficult • The sarcophagi can be used for cover • If PCs have the skeletal steed from D4, it refuses to enter this chamber—pawing at the threshold nervously
After the Encounter • If the stalker is destroyed or the sword is returned, peace returns to the chamber • The sword may still be taken afterward—but consider adding a lingering feeling: • A blessing from Tanamere’s spirit if PCs have acted honorably throughout the barrow • A haunting chill if they have desecrated or stolen from the dead
Sensory & Symbolic Details • The chamber smells of cold stone and stale incense • When the sword is lifted, the dragon skull seems to grin wider • The walls feel watchful, as if the very bones remember
Optional Selûnite or Spiritual Hooks • If a PC prays to Selûne or performs a funeral rite: • A single mote of light may descend onto the sword, or the stalker may hesitate for a beat • A vision or memory of Tanamere could briefly flash before a PC attuned to divine energies: a knight kneeling beside her fallen squire, whispering a vow through tear

note.name: Wrapping Up
note.text:
Dragon Barrow: Wrapping Up the Legacy
The crypt stills. The foul lights have fled. The bones of heroes and monsters alike lie undisturbed once more. Lady Tanamere’s story, half-buried by time and moss, has found a new chapter—written by the hands of those who dared to descend into her dragon-shaped tomb.
1. Completing the Quest
The Dragon Barrow quest concludes when: 1. The party retrieves the Dragon Slayer longsword from area D8. 2. They escape the barrow alive, surviving or defeating the invisible stalker that defends the sword’s resting place. 3. (Optional) They recover other magical heirlooms from Tanamere’s fallen comrades in area D7.
2. Narrative Outcomes and Thematic Echoes
This adventure is as much about memory as it is about treasure. It weaves together legend, decay, and quiet reverence. As the dust settles: • The Dragon Slayer longsword, forged for the blood of wyrms, now has new purpose in the hands of its bearer. It is a weapon with history—and weight. • Lady Tanamere’s legacy has been disturbed, but also remembered. Whether the characters leave a mark of honor, a prayer, or simply silence, they walk in the footprints of giants. • Azdraka’s bones, once sealed away with honor and fear, are now seen once more. The physical shape of the past is revealed—jawbone and fang, symbol and threat.
Consider giving the players a brief narrative reflection on the tomb’s age and solemnity, such as:
You ascend through the earthen throat of the dragon-shaped hill. The wind bites colder now than before. Behind you, the crypt exhales its last breath, and you carry with you not just gold and steel, but memory. The hill returns to its stillness.
3. Optional Rewards and Lore Tokens
In addition to the Dragon Slayer longsword, characters may uncover: 1. Lute of Illusions – A fitting treasure for a bardic spirit now at rest. 2. Necklace of Fireballs – Interred with the wizard who cast their final flames against Azdraka.
Additional discoveries could include: • Local legend growing: Once word spreads of the tomb’s plundering, bards in Neverwinter or Phandalin may ask to hear the story or offer to buy artifacts. • Reverence from nobility: House Alagondar’s name still stirs echoes in Neverwinter. Presenting the sword at a noble court might earn favor—or ire.
4. Adventure Hooks and Continuing Threads
After Dragon Barrow, your players might pursue: 1. The Circle of Thunder – If Xanth the centaur still waits outside, he offers to guide them into the heart of the corrupted woods. 2. Cryovain’s growing shadow – The act of taking the sword may attract attention. Perhaps Cryovain senses the presence of a draconic bane returned to the world. 3. Haunted follow-up – If the sword remains cursed or bound, a lingering spirit or dream might suggest that Tanamere’s rest is not complete.
5. Epilogue Moment (Optional Flavor Box)
Use the following scene to close the session if desired:
Night falls as you crest the hill. Behind you, the dragon’s barrow is silent once more. Stars pierce the coastal clouds like blades. In your hand, the Dragon Slayer hums faintly—its hunger for wyrm blood not yet satisfied. You’ve awakened more than legend. You’ve carried it forward.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 319, Player's Handbook p. 304, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 54

trait.name: Charge
trait.text: If the boar moves at least 20 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a tusk attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 3 (1d6) slashing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 11 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
trait.text: If the boar takes 7 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Tusk
action.text: Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6+1) slashing damage.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 319, Player's Handbook p. 304, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 54

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 51

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting
trait.text:
The anchorite's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save DC 12). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
3/day: thunderwave (2d8 damage) 1/day each: augury, bless, lightning bolt (8d6 damage), revivify

trait.name: Shapechanger
trait.text: The anchorite can use its action to polymorph into a boar or back into its true form, which is humanoid. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

action.name: Clawed Gauntlet (Humanoid Form Only)
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d4 + 3) slashing damage.

action.name: Tusk (Boar Form Only)
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) slashing damage.

spell.name: Thunderwave
spell.text:
A wave of thunderous force sweeps out from you. Each creature in a 15-foot cube originating from you must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 2d8 thunder damage and is pushed 10 feet away from you. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed.
In addition, unsecured objects that are completely within the area of effect are automatically pushed 10 feet away from you by the spell's effect, and the spell emits a thunderous boom audible out to 300 feet.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Augury
spell.materials: specially marked sticks, bones, or similar tokens worth at least 25 gp
spell.text:
By casting gem-inlaid sticks, rolling dragon bones, laying out ornate cards, or employing some other divining tool, you receive an omen from an otherworldly entity about the results of a specific course of action that you plan to take within the next 30 minutes. The DM chooses from the following possible omens.
• Weal, for good results
• Woe, for bad results
• Weal and woe, for both good and bad results
• Nothing, for results that aren't especially good or bad
The spell doesn't take into account any possible circumstances that might change the outcome, such as the casting of additional spells or the loss or gain of a companion.
If you cast the spell two or more times before completing your next long rest, there is a cumulative 25 percent chance for each casting after the first that you get a random reading. The DM makes this roll in secret.

spell.name: Bless
spell.materials: a sprinkling of holy water
spell.text:
You bless up to three creatures of your choice within range. Whenever a target makes an attack roll or a saving throw before the spell ends, the target can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the attack roll or saving throw.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Lightning Bolt
spell.materials: a bit of fur and a rod of amber, crystal, or glass
spell.text:
A stroke of lightning forming a line of 100 feet long and 5 feet wide blasts out from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 8d6 lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The lightning ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot above 3rd.

spell.name: Revivify
spell.materials: diamonds worth 300 gp, which the spell consumes
spell.text: You touch a creature that has died within the last minute. That creature returns to life with 1 hit point. This spell can't return to life a creature that has died of old age, nor can it restore any missing body parts.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 32, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 53

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: While the blight remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a tangle of vines.

action.name: Constrict
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (2d6+2) bludgeoning damage, and a Large or smaller target is grappled (escape DC 12). Until this grapple ends, the target is restrained, and the blight can't constrict another target.

action.name: Entangling Plants (Recharge 5-6)
action.text: Grasping roots and vines sprout in a 15-foot radius centered on the blight, withering away after 1 minute. For the duration, that area is difficult terrain for nonplant creatures. In addition, each creature of the blight's choice in that area when the plants appear must succeed on a DC 12 Strength saving throw or become restrained. A creature can use its action to make a DC 12 Strength check, freeing it self or another entangled creature within reach on a success.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 246, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 62

trait.name: Aggressive
trait.text: As a bonus action, the orc can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

action.name: Greataxe
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (1d12+3) slashing damage.

action.name: Javelin
action.text: Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6+3) piercing damage.

action.name: Blood Drain
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 5 (1d4+3) piercing damage, and the stirge attaches to the target. While attached, the stirge doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of the stirge's turns, the target loses 5 (1d4+3) hit points due to blood loss. The stirge can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement. It does so after it drains 10 hit points of blood from the target or the target dies. A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the stirge.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 284, Lost Laboratory of Kwalish p. 48, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 63

item.name: Staff of Birdcalls
item.text:
This wooden staff is decorated with bird carvings. It has 10 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 charge from the staff and cause it to create one of the following sounds out to a range of 60 feet: a finch's chirp, a raven's caw, a duck's quack, a chicken's cluck, a goose's honk, a loon's call, a turkey's gobble, a seagull's cry, an owl's hoot, or an eagle's shriek. The staff regains 1d6+4 expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the last charge, roll a d20. On a 1, the staff explodes in a harmless cloud of bird feathers and is lost forever.
Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything p. 139

item.name: Dust of Disappearance
item.text:
Found in a small packet, this powder resembles very fine sand. There is enough of it for one use. When you use an action to throw the dust into the air, you and each creature and object within 10 feet of you become invisible for 2d4 minutes. The duration is the same for all subjects, and the dust is consumed when its magic takes effect. If a creature affected by the dust attacks or casts a spell, the invisibility ends for that creature.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 166

item.name: Cloak of Billowing
item.text:
While wearing this cloak, you can use a bonus action to make it billow dramatically.
Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything p. 136

item.name: Immovable Rod
item.text:
This flat iron rod has a button on one end. You can use an action to press the button, which causes the rod to become magically fixed in place. Until you or another creature uses an action to push the button again, the rod doesn't move, even if it is defying gravity. The rod can hold up to 8,000 pounds of weight. More weight causes the rod to deactivate and fall. A creature can use an action to make a DC 30 Strength check, moving the fixed rod up to 10 feet on a success
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 175

item.name: Map To Circle Of Thunder
item.text: Source: Player's Handbook p. 150

item.name: Boots of Elvenkind
item.text:
While you wear these boots, your steps make no sound, regardless of the surface you are moving across. You also have advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks that rely on moving silently.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 155

note.name: Overview
note.text:
Woodland Manse – DM Overview
Theme & Tone: This location is a haunted ruin overwhelmed by nature’s wrath. It’s a place where Talos’s corrupting influence has taken root—literally. The manse crackles with old magic, blighted life, and storm-born fury. The oppressive silence of the deep woods is broken only by distant thunder, the hum of malevolent ritual, and the whisper of ivy against ancient stone.
Tier & Threat Level: Balanced for characters of 5th or 6th level, though it can be tackled at 3rd or 4th level with clever tactics and rests between encounters. The party will face: • Blights (twig, vine, needle) in large numbers • Anchorites of Talos, including Grannoc (the ringleader) • Orc mercenaries preparing for an attack on Falcon’s Lodge • Environmental hazards (traps, collapsing ceilings, rotting floors, etc.)
What the Players Will Discover: 1. A ruined stronghold once home to a reclusive half-elf wizard, now consumed by poisonous ivy and primal corruption. 2. A Gulthias tree in the courtyard well, spreading evil through its roots. Unless uprooted or burned, it regenerates over time. 3. Ritual spaces devoted to Talos, god of storms and destruction—storm sigils, blood sacrifices, and lightning-scorched murals. 4. Clues leading to the Circle of Thunder, where the anchorites gather to perform greater rites in service to Talos.
Objectives: To complete the Woodland Manse Quest, characters must: • Eradicate Grannoc and his followers. • Disrupt or destroy the Gulthias tree. • Survive the manse’s interior, traps, and inhabitants. • Return to Falcon’s Lodge to report their success (and face a potential counterattack).
Tactical Notes: • Noise matters: Many enemies respond to loud sounds (e.g., shouting, combat, falling debris). • Multi-level layout: Players may exploit the verticality—especially the hole between W9 and W18. • Anchorite Tactics: Anchorites use shapeshifting (boar form), lightning magic, and guerilla-style ambushes. They are not mindless—they withdraw when badly wounded unless cornered. • Gulthias Tree Synergy: Blights don’t move unless commanded by Grannoc or the tree is harmed. Players may avoid waking them if clever.
Treasure & Rewards: • Magic items: Cloak of Billowing, Immovable Rod, Dust of Disappearance, Staff of Birdcalls, Dragon Slayer map piece (optional). • Valuable objects: Silver candelabrum, Elvish texts, Falcon’s gratitude, and respect from Neverwinter’s Emerald Enclave if that faction is involved.
Campaign Hooks: 1. Talos’s Cult: This encounter can be one piece of a wider storm cult rising across the North. Surviving anchorites may flee to regroup at the Circle of Thunder. 2. Elven Lore: The ruined manse once held records of lost elven civilizations. Threads from these books might connect to deeper forest secrets, Moonshae Isles, or ancient ruins. 3. The Blighted Grove: If you’re planting seeds for Tomb of Annihilation or Out of the Abyss, the Gulthias tree could tie to larger druidic corruption or spread spores tied to Zuggtmoy.
Atmosphere Suggestions: • Smell: Musty rot, damp ivy, scorched wood, and coppery blood. • Sounds: Distant thunder, dripping stone, insect wings, creaking wood. • Weather: Always overcast or raining; the sky above the manse is unnaturally gray.

note.name: Supplementary Information
note.text:
1. Location-Specific Encounter Setup
A. Default Enemy Placement Summary Quick-reference list for where enemies start: • W1 – 6 boars, 3 anchorites of Talos (in boar form) • W8 (Well) – 1 vine blight + 1 per PC (max 5) • W10 – Grannoc, 3 twig blights per PC • W14 (Hallway) – 3 stirges per PC (max 12) • W18 (Guest Room) – 4 orcs + 1 per PC • Leaving the Manse – Surviving boars/anchorites from W1 + 2 needle blights per PC • Courtyard Noise – Triggers W10 and W18 occupants
B.
