Tactical Summary Sidebar Include this sidebar for dynamic response: • Noise in W8 or W9? → W10 (Grannoc + blights) and W18 (orcs) mobilize. • Disturb W1? → Anchorites reveal themselves upon departure unless engaged earlier. • If Grannoc is killed → Blights lose coordination (may fight less intelligently or retreat). • Destroy the Gulthias tree → No new blights spawn during blood moon nights.
2. Narrative and Atmosphere Primer
Tone of the Manse This is not a standard dungeon—it’s a corrupted place, once a scholar’s refuge, now a festering wound in the woods. • Invoke themes of ruin, dark nature, corrupted memory, and divine wrath. • Use Talos’s imagery: thunder rumbling even when skies are clear, static in the air, distant bestial growls like oncoming storms.
Recurring Symbols of Talos • Tri-bolt sigils, blood-soaked twigs, pig’s blood runes • Sacrificed small animals, storm-battered symbols • Ritual chants echoing in Orcish and Common
3. Adventure Hooks & Player Motivations Recap
If your players need a reminder or you want to reinforce stakes: • Falcon’s Lodge at risk: The longer they delay, the closer Talos’s storm draws. • Gulthias tree’s power grows: Mention how locals speak of twisted things crawling from the forest since the anchorites came. • Tying into Circle of Thunder: If they encountered the boar-druid or Xanth the centaur, Grannoc may be the source of rising corruption.

note.name: Arrival
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Following a winding trail through Neverwinter Wood, you step into a fog-shrouded clearing choked with the scent of wet moss and distant rot. Looming before you is a two-story stone manse, its cracked walls and gabled roof all but engulfed by thorny ivy. Moss creeps across its stone foundation, and wild pumpkins sprout in chaotic patches around the clearing. Several dark shapes—boars—snort and root among the gourds, raising their heads as you approach. Above the rotted wooden doors, a crumbling balcony clings to the façade like a broken jawbone. The forest here is silent, save for the crackling of leaves under hoof and foot.
DM Notes: 1. Points of Approach: • From Falcon’s Hunting Lodge (west): The trail breaks from the tree line and curves into the foggy clearing. The ground is soft with rain-soaked leaves. • From Circle of Thunder (north): The forest grows denser, until the manse appears like a tumor of stone and ivy in the mist. 2. First Impressions: • Characters with Wisdom (Survival) DC 12 notice signs of recent activity—orc tracks, gouges in trees, broken gourds with blood flecks. • A DC 15 Intelligence (Nature or Arcana) check reveals that the surrounding pumpkin patches show faint signs of magical influence—overgrowth, unnatural bloom patterns, and the pungent tang of transmutation magic. 3. Ambient Descriptors: • The ivy pulses faintly with a sickly green hue when moonlight hits it. • A low thrumming, almost like a heartbeat, can be heard by any character who succeeds a DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) check—this is the Gulthias tree’s slow, rhythmic stirring from within the well (area W8).
Exploration Hooks: • Characters may choose to: 1. Scout the perimeter (takes 10–15 minutes): Characters find ivy-covered windows and collapsed roof sections. This reveals possible points of infiltration: W2 (balcony), broken roof near W7, or collapsed ceiling above W9. 2. Approach the boars (area W1): Triggers potential engagement or future ambush. The boars ignore the party unless provoked or until the final encounter (“Leaving the Manse”). 3. Examine the manse magically: A detect magic spell reveals ambient transmutation and necrotic auras around the ivy, pumpkins, and beneath the courtyard well

note.name: W1. Pumpkin Patches
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Amid the tangle of ivy and creeping fog, ripe pumpkins bulge from the earth like swollen amber skulls. Nine patches stretch around the clearing, their vines thick and glistening with morning dew. You count several boars grunting and rooting through the loamy soil—some glance your way, snorting and blinking lazily in the mist. There’s a strange, pulsing warmth in the air, as if the gourds themselves were breathing.
DM Notes: 1. Creatures Present: • Nine total boar-shaped figures are present. • Six are ordinary boars. • Three are anchorites of Talos in boar form (via the Polymorph spell). • If needed, determine an individual boar’s true nature with a d6 roll: on a 5–6, it is an anchorite. 2. Behavior: • The boars (and anchorites in disguise) ignore the party unless provoked or until the group attempts to leave the manse (see “Leaving the Manse”). • Attacking or casting a spell near them will trigger a coordinated retaliation. If one is exposed, the rest join the fight. • Characters using Detect Magic or Detect Evil and Good will detect a faint necromantic aura on the disguised anchorites. 3. Investigation Options: • DC 13 Wisdom (Animal Handling): Reveals that some of the boars seem “too intelligent”—they stare too long, respond to subtle movement, or keep distance more deliberately than the others. • DC 15 Wisdom (Perception): Notes that three of the boars move with uncanny coordination, always mirroring one another’s spacing. • Speak with Animals reveals that the real boars are scared and uneasy; they’ll whisper that “the others don’t smell right.”
Magical Pumpkins: 1. Aura: • Detect Magic reveals a dim transmutation aura from each pumpkin. • Carving open a pumpkin (action) reveals six servings of enchanted seeds. 2. Effects of Eating Pumpkin Seeds: • As an action, a creature may eat a serving to regain 1 hit point. • Eating more than five servings in 1 hour triggers a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or the creature becomes poisoned for 1d4 hours.
Tactical Tip (Optional):
If the party sets up a camp or short rests in or near the patch, have a real boar or disguised anchorite observe them quietly from 60 ft. away. The anchorites could retreat to alert Grannoc if not exposed here

note.name: W2. Portico and Balcony
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Stone steps, cracked and crumbling with age, lead up to a weather-stained portico. Thick ivy coils around squat columns like strangling fingers. Above, a sagging stone balcony looms ten feet overhead, its cracked railing held together more by vines than masonry. The double doors at ground level bear a crude carving of a snarling boar’s head—its eyes gouged out and tusks exaggerated in size. Another set of unmarred double doors, half-shaded by ivy, waits atop the balcony.
DM Notes: 1. Access & Layout: • This area is the main point of entry to the manse. • Two entrances exist: • Ground level double doors (beneath the balcony). • Second-floor balcony doors (above, leads to W14). • Both sets of doors are free of ivy, not trapped, and safe to open (unlike many others in the manse). • Ivy clings to nearby walls and pillars, and is mildly poisonous to touch (see below). 2. Climbing to the Balcony: • A character may climb the ivy-covered wall or pillar to reach the balcony: • Requires a DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check. • On failure, the character falls and takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage (10 ft drop). • With assistance or a rope, the check is made with advantage. 3. Poisonous Ivy (Environmental Hazard): • Any creature climbing the ivy must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw upon contact. • On a failure, they take 2 (1d4) poison damage. • Repeat this save every round they remain in contact with the ivy. 4. Inspection of the Boar Carving: • A DC 13 Intelligence (Religion) check reveals the carving was hastily added, not original to the structure. • A DC 15 Wisdom (Survival) check notes fresh claw marks around the mouth, suggesting recent rituals or attempts to “feed” the carving.
Tactical Consideration: • If the party makes loud noise here (e.g., shouting, slamming doors, or smashing the carving), roll a d6: • On a roll of 5–6, a blight in the courtyard (W8) becomes aware and begins moving cautiously toward the sound. • If Grannoc (W10) is still alive and the party is loud at night, consider having him peek from the balcony above before retreating

note.name: W3. Downstairs Hall
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The air here is thick with mildew and rot. A creaky wooden staircase winds upward along the east wall, its railing partially collapsed and its steps warped with age. Faint water damage streaks the crumbling stone walls. A pair of rotted doors hang slightly ajar at either end of the corridor, their hinges whining in protest at the breeze.
DM Notes: 1. Structure & Layout: • The ground-level hallway connects the main entrance (W2) to rooms W4 and W5. • A rickety staircase rises 10 feet to area W14 on the second floor. • The ceiling is 8 feet high and heavily cobwebbed. 2. Trapped Stairs: • The upper half of the staircase (the last 5 feet) is compromised and trapped. • If 50 pounds or more is placed on the upper steps, they collapse, causing the creature to fall. • The collapsing stairs reveal wooden spikes underneath. Trap Mechanics: • A creature on the stairs must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. • On a failure, they fall and land on 1d6 spikes, taking: • 1d6 bludgeoning damage (fall). • 1d6 piercing damage per spike (1d6 total). • A successful save avoids the fall. 3. Detection & Disarming: • A DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals signs of rot and strain on the upper steps. • With 10 minutes of careful work, a character can brace the stairs with planks or rope, preventing collapse

note.name: W4. Parlor
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
This chamber reeks of damp wood and sour mold. Shards of shattered furniture litter the floor—jagged remains of chairs, a splintered side table, and what might once have been a wine cabinet. A circular rug lies rotting in the center of the room, its colors long bled into the dust.
DM Notes: 1. Decay and Mood: • The entire room is strewn with splintered debris. • The rug covers most of the floor and is soft, spongey, and harbors mildew spores. 2. Hazard – Moldy Rug: • If a creature disturbs the rug (e.g., stepping directly onto it or pulling it up), a cloud of spores erupts. • Creatures within 10 feet must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or begin coughing violently. • On a failure: Disadvantage on Perception checks that rely on smell or speech-based checks for 1 hour. 3. Exploration Clues: • Characters who inspect the wine cabinet notice signs that alcohol was recently taken—a small sticky smear on the shelf. • This clue could hint that Grannoc or the orcs from W18 have been looting the old cellar stores. 4. No Treasure: • This room has been fully ransacked and holds no items of value

note.name: W5. Dining Room
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The air is sharp with the tang of iron and decay. Crude drawings coat the walls in streaks of dark red—boars, their tusks gory, chasing stick-figure people beneath storm clouds and bolts of lightning. A smashed wooden dining table lies in a heap near the far wall, surrounded by broken chairs. A soot-stained fireplace broods along the southern wall, cold and silent.
DM Notes: 1. Atmosphere & Detail: • The blood-drawn murals are disturbing—childlike in form but vicious in energy. • Characters who inspect the drawings and succeed on a DC 10 Intelligence (Religion or Arcana) check recognize Talos iconography: lightning bolts and storm-touched beasts. • The table and chairs are splintered, likely broken during a violent struggle or ritual. 2. Fireplace Clue – Twig Figures: • If the characters spared or avoided the boar-form anchorite during the “Boar-ing Encounter” (Loggers’ Camp travel), they now see small twig figurines resting on the mantel. • There is one figure for each adventurer (including sidekicks). • Each figure bears crude features eerily similar to a character’s gear or hairstyle. Interacting with the Twig Figures: • If any figure is touched, lifted, or damaged: • It animates and transforms into a twig blight, immediately attacking. • All figures animate if one is triggered. • Use standard twig blight stat blocks. • If left alone, they remain inert. 3. Exploration Clues: • The fireplace ash smells of burned meat and fur, hinting at past rituals. • A DC 13 Wisdom (Survival) check shows tracks leading away from the fireplace toward the courtyard (W8), as if creatures have come and gone recently. 4. Treasure: • Hidden beneath the debris of a shattered chair leg is a tarnished silver candelabrum worth 25 gp. • A DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check is required to notice it glinting in the debris

note.name: W6. Kitchen
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The smell of damp rot and old wood hangs thick in this kitchen. Vines poke through the cracked stone walls and trail across decayed countertops. The outer door has long since been shattered off its hinges, and the inside of the pantry door shows gnaw marks where rats have chewed through the lower planks.
DM Notes: 1. State of the Room: • The room is weather-exposed, overgrown, and mostly useless for supplies. • Countertops are warped and splitting. Copper pans dangle from rusted hooks. • A small blackened iron stove stands cold and cracked near the back wall. 2. Signs of Wilderness Encroachment: • Ivy and moss grow thickly over stone surfaces. • A DC 10 Intelligence (Nature) check confirms the rat activity has been recent—no more than a few tendays. • Characters may hear faint chirping if they remain still—nesting birds in the pantry. 3. Exploration Hooks: • The door to area W7 (Pantry) is mostly intact but riddled with holes at its base. • A DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals tiny, muddy claw prints near the pantry—twig blights may have passed through here recently

note.name: W7. Pantry
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The roof here has half-collapsed, leaving a wide hole above and littering the floor with rotted beams and wet leaves. What once were rows of shelves now lean precariously, twisted under the weight of nests and decay. Birds flutter nervously in the rafters. Whatever food once lined the shelves has long since rotted or been consumed.
DM Notes: 1. Environmental Details: • The roof breach allows dim natural light to filter in during the day. • Birds (harmless) nest in the upper rafters. If disturbed, they panic and fly through the hole in the roof (see also W16). 2. Scavenged Storage: • No edible or usable provisions remain—everything has been spoiled by time, water, or wildlife. • Mold, mildew, and faint signs of blight passage (drag marks, scratches) are present. • Characters with a DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation) check might spot a twig blight claw mark on the back wall, indicating they emerged from the courtyard via a crack in the stones. 3. Collapsed Roof: • Connects to area W16: Slanted Rooftop. • If a character attempts to climb up, it requires a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check. • Failing by 5 or more causes them to dislodge rotted wood and fall back, taking 1d6 bludgeoning damage and creating audible noise that may alert W18

note.name: W8. Courtyard
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Worn stone steps descend into a sunken courtyard enclosed by the villa’s weather-stained stone walls. Pillared arcades ring the area to the east, their arches tangled with ivy. Seven shuttered windows stare down from the second story. At the courtyard’s center, a circular stone well yawns open—its mouth choked with thick, twisting vines that glisten with damp sap. The very air here feels still, thick, as though the garden itself is holding its breath.
From the southeast, you hear a low, guttural grunt—followed by orcish voices raised in argument and excitement.
DM Notes:
1. Layout and Features
a. The courtyard is 40 feet square with flagstone paving slick from years of moisture and moss. b. A five-foot-wide stone well sits in the center, its walls overgrown with ivy and veins of black-barked roots erupting from within. c. Pillared arcades along the eastern wall provide cover and line-of-sight breaks (use as half cover). d. Windows above overlook the area from W14 and other second-floor rooms. These can be accessed later or used by enemies.
2. The Gulthias Tree and Vine Blights
a. The well shaft descends 30 feet into the earth and contains a malformed Gulthias tree, warped and columnar, its twisting branches forming narrow gaps that descend into the dark. b. The tree is a Huge plant (AC 15, 250 HP, vulnerable to fire, regrows unless uprooted). c. Vine blights hide within the shaft—one blight plus one per PC, not counting sidekicks (max 5). They cling motionless unless provoked or commanded. d. Blights emerge if: - The tree or blights are damaged. - Grannoc (from W10) calls them forth. - Loud noise or combat breaks out.
3. Combat Triggers
a. Sounding the Alarm: - Grannoc and twig blights from W10 investigate on initiative count 20 (after the noise). - Orcs from W18 drop into W9, then burst into the courtyard on the following round. b. Tactical Notes: - The well is difficult terrain once the blights emerge. - The arcades offer partial cover but limit retreat options. - Characters attempting to climb down the well can do so without checks once the blights are cleared.
4. Gulthias Tree Effects
a. On nights with a blood-red moon, the tree spawns blights: - 2d6 twig blights - 1d6 needle blights - 1d4 vine blights b. These crawl free and lurk in the surrounding woods or reinforce Grannoc and his followers.
5. Investigation and Lore
a. A DC 13 Intelligence (Nature or Arcana) check identifies the tree as unnatural—a twisted remnant of dark magic and blood sacrifice. b. A DC 15 Intelligence (Religion) check connects the blight magic to the Anchorites of Talos and the corrupted rituals of their circle

note.name: The Gulthias Tree
note.text:
1. Description and Lore
The twisted husk growing from the old well is no ordinary plant—it is a Gulthias tree, a malevolent entity born of death and decay. It pulses faintly with unholy life, its branches knotted like gnarled claws and its sap as red as blood. This tree is the heart of the blight corruption that has spread across the manse and forest. • Appearance: A malformed column of dark wood, 30 feet tall, its bark striated with deep crimson veins. The roots twist unnaturally around the well’s interior. • Lore Hook (DC 15 Religion or Nature): This is no natural growth. Gulthias trees are created from stakes used to slay powerful undead or cursed beings, corrupted into spawning evil flora like twig, needle, and vine blights. • Origin Story (optional): Grannoc may have acquired the cursed seed during a Talos-blessed blood moon, planting it with the express purpose of birthing this corrupted grove.
2. Tree Stats and Mechanics
Treat the Gulthias tree as a unique environmental hazard and potential quest target. • Type: Huge Plant (immobile) • AC: 15 • HP: 250 • Damage Vulnerabilities: Fire • Damage Immunities: Psychic, Poison • Speed: 0 ft. • Senses: Blindsight 30 ft. (root network) • Actions: None (it is not actively hostile but reacts to damage or rituals) • Regrowth: Unless uprooted, it regrows from roots after 24 hours, recovering 1 HP/day.
3. Defensive Features
a. Vine Blight Guardians • There are 1d4+1 vine blights coiled within the well (max 5). • They attack if: • The tree is harmed. • Loud noise is made in the courtyard. • Grannoc commands them from area W10.
b. Blood Moon Bloom (Optional Rule) • On nights with a red moon, the tree spawns: • 2d6 twig blights • 1d6 needle blights • 1d4 vine blights • These crawl from the well like insects from a nest, spreading corruption across the forest.
4. Player Interactions
a. Climbing Into the Well • Once the blights are dealt with, a Medium or smaller creature can climb into the well safely—no check required—to investigate or destroy the tree.
b. Destroying the Tree • Fire is most effective. • Uprooting the tree (e.g. via powerful magic or druidic intervention) prevents its regrowth. • Casting Remove Curse or Hallow may suppress its effects, at the DM’s discretion.
c. Magical Effects • The tree radiates faint necromantic and transmutation auras (detectable via detect magic). • Its presence may taint healing magic nearby—consider having spells like Goodberry or Cure Wounds fail on a roll of 1 on a d6 when cast within 30 ft.
5. Narrative Hooks and Expansion
a. Druidic Response • The Emerald Enclave may become aware of the Gulthias tree’s presence and ask the party to destroy or study it.
b. Corruption Spreading • If left unchecked, the tree could begin tainting other parts of Neverwinter Wood, creating a larger wilderness threat or campaign arc.
c. Talos’ Will • If Grannoc dies and the tree is still standing, a new anchorite might rise from the roots—a blighted storm druid or vengeful dryad corrupted by Talos

note.name: W9. Apprentices' Room
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
This wide, low-ceilinged room blends kitchen, dining space, and sleeping quarters into one cluttered chamber. Four weathered beds line the southern wall, their blankets tattered and moth-chewed. Between the beds stand nightstands and shuttered windows, choked with ivy.
A trestle table near a blackened hearth is strewn with cracked pots, scorched utensils, and moldy cooking gear. A second dining table sits in the northeast corner, flanked by four wooden chairs, one of which lies splintered and overturned.
The southwestern ceiling has collapsed, spilling rubble into the room and revealing a jagged hole that looks up into a second story chamber.
DM Notes:
1. History & Use
a. This was once the shared chamber of the wizard’s four apprentices, who lived, studied, and cooked here. b. When their master vanished, the apprentices pillaged the manse’s library (W11) and fled with their belongings, leaving behind only ruined furnishings and decay.
2. Features
a. Four beds, wardrobes, and nightstands—all mundane and falling apart. b. Cooking gear is filthy and rusted, and the fireplace is long dead, its chimney cold. c. A cabinet full of dishware and cutlery is in poor condition but intact—nothing of value.
3. Climbing to W18
a. A 6-foot-wide hole in the ceiling opens into W18 (Guest Room). b. Adventurers may stack furniture (chairs, wardrobes) and climb up without a check if reasonable methods are used. c. If they try to jump or climb unaided, call for a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check.
4. Combat Alert
a. If characters make loud noise (such as fighting, smashing furniture, or shouting), the orcs in W18 respond: - On initiative 20, they drop down through the ceiling hole. - On their next turn, they burst into melee through the northern door. - There are four orcs, plus one per character, not including sidekicks.
5. Investigation Opportunities
a. A DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation) check reveals: - Old bootprints heading toward the library. - A charred symbol etched into the hearth—three lightning bolts joined at the tips (Talos). b. DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) identifies faint bloody fingerprints on the wardrobe doors.
6. Mood & Atmosphere • Scents: mildew, scorched iron, and spoiled meat. • Sounds: wind through ivy, groaning floorboards above

note.name: Grannoc, Anchorite Of Talos W.10
note.text:
“The storm does not ask your name. It only comes.”
Race: Half-Orc Class/Role: Anchorite of Talos (lightning-wielding cultist leader) HP: 76 | AC: 14 (Hide armor) | Spells: Shocking Grasp, Thunderwave, Call Lightning Language: Common, Orc
Personality: Grannoc is deliriously devoted to Talos. His faith is raw, elemental, and terrifying. He believes the world must be broken before it can be reborn in lightning and fire. He speaks in cryptic imagery, often quoting storms as omens or signs of Talos’s pleasure. • Voice: Gravel-thick, punctuated by sharp inhales like he’s breathing in a storm. • Mannerisms: Constantly muttering invocations. Traces lightning sigils in the air with bloodied fingers. • Mood: Frenzied serenity—like a calm eye of a storm ready to burst.
Sample Quips: • “Do you hear it? The sky hungers.” • “Talos feeds on the bones of still houses.” • “Your breath belongs to thunder.”
Combat Tactics: 1. Opens with Call Lightning, targeting the largest cluster of PCs. 2. Commands twig blights to swarm and flank. 3. Uses Thunderwave if cornered. 4. Retreats if reduced below 20 HP, only if blights or orcs can cover his escape. 5. If killed during a storm, his blood arcs upward like static into the clouds—a parting gift from Talos.
Reinforcements: If alarm is raised in W8 or W9, Grannoc commands the vine blights in the well to emerge. He uses his first turn to issue this command, then hurls spells from behind their wall of bramble limbs.
Optional Lore Hook: If your campaign involves the Rise of Talos or you wish to connect to Storm King’s Thunder or Princes of the Apocalypse, Grannoc was only a minor prophet. He carried a bone idol of Talos, which can act as a cursed relic or divine focus. Destroying it could weaken the storms plaguing the region—or unleash a worse wrath

note.name: W10. Wizard's Laboratory
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Beyond a broken door lies a ruined laboratory. Shattered glass, splintered wood, and crumpled parchment litter the stone floor. In the center of the room, scrawled in mud, is a 10-foot-wide arcane sigil: three jagged lightning bolts joined at their tips, forming a rough triangle.
The scent of damp earth and rotting meat hangs heavy in the air.
DM Notes:
1. Layout & Condition
a. The door from W8 is smashed open; the lab lies in complete darkness unless lit by torches, spells, or darkvision. b. Shelves once stocked with reagents and scrolls are now emptied or collapsed. c. Rubble along the walls marks the destruction of magical furniture, potion racks, and arcane tools.
2. The Symbol
a. The sigil is Talos’s mark—three lightning bolts converging. b. A DC 15 Intelligence (Religion) check identifies it. A cleric of the Tempest domain auto-succeeds. c. Characters who step into or disturb the sigil cause it to sputter with static energy but suffer no damage.
3. Grannoc’s Ritual
a. If the party has not made noise in W8, Grannoc is here conducting a ritual. - He dances wildly in the mud sigil, chanting prayers to Talos and eating possum entrails. - Around him stand twig blights (3 per PC, not including sidekicks). b. DC 15 Intelligence (Religion) reveals the ritual’s aim: to invoke a storm on Falcon’s Lodge. c. Interrupting the ritual draws Grannoc’s immediate fury.
4. Grannoc’s Stats and Notes • Anchorite of Talos (see Monster Manual or Essentials Kit appendix). • Wears hide armor with boar tusk trim, streaked with ash and blood. • Carries a charred satchel flap bearing a crude map of Neverwinter Wood, marking the Circle of Thunder.
5. Tactics
a. If startled, Grannoc shouts to the twig blights and commands the vine blights in W8’s well to rise. b. He casts shatter first (if needed), then wields a lightning-infused spear (flavor only, standard attack). c. If bloodied, he tries to flee into W17 or W12, using chaos to regroup with orcs.
6. Treasure
a. The map in his satchel grants the party access to the Circle of Thunder quest. b. His boar-tooth amulet (nonmagical) has value to a druidic faction like the Emerald Enclave (worth 25 gp). c. If you wish to seed lore, include a fragmented scroll of Talos’s rites, which could foreshadow Gorthok the Thunder Boar or other anchorite schemes

note.name: W11. Library
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The musty scent of rotting parchment and old wood fills this once-grand library. A ten-foot-high wooden balcony curls around the upper walls, supported by carved pillars and accessed by a spiral staircase to the west. Bowed and broken bookshelves line the walls on both levels, while below, four writing desks stand amid scattered tomes and the wreckage of time.
A few moldy books cling to the shadows, their pages warped by damp and years of neglect.
DM Notes:
1. Physical Description • The room spans both floors of the manse. The spiral staircase near the west wall connects the ground to the 10-foot-high balcony. • Balcony railing is damaged in places. Characters leaning against it must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw to avoid falling if a section gives way (optional tension moment).
2. Lighting & Atmosphere • Dim natural light seeps through broken roof slats, casting lines of sun or moonlight onto the floor. • The silence here is unnatural, broken only by the occasional soft sound of dripping water or shifting wood.
Exploration & Interactions
3. Book Contents
a. Most of the shelves are empty or hold worthless, water-damaged tomes. b. A character searching for information on the manse’s history or Talos cults finds little of value, unless you choose to seed a clue.
4. Notable Finds
a. A character who searches the ground-floor desks and succeeds on a DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check finds: • A book used to prop up a desk leg: Elvish Idioms, a small text with a hidden compartment. • Inside: a tiny leather packet of dust of disappearance. (Give the Dust of Disappearance card or reference it in the magic item list.)
5. Secret Door
a. One of the bookcases on the balcony conceals a secret stone door to W12 (Master Bedroom). b. A character examining the shelves and succeeding on a DC 10 Wisdom (Perception) check notices slight scrape marks and wear in the dust. c. Pulling the shelf outward swings the bookcase and the door open silently.
Optional Enhancements • Arcane Echo (if you want a magical trace): When standing alone on the balcony, a character might hear faint whispers in Elvish—perhaps the wizard’s voice or scraps of poetry or incantations. This could tease a deeper history of the house or its original owner. • Lore Hook: Include a fragment referencing the Gulthias tree, Talos cult rituals, or names of lost elven kingdoms—especially useful if players are seeking larger lore connections.

note.name: W12. Master Bedroom
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
This once-stately chamber still clings to a memory of elegance. A four-poster bed draped in dusty rags rests against the western wall, flanked by shuttered windows tangled with ivy. An empty wardrobe leans crookedly along the eastern wall, its door ajar like a yawning mouth. A simple desk and chair stand silently in the northern alcove, while a soot-blackened fireplace dominates the south wall, its mantel carved with leafwork and crescent motifs.
DM Notes:
1. General Description • This room belonged to the half-elf wizard who built the manse. • Most furnishings are mundane and degraded: cracked wood, dusty linen, and mildew stains. • No enemies are present unless a haunt or magical echo is introduced by you.
2. Atmosphere • The air smells faintly of burned wood and dried lavender. • If players have experienced any ghostly phenomena in the library (W11), they may feel a subtle arcane residue lingering here.
Exploration & Discoveries
3. Desk & Wardrobe • Desk: Empty drawers, old ink stains, and a brittle quill. No hidden compartments. • Wardrobe: Stripped bare. Cobwebs fill its corners, and claw-like ivy has crept in through cracks in the shutters nearby.
4. Magical Mantelpiece (Treasure Hook)
a. A detect magic spell reveals a conjuration aura coming from the fireplace mantel. b. A character who searches the mantel and succeeds on a DC 10 Wisdom (Perception) check finds a cleverly hidden compartment lid carved to match the surrounding woodwork. c. The lid lifts away, revealing a recessed, silk-lined nook.
Treasure: • A staff of birdcalls, perfectly preserved, lies nestled inside. • When identified or attuned, it becomes a whimsical utility item beloved by druids or rangers.
(Give the players the Staff of Birdcalls card, or allow them to reference it in the Magic Items Listing.)
Optional Enhancements • Magical Echo: If you’re adding arcane memory traces or flavor haunts, you might have the characters hear a quiet voice (in Elvish or whispered Common) reciting nature-based invocations or names of old friends. • Clue to Grannoc: A faded ink scrawl on the desk’s underside reads: “Protect the well. Guard the tree.” This cryptic line hints at the Gulthias Tree in W8

note.name: W13. Magic Item Vault
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The air here is still and dry, untouched by the rot that plagues the rest of the manse. A faint shimmer of arcane protection fades as the secret door swings open. Hanging on the far wall is a dramatic cloak that billows slightly, as if caught by a breeze that isn’t there. Beneath it, nestled in the shadows against the north wall, squats a wooden chest with tiny clawed feet. Its blackened iron bands glint faintly in your torchlight.
DM Notes:
1. General Description • This chamber is lightless and unnaturally clean, sealed for decades behind a secret door from W12 (Master Bedroom). • The air is cool and dry, suggesting a preserved vault untouched by weather or wildlife. • A light magical pulse can be felt by anyone attuned to magic.
2. Security & Opening
a. The secret door can be found from W12 by tugging a disguised bookcase (as described there). b. Once opened, there’s no trap or ward beyond the arcane seal that preserved the items inside.
Magic Items
3. Cloak on Hook • A cloak of billowing, enchanted for style rather than combat, hangs on a heavy iron hook. • When donned, it flutters dramatically at the wearer’s command (as a bonus action). • The cloak is well made, black and silver, with subtle lightning embroidery on the hem—perhaps a vanity gift from the original wizard to themselves.
4. Chest with Clawed Feet • This Small object weighs 30 lbs and has AC 15, 20 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. • The chest is magically locked and opens in one of three ways: • A knock spell or similar magic. • A successful DC 20 Dexterity check using thieves’ tools. • Smashing it open (no traps, but loud).
Inside the Chest: • An immovable rod, wrapped in black cloth and resting atop a folded note that reads: • “May this hold the heavens steady should the storms try to take you.” • This poetic phrasing could be tied to Talos or the original wizard’s superstitions.
(Give the players the Cloak of Billowing and Immovable Rod cards when identified, or allow them to reference them in the Magic Items Listing.)
Optional Narrative Hooks • Legacy Note: You may place a folded, weathered page in the cloak’s inner pocket—perhaps a fragment from the wizard’s journal hinting at their disappearance or regret for awakening something dark (like the Gulthias tree). • Talisman of Talos: The chest may have been desecrated at one point by Grannoc—smudged chalk lightning bolts on the inner lid are nearly rubbed away

note.name: W14. Upstairs Hall
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
This dusty, L-shaped corridor stretches before you, the cracked walls lined with shuttered windows and iron hooks where portraits or tapestries once hung. One wall bears a fireplace choked with ash and crowned by a massive insectoid head mounted above the mantel—its glassy eyes catching what little light filters in from a collapsed section of roof at the far end. The wooden floor creaks underfoot, and a chill breeze stirs the ivy pushing through broken shutters. Above, dark wooden rafters disappear into gloom.
DM Notes:
1. General Features • Ceiling: 15 feet high and peaked. Wooden rafters cross at 10 feet, creating shadows where creatures might lurk. • Natural Light: Dim illumination filters in through holes in the roof at the eastern end. • Fireplace: A cold hearth is set in the wall, above which hangs the mounted head of an ankheg, its chitin cracked and mottled from exposure.
2. Decor and Decay • The ankheg head is real, a grotesque trophy from the original wizard’s early exploits. It’s harmless, but disturbing. • The hooks once held banners of ancient elven ruins or arcane charts—now lost or stolen. • The floorboards groan, but are stable except for where the roof has collapsed—here, debris counts as difficult terrain (10-foot-square area).
Creature Encounter: Stirges
3. Lurking Threats • Hanging silently among the rafters, three stirges per party member (not including sidekicks), up to a maximum of twelve, roost in the shadows. • They remain passive until a warm-blooded creature enters the darkened corridor leading toward W12 (Master Bedroom).
4. Triggering the Stirges • Trigger: Any creature stepping into the darker stretch of hall within 20 feet of W12 awakens the stirges. • Surprise Round: If characters aren’t actively watching the rafters, the stirges ambush with advantage on initiative. • Tactics: Stirges dive for the first warm-blooded creatures, ignoring constructs or undead, and latch on immediately using Blood Drain.
Optional Clue: A DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals faint droppings and dried blood stains on the floor directly below the rafters.
Sidebar: Environmental Clues & Exploration • A character inspecting the ankheg head with a DC 12 Intelligence (Nature) check can determine it’s been dead at least a decade and slain with precision blows—hinting the wizard was once a capable hunter. • The collapsed roof section above the eastern end of the hall may lead PCs to wonder if enemies above have alternate ways in or out (W16 lies just above)

note.name: W15. Bathroom
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
A narrow door opens into a circular chamber with a conical roof. A claw-footed iron tub dominates the center of the room, its sides rusted and streaked with mildew. Ivy creeps in through a gaping window to the north, curling around the tub’s legs like searching fingers. Next to the tub stands a squat iron water pump, its spout crusted with red mineral deposits.
DM Notes: 1. General Features: • Natural Light: Dim sunlight filters through the open northern window. • Ivy Growth: Ivy enters through the broken frame, making the tub look partially consumed by the forest. • Water Pump: Still functional. Drawing the pump handle causes lukewarm water to flow—fed by a hot spring beneath the manse. • A character inspecting the plumbing with a DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation) check discovers the same spring is connected to the W26. Ghoul Bath in Axeholm (eerie coincidence or hint at ancient plumbing magic). • Scent: A mix of wet iron, mildew, and the faint metallic tang of decay. 2. Optional Interaction: • Pump Use: A character who cleans themselves in the tub and drinks the spring water regains 1d4 hit points, but only once per long rest. • Surprise: If you want a moment of eerie tension, have the sound of water awaken a distant echo from the courtyard, as if something deep underground stirs

note.name: W16. Slanted Rooftop
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The attic hatch groans as you push it open, revealing a steeply sloped rooftop shingled in wood and crawling with ivy. Large holes yawn where the roof has collapsed into the pantry below, the shattered beams exposed like ribs. The scent of rotting leaves and wet thatch fills the air, and every step feels like it might be your last.
DM Notes: 1. Rooftop Terrain: • Slope: The rooftop rises toward the east and west. Movement across it requires caution. • Ivy: Ivy covers much of the surface. A character who runs or dashes across the rooftop must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check to avoid slipping (treat as difficult terrain). • Rot and Weakness: The westernmost 15-foot-square section is particularly unstable. • Trap: If a creature weighing 50 pounds or more walks on this section, it collapses. • Any creature in the area must make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall into W7. Pantry, taking 3 (1d6) bludgeoning damage. 2. Exploration Hooks: • View of the Forest: A character who crawls to the roof’s peak and spends a few moments scanning the horizon can spot the towering Circle of Thunder stone circle in the far distance (DC 15 Wisdom [Perception] check). • Landing Point: Characters trying to access the manse through broken windows or the collapsed roof might enter W7 or use this area to stealthily climb down to W8 (Courtyard)

note.name: W17. Upper Arcade
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
This long corridor runs behind a crumbling exterior wall. Four narrow windows let in shafts of pale light through ivy-covered openings, and thick vines coil across the floor like tangled ropes. Two sets of double doors stand to the north and south, their wood swollen with age and streaked with moss.
From beyond the southern door comes the low murmur of guttural voices, punctuated by the scrape of metal on stone.
DM Notes: 1. General Features: • Lighting: The arcade is dimly lit by natural light from open, ivy-choked windows. • Ivy: Treat as difficult terrain. A creature moving through must make a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check to avoid tripping unless moving at half speed. • Doors: • North Door: Leads to W16. Rooftop. Unlocked but heavy. • South Door: Leads into W18. Guest Room, where orcs lie in wait. • Sounds: A character who succeeds on a DC 10 Wisdom (Perception) check hears: • “Falcon dies tonight.” • “Grannoc said wait for the thunder.” • The unmistakable rasp of blades being sharpened. 2. Tactical Tip: • Characters who eavesdrop or plan an ambush may gain surprise on the orcs in W18. • If characters force or break down the southern doors, the orcs are immediately alerted and gain surprise instead

note.name: W18. Guest Room
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Once a lavish guest room, this chamber is now a ruined den of violence. Broken bedframes and splintered furniture are pushed against the walls. Faded tapestries hang in tatters, soaked with mildew. Four burly orcs sit amid the wreckage, sharpening axes, gnawing bones, and arguing over the timing of a coming raid.
They freeze when the door opens, snarling and rising to grab their weapons.
DM Notes: 1. Enemies: • There are four orcs, plus one additional orc per party member, not including sidekicks. • These orcs serve Grannoc and are preparing to assault Falcon’s Hunting Lodge. 2. Combat Guidance: • The orcs fight fiercely and loudly. If they were not previously dealt with in W8, the sounds of battle alert the courtyard. • If characters entered via W9 (using the hole in the floor), the orcs are surprised unless they were already on alert. 3. Terrain Features: • Hole to W9: A 5-foot hole in the southwest corner leads to the Apprentices’ Room below. Climbing up or down requires a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check unless furniture is used. • Barricades: The orcs have arranged furniture to make rough cover (+2 AC). A character can shove or leap over these with a DC 12 Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. 4. Flavor Details: • The room reeks of blood and wet fur. • Orc graffiti scrawled on the walls includes crude symbols of Talos and the words: “Storm comes. All burn.” 5. Optional Treasure (if you want to include loot): • Tucked under a broken cabinet is a pouch of iron teeth, a totem of Grannoc’s making (worth 25 gp to the right collector or used to identify other cults of Talos). • A scrap of parchment with a crude map pointing toward Falcon’s Lodge, confirming the planned raid

note.name: Leaving the Manse
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The ruined manse falls quiet behind you, its ivy-covered walls cloaked in fog and silence once more. But as you turn to leave the clearing, a low growl carries on the wind. Twigs crack. Boars snort in unison. From the tree line and pumpkin patches, shapes begin to stir—more than just beasts…
A final challenge waits for those who dare disturb the domain of Talos.
DM Notes:
As the characters attempt to exit the manse—whether through the courtyard (W8), front portico (W2), or even upper windows—a last ambush is triggered if any of the following conditions are met: • Not all anchorites in boar form from W1 were slain. • Any boars from W1 escaped. • Grannoc’s ritual was interrupted but not all blights were destroyed. • The players made excessive noise and fled the manse prematurely.
Encounter Structure: 1. Ambushing Forces: a. Anchorites of Talos (W1 survivors): • Any surviving anchorites in boar form revert to their humanoid shape mid-charge and attack with lightning spells and savage glee. b. Boars (W1 survivors): • Fight alongside anchorites, darting and flanking to push characters toward the vine-choked terrain. c. Needle Blights: • Two blights per character, not including sidekicks, rise from the forest shadows. • They position themselves to cut off retreat from the trail to Falcon’s Lodge or the Circle of Thunder. 2. Tactical Terrain: • Vines and Ivy: Treat the edges of the clearing as difficult terrain. • Pumpkin Patches: Creatures moving through must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or become entangled (speed halved for 1 round). • Fog: Lightly obscures the field unless magical light or darkvision is used.
Narrative Flavor: • The ambush is not purely tactical—this is a thematic final push by Talos’s forces to crush the invaders. • If the party defeated Grannoc, surviving anchorites scream his name in fury. • If Grannoc survived and escaped, he may appear here himself riding a summoned storm boar (you can optionally reskin Gorthok the Thunder Boar at lower power).
Aftermath Options: 1. Victory: • The adventurers break the last resistance of Talos’s cultists. The storm clears. The forest is still. • If they spare any anchorites, those cultists may flee into Neverwinter Wood and become recurring threats. • The Gulthias tree, if still standing, may now regrow or summon new horrors if not dealt with. 2. Retreat: • Characters who flee may be hunted later or ambushed again on the road. • Falcon may offer a reward just for the warning, even if the manse wasn’t fully cleansed

note.name: Counterattack!
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Storm clouds churn over Neverwinter Wood, unnatural and thick with fury. Thunder cracks like war drums. Rain slashes the trees sideways. Then—a deafening boom. From the misted treeline near Falcon’s Hunting Lodge, a monstrous squeal echoes… and a wall of tusks and muscle crashes through the palisade.
The thunder boar has come.
Overview:
The day after the adventurers attack Woodland Manse, Talos’s surviving forces strike back with divine fury. Whether the manse was cleared or merely disturbed, this counterattack shows the party what happens when you draw the wrath of the Storm Lord.
This event can take place at Falcon’s Lodge, along the road, or as a dreamlike omen—depending on your pacing needs.
Encounter Setup: 1. Gorthok the Thunder Boar • A divine beast of storm and destruction. • If the party is still low level or injured, reduce his HP slightly or give foreshadowing before he arrives fully. • Full stats in the adventure (p47): AC 16, HP 136, Speed 60 ft., attacks with tusks and lightning aura. • Legendary Actions: Move, Tusk, Thunder Crash. 2. Orc Warband • 20 orcs total, scaled by player strength. • 1 orc per party member enters each round after Gorthok breaches the palisade, flooding in from the woods. • If needed, substitute half-orc anchorites of Talos for some variety. 3. Falcon and Allies • Falcon fights valiantly (stat block: scout), but is overwhelmed if unaided. • He can escape on horseback with his servants if the party falters. • If Falcon survives, he may offer the lodge as a future stronghold for the party.
Combat Flow (Suggested Structure): 1. Round 1: a. Gorthok crashes through the wooden palisade. b. Falcon shouts an alarm. Servants scatter. c. Storm intensifies. Roll for initiative. 2. Round 2+: a. 1–2 orcs enter from the forest edge each round (per character, not sidekicks). b. Characters can use the terrain: rope bridges, walls, firepits, etc. 3. Optional Twist: If Grannoc survived the manse, he rides atop Gorthok, hurling lightning or spells.
Outcomes: 1. If the Party Defends the Lodge Successfully: • The storm fades. The sky clears. • Falcon offers refuge, a banquet, or a title (“Guardians of the Lodge”). • Local fey or druids might appear with respectful curiosity. 2. If the Party Is Defeated or Retreats: • Falcon and his surviving staff flee toward Phandalin. • The orcs take the lodge, turning it into a Talosite war camp. • Falcon swears to rebuild… and seeks vengeance.
Narrative & Character Integration:
Use this moment to: • Emphasize the wrath of Talos and the cost of opposing storm-worshippers. • Foreshadow future adventures with surviving anchorites or corrupted nature. • Give each PC a personal spotlight—e.g., a lightning strike barely missing, a choice to save Falcon or fight Gorthok, a vision of Talos if unconscious

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 51

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting
trait.text:
The anchorite's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save DC 12). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
3/day: thunderwave (2d8 damage) 1/day each: augury, bless, lightning bolt (8d6 damage), revivify

trait.name: Shapechanger
trait.text: The anchorite can use its action to polymorph into a boar or back into its true form, which is humanoid. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

action.name: Clawed Gauntlet (Humanoid Form Only)
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d4 + 3) slashing damage.

action.name: Tusk (Boar Form Only)
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) slashing damage.

spell.name: Thunderwave
spell.text:
A wave of thunderous force sweeps out from you. Each creature in a 15-foot cube originating from you must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 2d8 thunder damage and is pushed 10 feet away from you. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed.
In addition, unsecured objects that are completely within the area of effect are automatically pushed 10 feet away from you by the spell's effect, and the spell emits a thunderous boom audible out to 300 feet.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Augury
spell.materials: specially marked sticks, bones, or similar tokens worth at least 25 gp
spell.text:
By casting gem-inlaid sticks, rolling dragon bones, laying out ornate cards, or employing some other divining tool, you receive an omen from an otherworldly entity about the results of a specific course of action that you plan to take within the next 30 minutes. The DM chooses from the following possible omens.
• Weal, for good results
• Woe, for bad results
• Weal and woe, for both good and bad results
• Nothing, for results that aren't especially good or bad
The spell doesn't take into account any possible circumstances that might change the outcome, such as the casting of additional spells or the loss or gain of a companion.
If you cast the spell two or more times before completing your next long rest, there is a cumulative 25 percent chance for each casting after the first that you get a random reading. The DM makes this roll in secret.

spell.name: Bless
spell.materials: a sprinkling of holy water
spell.text:
You bless up to three creatures of your choice within range. Whenever a target makes an attack roll or a saving throw before the spell ends, the target can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the attack roll or saving throw.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Lightning Bolt
spell.materials: a bit of fur and a rod of amber, crystal, or glass
spell.text:
A stroke of lightning forming a line of 100 feet long and 5 feet wide blasts out from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 8d6 lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The lightning ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot above 3rd.

spell.name: Revivify
spell.materials: diamonds worth 300 gp, which the spell consumes
spell.text: You touch a creature that has died within the last minute. That creature returns to life with 1 hit point. This spell can't return to life a creature that has died of old age, nor can it restore any missing body parts.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 32, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 53

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: While the blight remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a dead shrub.

action.name: Claws
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 3 (1d4+1) piercing damage.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 32, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 53

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: While the blight remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a tangle of vines.

action.name: Constrict
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (2d6+2) bludgeoning damage, and a Large or smaller target is grappled (escape DC 12). Until this grapple ends, the target is restrained, and the blight can't constrict another target.

action.name: Entangling Plants (Recharge 5-6)
action.text: Grasping roots and vines sprout in a 15-foot radius centered on the blight, withering away after 1 minute. For the duration, that area is difficult terrain for nonplant creatures. In addition, each creature of the blight's choice in that area when the plants appear must succeed on a DC 12 Strength saving throw or become restrained. A creature can use its action to make a DC 12 Strength check, freeing it self or another entangled creature within reach on a success.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 345, Lost Laboratory of Kwalish p. 38, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 55

action.name: Club
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +2 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 2 (1d4) bludgeoning damage.

note.name: Overview
note.text:
DM Notes
This adventure is a standalone encounter zone balanced for level 6, though parties of level 4–5 can survive it with caution, smart tactics, and possibly a helpful NPC like Xanth the Centaur or BURTOLLI.
There is no formal quest hook, making this an ideal follow-up to Dragon Barrow, Woodland Manse, or Falcon’s Hunting Lodge. Frame it as a ritual nexus—a sacred hill corrupted by Talos worshippers channeling storm magic, sacrificial rites, and unnatural boars.
The central tension lies in the summoning of Gorthok, a colossal thunder-charged monstrosity that represents Talos’s wrath. The anchorites here are fanatics, but each has unique characteristics that can offer story flavor, foreshadowing, or dark mirroring of the PCs’ own beliefs.
Location Overview
The Circle of Thunder centers around an ancient ring of standing stones used to summon storms—and, in dire cases, Gorthok the Thunder Boar, a divine beast of destruction. The anchorites of Talos—Flenz, Narux, and Yargath—are all that remain of the sect here. Each is cruel in devotion, but distinct in role and voice.
When the party arrives, the anchorites are atop the hill conducting a storm ritual or, if Gorthok hasn’t yet appeared, attempting to summon him.
Terrain Notes • Hill Height: ~90 feet high. Forested lower slopes. • Caves: Hidden beneath the hilltop, opening out near the summit’s edge. Each serves as a twisted home and sacrificial chamber. • Standing Stones: Each 10 ft high, weathered but inscribed with storm glyphs and boar imagery. DC 12 Religion or History reveals their link to Talos.
NPC Summary: The Anchorites of Talos
Flenz • Visual Trait: Wears an iron crown of forked antlers, scorched black from repeated lightning strikes. • Quip: “Let your bones ring like bells beneath the storm!” • Personality & Motive: Flenz sees the storm as music, and Gorthok as the final crescendo. Zealously faithful, he hopes to be struck down during the ritual and reborn in thunder.
Narux • Visual Trait: Missing both eyes, sockets weeping with blue sparks—an offering she took from herself. • Quip: “I do not need sight. I see the storm in your soul.” • Personality & Motive: A prophetic seer among the cult, Narux believes Gorthok is the spirit of Talos made flesh, and longs to see the world torn down in elemental judgment.
Yargath • Visual Trait: Arms stretched unnaturally long, with clawed hands like twisted lightning rods. • Quip: “You cannot run. The sky touches everything.” • Personality & Motive: A scout and war-leader, Yargath believes Talos commands dominance over nature. He prefers destruction by force, and sees Gorthok as a weapon, not a god.
Sensory & Magical Atmosphere • Sound: Distant thunder rolls even in clear skies; drumming made from stretched boar hides echoes from the henge. • Scent: Wet moss, burning incense of copper and pine sap, dried blood. • Sight: Blue-white arcs of static twitch across the stones. The deer carcass in the ritual circle is still steaming—its throat carved in a spiral rune shape. • Magic: A detect magic spell reveals evocation and transmutation auras humming from the stones and ritual markings in the dirt. A successful Arcana DC 13 reveals that these rituals fuse elemental power to natural beasts

note.name: Travel Encounter - Tree Trap
note.text:
Read-Aloud
A wide clearing—roughly sixty feet across—breaks through the dense forest, the canopy giving way to gray sky. At its center stands a blackened pine trunk, forty feet tall and stripped bare, its limbs long burned away. Twisted dolls made of twigs and bound in coarse black hair hang in silent vigil at the base of the tree. Their empty heads nod faintly in the wind.
You count ten such effigies. Each is tied low—within arm’s reach. The clearing is still. Too still.
DM Notes • Clearing Dimensions: 60 ft diameter. Tree in exact center. • Tree: 40 ft tall. Base is 3 ft wide. Bark is charred, roots exposed. • Dolls: 10 total, spaced in a loose semicircle on the tree’s windward side. Each is about 1 ft tall.
Trap Mechanics • Trigger: Destroying or disturbing a doll activates the trap. • Effect: Roots erupt from the tree and lash outward. All creatures in the clearing must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 5 (2d4) bludgeoning damage and become restrained. • Restrained creatures take the damage again at the start of their turns. • Escape: DC 15 Strength (Athletics) to break free or 5+ slashing damage to a root (AC 13, immune to all but slashing).
Exploration Clues • Detect Magic: Transmutation aura in 60-ft radius. • Arcana DC 13: This is a Talassan blood snare, designed to deter intruders and warn the cult of disruption. • Religion DC 12: The dolls resemble sacrificial fetishes—each likely used in a previous summoning. The pig hearts are offerings.
Tension Builder • If the dolls are left undisturbed, one of them begins to twitch—slowly at first… then rhythmically

note.name: Travel Encounter - Yargath’s Patrol
note.text:
Read-Aloud
The forest gives way to a gradual incline—rough, uneven terrain strewn with jutting stones and fallen logs. As you crest a rise, you see another ridge opposite you, sixty feet away and separated by a gully ten feet deep and twenty feet across at its narrowest.
From behind the far ridge, brutish shapes emerge—orc warriors, tusks bared and weapons raised. Behind them stands a gaunt figure with elongated arms and clawed fingers like lightning rods. He lifts a hand, and a pulse of divine energy surges outward—blessing his soldiers.
With a guttural roar, the orcs begin to charge.
DM Notes • Battlefield Dimensions: • Gully: 60 ft wide across, 10 ft deep, 20 ft wide at narrowest point. Sloped earthen sides (half movement to climb). • Party on one ridge (30 ft wide), enemies on the opposite ridge (similar size). • Yargath: Begins on elevated terrain, uses Bless on three orcs in round one. • Orc Count: Two orcs per character (including sidekicks).
Tactics • Orcs: Attempt to jump the gully or climb down and up to engage in melee. • Yargath: Stays back for first two rounds, casting cantrips or using claw attacks from behind cover.
Exploration & Loot • Survivors: If an orc is captured, they mutter about “The Boar That Thunders” and “The Hill That Bleeds the Sky.” • Yargath’s Body: Carries a Potion of Greater Healing. • Arcana DC 13 or Religion DC 12: Yargath’s claws are stained with black ichor from previous summoning rites—he channels storm energy directly through his flesh.
Tension Builder • As the final orc falls, the storm above darkens unnaturally. A lone peal of thunder echoes—too close, too soon

note.name: Gorthok The Boss Boar
note.text:
Role in the Adventure
Gorthok the Thunder Boar is the apex of the Circle of Thunder’s ritual purpose—a summoned avatar of Talos, god of storms, destruction, and chaos. His appearance signals that the storm god has heard his followers’ call—and answered with raw, elemental violence.
Gorthok appears at the Circle’s henge (Area C1) only if he has not been defeated previously. His summoning is triggered when Flenz and Narux, the anchorites performing the ritual, are both slain mid-sacrifice. With a clap of thunder, he materializes in the center of the henge and attacks all living creatures in the area.
Read-Aloud: Gorthok’s Arrival
As the final anchorite falls, a thunderclap rends the sky overhead—louder than any you’ve heard before, sharp and punishing. The standing stones flash white-blue as lightning lances between them.
Then the storm takes form. From the center of the henge, a massive boar explodes into existence in a burst of light and wind. Its hooves churn the earth, its bristles crackle with arcane charge, and its tusks gleam with divine fury. The air grows electric. The storm has come to fight you itself.
Combat Details • Stat Block: Gorthok’s stats appear in Dragon of Icespire Peak, p. 47. • Type: Huge beast, unaligned • AC: 16 • HP: 136 (16d12 + 32) • Speed: 40 ft • Notable Abilities: • Storm Aura – 10-foot radius lightning field (2d6 lightning damage to creatures within 10 ft at the start of their turns) • Charge – Dash 20+ feet and hit with gore attack deals bonus damage and knocks target prone • Gore – Melee attack with tusks (2d10+4 piercing)
Gorthok uses brute tactics, focusing on trampling weaker foes and maintaining his storm aura. He makes no distinctions between friend or foe—only living or not.
Tactical Guidance for DMs • Target priorities: He charges the most clustered foes or spellcasters. His AI is primal and destructive, not cunning. • Mobility: Use his Huge size and 40 ft speed to control the field. Trampling and repositioning are core. • Environment: The stone henge provides partial cover and can be used for dynamic movement (forcing PCs to scatter, vault, or break formation).
Atmosphere & Sensory Details • Sound: Constant crackling of electrical static, distant thunder echoing even in clear skies. • Smell: Ozone, scorched hair, the earthy tang of fresh-turned soil under massive hooves. • Sight: Glowing white-blue bristles; tusks arc lightning into the stones and soil; each footstep sends sparks through the grass. • Touch (PCs near): Fine hairs rise from skin; metal objects hum; the air feels tight, like it’s been compressed by wrath.
Exploration, Religion, and Lore Hooks
Religion DC 13 or History DC 15 • Gorthok is not a beast, but a divine construct—a weapon shaped by Talos’s will and storm-magic channeled through blood rituals. • Ancient druids of the north once bound Gorthok beneath a storm-sealed mountain, but the rites of Talos have unshackled him. • Cultists refer to Gorthok as the “Boar of the Ninth Thunder,” believing he is one of several apocalyptic beasts foretold in stormborn prophecy.
Speak with Animals or Divination Magic • Gorthok cannot be reasoned with. Attempts to commune return only static and pain. He is a storm, not a soul.
Treasure and Aftermath • Gorthok carries no treasure—but the divine lightning that brought him here leaves behind charged soil, fractured monoliths, or even residual storm essence. • Possible rewards: • Stormshard (custom item): A glowing tusk fragment that can cast Thunderwave once per day. • Burnt sigils around the henge that hint at other Talassan circles (expandable campaign thread).
Future Integration Options • Cryovain Contrast: Gorthok’s raw storm magic distorts frost effects—Cryovain may view Gorthok (or his summoners) as a rival elemental force. • Selûne’s Interference: In moonlight, Gorthok’s lightning flickers erratically—as if Selûne’s glow interferes with the ritual. Nsyldam may sense this and learn to use it as a divine clue. • Tyranny of Dragons Connection: Cultists may speak of “the rising of sky-born beasts” and “the scaled ones who ride storms,” connecting Talos cults with storm dragons, lightning wyverns, or future elemental nodes tied to the Dragon Queen’s rise

note.name: Arrival
note.text:
Read-Aloud: Approaching the Hill
A low rumble of thunder rolls across the sky—not overhead, but ahead. The forest thins, and a broad hill rises before you, nearly ninety feet tall from base to summit. Gnarled trees cling to its slopes, their boughs whipping in an unnatural wind.
At the crown of the hill stands a ring of stone monoliths—tall, jagged, and weathered. Within them, two masked figures dance in a feverish rhythm around a bloodied deer carcass. Smaller creatures caper around them like shadows in a lightning flash.
The wind shifts. The clouds churn. And the stones begin to hum.
DM Notes • Topography: • Hill height: ~90 ft from base to summit. • Slope: A 45–60 degree incline covered in root-snarled dirt, slick with intermittent rain. • Circumference: ~300 ft at the base, tapering to a ~60 ft diameter clearing at the summit. • Three cave entrances are visible near the summit’s edge: one on the northwest, one northeast, one southeast. • Lighting: • Overhead storm clouds block direct sunlight. • Natural light flickers intermittently from storm-glow above (dim lighting unless magical light is used). • Magical glow pulses between the standing stones like lightning building pressure in the air. • Anchorite Activity: • If Gorthok has not been defeated, the anchorites (Flenz & Narux) are in mid-summoning—chanting and slashing their own palms over the deer carcass. • If Gorthok has been slain previously, they are instead conducting a storm ritual, eyes rolled back, calling for vengeance from Talos. • Twig blights (2 per character including sidekicks) dance and lurch around the circle, echoing the anchorites’ movements.
Exploration Options • Surveying the Hill: • Characters circling the base before ascending spot three cave mouths (Areas C2, C3, C4) tucked beneath mossy overhangs. • DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) reveals subtle trails of hoofprints, blood-spatter, and twig-blight tracks leading from each cave toward the henge. • Arcana or Religion Checks: • DC 12 Arcana: The ring of stones serves as a focus for elemental evocation—a lightning conductor and summoning nexus. • DC 14 Religion: Recognize this ritual as a variant of Talassan Beastbinding—a rite reserved for summoning elemental avatars like Gorthok. • History DC 13: • These stones predate the anchorites—an ancient druidic site, possibly corrupted over time. Old sigils remain beneath the new carvings.
Atmospheric Details • Sound: • Wind howls unnaturally at the summit, occasionally dropping into sudden silence—then returning with a shriek. • Chanting and low-pitched humming echoes from the stones like the hill itself is vibrating. • Distant thunder repeats in rhythmic pulses, like a heartbeat under stone. • Smell: • Coppery tang of blood. • Ozone thick in the air, like the sky is bracing to split open. • Rotten herbs and singed fur clinging to the stone ring. • Touch: • The closer you get, the more charged the air feels—armor tingles, hair lifts. • The grass is damp and brittle—crushed by many feet or burned from ritual residue.
Tension Builder • If the party waits too long or makes noise approaching, Flenz may interrupt his ritual to scream: “The sacrifice has arrived! Let Talos see you bleed!” • If stealth is maintained, the players may observe the full ritual cycle—and possibly intervene just before Gorthok is summoned, or during the final bloodletting

note.name: C1. The Henge
note.text:
Read-Aloud: Stone Circle at the Summit
The storm howls louder as you crest the hilltop. Standing before you is a ring of eight towering stone arches—each formed by two jagged, vertical slabs ten feet high, capped by a flat lintel three feet thick.
Within the ring, two humanoid figures twirl and chant in a storm-born frenzy. Their faces are hidden behind rotting boar skulls, bone cracked and blackened by lightning. They dance around a blood-soaked deer carcass splayed across a crude stone altar. Smaller, twisted shapes—twig blights—jerk and caper around them in mimicry.
The stones shimmer with stormlight. The air grows charged. Something is coming.
DM Notes • Stone Circle Dimensions: • The henge spans a 40-foot-diameter circle at the hill’s crown. • Each of the eight stone arches is 10 ft tall, spaced evenly and connected by a hummed current of magical lightning. • The ground inside the circle is scorched, pitted with hoofprints and bloodstains. • Flenz & Narux: • Two anchorites of Talos mid-ritual. • Surrounded by twig blights—2 per character (including sidekicks). • If the PCs interrupt the ritual before either anchorite is slain, Gorthok is not yet summoned. • If both anchorites die during the ritual, Gorthok the Thunder Boar appears in the center of the circle on the next initiative count 20 with a thunderclap arrival (see Gorthok side note). • Tactics: • Flenz opens with Thunderwave to disrupt enemy lines. • Narux casts Shatter centered just outside the henge. • Twig blights swarm spellcasters or archers, taking advantage of flanking. • Flenz and Narux fight to the death, channeling pain into their summoning.
Anchorite Profile: Flenz • Visual Trait: Flenz wears a cracked boar skull helmet seared black on one side by lightning. A jagged tooth dangles from his neck, constantly sparking with static. • Quip: “Pain is the price. And I pay gladly.” • Motivation: Flenz believes he is already dead—his body a vessel for Talos’s wrath. His only purpose is to birth the storm into flesh. • Personality: Fanatic. Joyfully self-destructive. Speaks in prophetic verse when injured.
Exploration & Interactions • Perception DC 10: Characters searching the summit discover hidden trapdoors beneath loose grass. There are three total, each leading to one of the caves (C2–C4). • Arcana DC 12: The stones resonate with evocation magic. If toppled (Strength 80 combined), the spellwork collapses and prevents Gorthok’s summoning. • Nature DC 13: The storm above is not natural—it follows the ritual, not the other way around. • Aftermath: When all foes are defeated, the stones lose their charge with a final gust of wind. The summit returns to silence, but the residue of the ritual lingers—small arcs of lightning occasionally twitch through the wet grass

note.name: C2. Northwest Cave (Flenz’s Lair)
note.text:
Read-Aloud: Lintel Mark and Interior
Carved into the lintel stone above this cave’s mouth is a crude pictograph: a wild boar chasing a stick-figure humanoid. The cave entrance yawns beneath it, framed in stone slabs and closed by a warped wooden gate lashed with frayed rope.
The interior is close and damp—7 feet high, with packed-earth walls and a stale, smoky smell. Bones and feathers hang from the ceiling by leather cords. In the dim light, a pile of bones lies just inside the entryway—crowned by a bleached boar skull.
DM Notes • Dimensional Layout: • Entry hall: 10 ft wide, 15 ft deep. • Retreat chamber (D): 15×20 ft, unfurnished, but scattered with totems, clay dishes, and twisted symbols of Talos. • Adjacent rooms: • Boar Pen (B): Gate lashed shut. Boar snorts and thrashes if disturbed. • Cell (C): 25% chance a live deer is trapped. Otherwise empty. • Treasure: • In the retreat room (D), a Potion of Invulnerability is buried beneath the packed earth in a random 5-ft square. It’s wrapped in boar hide and tied with bone cord. • Investigation DC 14 to find it by searching; auto-find with detect magic.
Exploration & Clues • Religion DC 10 (at bone pile): Recognize this as a ritual threshold—a warning marker to trespassers and a spiritual “gatekeeper” to ward off the uninitiated. • Insight DC 12: The items in the retreat chamber are not lived in. This was a shrine more than a resting space. Flenz likely slept elsewhere, or not at all. • Secret Exit (E): A 5 ft-wide earthen tunnel slopes up to a trapdoor hidden beneath the grass near the stone circle above. From below, the planks are obvious. This tunnel provides an escape route or stealthy entry into the henge

note.name: C3. Northeast Cave (Narux’s Lair)
note.text:
Read-Aloud: Lintel and Interior
The stone lintel above this cave is bare—no symbols, no warnings, only rain-slicked stone and silence. The cave mouth itself is framed in moss-covered slabs, the rope-lashed gate slightly ajar, swaying gently in the storm breeze.
Inside, the air is sharp with the scent of copper and crushed herbs. Shadows cling to the low, earthen walls. Ritual bones hang from strings of sinew. At the back, bundled herbs and twisted root dolls line shallow niches—some of them seem to twitch when you pass.
DM Notes • Dimensions: • Entry (A): 10×10 ft, boar skull atop a pile of bones warns intruders. • Boar Pen (B): Lashed wooden gate. The boar inside paces restlessly, agitated by the storm. • Cell (C): 25% chance a deer is inside. Otherwise, empty. • Retreat (D): 20×20 ft chamber filled with disturbing totems, bundled storm herbs, and symbols carved into the dirt walls. • Secret Exit (E): Tunnel sloping upward to a hidden trapdoor beneath the hilltop grass. • Narux’s Hidden Treasure: • +1 Shield, buried in a random 5-ft square under the earthen floor in her retreat. • Wrapped in a moldy prayer cloth, its surface etched with Talossan runes of protection through violence. • Investigation DC 14 or Detect Magic to locate.
Anchorite Profile: Narux • Visual Trait: Narux’s mask is fused to her face—bits of tusk erupt from her cheeks. Her cloak is made of interwoven animal hides and dead twigs, rustling even when there’s no breeze. • Quip: “The storm feeds. And I am its tongue.” • Motivation: Narux is Talos’s mouthpiece. She claims to hear the storm’s will directly, speaking aloud its “commands” even mid-battle. • Combat Style: Tactician. Uses terrain, triggers blights tactically, prefers ranged thunder spells.
Exploration & Interactions • Arcana DC 12: Her storm charms are shaped for transmutation and evocation—the kind that twists living things into storm-bound servitors. • Religion DC 13: Some of the symbols mimic ancient druidic sigils, corrupted and inverted—suggesting Narux may have once been a druid or studied under one. • Investigation DC 14: One niche holds a cracked wooden bowl containing a slurry of boar blood and lightning-burnt feathers—used as ink for tattoos and blight sigils

note.name: C4. Southeast Cave (Yargath’s Lair)
note.text:
Read-Aloud: Lintel and Entry
Above the mouth of this cave, the lintel stone bears a chilling pictograph—three stick-figure humanoids struck by jagged bolts of lightning. The gate is still, but the faint crackle of storm magic lingers in the air like a memory that doesn’t want to fade.
The cave beyond is dark and raw. No herbs or bundles here. Just bare earth, clawed stone, and the scent of old iron and ozone. It feels… angry. Like the place itself resents being entered.
DM Notes • Dimensions: • Similar layout to C2 and C3, but far more austere—no signs of living comfort or arcane study. • Entry (A): Boar skull atop a pile of humanoid bones—gnawed and burned. • Boar Pen (B): The boar here is larger and more aggressive, its flanks scarred from combat and ritual branding. • Cell (C): Empty unless you choose to place a captured orc traitor or wild animal as flavor. • Retreat (D): 15×15 ft chamber with nothing but claw marks, bones, and a single broken anchorite sigil on the floor. • Secret Exit (E): Tunnel as in other caves—clear trapdoor beneath the hilltop. • Treasure: Yargath keeps no treasure. He sees wealth as weakness. His legacy is death and devotion.
Anchorite Profile: Yargath • Visual Trait: His forearms and lower jaw are covered in thick ritual scars. His fingers end in blackened claws, fused by lightning magic. His eyes spark faintly even when he’s still. • Quip: “I do not summon the storm. I am what’s left when it passes.” • Motivation: Yargath believes mortality is a burden to be burned away by divine lightning. He fights to be unmade, to become pure storm. • Combat Style: Brutal. Leads from the front. Casts Bless, then charges with orcs and claws through melee.
Exploration & Interactions • Nature DC 12: Scorched claw marks suggest uncontrolled lightning surges have erupted in this space before—likely during fits of rage or failed rituals. • Insight DC 13: This cave is less a home and more a cell Yargath used to imprison himself between battles. • Optional Find: A half-burned, claw-etched map showing orc movements through Neverwinter Wood—useful for tracking Talassan alliances or future threats

note.name: Wrapping Up
note.text:
With the thunder dying down and the bodies of anchorites and their blightspawn still cooling beneath storm-wracked skies, the ancient circle breathes again—no longer a site of cruel rituals but of uneasy silence.
1. Conclusion of the Quest
The adventurers succeed in stopping the anchorites’ storm rites and disrupting their link to Talos, at least for now. If Gorthok the Thunder Boar was summoned and defeated, the characters end a devastating ritual before it can be repeated.
Narration:
Lightning crackles far overhead, fading into murmurs of distant thunder. With the death of the last anchorite, the storm’s fury loses its teeth. The ancient standing stones shudder briefly, then fall still—silent watchers once more. The scorched soil, stained with blood and sap, begins to cool.
Quest Completion Outcomes: • The storm magic binding the site is broken; future rituals must be reforged from scratch. • Anchorite survivors elsewhere in the region may take notice and prepare reprisals. • The Circle may be cleansed or claimed by another faction (e.g., the Emerald Enclave or Harpers) if the characters take steps to invite them.
2. Treasure and Rewards
The following loot and rewards may be present or granted later:
a. Stormtouched Totem (Uncommon Wondrous Item) Crafted from boar tusk and twisted silver wire, this fetish pulses faintly with storm energy. As a bonus action, a bearer can gain resistance to lightning damage for 1 minute, once per long rest.
b. Anchorite’s Journal (Clue/Prophecy) Scorched but legible, this leather-bound book contains fragments of storm rituals, maps of Neverwinter Wood, and references to a second circle, or a place “where the roots gnaw through the sky.”
c. Thundercaller’s Crook (Rare, attunement by druid or cleric) Recovered from Grannoc or his successor. This gnarled staff crackles with latent energy. It grants +1 to spell attack rolls and once per day can cast Thunderwave at 2nd level.
3. Narrative Threads and Divine Attention
If the characters destroyed the Gulthias Tree before arriving, or recently battled anchorites elsewhere, the Circle of Thunder responds to them uniquely.
Divine Threading (Optional): • The sky rumbles, and one PC experiences a dreamlike whisper of Talos’s displeasure—or amusement. • A PC may receive a vision of a drowned temple, a boar-crowned warrior, or a storm brewing over Falcon’s Hunting Lodge (tie into Counterattack! if not yet played).
If the characters allow Gorthok to escape or flee:
In the distance, a guttural cry echoes into the storm. Something still lives in the thunder, and it remembers you.
4. Epilogue Options
