If the party purged the Circle with honor and protected nature:
“The ancient stones crack, then settle. Moss begins to reclaim their base. Rain falls soft now—not with rage, but with relief.”
If they desecrated or exploited the power within:
“The wind howls in protest. The ground spits up thorns. Even in victory, something in the forest grows twisted.”
If any anchorite escaped or fled:
“Somewhere in the wood, a stormborn child of Talos still chants. The rites are broken, but not forgotten.”
5. Faction and World Responses
a. Falcon’s Reaction: Falcon may offer boons, hospitality, or lore, especially if the anchorites’ grip weakens over the forest.
b. Emerald Enclave: A druid or emissary may arrive at the ruins to examine them, potentially offering quests or gratitude.
c. Harpers or Zhentarim: Depending on your party’s allegiances, other factions may approach—interested in harnessing or containing the stormy power of Talos’s broken shrine

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 246, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 62

trait.name: Aggressive
trait.text: As a bonus action, the orc can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

action.name: Greataxe
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (1d12+3) slashing damage.

action.name: Javelin
action.text: Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6+3) piercing damage.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 237, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 61

action.name: Greatclub
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d8+4) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Javelin
action.text: Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d6+4) piercing damage.

note.name: Overview
note.text:
Adventure Tier & Hooks • Level Range: Balanced for characters level 1–6. Scaling enemy roster ensures threat at all levels. • Entry Points: • No quest directly leads here, but the Phandalin Tales table or leads from the wererats at Mountain’s Toe Gold Mine may draw characters in. • Alternatively, the shrine makes a compelling detour for any characters curious about divine sites, lost knowledge, or arcane relics—especially relevant to Selûnite, Harper, or knowledge-seeking PCs.
What This Place Is • A crumbling ruin standing isolated in a vast field—its once holy walls now host a dangerous mix of orcs and ogres, all displaced by Cryovain the white dragon. • Once, the Shrine of Savras was a respected temple of divination, home to priest-seers who predicted the fall of Conyberry and tried to save its people. • As barbarians closed in, the seers helped the townsfolk melt their wealth into a bell—now hidden in plain sight in the belfry under a layer of copper paint.
Current Occupants • The shrine has changed hands many times—wererats, orcs, and now ogres fight for dominance. • Enemy Leadership: There is no formal chieftain. Instead, brute force reigns. The ogres are opportunistic squatters; the orcs have laid claim to the fortification. • Sentry Alert: One orc atop the northeast tower (S6) serves as a lookout—crucial for infiltration timing.
What’s at Stake • The Golden Bell: Hidden in the belfry, this solid gold relic is worth 2,500 gp and may be overlooked unless the players get curious. • Divine Vision: The Altar of Fate (S10) is still charged with magic. If Cryovain lives, it grants a prophetic vision of the white dragon sleeping atop Icespire Hold—a perfect lead-in to the campaign finale. • Secret Coffer: The altar conceals a mystery key and 57 gp—accessible by perceptive or thorough characters.
Themes & Tone • Fallen Sanctity: A once-sacred place now corrupted by violence, with remnants of the divine still flickering beneath ruin and rot. • Layers of History: The shrine is a tapestry of eras—divination priests, refugee townsfolk, wererats, and now orcs/ogres—each leaving physical and spiritual echoes. • Mystery & Fate: The altar connects directly to the campaign’s core antagonist, making this location feel like a thread of prophecy woven into the larger arc.
DM Usage Highlights • Adjustable Challenge: Use the Enemy Roster table to scale difficulty. • Time of Day Matters: Approach at night allows stealth; daytime approach guarantees detection. • Multiple Entrances: Broken towers and ruined walls offer nonlinear infiltration options. • Perfect Link to Cryovain/Icespire Hold: The altar’s vision makes this a natural narrative springboard to the climax of Dragon of Icespire Peak

note.name: Arrival
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The trail from Conyberry fades into overgrown scrub and wind-tossed grass. Then, rising from the field like a forgotten prayer, the shrine appears—a crumbling stone ruin bathed in the pale light of overcast sky.
A cracked stone wall encircles the compound, its southern gatehouse gaping like a broken mouth. Three of four towers have collapsed into rubble, jagged teeth around the shrine’s perimeter. Only the northeast tower remains intact, where a dark figure paces beneath tattered banners, eyes scanning the empty field.
At the shrine’s heart, a crooked temple rises, its peaked roof crowned by a belfry. Though the stone is weathered, the bell gleams faintly through the mist—untarnished copper or something else beneath?
DM Notes
Approach & Terrain • Distance from Conyberry: ~5 miles south via an old dirt trail, now overgrown and weathered by time. • Field: Flat, open, and exposed—no cover for hundreds of feet in every direction. • Shrine Walls: Roughly 12–15 ft high, partially collapsed in many places (especially SW and NW corners). • Gatehouse (S1): Doors shattered long ago. Rusted iron portcullis still in place but bypassable via rubble.
The Lookout – Orc in S6 • Visibility: • Daytime: The orc atop the northeast tower (S6) automatically spots any approach across the field unless characters are invisible, burrowing, or magically concealed. • Nighttime: Clouds obscure moonlight. Stealthy approach is possible if characters stay beyond 60 ft of the tower, outside the orc’s darkvision. • If the orc spots the party, it bellows an alarm, alerting all orcs and ogres inside the shrine. Roll initiative immediately after the cry.
Optional Exploration Details • Perception DC 12: Characters notice scorch marks, smashed helmets, and bones littered along the crumbling outer wall—evidence of old, brutal conflict. • Religion DC 13: Recognizing the iconography of Savras (an all-seeing eye) on broken pillars or altar fragments; some pieces glow faintly when touched under moonlight. • History DC 14: Players recall the fall of Conyberry and the prophecy of the priest-seers, who warned of a barbarian horde but could not save all.
Tone & Tension Tools • If the players arrive near dusk: Emphasize golden light catching the bell’s “copper” finish—hinting at hidden treasure. • If they arrive in stormy weather: Let thunder echo behind the orc’s pacing figure. Clouds churn. The bell swings faintly, but no wind touches it. • Add subtle signs of divine residue: A faint humming when near the belfry, a sense of déjà vu when crossing the courtyard, or flickers of ghostly light around the altar

note.name: S1. Gatehouse
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The shrine’s entrance yawns before you—a battered gatehouse rising two stories high. Its doors have long since been shattered, reduced to splinters scattered across the cracked stone floor. A jagged portcullis of rusted iron remains lodged in the archway beyond, its teeth biting into the dirt like forgotten fangs.
To your left, a crumbled hole in the wall reveals a way through: a narrow tunnel of rubble just large enough to crawl beneath.
DM Notes • Structure Dimensions: 20 feet tall, 15 feet wide, interior choked with detritus and splintered beams. • Portcullis: Heavy, rusted iron—jammed in the “down” position. • Bypassing It: • DC 25 Strength (Athletics) to lift manually. • Or the party may crawl through the rubble-filled hole in the SW corner without checks (10 ft of squeezing terrain). • Sounds: Occasional clink of metal, guttural snoring or muttered orc-speech from beyond the gate, depending on time of day. • Exploration Details: • Investigation DC 12: Reveals faded graffiti in Orcish—“All gods fall,” scratched into the inner stone wall. • Religion DC 10: Characters recognize weather-worn symbols of Savras etched along the archway—once meant to ward off misfortune

note.name: S2. Courtyard
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
Beyond the gatehouse sprawls a wide courtyard overgrown with tufts of brittle grass and choked by the detritus of many battles. Scattered bones, dented helms, and rusted weapons lie where they fell. Crude tents of canvas and hide sag between the broken columns of the old temple’s façade.
The scent of sweat, rot, and burnt meat lingers heavy in the still air. You spot towering ogres bickering near a pile of bones in the southeast, while orcs squat or sharpen weapons elsewhere—grunting, gambling, and eyeing the sky.
DM Notes
Tactical Overview • Size: Roughly 80 ft x 100 ft rectangular area, framed by crumbled walls and towers. • Terrain: • Scattered bones and debris = Difficult terrain in 30% of the space. • Burn pits and smashed furniture offer half cover in a few places. • Quadrants: • SE: Claimed by the ogres (tents made from ox-hide, roughly built spit-roast, crude weapons). • NW, NE, SW: Claimed by orcs (each has a makeshift bedroll zone, gambling pit, or weapon rack). • NW/NE: Still bear evidence of the shrine’s original function—rotted feeding troughs, broken stone benches, and shattered statues of Savras.
Encounter Setup • Use the Enemy Roster (p38) to scale based on party level: • 1st level: 2 orcs per character, 1 ogre here, 1 orc in S6 • 6th level: 4 orcs per character, 4 ogres total • Initiative: Roll once for all orcs, once for all ogres. • If the lookout in S6 spotted the party, they’re alert and hostile. • If not, PCs may observe or ambush the group, or attempt to socially manipulate (Disguise/Deception checks) if they come from Mountain’s Toe and pose as wererat allies.
Exploration Details • Perception DC 14: A player notices something odd about the belfry bell’s coloration—it seems untouched by age or grime. • Investigation DC 13 (bodies and bones): The orcs’ firepit contains melted silver trinkets, now fused into worthless lumps—once prayer tokens. • Stealth DC 15: Characters can move between quadrants if the camp is unaware of them (e.g., sneaking during night infiltration).
Tone & Atmosphere • Emphasize the juxtaposition of once-holy ground defiled by the brute presence of ogres and the reckless cruelty of orcs. • Describe broken stained glass, wind blowing through hollowed stone, and forgotten blessings carved into cracked archways

note.name: S3. Northwest Tower
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The northwest tower has collapsed inward, its upper floors reduced to jagged stone and tangled ivy. The walls rise no more than ten feet in places, and heaps of broken masonry form twisted piles throughout the ruin.
Wind whistles softly through the open sky above, disturbing a few bird bones and dry leaves that have settled here like ash.
DM Notes • Open to the sky. Walls stand at half-height (10 ft or less), crumbled and dangerous. • Exploration Hooks: • Perception DC 12: Amid rubble, players find a half-shattered lens of polished crystal—a fragment of a priest’s divination focus (worth 5 gp, or sentimental if tied to Savras). • Investigation DC 13: Scorch marks on the wall suggest magical fire—possibly from the shrine’s fall during the barbarian attack. • Climbable debris may allow entry into the courtyard unseen if PCs infiltrate from outside

note.name: S4. Southwest Tower
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
Crumbled stone spills outward from this tower’s base, where a jagged gap has formed in the southeast wall. Vines curl through cracks, and the scent of damp earth rises from within.
A wide nest of bones, fur, and cloth has been flattened in one corner—abandoned but recent.
DM Notes • Partial collapse: The southeast wall is open wide enough to walk through, creating an alternate entry into the shrine grounds. • Creature Evidence: • The nest belonged to a wererat (from a previous occupation). It holds nothing of value, but: • Perception DC 14: A tucked-away scrap of parchment reads, in Thieves’ Cant, “Bell above, painted below.” A clue to the gold bell’s nature. • Great entry point for stealth-inclined parties (especially during night infiltration)

note.name: S5. Southeast Tower
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
Little more than a shattered ring of stone remains here. Amid the debris lies a massive, rust-covered bell—the iron warped, the yoke shattered. It lies on its side like the hulk of a fallen beast, half-buried in grass and moss.
DM Notes • This is the original bell, replaced by the golden one now hanging in the belfry (S7). • Insight DC 12: Realizing that this bell is too old and damaged to match the shine of the one above, possibly raising suspicion about its replacement. • Perception DC 10: Characters can spot claw marks or gouges on the stone from ogres dragging it here, suggesting it was intentionally removed

note.name: S6. Northeast Tower - The Lookout
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
This tower still stands, its conical roof long since caved in, though its battlements remain intact. An iron ladder fixed to the interior wall leads up through a stone trapdoor, which stands ajar.
Above, the silhouette of a sentry paces back and forth—a heavy orc clutching a javelin and scanning the horizon with narrowed eyes.
DM Notes
Structure & Visibility • Interior: 20 ft tall, dry and narrow. Ladder is bolted into place. • Trapdoor: Opens onto a rooftop view of the entire surrounding field. • Sentry Behavior: • The orc is alert during daylight, pacing every few moments. • At night, it dozes lightly—Perception reduced to passive 10. • If the orc spots intruders, it shouts in Orcish, alerting all other occupants.
Combat Notes • Stats: Standard Orc. Armed with a javelin and greataxe. • Tactics: The orc throws its javelin to signal combat, then retreats downstairs to reinforce S2.
Exploration Hook • If subdued or killed quietly, PCs can use this tower to: • Scout the courtyard. • Watch for patrols. • Signal allies without being seen

note.name: S7. Main Hall And Belfry
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
You step into the crumbling heart of the shrine. Rows of worn stone pillars stretch toward the heavens, many cracked or leaning, supporting a vaulted ceiling that still rises forty feet overhead. Shafts of pale daylight spill through fissures in the roof, catching motes of dust that swirl like spirits in silence.
Humanoid bones lie scattered across the flagstones—some picked clean, others still clutched in tattered vestments. At the far end of the hall, beneath four narrow windows, stands a humble stone altar. And above you, suspended in stillness within the belfry’s hollow throat, hangs a bell that gleams like burnished copper despite the ruin that surrounds it.
DM Notes
Scale and Atmosphere • Dimensions: 80 ft long × 40 ft wide × 40 ft tall at the apex. • Tone: This is where the divine presence of Savras lingers. It feels eerily preserved, almost sacred—yet choked with sorrow and time.
The Bell (Treasure & Reveal) • The bell appears to be copper, but upon closer inspection: • Investigation DC 12: The copper “coating” is flaking—revealing gold beneath. • The Truth: The bell is solid gold, painted to disguise it. It was cast from the town’s melted treasure during the barbarian siege. • Value: 50 pounds of gold = 2,500 gp. • Removing the Bell: • Suspended by an iron fixture on a rotting wooden beam. • A character with carpenter’s tools or smith’s tools can detach it safely in 1 minute. • Otherwise, damaging the supports causes it to fall. • Falling Bell: • DC 12 Dexterity save to avoid it. • Fail = 14 (4d6) bludgeoning damage. • Climbing Up: • Interior Method: Requires magical means (e.g., spider climb, fly). • Exterior Method: Scaling the outer wall and reaching the belfry from the rooftop = DC 15 Strength (Athletics).
Bones and Fallen Priests • 4 skeletal remains are scattered across the chamber, once townsfolk or priest-seers. • Religion DC 13: Identifies their vestments as those of Savras, god of divination and foresight. • Investigation DC 14: One skeleton clutches a broken holy symbol—a pendant with an open eye motif, cracked but intact enough to function as a divine focus.
Atmospheric Details • The Light: As sunlight (or moonlight) filters through the roof, it catches the bell and causes a faint golden shimmer to glow across the floor. A symbol of fate… or temptation. • Sound: Any loud noise echoes for several seconds before being swallowed in silence. If the bell is rung, the sound is deep, rich—and piercingly loud, alerting all in the shrine.
Optional Additions
If you want to deepen the lore: • Arcana or Religion DC 15: A player recognizes the layout of the hall mirrors Savras’s divine cosmology—pillars spaced to resemble constellations or divinatory runes. • Divine Favor: If a PC has a holy symbol of Savras or spends 10 minutes in prayer, the dust around the altar shifts faintly, as if moved by unseen wind

note.name: S8. Visitors Sanctuary
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
A sour draft greets you as you push open the rotting doors to this side chamber. The room is dim and half-collapsed, lit by shafts of daylight slicing through a fissure in the north wall. Six beds line the walls, their mattresses black with mold and half-sunken into the floor.
A shattered table lies in the center of the room, surrounded by splintered chairs, and the soot-stained fireplace still clutches a rusted iron cauldron like a forgotten cradle.
DM Notes
Purpose & Condition • This was once a modest guest wing for pilgrims, allies, or messengers of Savras. • Later, the wererats from Mountain’s Toe made it a temporary lair. • The room now bears signs of both use and neglect—disease-ridden fabrics, gnawed furniture legs, soot trails along the hearth.
Exploration & Discoveries • Perception DC 10: A narrow break in the north wall (2 ft wide) allows passage outside—useful for escape or infiltration. Medium creatures can squeeze through. • Investigation DC 12 (fireplace): Shifting ashes reveals chewed bones and a melted silver spoon (1 gp). • Survival DC 13: The footprints in here are mixed—orc, ogre, and smaller humanoids with clawed toes (wererat tracks, about a tenday old).
Sensory Details • Smell: Damp straw, mold, and rotted food. • Sound: Occasional creaks from above as roof tiles settle or shift. • Mood: A mix of sanctuary and desecration—still echoes of care amidst ruin

note.name: S9. Priest-Seer’s Sanctuary
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
This chamber once held peace—and purpose. Now, it has been savaged by time and violence. Tattered curtains hang like ghost-skin from shattered curtain rods, and what remains of elegant beds and bookshelves lies strewn beneath a collapsed section of the south wall.
You catch a glimpse of parchment under debris, fluttering slightly in the breeze, its script half-burned and smeared with soot.
DM Notes
Purpose & Condition • This was the private quarters of the shrine’s diviners—those who served Savras directly. • All furnishings are destroyed, and the southern wall has partially collapsed, allowing daylight, moisture, and forest detritus to drift in.
Exploration & Discoveries • Investigation DC 12 (under rubble): Characters find a half-burned scroll in Elvish. It records a final prophecy: “Gold will ring above ruin. Eyes will open when the stars are drowned. The beast sleeps beneath the crown.” (This is a cryptic reference to the bell, the Altar of Fate, and Cryovain atop Icespire Hold.) • Religion DC 13: Players recognize the room’s layout follows divinatory alignments, like a star map—likely used for group rituals. • Arcana DC 15: One of the broken walls is faintly scorched with residual divination magic—now faded but not entirely gone.
Sensory Details • Smell: Wet stone, burned parchment, faint incense lingering in the walls. • Sound: The wind breathes through the breach in the wall, stirring old pages. • Mood: A holy place desecrated, but not forgotten—as if the seers’ vision still lingers, waiting for the right eyes

note.name: S10. Altar Of Fate
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
A hush settles the moment you cross the threshold into the shrine’s inner sanctum. The stone walls, cracked but still standing, form a half-lit chamber of eerie quiet. Six pillars rise to support a vaulted ceiling thirty feet above, where narrow windows filter in beams of pale, shifting light.
Dust lies thick on the floor, undisturbed in decades—except where four skeletal forms rest in crumpled priestly vestments, their bones curled in final prayer around a stone altar.
Etched into the altar’s surface is a single symbol: an open eye, worn soft by time but still watching.
DM Notes
Room Dimensions • Size: 40 ft × 40 ft square • Ceiling Height: 30 ft vaulted • Lighting: Dim natural light through four narrow slits near the ceiling, illuminating the altar in hazy gold.
The Vision of Fate (Divine Event) • Trigger: If Cryovain is still alive, a character who touches the altar receives a 1-minute vision and becomes incapacitated for its duration.
Vision Description (Read-Aloud)
Your vision blurs, and your body feels weightless. You rise—not walking, but drifting—through the ceiling and high into the sky. Below, the land unfurls like a scroll: forest, field, and mountain.
You soar north, pulled by unseen force, until you come upon a jagged peak crowned by ruined walls: Icespire Hold. There, curled like a serpent atop its battlements, sleeps the white dragon Cryovain, snow swirling around his slumbering form.
He stirs as if sensing your gaze—but then the vision fades. You return to your body, the chill of distant frost still clinging to your breath.
• This vision only happens once per character. • It functions as an in-world pointer: “Go to Icespire Hold to face the dragon.”
The Altar • Divination Aura: Detect Magic reveals a lingering aura of divination magic clinging to the altar. • Arcana or Religion DC 13: Identifies this as a conduit of prophecy, likely linked directly to Savras. • The altar is carved from white-veined black marble, its base subtly lifted from the floor by rollers.
Treasure (Hidden Compartment) • Perception DC 10: The altar’s base doesn’t fully touch the floor—revealing rollers. • Discovery: Sliding the altar 3 feet south reveals a 1-foot-square hollow. • Inside is an unlocked wooden coffer containing: • 57 gp • A Mystery Key (5% chance to unlock any door it’s used on)
The key is silver, etched with spiral lines like a fingerprint. It radiates faint magic, as though attuned to chance itself.
Skeletons of the Seers • The four priestly skeletons are arranged intentionally—hands folded, heads bowed toward the altar. • Their vestments bear the open eye of Savras, threadbare but dignified.
Optional Discovery • Speak with Dead cast here receives a vision instead of words: four fleeting images— 1. A hammer striking molten gold 2. A tower shattered by frost 3. A mask with a thousand eyes 4. A moon rising over a ruined keep
These can foreshadow the bell, Cryovain’s destruction, future NPCs, or Moonveil Academy themes—tailor to your campaign.
Sensory Details • Sound: Absolute silence. If anyone speaks, the echo feels unnaturally delayed. • Scent: Dry stone, a faint metallic tang. • Touch: The altar feels cold, but grows slightly warm under a character’s hands as they receive a vision.
This room closes the Shrine of Savras with thematic resonance and divine tone—linking your players’ journey to Icespire Hold in a way that feels earned and sacred

note.name: Wrapping Up
note.text:
Once the shrine is cleared of hostile forces and its sanctity restored, the characters have a moment to reflect and recover amid the crumbling but sacred halls of the All-Seeing.
1. Conclusion of the Quest
If the players rescued the acolyte or reclaimed the shrine from hostile forces (such as orcs or cultists), they have effectively completed the Shrine of Savras quest. You can resolve it with the following:
Narration:
As the last echoes of violence fade, a heavy stillness settles over the ancient stones. The once-defiled shrine now breathes with sacred quiet. Though worn with age, the symbol of Savras—an eye surrounded by stars—seems to shimmer faintly with divine awareness, as if acknowledging your deeds.
Quest Completion Effects: • The surviving priest (if present) blesses the party in the name of Savras, granting inspiration or temporary boons of foresight at your discretion. • The shrine becomes a safe location for a future long rest, and locals may begin to return to it. • The PCs may be rewarded by Sister Garaele of the Harpers or Townmaster Wester, depending on your campaign’s faction ties.
2. Treasure and Relics
The following items may be found or bestowed:
a. Scrying Eye Amulet A small silver eye-shaped pendant, radiating faint divination magic. Acts as a spellcasting focus for clerics or wizards and grants advantage on one Wisdom (Insight) check per long rest.
b. Scroll of Augury Tucked into the altar’s base is a sealed scroll tube bearing the sigil of Savras. The spell scroll contains Augury.
c. Offering Box (DC 12 Perception to Find) Beneath rubble or behind the altar, characters may uncover a concealed donation box holding: • 2d10 gp • 3 polished stones worth 10 gp each • A prayer journal containing cryptic prophecies (use these as story seeds later)
3. Ties to the Divine and Future Threads
Characters who take time to meditate at the altar or restore the shrine may experience minor visions or flashes of insight. Use this to plant divine foreshadowing, such as: • A dream of a storm-wreathed manse (Woodland Manse) • The image of orc warbands crossing rivers beneath moonlight • A crystal orb reflecting the face of someone the PC has not yet met
4. Narrative Epilogue Options
You can customize the epilogue based on how the party handled the shrine: • If they cleansed it with care and reverence: “For a moment, the air hums with resonance—like a harp string plucked by unseen fingers. Somewhere in the veil between worlds, a god of truth sees you.” • If they desecrated or looted it carelessly: “The shadows behind the altar seem to deepen. A single, cracked eye stares from the crumbling stone, and you feel—for a fleeting instant—that you are being watched.” • If they rescued a priest or left one behind: “Word spreads from pilgrim to priest: the shrine of Savras stirs once more. Some say a storm is coming. Others say a light has returned.

monster.label: Miraal
monster.name: Banshee
monster.resist: acid, fire, lightning, thunder; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks
monster.conditionImmune: charmed, exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 23, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 52

trait.name: Detect Life
trait.text: The banshee can magically sense the presence of living creatures up to 5 miles away. She knows the general direction they're in but not their exact locations.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
trait.text: The banshee can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. She takes 5 (1d10) force damage if she ends her turn inside an object.

action.name: Corrupting Touch
action.text: Melee Spell Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 12 (3d6+2) necrotic damage.

action.name: Horrifying Visage
action.text: Each non-undead creature within 60 ft. of the banshee that can see her must succeed on a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened for 1 minute. A frightened target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if the banshee is within line of sight, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to the banshee's Horrifying Visage for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Wail (1/Day)
action.text: The banshee releases a mournful wail, provided that she isn't in sunlight. This wail has no effect on constructs and undead. All other creatures within 30 ft. of her that can hear her must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature drops to 0 hit points. On a success, a creature takes 10 (3d6) psychic damage. The woeful banshee is a spiteful creature formed from the spirit of a female elf. Its face is wreathed in a wild tangle of hair, its body clad in wispy rags that flutter and stream around it.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 181, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 59

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The harpy makes two attacks: one with its claws and one with its club.

action.name: Claws
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (2d4+1) slashing damage.

action.name: Club
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 3 (1d4+1) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Luring Song
action.text: The harpy sings a magical melody. Every humanoid and giant within 300 ft. of the harpy that can hear the song must succeed on a DC 11 Wisdom saving throw or be charmed until the song ends. The harpy must take a bonus action on its subsequent turns to continue singing. It can stop singing at any time. The song ends if the harpy is incapacitated. While charmed by the harpy, a target is incapacitated and ignores the songs of other harpies. If the charmed target is more than 5 ft. away from the harpy, the target must move on its turn toward the harpy by the most direct route. It doesn't avoid opportunity attacks, but before moving into damaging terrain, such as lava or a pit, and whenever it takes damage from a source other than the harpy, a target can repeat the saving throw. A creature can also repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If a creature's saving throw is successful, the effect ends on it. A target that successfully saves is immune to this harpy's song for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 181, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 59

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The harpy makes two attacks: one with its claws and one with its club.

action.name: Claws
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (2d4+1) slashing damage.

action.name: Club
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 3 (1d4+1) bludgeoning damage.

monster.label: Moesko
monster.name: Anchorite of Talos
monster.text: Enemy: Moesko, anchorite of Talos • Behavior: Demands trespassers leave; attacks if challenged • Special: Cannot die permanently unless his heart (T9) is destroye

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 51

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting
trait.text:
The anchorite's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save DC 12). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
3/day: thunderwave (2d8 damage) 1/day each: augury, bless, lightning bolt (8d6 damage), revivify

trait.name: Shapechanger
trait.text: The anchorite can use its action to polymorph into a boar or back into its true form, which is humanoid. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

action.name: Clawed Gauntlet (Humanoid Form Only)
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d4 + 3) slashing damage.

action.name: Tusk (Boar Form Only)
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) slashing damage.

spell.name: Thunderwave
spell.text:
A wave of thunderous force sweeps out from you. Each creature in a 15-foot cube originating from you must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 2d8 thunder damage and is pushed 10 feet away from you. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed.
In addition, unsecured objects that are completely within the area of effect are automatically pushed 10 feet away from you by the spell's effect, and the spell emits a thunderous boom audible out to 300 feet.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Augury
spell.materials: specially marked sticks, bones, or similar tokens worth at least 25 gp
spell.text:
By casting gem-inlaid sticks, rolling dragon bones, laying out ornate cards, or employing some other divining tool, you receive an omen from an otherworldly entity about the results of a specific course of action that you plan to take within the next 30 minutes. The DM chooses from the following possible omens.
• Weal, for good results
• Woe, for bad results
• Weal and woe, for both good and bad results
• Nothing, for results that aren't especially good or bad
The spell doesn't take into account any possible circumstances that might change the outcome, such as the casting of additional spells or the loss or gain of a companion.
If you cast the spell two or more times before completing your next long rest, there is a cumulative 25 percent chance for each casting after the first that you get a random reading. The DM makes this roll in secret.

spell.name: Bless
spell.materials: a sprinkling of holy water
spell.text:
You bless up to three creatures of your choice within range. Whenever a target makes an attack roll or a saving throw before the spell ends, the target can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the attack roll or saving throw.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Lightning Bolt
spell.materials: a bit of fur and a rod of amber, crystal, or glass
spell.text:
A stroke of lightning forming a line of 100 feet long and 5 feet wide blasts out from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 8d6 lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The lightning ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot above 3rd.

spell.name: Revivify
spell.materials: diamonds worth 300 gp, which the spell consumes
spell.text: You touch a creature that has died within the last minute. That creature returns to life with 1 hit point. This spell can't return to life a creature that has died of old age, nor can it restore any missing body parts.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 330, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 59

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
trait.text: The shark has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Water Breathing
trait.text: The shark can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d8+4) piercing damage.

item.name: Ring Of Lightning Bolts
item.text:
This ring has 3 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 or more of its charges to cast the lightning bolt spell (save DC 15) from it. For 1 charge, you cast the 3rd-level version of the spell. You can increase the spell slot level by one for each additional charge you expend.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 211

item.name: Carved Mermaid statuette
item.text: Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 135

item.name: Cloak of Many Fashions
item.text:
While wearing this cloak, you can use a bonus action to change the style, color, and apparent quality of the garment. The cloak's weight doesn't change. Regardless of its appearance, the cloak can't be anything but a cloak. Although it can duplicate the appearance of other magic cloaks, it doesn't gain their magical properties.
Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything p. 136

item.name: Wand of Secrets
item.text:
The wand has 3 charges. While holding it. you can use an action to expend 1 of its charges, and if a secret door or trap is within 30 feet of you, the wand pulses and points at the one nearest to you. The wand regains 1d3 expended charges daily at dawn.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide p. 211

item.name: Spellbook
item.text:
Essential for wizards, a spellbook is a leather-bound tome with 100 blank vellum pages suitable for recording spells.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 153

item.name: Treasure Chest
item.text: A treasure chest full of gold and gems.

note.name: Overview
note.text:
Read-Aloud Summary (for DM reference): Perched atop a jagged sea-spire, where waves crash and storms gather like vultures, a cursed lighthouse pulses with the rhythm of a stolen heart. The beacon’s green glow lures ships to ruin, and the god of storms smiles through shattered rigging and drowned screams. The Tower of Storms is no mere ruin—it is a temple to wrath.
Overview for the Dungeon Master
The Tower of Storms is a moody, weather-beaten dungeon site centered on a Talos-worshiping lighthouse run by the half-orc anchorite Moesko, who draws ships to their destruction with a cursed beacon powered by his own beating heart, torn from his chest in a dark ritual. • The location is suitable for characters around 3rd level, though cautious play can allow survival at lower levels. • The environment is highly thematic and atmospheric, merging land, sea, and sky in an area infused with elemental fury, divine malice, and haunting sadness. • It introduces both combat (harpies, banshee, sharks, Moesko) and narrative hooks (a cursed spirit, haunted wrecks, divine magic). • Underwater combat is relevant in later sections (shipwreck dives); review the relevant rules to run these encounters smoothly.
Key Themes and Motifs • Divine Storms & Wrath: Talos’s presence is felt in the altar, the lightning rod, and the very air—moody, oppressive, and electric. • Undead Lament: Miraal the banshee offers a haunting counterpoint to Talos’s fury—a plea for peace in a place that knows only violence. • Environmental Threats: Slippery slopes, crashing surf, sharks, blinding beacon light—natural hazards are a constant companion. • Cursed Divinity: The altar and Moesko’s ritual heart grant one-time magical boons or perilous fates, reinforcing the location’s magical weight. • Treasure & Temptation: Shipwrecks surrounding the lighthouse hold magical items, gold, and grim stories—rewards for brave or reckless divers.
Dungeon Structure and Exploration Flow 1. Arrival at Low Tide – Characters descend the cliff and cross a narrow causeway to the outcropping. They may meet a giant crab companion. 2. T1: Haunted Cave – A mournful banshee seeks the return of a stolen relic to find rest. 3. T2–T5: Exterior & Temple – The stair ascent is guarded by harpies. Inside, the altar of Talos offers storm magic—at a cost. 4. T6–T9: Lighthouse Tower – Moesko awaits atop the lighthouse. His opalescent conch and beating heart are key story and loot items. 5. T10–T14: Shipwrecks – Optional underwater side-treks offer treasure and danger (especially the shark Daggermaw).
Villain Profile – Moesko, Anchorite of Talos • Visual Quirk: Clad in barnacle-encrusted armor made from giant octopus hide, chest gaping with a ritual cavity where his heart once beat. • Quip: “This light is my pulse, and the storm—my breath. Leave now, or drown in devotion.” • Motivation: Moesko is wholly devoted to Talos, believing the destruction he brings is sanctified. His beacon is a holy flame; death is a form of offering

note.name: Travel
note.text:
Distance: ~35 miles west of Phandalin Terrain: Coastal cliffs, sea winds, crashing waves Suggested Level: Characters reach the lighthouse around Level 3
Overview (DM Summary)
The journey westward takes the adventurers from the familiar inland roads of Phandalin to the savage, wind-lashed cliffs of the Sword Coast. A storm brews on the horizon—ominous and unnatural. This is not just inclement weather; it is a sign. The closer the characters draw to the coast, the louder the sea roars, and the more they feel something watching from the sea.
Atmospheric Read-Aloud: Journey West
The winds sharpen as you leave Phandalin behind. The road west unspools like a gray ribbon between wind-warped trees and jagged stones. By midday, the sky begins to churn—slate-gray clouds swirl above the Sea of Swords, veined with green lightning. Thunder growls low and hungry across the surf. Salt rides the wind now, biting at your eyes and lips. The storm is not here yet… but it is coming.
As evening falls, the High Road breaks away to the cliffs. From there, the sea stretches out—black, endless, heaving like some ancient beast. A light pulses on the horizon, not white or warm… but eerie green. With every rhythmic throb, you feel it in your chest—a deep, slow beat, like a heart echoing across the waves.
Exploration & Travel Notes (DM Only) • Weather: A storm gathers over the sea. Winds rise steadily, with sporadic rainfall and distant lightning. Emphasize how unnatural the storm feels. • Terrain: Coastal terrain becomes treacherous. Cliffside paths narrow, slick with sea spray. The players may encounter: • Cracked flagstones of old watch paths (remnants of when the lighthouse was still used). • Washed-up driftwood, bits of seaweed, and bones of seabirds littering the route. • Skill Checks: • DC 13 Wisdom (Survival): Notice that the storm clouds seem to swirl directly over the lighthouse itself—this is no natural tempest. • DC 14 Intelligence (Nature or Arcana): The green light has no natural origin. It pulses like a lure, almost hypnotic, drawing even birds off-course

note.name: Arrival
note.text:
You crest the final rise of the coastal cliffs. Wind screams past you, tearing at cloaks and cloaking your footsteps in thunder. Below the bluff, the land drops away to a jagged outcropping of black stone, surrounded on all sides by churning sea.
An ancient lighthouse squats atop the stone—a squat, salt-stained temple crowned by a spiraling tower. The structure leans subtly westward, defiant against the tides. At its apex, a green light pulses, steady and slow, like a beacon… or a warning.
Each burst of that light beats in time with a deep sound—not a bell, not thunder. A heartbeat. Slow. Massive. Endless.
Dimensional Description • The cliffside where the characters stand is 100 feet high, jagged and wind-swept. • The outcropping below is about 80 feet tall itself, sheer-sided and natural. The lighthouse and plateau are built atop it. • A narrow causeway (5 feet wide, 60 feet long) connects the beach to the rock. It lies 5 feet above sea level at low tide, but submerges entirely at high tide.
DM Guidance • Low Tide Arrival: As written, the party arrives at low tide, giving them full access to the causeway. This is the only time the path is safe to traverse. • Cliff Descent: If the party tries to climb down the cliffs to the shore directly, call for a DC 13 Strength (Athletics) check due to the wind and slick stone. Failure results in 1d6 bludgeoning damage per 10 feet fallen (up to 10d6). • Foreshadowing: The pulse of the green light should unsettle players. It’s a beacon, but one charged with divine malice. Make it feel alive.
Immediate Sights and Sounds • The sea below churns unnaturally, glowing faintly green where the lighthouse’s beam passes over it. • Gulls circle, but do not land. Some even flee inland, which is unusual. • Faint chanting—drowned by wind—might be heard on a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check. This is Moesko, reciting storm-prayers to Talos inside the tower

note.name: Giant Crab Encounter
note.text:
When to Introduce It • Timing: Introduce the giant crab immediately after the characters descend the cliffs to the shoreline, or when they begin crossing the causeway at low tide. • Purpose: This crab is not a threat. It creates a moment of strange camaraderie, offers helpful lore, and may lead to a side quest (setting Miraal’s spirit to rest in area T1). • Vibe: Oddly intelligent, affable, and reverent toward its former master, the sea elf Miraal. Think: “A creature caught between tragedy and curiosity.”
Read-Aloud: Shoreline Encounter
The wind dies as you descend the cliffside. Below, waves slap at a narrow strip of beach—wet sand glistens in the eerie pulse of green light overhead. Sea foam curls like breath around driftwood and kelp.
Crawling along the tideline is a massive crab—its shell dark and barnacle-studded, eyes gleaming with strange intelligence. It waves one claw at you, slowly, deliberately, as if beckoning or offering a polite hello.
Crab Behavior & Dialogue
If the party approaches peacefully: • The crab raises both claws and clicks them softly in greeting. • It speaks Common in a hoarse, salty voice. • It introduces itself simply as “Crab.”
Suggested Dialogue (choose or paraphrase as needed): • “Well met, dry-walkers! Stormy day for sightseeing.” • “Don’t mind me. Just watching for treasure. Or sharks.” • “You’ve the look of those who meddle with gods. I’d not linger here if I were you.”
Crab’s Role in the Narrative
This crab was magically uplifted by Miraal, a sea elf cleric slain by Moesko. Its loyalty remains steadfast. It: • Requests help laying Miraal’s spirit to rest in T1 (Haunted Cave). • Promises a reward: “Bring peace to her shade, and I’ll pluck treasure from the deep for you.”
If the players agree, the crab: • Scuttles off to wait nearby. • Returns after T1 is completed to deliver the +1 weapon from the wreck of the Star-Crossed Lover.
Information the Crab Shares
If treated kindly, the crab offers the following in any order: • “Harpies roost up there. Nasty things. Sing you right off a cliff if you’re not careful.” • “Sharks prowl the wrecks. Meanest one’s named Daggermaw. She’ll bite your head off and laugh.” • “The green light? Moesko’s heart, torn out by his own hand. Beats with Talos’s hatred now.”
Side Quest: Miraal’s Rest
If the players ask about Miraal: • “She was a priestess of the sea, taken too soon. Her spirit’s trapped now, weeping in the rocks.” • “Bring her conch back to her cave. That’s all she needs. Then she can sleep.”
DM Tip: The conch is in Moesko’s lap (area T7). The crab doesn’t know this—just that “he stole something sacred.”
Summary of Outcomes
If players help the crab: • They avoid combat with it. • They gain access to a +1 weapon after dealing with T1. • They build a thematic bond with the sea and storm—highlighting that even the strange and monstrous have reverence and sorrow.
If they ignore or threaten it: • The crab hides in the surf and does not aid them further. • It may alert sharks to their presence during wreck exploration (at your discretion)

note.name: T1. Haunted Cave
note.text:
Read-Aloud Description
The narrow tunnel curves through wet rock, slick with moss and lichen. It opens into a shallow, sea-carved cave that smells of salt, decay, and old grief. The air is damp and cold, as if the cave breathes in slow tides.
Drifting in the middle of the chamber is a ghostly figure—an elven woman with translucent gills and long, tangled hair that floats as if underwater. Her eyes are pools of sorrow. Her garments ripple without wind, and her voice echoes like a lullaby from the depths.
“He stole it,” she whispers. “My conch. My voice. My anchor to the world.”
Overview and DM Notes • This is the final resting place of Miraal, a sea elf cleric slain by Moesko. • Her spirit manifests here as a banshee but does not attack immediately. • She is bound to this cave by the loss of her spellcasting focus: a radiant opalescent conch. • Her only desire is for the conch to be returned so she can rest.
Sensory Details • Sight: Faint blue bioluminescence glimmers across the lichen-covered stone. Her form flickers like candlelight seen underwater. • Sound: Occasional drips of water. Her whispers seem to echo off wet stone in distant, mournful layers. • Smell: Brine, mildew, and a faint floral note that once marked a sea priest’s incense. • Touch: The air is unnaturally cold and humid, clinging like sea fog.
Interaction & Roleplay
If spoken to calmly, Miraal pleads: • “He carved it from coral. I sang to it. Prayed through it. When he tore it from me, he tore me from the sea.” • “Return it to me, and I will sleep.” • “It lies in the tower. In his lap. In the house of storms.”
If the party agrees to retrieve the conch, she bows her head in gratitude and vanishes into mist.
If the party refuses or tries to trick her: • Miraal becomes hostile, fighting as a banshee. • She cannot leave the cave or move more than 100 feet from it. • If defeated violently, her spirit wails once more, then dissipates. The crab later mourns her loss and refuses to help the party.
Resting Her Spirit • Location of the conch: Moesko’s lap in area T7. • Returning the conch here causes Miraal to weep with relief. • “You have unchained me from this place. May your path be calmer than mine.” • Her spirit fades into glowing seafoam that coils upward and vanishes.
Reward via the Giant Crab (from earlier)
Once Miraal is laid to rest, the giant crab fulfills its promise: • Dives into the sea. • Returns within 10 minutes dragging a +1 weapon of your choice (from the Star-Crossed Lover wreck). • “She sleeps now. My thanks.

note.name: T2. Plateau - Path To The Storm Temple
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
A steep, weather-beaten stairway winds up the eastern face of the jagged outcropping, carved into the black rock by ancient hands. As you ascend, the sound of crashing waves fades beneath the roar of distant thunder and the pulse of eerie green light overhead.
The climb ends atop a rain-slicked plateau. Slick stone spreads out beneath you like a forgotten altar, and a squat structure of pale stone looms ahead. The wooden doors bear the symbol of a jagged lightning bolt carved deep into their surface. Each pulse of green light sends a flicker through the wet stone at your feet—like the heartbeat of the storm itself.
DM Notes & Exploration • Dimensions: The plateau is 80 feet above sea level and spans roughly 60 × 40 feet. Slippery, uneven terrain counts as difficult terrain during rain or magical storms. • The wooden double doors leading into the Tower (T3) are weathered, but not locked. • The green pulses of light from the tower’s beacon wash across the rock every 6 seconds, causing brief illusions of sea creatures or drowning sailors in the mind of anyone with an active curse or madness effect (purely flavor). • The rock walls drop 80 feet to the sea below, and climbing down without magical aid requires a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check.
Encounter: Harpy Ambush (From T5)
As the party ascends or emerges onto the plateau, the harpies from T5 may ambush: • Trigger: They swoop in when the party is halfway up the steps or fully onto the plateau. • Enemies: One harpy per character (max 3). If bloodied (10 HP or less), they flee to their aerie (T5) unless boxed in. • Tactics: Harpies use Luring Song to drag characters toward the ledge. Save DC 11 Wisdom.
Optional Clue:
With a DC 15 Wisdom (Survival or Perception) check, a character notices harpy feathers scattered across the ledge, and claw marks in the stone near the edge—proof of previous victims dragged to their deaths

note.name: T3. Foyer - Breaching The Tower Of Storms
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
The double doors creak open into a cold, damp chamber. Stone walls sweat with condensation, and a faint salty mist hangs in the air. The floor is slick and gritty beneath your boots, and a briny wind pushes through a narrow, cracked window set into the southern wall.
Beyond that window, crooked ship masts rise from the sea—half-sunk monuments to Talos’s wrath. The silence here is uneasy. Watching. Waiting.
DM Notes & Sensory Elements • Dimensions: The foyer is a 15 ft × 15 ft stone chamber, ceiling height 15 feet. • Window: A cracked, salt-encrusted window faces south, offering a view of shipwrecks in the waters beyond (T10–T14). • Smell: Brine and ozone. The air is charged, as if a lightning storm had just passed. • Sound: A distant pulsing—Moesko’s heart beating in rhythm with the beacon above.
Exploration Hooks • A DC 13 Perception check reveals that the stone beneath the window is etched with tiny symbols—runes of Talos etched in ink and blood. Knowledgeable characters (DC 15 Religion) recognize this as an invocation to summon storms. • Footprints in the dried salt dust suggest heavy armored movement, pacing back and forth from this room deeper into the tower

note.name: T4. Shrine Of Talos - The Storm God’s Heart
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text
This dim chamber feels heavier than stone alone can explain. The salt-stained air trembles as though the walls themselves remember a scream. Lightning dances across murals that writhe with motion—painted waves crashing against ships, a dark, bearded god above them grinning wide.
At the southern end, a squat stone altar pulses faintly. A metal rod descends from the ceiling above, splitting into twin forks that plunge into the stone slab. Every few seconds, a tiny crackle of static leaps between the forks—faint, but growing.
Room Dimensions & Structure • Size: Roughly 25 ft × 25 ft, with 15-foot ceilings. • Windows: A single grimy, salt-caked window in the west wall (opposite the altar) provides minimal illumination. • Altar of Talos: A 3 ft tall block of dark green veined stone, adorned with carved lightning bolts and etched storm spirals. • The ceiling is reinforced and subtly domed to allow for lightning conduction from the rooftop rod (T8).
Sensory Details • Sight: Lightning traces glow faintly in the carved mural lines as if alive. • Sound: Distant thunder echoes through the stone like footsteps in the sky. • Smell: Ionized air, brine, and mildew cling to the cracked walls. • Touch: The altar hums with low, static vibrations—tingling against skin or metal tools.
Divine Recognition • A DC 15 Intelligence (Religion) check identifies the grinning figure in the frescoes as Talos, chaotic evil storm god of destruction. • Clerics of the Tempest Domain recognize this shrine automatically.
The Altar’s Power:
The altar acts as a magical conduit. When struck by three lightning bolts via the rooftop rod (T8), it recharges and may grant a boon.
First character to touch the charged altar gains:
Charm of the Storm Your veins spark with raw energy. Your eyes glint with elemental fury. You can cast the lightning bolt spell (3rd level) as an action. Once used three times, the charm fades. (This does not require concentration and does not use spell slots.)
After use: The altar remains inert until three more bolts recharge it. • DM Tip: Keep track of storm activity. Random lightning strikes during storms may recharge the altar organically. • Alternative Source: Storm spells cast at the rod do not count; only natural lightning (or storm-empowered effects from Talos) qualifies.
Exploration & Clues • A DC 14 Investigation check reveals a scratched name beneath the altar: “Moesko – The First Voice.” Suggesting the half-orc may have founded this shrine or was elevated here. • Characters with detect magic see the altar and rod shimmer with evocation and transmutation auras. • Divine Consequence: If a cleric or paladin of a good-aligned deity uses Turn Undead or attempts to consecrate this room, a single bolt of lightning (22 [4d10] damage, DC 15 Dex save) crashes through the rod as divine rejection

note.name: T5. Harpers Aerie
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
A sharp wind whips across the jagged stone as you emerge onto a high ledge flanked by a crumbling 3-foot-high stone wall. The sky churns with gathering storm clouds, and the stench of brine and rot hangs thick in the air. Tangled nests of rotting seaweed, broken shells, and bird bones cluster against the wall—and in them, you hear the low croon of something not quite human.
A harpy lifts its gaze, yellow eyes gleaming with hunger, and lets out a song that dances on the wind like a siren’s plea.
DM Notes: • Location Context: This ledge lies directly above the staircase at area T2 and is accessible via a natural incline or by climbing the cliffside (DC 15 Strength [Athletics] check if not using the staircase). The aerie is partially enclosed by the low wall but open to the wind and sea spray. • Harpies: There is one harpy per character in the party, including sidekicks (max 3). The harpies attack on sight unless the characters take stealthy precautions approaching the ledge. A character who succeeds on a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check while nearing the top of the steps can spot feathers and hear their eerie song before being seen. • Combat Tactics: Harpies open combat with their Luring Song to draw characters over the ledge’s edge. Any character charmed in this way may attempt to leap or climb the wall (DC 10 Dexterity saving throw to avoid falling if they do). The harpies fight until reduced to 10 HP or fewer, at which point they try to flee, flying down toward the shipwrecks or high into the air. • Sensory Details: • The wind here is fierce, buffeting cloaks and rattling armor. • The harpies smell of sea rot, wet feathers, and old blood. • Their nests are tangled, foul-smelling heaps made of kelp, fish bones, driftwood, and refuse from shipwrecks. • Treasure: Characters who spend 10 minutes searching the aerie or succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) or Wisdom (Perception) check uncover a potion of water breathing hidden in a shattered ceramic jug beneath seaweed and bones. • If the potion is found, let players reference the Potion of Water Breathing card or describe it: A translucent glass vial filled with shifting blue liquid that smells faintly of salt and ozone.
Optional Exploration Hooks: • A tattooed sailor’s bone with a faint marking of the Star-Crossed Lover (linking to T10). • A scrap of sea chart flapping in the wind, hinting at more shipwrecks below. • Strange clawed prints in the stone, clearly harpy feet—but with another set deeper and three-toed. (Possibly left by Moesko or Daggermaw.

note.name: T6. Lighthouse Interior
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
You step into a round stone chamber where the salty scent of the sea hangs thick in the air. A spiral staircase climbs the curving wall, its carved stone railing etched with lightning bolts and barnacle crust. The walls are damp, and water drips steadily from the ceiling—each drop echoing like a ticking clock in the otherwise hushed interior.
Through a narrow slit of a window, you glimpse the boiling sea far below and broken masts piercing the waves like the ribs of drowned giants.
DM Notes: • Dimensions: The tower’s interior rises 60 feet tall with 15-foot-high ceilings per level. The spiral staircase winds up the interior perimeter, connecting areas T6 (ground floor), T7 (chamber), T8 (rooftop), and T9 (beacon). Each landing is 20 feet apart vertically, requiring 1 round to ascend/descend at full movement speed. • Environmental Details: • The air is damp and moldy, with slick patches along the stone floor. • Light levels are dim without an external source—torches or darkvision are necessary. • The sea wind can be faintly heard through the stone walls, rising in pitch as characters climb. • Hazards: Slippery stairs: Characters rushing (running) up the stairs must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or slip, falling prone and tumbling down 10 feet

note.name: T7. Moesko The Anchorite
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The chamber is eerily quiet. Two tall windows face the sea, their glass streaked with salt and grime. Against the south wall sits a strange throne—half carved coral, half splintered driftwood—encrusted with barnacles and clinging seaweed.
Sitting upon it is a half-orc clad in armor made from the rubbery hide of some sea creature. Where his chest should rise and fall with breath, there is only a hollow cavity, pulsing faintly with sickly green light. Cradled in his lap is a conch shell that shimmers with opalescent hues. He lifts his gaze, and a deep voice rumbles: “The storm watches you. Leave this place… or join the wrecks below.”
DM Notes: • Moesko, Anchorite of Talos • Appearance: Salt-pale skin with gills along his neck, barnacle-pocked face, and armor fashioned from a giant octopus hide. • Voice: Low and damp, like thunder echoing underwater. • Quip: “Talos took my heart so the sea could hear it beat.” • Motivations: Moesko is fanatically devoted to Talos and believes every shipwreck is a divine offering. He views intruders as either supplicants or sacrifices. He is proud of his immortality and will fight to the death unless his heart (in T9) is destroyed. • Combat Traits: • Anchorite of Talos stat block (Monster Manual pg. 139) • If reduced to 0 HP but his heart (T9) is intact, Moesko reforms after 24 hours at its location. • Wields lightning-based spells and enthralls storm energy to empower attacks. • Treasure: • Opalescent Conch: Spellcasting focus of Miraal the banshee. Returning it to her (T1) sets her spirit to rest. • Can also be sold for 125 gp to Linene Graywind, or 250 gp in a city like Neverwinter.
Optional Discoveries: • DC 15 Investigation (10 minutes): Discovers Moesko’s journal—a waterproof tome filled with storm prophecies, shipwreck sketches, and a diagram showing the lightning altar in T4 connected to the heart in T9. • DC 12 Arcana or Religion: Recognizes the heart-based beacon as a dark blessing of Talos—an unholy relic

note.name: T8. Rooftop And Lightning Rod
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The sea wind lashes against you as you emerge onto the lighthouse rooftop. The sky above churns with bruised clouds and forked lightning. A low iron railing circles the edge of the platform, rising just above a one-foot stone parapet.
At the center, like a spear raised in defiance of the gods, stands a 10-foot-tall wrought-iron lightning rod, its prongs blackened and warped by countless strikes. The air hums with static, and the hair on your arms stands on end.
DM Notes: • Dimensions & Layout: • This platform is 60 feet above ground level, 20 feet below the beacon level (T9). • A narrow iron spiral stair leads from here to T9. • The stone parapet (1 ft) and iron railing (2 ft) provide minimal cover. • Storm Effects: During an active storm, roll 1d6 every minute. On a 1, lightning strikes the rod. • Lightning Rod Mechanic: • If a creature is in physical contact with the rod when struck, it must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 (4d10) lightning damage on a fail or half on a success. • The lightning energy is channeled to the altar in area T4, recharging its Charm of the Storm ability after three successful strikes. • Optional Clue: • DC 13 Intelligence (Arcana or Religion) reveals the rod is sacred to Talos. A lightning-focused divine conduit, it empowers storm-based rituals in the shrine below.
Optional Exploration Hook: • If the party disables or breaks the rod (AC 15, 20 HP), the altar in T4 loses its recharge mechanic, but Moesko is enraged and may seek vengeance (even in spectral form if heartless)

note.name: T9. Moesko’s Heart
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The beacon chamber pulses with eerie green light that washes the curved stone walls in sickly radiance. Three open archways allow the glow to spill out across the waves, and a narrow balcony wraps around the room just beyond.
Floating five feet above the floor—hovering between arcane chains of air and power—is a grotesquely enlarged, still-beating heart. It pulses in rhythm with the green light. Its surface glistens wetly, and the room hums with a low, resonant thump… thump… thump.
DM Notes: • Beacon Chamber Dimensions: • The room is 20 feet high, ringed by an outer 2-foot-wide balcony, bordered by a 2-foot-high iron railing. • The light reaches 20 miles out to sea when active. • Heart Mechanics: • Size: Small object (roughly 3 feet long) • AC: 10 • HP: 10 • Damage Immunity: Psychic • Traits: Attacks have disadvantage unless the attacker is immune to blindness or the light is obscured. • Covering it (with a cloak or blanket) removes this effect. • Effect on Moesko: If the heart is destroyed: • The green beacon dies with a thunderous pop and the smell of burnt copper. • Moesko’s body (T7) cannot reform and is permanently slain. • Light Hazard: • Any creature that looks directly at the beacon must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or be blinded for 1 minute. • Creatures immune to the blinded condition are unaffected.
Optional Discoveries: • DC 15 Arcana or Medicine (10 minutes): • Reveals the heart is preserved by unnatural magic and bound to Moesko’s soul through a rite of Talos. Destroying it severs that bond permanently. • Macabre Detail: • Characters who touch the heart feel it throb once more… as if recognizing them

note.name: Overview: Exploring the Wrecks
note.text:
• These shipwrecks lie west of the lighthouse, partially submerged in murky, salt-churned water that reaches 20 feet deep at high tide. • From atop the lighthouse (T8 or T9), players can spot crooked masts rising like broken spears through the surf. • The slope from the lighthouse to the shoreline is 80 feet down, wet but climbable with DC 10 Strength (Athletics) checks. • Three hunter sharks, including the named brute Daggermaw, patrol the wrecks.
Read-Aloud (General Wreck Area):
Choppy waves crash against jagged rocks and broken hulls as the sea churns with old ruin. The masts of sunken vessels rise like skeletal arms reaching for salvation. The water is cold and murky—visibility fades beyond a few feet. Somewhere below, shapes twist and move… and teeth wait in the gloom.
Exploration Mechanics: • Each wreck can be searched once. • To find treasure, a character must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check while inside. • If the treasure is inside a locked chest, a further DC 15 Dexterity (Thieves’ Tools) check opens it. Keys can be found on a DC 20 Wisdom (Perception) check with an additional action
Shark Threat: • Daggermaw, the largest and most aggressive of the three sharks, attacks after the party explores two wrecks. • If she draws blood, the other two sharks join in on her next turn. • Consider adding underwater combat complications (disadvantage on melee unless piercing, ranged auto-miss beyond 30 ft unless magical, etc.)

note.name: T10. The Star-Crossed Lover
note.text:
+1 Weapon (party choice)
Read-Aloud:
Nestled between broken planks and coral-encrusted beams lies a skeleton still clad in epaulets of a ship’s captain. One hand clutches something gleaming—your eye catches the curve of steel, unmarred by salt or time.
Treasure: • A +1 weapon of your choice (battleaxe, longbow, mace, or shortsword) gripped in the skeletal hand of the captain. • Choose a weapon one of the characters is proficient with

note.name: T11. The Sea Urchin
note.text:
Blue Quartz Mermaid Statuette (75 gp)
Read-Aloud:
This smaller vessel lies on its side, its timbers split like a gutted fish. A chest, waterlogged and barnacle-bitten, rests against a bulkhead. Clinging to its lid: a bright orange starfish.
Treasure: • Locked chest holds a delicate 9-inch-tall statuette of a mermaid, carved from blue quartz (worth 75 gp). • The chest is padded with straw that disintegrates at touch

note.name: T12. The Vainglory
note.text:
Cloak of Many Fashions
Read-Aloud:
The wreck’s shattered forecastle leans heavily to one side. Inside, a skeleton rests against the wall, slumped with elegance even in death. Draped across its shoulders is a cloak of brilliant hues, shifting in subtle patterns even underwater.
Treasure: • A Cloak of Many Fashions worn by the ship’s captain. • This cloak can change its appearance at will, though it offers no magical protection

note.name: T13. The Golden Gull
note.text:
120 electrum pieces + six pearls (100 gp each)
Read-Aloud:
Within the broken captain’s quarters, a chest lies wedged beneath a collapsed beam. Inside is a bundle wrapped in a black silk pouch, glinting with soft light even in the gloom.
Treasure: • Locked chest holds: • 120 electrum pieces • Six pearls, each worth 100 gp, tied together in a pouch

note.name: T14. The Orca
note.text:
Wand of Secrets + Spellbook
Read-Aloud:
The hold of this ship smells faintly of ozone and rot. A lacquered chest sits propped in a pile of shattered barrels. Inside, coiled beside water-warped tomes, lies a wand etched with arcane script.
Treasure: • A Wand of Secrets (fully charged). • A spellbook containing the following spells: • blur, charm person, comprehend languages, hold person, mage armor, sleep, spider climb
Optional Shark Encounter (Daggermaw & Friends): • Trigger after two wrecks are fully searched. • Daggermaw targets wounded PCs first. Blood in the water lures the other two sharks. • Use Hunter Shark stats (MM p330), with Daggermaw having max HP and advantage on perception checks while in bloodied waters

note.name: Possible Conclusions?
note.text:
Read-Aloud:
As the opalescent conch is placed upon the stone at the heart of Miraal’s cave, a breathless silence descends. Her spectral form flickers, its water-bound garments drifting one final time. Her gilled face softens. “Thank you,” she whispers. “The tide turns.”
With a shimmer like moonlight on water, she vanishes.
• Effect: Miraal’s banshee spirit is laid to rest. The cave no longer radiates undead presence. • The giant crab companion fulfills its promise and retrieves the +1 weapon from The Star-Crossed Lover if the party hasn’t already found it.
Destroying Moesko’s Heart (T9)
Read-Aloud:
The pulsating green light sputters as the final blow lands. Moesko’s heart convulses once, then implodes in a flash of stormlight. The sound of crashing waves hushes as the lighthouse beacon fades, leaving only the natural dark of night and the churn of honest tides.
• Effect: The beacon’s deadly lure ceases permanently. • If Moesko had been previously killed but not yet reformed, he does not return. • A detect magic spell confirms that no trace of the heart’s magic remains.
If Moesko Is Defeated First… • Without destroying his heart, Moesko reforms after 24 hours, returning fully healed near the lighthouse’s summit. • If the characters learn of this, it may create tension for a repeat encounter or future vengeance plot.
Regional Consequences • With the beacon extinguished, ships stop vanishing near the coast, and fishing villages west of Phandalin begin to recover. • Local sailors, especially from Leilon and Neverwinter, begin spreading tales of heroes who ended the “Lighthouse Curse.” • Shrines of Talos may respond. If the party has disrupted multiple anchorite plots (Circle of Thunder, Woodland Manse), this may escalate Talosian retaliation.
Future Hooks & Leads • Mystery of Moesko’s Ritual: Why was his heart used? Who taught him the rite? Could other lighthouse-temples exist? • Shipwreck Follow-Ups: • The Orca’s spellbook could connect to a drowned wizard’s apprentice or sea cult. • The Vainglory’s Cloak of Many Fashions bears the sigil of a noble house—perhaps presumed lost. • Daggermaw’s Remains (if defeated) might be taken by sahuagin or sea elves—either for vengeance, magic components, or worship.
Closing Box
With the sea no longer cursed by the tower’s glow, dawn breaks over the cliffs in golden silence. Where once a heart beat like a thunderhead, only waves remain—free, untamed, and clean

monster.label: Warrior 1
monster.name: Warrior
monster.languages: Common, plus one of your choice

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 63

trait.name: Martial Role
trait.text:
The warrior has one of the following traits of your choice:
• Attacker: The warrior gains a +2 bonus to attack rolls. • Defender: The warrior gains the Protection reaction below.

action.name: Longsword
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d8 + 2) slashing damage, or 7 (1d10 + 2) slashing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Longbow
action.text: Ranged Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d8 + 1) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Protection (Defender Only)
reaction.text: The warrior imposes disadvantage on the attack roll of a creature within 5 feet of it whose target isn't the warrior. The warrior must be able to see the attacker.
