trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 284, Lost Laboratory of Kwalish p. 48, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 63

action.name: Blood Drain
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 5 (1d4+3) piercing damage, and the stirge attaches to the target. While attached, the stirge doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of the stirge's turns, the target loses 5 (1d4+3) hit points due to blood loss. The stirge can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement. It does so after it drains 10 hit points of blood from the target or the target dies. A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the stirge.

monster.label: Cryovain
monster.name: Young White Dragon
monster.speed: 40 ft., burrow 20 ft., fly 80 ft., swim 40 ft.

trait.name: Source
trait.text: Monster Manual p. 101, Dragon of Icespire Peak p. 64

trait.name: Ice Walk
trait.text: The dragon can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra moment.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The dragon makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 15 (2d10+4) piercing damage plus 4 (1d8) cold damage.

action.name: Claw
action.text: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d6+4) slashing damage.

action.name: Cold Breath (Recharge 5-6)
action.text: The dragon exhales an icy blast in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 45 (10d8) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

item.name: Riding Horse
item.text: Source: Player's Handbook p. 157

item.name: Cracked Spyglass
item.text:
Objects viewed through a spyglass are magnified to twice their size.
Source: Player's Handbook p. 153

item.name: Greataxe
item.text:
Heavy: Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.
Two-Handed: This weapon requires two hands when you attack with it.
Proficiency: martial, greataxe Source: Player's Handbook p. 149

item.name: 100 GP - Coral
item.text:
An opaque crimson gemstone worth 100 gp.
Source: Dungeon Master's Guide, page 134

note.name: Overview
note.text:
Read Aloud:
Icespire Hold looms above the clouds, clinging to the jagged, ice-crusted cliffs of Icespire Peak. The cold wind whips down the mountainside with a mournful howl, carrying with it a sense of dread. The once-proud fortress has fallen to ruin, its battlements battered by time and frost. Somewhere within, the white dragon Cryovain slumbers… for now.
DM Information:
Adventure Tier & Level Range: Icespire Hold is a climactic location designed for characters of 6th level, though careful, resourceful adventurers at lower levels may still succeed with clever tactics, preparation, or powerful allies.
Setting: The fortress rests 2,500 feet up the side of Icespire Peak and is surrounded by sheer cliffs, freezing winds, and treacherous terrain. Built as a military outpost by the warlord Delsendra Amzarr, the hold has since fallen into disrepair—first occupied by orcs, and now claimed by the white dragon Cryovain.
Key Features: • Cold Weather Hazard: The temperature drops below freezing, especially at night. Prolonged exposure without cold-weather gear can be deadly. (See Extreme Cold, DMG, pg. 110.) • Treacherous Terrain: Slippery ice and rubble cover many parts of the fortress. • Secret Passages: Several secret doors remain hidden unless discovered with Perception checks or thorough investigation. • Roaming Dragon: Cryovain sleeps on the rooftop (H20), but may awaken and hunt through the fortress if disturbed. • Stone-Cold Reavers: A faction of mercenaries hides in the gatehouse, unaware the dragon still dwells within. They may be hostile, paranoid, or potential temporary allies—depending on the party’s approach.
Tone & Atmosphere: Desolate, wind-scoured, and full of haunting echoes of the past. The skeletal remains of Delsendra’s followers, the scorched remnants of orc raids, and the icy breath of the dragon all tell a story of layered tragedy. Keep the players on edge with subtle sensory cues—creaking wood, howling wind, faint claw scratches, and the ever-present cold.
Adventure Hook Suggestions: • Dragon’s Lair: The party has tracked Cryovain to his lair, hoping to end his terror over the region once and for all. • Savras’s Vision: A cryptic vision from the Shrine of Savras has led the characters to seek out the fortress. • Captured Orc Intel: A wounded orc prisoner reveals the location of the dragon’s lair during interrogation. • Tymora’s Blessing: A stranger in Phandalin (secretly a Reaver) unknowingly leads the party to the hold.
Dangers Within: • Cryovain, the white dragon, is the primary threat and the likely final encounter of the Dragon of Icespire Peak adventure. • The Stone-Cold Reavers may confront or harass the party, especially if they believe treasure is at stake. • Hazardous terrain, stirges, and lingering signs of orcish occupation provide danger and narrative texture.
DM Notes: • Decide whether Cryovain remains present or has temporarily left for a hunting flight. • Determine how alert the Reavers are and what their immediate goals are (hiding, looting, waiting). • Be flexible with the dragon’s behavior—it might take to the air, ambush from above, or toy with intruders from a distance

note.name: Condition And Survival
note.text:
Use this toolkit to reinforce the brutal environment of Icespire Hold:
1. Cold Exposure (Environmental Hazard): • Trigger: Whenever the temperature drops below 0°F, typically at night. • Effect: At the end of each hour, a creature not protected by cold weather gear or magical resistance makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. • Failure: Creature gains exhaustion (1 level). Alternatively, if you’d rather keep it simple, use: • Disadvantage on ability checks, saving throws, and attack rolls. • Speed halved. • After 6 hours, the creature freezes to death. • Recovery: A creature must spend 1 hour in warmth to remove all effects.
2. Howling Wind (Auditory & Stealth Penalty): • Effect: • Disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing outdoors. • Characters more than 30 feet apart must shout to hear each other. • Sound of combat or shouting cannot be heard more than one room away unless doors/windows are open.
3. Slippery Ice (Terrain): • Trigger: Rooftop and exposed outdoor walkways (like the bridge) • Effect: • Treated as difficult terrain • First time a creature moves on the ice each round, it must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or fall prone. • Creatures who are prone while fighting on the ice must make concentration checks to maintain spells or weapon holds (DM discretion).
4. Vision Obscurement: • Heavy Wind with Snow Flurries: Reduces visibility to 60 feet outdoors. Ranged attacks beyond this range are made with disadvantage

note.name: The Stone Cold Reavers
note.text:
Overview: Four neutral evil mercenaries calling themselves the Stone-Cold Reavers have taken refuge in the gatehouse of Icespire Hold. They believe Cryovain has a hoard hidden within the fortress and are biding their time until the dragon departs to claim it. The Reavers are cunning but not suicidal—they’ll retreat, negotiate, or turn on one another if survival is at stake.
Party Members: 1. Syleen Wintermoon (Veteran, Reaver Leader) • Visual Trait: Red ponytail, half-shaved scalp, sharp green eyes • Quip: “Truth’s overrated. I prefer useful lies.” • Motivation: Fame, gold, the thrill of risk. Deeply suspicious of loyalty. • Daily Routine: Stays alert in area H4, sharpens her blades, sings to herself when bored. 2. Runa Vokdottir (Veteran) • Visual Trait: Towering and silent with black braids and an ice-scarred left cheek • Quip: “Don’t talk. Freeze faster.” • Motivation: Survival through strength. Finds cruelty practical, not moral. • Daily Routine: Watches the trail from area H6, rarely speaks unless provoked. 3. Brakkis Elspaar (Veteran) • Visual Trait: Pudgy, pockmarked, with droopy eyes and a wheezy laugh • Quip: “Dogs are smarter than people. At least they don’t owe me money.” • Motivation: Wants an easy score and a peaceful retirement. • Daily Routine: Sleeps often, tends to gear, daydreams aloud about retirement. 4. Jabarl the Orc-Biter (Veteran) • Visual Trait: Broken nose, missing ear, patchy beard, smells like horses • Quip: “Nothing’s softer than a horse’s eye. Wish I’d been a stablemaster.” • Motivation: Avoids jail or war. Scares others to avoid being scared himself. • Daily Routine: Sleeps in H4, tends to the horses in H2, sharpens weapons.
Reaver Tactics: • First Contact: Issue vague threats. If outnumbered, act tough and request parley. • Combat: Fight with calculated aggression. Focus fire on spellcasters and visible leaders. • Morale: If two Reavers are killed or incapacitated, the rest attempt to negotiate a truce or flee across the stone bridge

note.name: Travel To Icespire
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Wind howls across the barren foothills of the Sword Mountains as jagged peaks loom in the distance, casting long, icy shadows across the snowdrifts. For miles, the land rolls with frost-crusted boulders and withered grass, and the air grows colder with every step. At one point, a frozen corpse juts from a drift—its limbs outstretched in a final, frostbitten spasm.
Beyond the ridges, Icespire Peak rises like the tusk of a buried giant. Its jagged spurs, thousands of feet high, vanish into stormclouds overhead. Somewhere atop its frozen crown waits the white dragon Cryovain… and the fortress that bears its name.
DM Notes: 1. Distance & Pace: • Icespire Hold lies over 30 miles from Phandalin—about 1.5 to 2 days’ journey through increasingly treacherous terrain. • Characters must traverse rocky foothills, narrow switchbacks, and snow-choked valleys. As they ascend, ambient temperatures drop, and terrain transitions to difficult terrain in many sections (especially near the summit). 2. Encounter: Frozen Ogre • Found mid-journey, embedded in ice like a grotesque statue. • Read-Aloud Cue: Beneath a snow-laced ridge, a large mound of glistening ice catches the sunlight. Within the translucent mass, the outline of an ogre—its jaws frozen in a rictus snarl—stares skyward. A battered sack is suspended in the ice beside it. • The sack contains 3 potions of healing if the party is low on magic, plus strange trinkets (a cowboy hat, tumbleweed, etc.) for levity or clues to past travelers. 3. Dimensional Awareness: • As characters reach higher altitudes, describe narrow ridgelines (4–6 feet wide), snow-packed inclines (30–60 degrees), and rock faces that drop away into mist-veiled canyons hundreds of feet deep. 4. Environmental Pressure: • Use the Conditions Toolkit (cold checks, wind effects) starting here. • Let survival-savvy players use Wisdom (Survival) or Constitution to manage campsites, exposure, and frostbite risk

note.name: Arrival
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
Rising from the jagged mountainside like a broken crown, the fortress of Icespire Hold appears through gusting snow. Its high stone towers cling to a 2,500-foot-high icy spur, part of Icespire Peak’s frozen skeleton. Two stone structures—one large and square, the other squat and fortified—are connected by a narrow 35-foot stone bridge, spanning a chasm deep enough to swallow a storm.
The path coils upward in steep switchbacks, carved directly into the mountain’s face. Snow gathers in the corners, and wind shrieks like a ghost through the cliffs. From this distance, the fortress looks abandoned—until a faint shape shifts atop the main roof: a white dragon, coiled in restless slumber, its breath fogging the air in thick clouds.
DM Notes: 1. Approach Details: • The trail to the gatehouse (H1) is single file, with several stretches reduced to 4–5 feet wide, and one 20-foot rubble patch (difficult terrain). • Visibility is 60 feet in snowy wind, and sound is muted—characters may approach without alerting the Reavers or Cryovain if they keep quiet. 2. Dragon Awareness: • Cryovain sleeps atop the main keep (H20), and only wakes if: • It is harmed or targeted by magic. • A loud noise occurs (combat, bell ringing, Thunderwave, etc.). • Characters whisper directly near it. • Once awakened, it takes to the skies to search for intruders. 3. Dimensional Descriptors: • The gatehouse doors stand 10 feet tall, flanked by 3-foot-wide arrow slits and walls 15 feet thick in places. • The bridge between H7 and H8 is 50 feet above the trail, and its 3-foot-high railings offer little safety in the wind. 4. Optional Encounter Hook: • If you want to foreshadow the Stone-Cold Reavers, let a PC with high Passive Perception notice movement in the gatehouse (a flicker of red hair—Syleen—or a flickering lantern)

note.name: H1. Narrow Trail
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The trail narrows to a winding ledge that clings to the side of Icespire Peak like a scar. It rises steadily in a series of switchbacks, barely 5 feet wide in places, with sheer cliffs dropping away to one side and frozen rock walls rising to the other. Wind lashes at you in bitter gusts, biting through cloaks and stinging exposed skin.
Hoofprints and boot tracks—some fresh, some half-filled with snow—mar the otherwise pristine frost. A crumbled section of the trail ahead is buried in 20 feet of loose rubble, partially concealing the path beyond.
DM Notes: 1. Trail Dimensions: • The path is approximately 4–6 feet wide, narrowing to 3 feet in certain icy places. • Most of the trail has a gentle upward slope, though occasional switchbacks are at a 30–40 degree incline. • One 20-foot-long section is difficult terrain due to collapsed stonework and windblown debris. (Athletics checks may be required here if players attempt to rush or lead pack animals.) 2. Travel Conditions: • Cold Exposure: If the ambient temperature is below 0°F, use the Cold Weather check from the Conditions Toolkit: • DC 10 Constitution saving throw every hour of exposure (or more frequently if the wind intensifies or they rest). • Wind Chill: Strong wind imposes disadvantage on ranged weapon attacks and Wisdom (Perception) checks relying on hearing. • Characters may seek a sheltered niche or overhang to take a short rest with a successful DC 12 Wisdom (Survival) check. 3. Signs of Activity: • Fresh hoofprints in the snow belong to the Stone-Cold Reavers’ horses. A DC 13 Wisdom (Survival) check reveals that they passed this way less than a day ago and continued up toward the gatehouse. • Characters with 15+ Passive Perception might notice drag marks or signs of a sled—perhaps used to haul supplies or something heavier. 4. Encounters (Optional): • If you want to add tension, consider a minor obstacle: • Ice Slide: A patch of glazed stone forces one party member to make a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or slide 10 feet down the trail (possibly colliding with another PC). • Mountain Goat Watcher: A lone goat watches from above. If startled or spooked (loud noise or a failed Stealth check), it dislodges a small avalanche (2d6 bludgeoning, DC 12 Dex save for half). 5. Atmosphere Hooks: • Describe the echo of falling ice, wailing wind through the rock, and how the mountain groans faintly as the storm builds around them. • The occasional snowflake or wisp of frost may seem to shimmer with dragon-like shapes—hinting at Cryovain’s growing presence even before he’s seen

note.name: H2. Stables
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
This cold, rectangular chamber reeks of wet hay and old sweat. Four horses—nervous, winter-coated beasts—shift restlessly in their stalls, snorting mist into the frozen air. One stall stands empty, its gate hanging open, the straw within trampled flat.
Hooks for gear and saddle blankets line the frost-glazed stone walls, and faint hoofprints lead in and out of the open entrance.
DM Notes: 1. Room Dimensions: • The stables are 20 feet wide by 40 feet long, with 15-foot-high vaulted ceilings. • Each stall is 5 feet by 10 feet, separated by wooden rails. 2. Occupants: • Four riding horses belonging to the Stone-Cold Reavers. They are trained for mountainous terrain and moderately well-cared-for. • If frightened or spooked (e.g. combat in H4), the horses rear and kick, causing potential chaos or stampedes if freed. 3. Exploration Opportunities: • A DC 10 Wisdom (Animal Handling) check calms the horses. • A DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check reveals muddy hoofprints leading from the gatehouse to the fortress bridge—evidence the mercenaries have been exploring Icespire Hold. • Searching the hay in the empty stall uncovers a hidden dagger with an ice-blue hilt (nonmagical, used by Jabarl the Orc-Biter). 4. Environmental Notes: • No light sources are active. Vision requires darkvision or torches. • A cold draft from the open gateway causes hoarfrost to rim the horses’ tack

note.name: H3. Storage
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The scent of dry rot and dust hangs heavy in this low room. Crumbling barrels line the walls, their lids cracked or sunken in. A few wooden crates—most collapsed in on themselves—reveal nothing but splinters and brittle cloth within.
Your boot crunches on what was once a preserved carrot. The rest of the food has long since turned to mold, husks, or powder.
DM Notes: 1. Room Dimensions: • Roughly 15 feet square, with 15-foot-high ceilings like the rest of the gatehouse. 2. Contents: • All barrels and crates are empty or too old to be useful. The room was abandoned decades ago after Delsendra’s forces died out. • Some wooden debris can be used to build a quick barricade or a fire if necessary (DC 10 Intelligence (Survival) or (Carpenter’s Tools)). 3. Optional Discovery: • With a DC 12 Wisdom (Perception) check, characters can spot orc claw marks in the frost-covered plaster, suggesting the room was hastily ransacked during Cryovain’s arrival. • A DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals tiny boot prints (halfling-sized), suggesting one of the Reavers may be smaller than expected or previously had a companion. 4. Exploration Flavor: • Touching the broken barrels releases a puff of decades-old mildew and dried grain dust. • Occasionally, a gust of wind howls through the cracks in the wall, causing the rotten wood to groan eerily

note.name: H4. Gatehouse Barracks
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The smell of stale sweat and unwashed wool lingers in the dry air. Bedrolls and threadbare blankets are spread across cracked flagstone in the open center of this ruined barracks. The remains of old cots lie splintered along the walls, abandoned like bones in a forgotten grave.
A woman with crimson hair, tied back in a sharp ponytail, sits on a three-legged stool. Her eyes—dark, calculating—glance up from a blade she’s honing on a whetstone. Nearby, two others lie curled beneath heavy cloaks, their breath faintly fogging in the chill.
Syleen quips:
1. (Sizing up the party): “I once gutted a red dragon with a butter knife and a prayer. So unless you’ve got something sharper, maybe rethink the bravado.” 2. (When asked about the dragon): “Oh, Cryovain? Flew east this morning to negotiate trade routes with the giants. Should be back by tea.” 3. (If tensions rise): “You wanna draw blades? Just don’t bleed on the horses. Jabarl gets sentimental.” 4. (Feigning friendliness): “Look at us! Just a bunch of wandering misfits freezing our arses off. Let’s not ruin the mood with murder, hmm?” 5. (Reacting to treasure talk): “Treasure? Oh yes, piles of it. Right beneath the floorboards. Guarded by the ghost of my better judgment.
Room Dimensions: • This 25-by-30-foot rectangular chamber features a 15-foot-high arched ceiling. • Two wide doorways (to H2 and H6) are currently unbarred, allowing free movement.
DM Notes: 1. Stone-Cold Reaver Presence: • Syleen Wintermoon, the group’s leader, is seated and alert, feigning nonchalance. She speaks first. • Brakkis Elspaar and Jabarl the Orc-Biter are dozing lightly. If not alerted before the party arrives, they wake at loud noises or if someone gets within 10 feet. • These veterans will confront intruders in a wary but civil manner, trying to gauge the PCs’ strength and intentions. 2. Roleplaying Hooks (Reavers): • Syleen lies constantly and assumes the worst of others. Her first instinct is bluffing the party into leaving, claiming the dragon has returned. • Brakkis is an opportunist—more likely to talk than fight, especially if dogs, retirement, or beer come up. • Jabarl says little, but flexes his grip on his greataxe meaningfully if things get tense. 3. Exploration Opportunities: • A DC 13 Wisdom (Insight) check reveals that Syleen is nervous—she’s keeping her voice low to avoid waking Cryovain. • DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check among their gear reveals a crudely drawn map of the fortress, marked with a big “X” at area H20. • A half-eaten wheel of hard cheese (rations for 1 day) can be taken from Brakkis’s bag. 4. Tension Trigger: • If the party draws weapons, acts aggressively, or tries to press past them, the Reavers react with threats first, violence second. • Killing or incapacitating two or more causes the others to stand down and negotiate a truce. 5. Lighting & Conditions: • The fireplace is cold, and the only light is what the party brings. • Cold from outside seeps in, and each breath mists the air—reminding the party how thin the warmth is at this altitude.
Optional Sidebar: “Mercenary Loot Bag” If the party searches the area after combat or a truce: • A leather sack containing: • 32 gp and 15 sp • A small silver locket with a crude carving of a dog (Brakkis’s) • Map of Sword Coast with “PHANDALIN?” circled and crossed ou

note.name: H5. Smithy
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: The cold clings to this chamber like rust on iron. An old anvil sits askew beside a stone hearth, its fire long dead. The bellows droop like collapsed lungs, too dry-rotted to draw breath. Scattered about the floor are rust-flecked tools—hammers, tongs, horseshoes—all succumbing to decay.
DM Notes: • Sensory Details: The air smells of mildew, with a faint metallic tang. The only sounds are the occasional creak of shifting stone and the wind groaning faintly through the arrow slits. • Condition Notes: The room is cold but enclosed. If the characters linger here during low temperatures, this could be a short rest location, but cold-weather gear or magic is needed to avoid conditions outlined in the Conditions Toolkit. • Exploration Hooks: • The tools are brittle but recognizable. A character with smith’s tools or a background in blacksmithing might reflect on the bygone craftsmanship—this was once a practical forge, not a decorative one. • The remains of an insignia carved above the hearth depict a crossed hammer and shield—perhaps a remnant of the warlord’s pride in self-sufficiency

note.name: H6. Barbican
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: Arrow slits in the north and south walls offer sweeping views of the treacherous trail and the icy crags below. A wide stone fireplace squats against the southern wall, its interior blackened and crumbling. The wind whistles faintly through the slits, a mournful wail echoing off the stone.
NPC Presence: • Runa Vokdottir is stationed here unless already encountered. If so: • She watches through the arrow slits with a piercing gaze and quiet menace, her breath frosting on the stone as she holds still like a statue. • If Runa sees the characters, she slips away to alert the others in H4, preferring to keep them quiet and organized rather than fight on her own. • If the characters enter while she is alone and unaware, she may be surprised for 1 round.
DM Notes: • Sensory Details: The room smells faintly of scorched stone and animal fur. A layer of frost rims the inside of the arrow slits. • Tactical Note: If Runa takes a defensive position here, she gains three-quarters cover and advantage on Stealth checks while firing through the slits. • Exploration Hooks: • A small leather-bound notebook wedged behind a stone near the fireplace contains Runa’s kill tally—forty-six orcs, a dire wolf, and a goliath named Torrik. It’s grim, but may spark curiosity or conversation

note.name: H7. Stone Bridge and Iron Bell
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: A 35-foot span of cold-hewn stone connects the gatehouse to the fortress proper, the bridge clinging to the mountainside like a scar. Its surface is slick with patches of frost, and waist-high railings of ancient stone run along either side—worn smooth by time and wind. Fifty feet below, the mountain path coils in tight switchbacks, lost in shadow and blowing snow.
Above the fortress door stands an iron bell, blackened with age and rimed with ice. A short chain dangles from its clapper like a beckoning finger. The door beneath it gapes slightly open, its crossbar cracked and splintered, as if torn aside by something far stronger than a man.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions & Terrain: • The bridge is 35 feet long and 10 feet wide, with 3-foot-high stone railings. • The surface is considered difficult terrain due to slick frost patches. Any creature moving faster than half speed must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or fall prone. • A creature knocked off the bridge falls 50 feet to the trail below, taking 5d6 bludgeoning damage and potentially sliding further depending on the slope (at your discretion). 2. Iron Bell: • The bell is 20 feet above ground, mounted just above the fortress door on a corroded bracket. • Ringing the bell loudly immediately awakens Cryovain if he is asleep in H20. This may lead to a sudden ambush from above or an aerial sweep of the fortress. • The sound can also alert the Reavers in H4 and Runa in H6, if they haven’t yet detected the party. 3. Exploration Hooks: • Characters inspecting the bell closely may note claw marks on the wall above it (DC 13 Investigation), suggesting a large creature (Cryovain) once tried to perch or claw its way inside. • Traces of dried blood on the bridge stones hint that someone was thrown from here not long ago. A successful DC 15 Survival check reveals drag marks leading toward the barracks (H4). 4. Tactical Use: • The bridge provides a narrow chokepoint. Characters may wish to hold it against charging enemies—or risk being caught here themselves. • Archers or spellcasters stationed at the arrow slits in H8 or on the rooftop (H20) could pin down characters caught mid-span

note.name: H8. Fortress Entrance
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: Beyond the bridge lies a short, arched corridor of ancient stone, just wide enough for two warriors to stand abreast. Arrow slits pierce the north and south walls like narrow eye sockets, letting in freezing drafts and dim blue light. Snow dusts the floor, tracked through from the open door and stirred by the wind. To the west, a battered wooden door hangs ajar, its heavy crossbar splintered into kindling.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions & Layout: • This entry corridor is 15 feet long, 10 feet wide, and 15 feet high, with an arched ceiling and sturdy stonework. • The corridor is enclosed except for the open door to the west and the arrow slits facing out. 2. Arrow Slits: • Characters passing through may not immediately notice the arrow slits unless they pause to investigate (DC 10 Passive Perception). • The slits provide line of sight to the approach bridge (H7) and parts of the surrounding mountainside. 3. Traces of Invasion: • A DC 12 Investigation check reveals crushed ice shards and gouge marks along the doorframe and stone floor—signs of Cryovain forcing entry. • A DC 13 Survival check confirms the dragon’s tracks lead deeper into the fortress, not back outside. 4. Tactical Info: • If the Reavers are aware of the party’s approach, they might attempt to funnel characters through this choke point and attack from cover behind the slits (H9). • Alternately, smart PCs can use this space for cover when anticipating retaliation from the roof (H20)

note.name: H9. Outer Defenses
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text (if entered): A narrow hallway curves behind the outer wall of the fortress, choked with shadows and silence. Arrow slits line the outer wall at regular intervals, each a cold window to the blizzard-lashed peaks beyond. The corridor smells of mildew and old stone, untouched by orc or dragon in years.
DM Notes: 1. Layout & Access: • This area consists of narrow 5-foot-wide corridors running behind the outer wall. • These are accessed via secret doors—one in H12 and another (optional) behind a false panel near H11. • The arrow slits are 6 inches wide, offering partial visibility to the cliffside and narrow trail (H1–H7). 2. Tactical Opportunity: • These passages are ideal sniper positions. Characters wielding ranged weapons can fire at anyone crossing H7 (the bridge) with three-quarters cover. • PCs could use this zone for ambush, retreat, or flanking—especially clever if they discover it while Cryovain is airborne and distracted. 3. Unused By Orcs or Reavers: • The orcs never breached this zone; their war paint still coats the walls of the main fortress but doesn’t extend here. • Players may find old footprints, ancient dwarven graffiti, or sealed cracks in the walls—remnants of Amzarr’s soldiers. 4. Atmosphere: • Lean into the cold silence and sense of disuse here. This corridor hasn’t seen life in decades. A minor haunt, wind moaning through the slits, or a long-faded warning carved in Dwarvish might lend eerie atmosphere

note.name: H10. Rubble
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: Two corners of the fortress have collapsed into jagged heaps of ice-crusted stone. The broken remains of walls and battlements are strewn about like the bones of some ancient giant, half-buried under windblown snow. Bitter winds whistle through the gaps, carrying the ghostly howl of the mountain itself.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions & Terrain: • Each collapse spans roughly 30 feet in diameter and is composed of difficult terrain (rock piles, unstable footing, and slippery ice). • The rubble mounds rise 5 to 10 feet high, depending on the area. Climbing across requires a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check. 2. Cryovain’s Path: • A DC 12 Investigation or Survival check reveals deep gouges, claw marks, and scattered bones—evidence of Cryovain’s explosive entry into the hold. • Characters might find a frozen hand, an orc skull, or a snapped greataxe buried among the rubble. 3. Tactical Use: • These open, ruined areas are exposed to the sky—Cryovain could spot intruders here from H20 (the rooftop) if he’s awake or alerted. • Characters taking a stealthy approach might use the rubble for cover, but doing so risks making noise (DC 10 Dexterity [Stealth] to move quietly). 4. Optional Encounter: (for higher tension or time pressure) • If the party has made noise or taken too long, 1d4+1 stirges or ice mephits emerge from cracks in the rubble or icy fissures, drawn by movement and heat

note.name: H11. Abandoned Guard Post
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: This cold hall lies in eerie silence. Its arrow slits are caked with frost, and the wind seeps in around their edges. The remains of an old table, two stools, and a crumpled standard lie under a layer of snow blown in from the broken eastern wall, where something massive once smashed through.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions & Layout: • This room is approximately 25 by 20 feet, with a 15-foot-high arched ceiling and arrow slits along the east wall, now partially collapsed. • The east door was obliterated by Cryovain, and rubble now litters the floor near the breach. 2. Signs of Cryovain: • A successful DC 13 Investigation check reveals claw gouges in the stone floor and scattered frost-burned bones near the breach—likely orc sentries surprised mid-meal. • Anyone examining the flag or remains can recognize (DC 10 History) the emblem of Amzarr’s watch: a black tower struck by lightning. 3. Environmental Threat: • The constant draft through the shattered wall lowers the temperature in here by an additional 10°F. • If your group is using the Conditions Toolkit, this room qualifies for an early Cold Check within 10 minutes of exposure unless characters have proper gear or resistances. 4. Exploration & Lore Hooks: • A hidden compartment under the table (DC 14 Investigation) contains a frost-damaged officer’s journal detailing the hold’s last stand. Most pages are ruined, but one entry mentions: “If the gods are just, the crypt will remain sealed. We were not made to live forever in the cold.” This could foreshadow H21–H23 and the crypt’s secret toboggan escape route

note.name: H12. Audience Chamber
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: A wide chamber stretches before you, its high, frost-dusted ceiling supported by fluted stone pillars. Tattered banners hang in tatters from iron rings, and a faded mural of a black tower struck by golden lightning spans the far wall behind a raised stone dais. The skeletal remains of long-dead warriors lie scattered across the cracked floor, their armor rusted and broken. From the rafters, you hear a faint, restless fluttering…
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions & Layout: • The audience hall is 40 feet long and 30 feet wide, with a 15-foot-high vaulted ceiling supported by four stone columns. • A raised dais at the northern end of the room (5 feet high) holds a desecrated throne, now broken and dusted with rime. 2. Stirges Encounter: • 3 stirges flutter high in the rafters, clinging to old beams. They awaken and attack as soon as any character crosses the room or approaches the dais. • Add +1 stirge per PC beyond 4 players, up to a max of 6. • Stirges swoop silently; consider giving them a Surprise Round if the players aren’t actively listening (DC 13 Wisdom [Perception] to detect them). 3. Tactical Terrain: • The center of the room is open, but bones and frost patches create difficult terrain in several 5-foot squares. • Stirges can dive from the high ceiling and cling to pillars to avoid retaliation. 4. Lore & Visuals: • The crest on the floor—a black tower struck by golden lightning—is the emblem of Warlord Delsendra Amzarr. A character who succeeds on a DC 10 History check recognizes it and may recall the hold’s original purpose: defending against orcs from the Sword Mountains. 5. Skeletons: • A dozen humanoid skeletons lie here, most in rusted armor, some still clutching weapons. A few are positioned as if they starved while sitting against the walls, adding to the tragedy. • None animate unless you decide to add a necromantic twist (optional). 6. Secret Doors: • East wall secret door: Pushes open with a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) to spot. Leads to H9 (Outer Defenses). • West wall secret door: Pulls open to reveal a narrow 3-foot-wide staircase descending 10 feet to H21 (Undercroft). This door is cleverly concealed behind a half-collapsed wall tapestry. • Cryovain is too large to enter the west stairwell, giving players a possible safe retreat or stealth route. 7. Optional Flavor Element: • If Cryovain has been alerted or is circling above, characters might hear distant stone cracking or wind shrieking down chimneys, adding tension. Consider a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check to identify Cryovain’s wingbeats echoing faintly through the fortress

note.name: H13. Dining Room
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: A long, ruined dining hall stretches before you. Shattered chairs and a splintered banquet table lie in heaps, half-buried in frost. Two iron chandeliers, torn from their chains, rest broken on the stone floor. Mounted low in the soot-stained fireplace is the severed head of a large white wolf, its glassy blue eyes reflecting the faintest gleam of light—lifeless, yet somehow watchful.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions: • The dining hall is 30 feet long and 20 feet wide, with a 15-foot-high arched ceiling and two massive chandeliers that once hung overhead, now lying amid the wreckage. 2. Wolf Head: • The mounted wolf head once served as a hunting trophy from Warlord Delsendra’s campaigns. The glass eyes and finely preserved fur suggest some kind of preservation magic, but it’s now inert. • A character who investigates the head and succeeds on a DC 12 Wisdom (Perception) check notices scratch marks around its jaw—indicating it may have been ripped from another mount and hastily repositioned here. 3. Exploration Hooks: • If the characters are being stalked by Cryovain or another creature, this room’s high ceiling and heavy furniture provide cover. • Optional: Add faint whispers that echo if anyone speaks aloud here—remnants of old war councils or magical residue. DC 15 Arcana to recognize them as harmless echo phenomena. 4. Atmosphere: • A cold wind moans faintly through one of the broken windows, unsettling the stillness and adding a subtle horror vib

note.name: H14. Kitchen
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: Blackened hearths gape like hollow mouths along the southern wall, their chimneys long-silent. Shattered crockery, broken shelving, and butchered iron cookware are scattered everywhere. A frost-edged cleaver is embedded in a warped cutting board, and a half-burnt wooden ladle juts from a pile of ash.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions: • The kitchen is 20 feet by 20 feet, with a 15-foot-high ceiling and two large fireplaces set into the southern wall. The chimneys rise through to H20 (Rooftop) and are too narrow to climb—but smoke or noise could travel. 2. Cold Draft: • A steady breeze blows through the chimneys, and characters who listen quietly for 1 minute can make a DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) check to hear distant echoes of wind or Cryovain’s movements above. 3. Optional Hazard (Flavor or Tension Tool): • The iron pot handles and cleavers are bitingly cold. A creature that grabs them without gloves or protection must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution save or take 1 cold damage from the frostbite shock. 4. Atmosphere & Roleplay Opportunities: • The kitchen once served a garrison of soldiers. A detect magic spell reveals faint conjuration residue—the remnants of past Create Food and Water spells once cast here during the famine. • A character who investigates the cleaver and succeeds on a DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation) check notices that it was recently used…perhaps by an orc or mercenary. The faint smear of frostblood along the blade could be a clue

note.name: H15. Pantry
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: This narrow chamber is a ruin of survival turned grave. Smashed barrels, torn sacks, and rotted shelves lie in disarray across the icy stone floor. Amid the ruin, a humanoid skeleton rests slumped against a wall—still clad in a rust-pitted breastplate. One arm is outstretched toward a broken crate, as if the poor soul died crawling toward one last hope of sustenance.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions: • The pantry measures 15 feet by 20 feet, with an 8-foot-high ceiling, making it one of the more cramped spaces within the fortress. 2. Skeleton Clue: • The remains belong to a desperate guard who died trying to steal from dwindling stores during the final days of the fortress. A DC 12 Wisdom (Medicine) check confirms the cause of death as starvation. • A DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check reveals scratch marks on the wooden floor—suggesting the guard tried to hide something beneath the broken shelf before expiring. 3. Exploration Hook: • Hidden beneath warped wood and spoiled grain is a frost-stiff leather pouch. Inside is: • One silver holy symbol of Helm (25 gp) • A faded, half-written prayer for deliverance • A rusty key that opens the coffer in H17 (if you wish to seed that option) 4. Atmosphere: • The cold here is oppressive. Even characters used to the mountain air feel a chill that sinks deeper than the wind—a memory of hunger and hopelessness

note.name: H16. Armory
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: Weapon racks lie smashed in jagged piles against the walls. The wooden mannequins that once bore suits of gleaming armor have been reduced to splinters, their severed limbs scattered like battlefield corpses. Rusted hooks cling to the walls, still shaped for helms and shields that are long gone.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions: • This room spans 25 feet by 20 feet, with a 15-foot-high ceiling, and is openly visible from adjoining halls through splintered doors. 2. Atmosphere: • A bitter draft swirls through cracks in the stone, whispering like voices through the gaps. A DC 10 Wisdom (Perception) check detects this eerily whispering wind. 3. Optional Detail – Cryovain’s Mark: • A DC 14 Survival or Nature check reveals signs of a dragon’s passage—deep gouge marks on the walls from claws, perhaps when Cryovain thrashed in frustration at the absence of treasure. 4. Exploration Hook: • Among the debris, a DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check finds a concealed recess behind a broken wall hook containing: • A dagger with an antler hilt, etched with old Sword Mountain ranger runes (worth 50 gp) • A bundle of aged blueprints showing fortress battlements (useful if PCs plan an ambush or tactical defense here

note.name: H17. Warlord's Quarters
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: A heavy silence hangs in this large, fire-scorched chamber. A long-stilled fireplace yawns in the southern wall, and an overturned oak table lies surrounded by scattered soldier miniatures and shredded maps. Near the hearth, three skeletons in rusted chain mail lie where they fell, weapons still within reach. Slumped in a chair at the far end is another skeleton, this one encased in a suit of dulled plate armor. A tarnished goblet rests on the floor beneath its limp, skeletal hand.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions & Layout: • The room measures 30 feet long and 20 feet wide, with a 15-foot-high vaulted ceiling. • The furniture, once fine and war-ready, lies in chaotic heaps—smashed, frost-split, or upturned. 2. Lore & Atmosphere: • This was once the war room and personal quarters of Warlord Delsendra Amzarr. The icy hearth no longer burns, but it was once a seat of strategy, justice, and fatal pride. • A DC 12 Intelligence (History) check connects the crest on the goblet and war table to Amzarr’s campaign against the orcs of the Sword Mountains. • The air smells faintly of old wine and rotted parchment, oddly untouched by time—perhaps a lingering echo of the warlord’s doomed final days. 3. Story Clues: • Three skeletons near the fireplace wear broken chain mail and hold rusted longswords. These were soldiers who tried to stage a mutiny in the face of starvation. • The skeleton in the chair (Delsendra) wears a crumbling suit of plate armor and a steel goblet lies beside it. The goblet is rimmed with faint greenish residue—a DC 10 Intelligence (Arcana or Medicine) check confirms it as a fast-acting poison. 4. Treasure: • The greataxe once wielded by Amzarr is missing (now found in area H19), but hidden among the torn maps and soldier figurines is: • A bone-and-ivory chess set worth 75 gp • A crumpled campaign log detailing orc activity in the Sword Mountains (could be valuable to historians or tacticians) • A brass scroll tube containing an intact map of the Sword Coast with Amzarr’s patrol routes—useful if the party wants to track down old ruins or hidden supply caches (DM’s discretion) 5. Secret Door: • A DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals a faint seam in the eastern wall, concealed behind a fallen wall tapestry. • Pulling on a wall sconce activates the secret stone door, revealing a narrow 3-foot-wide staircase descending 10 feet to area H21 (Undercroft). • Cryovain is too large to follow down this stairwell, making it a useful escape or ambush path. 6. Optional Flavor – Haunting Echoes: • If you enjoy supernatural touches, a character who sleeps here hears a whispering woman’s voice in the night: “Forgive me… the cold came too fast…

note.name: H18. Orc Barracks
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: This dark, foul-smelling chamber was once a barracks—now, it’s a charnel heap. Burnt timbers, shredded bedding, and half-chewed bones are piled along the walls, while the fireplace gapes like a blackened maw, clogged with ash and refuse. A choking stench of rot, sweat, and scorched fur hangs in the air.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions & Layout: • The barracks spans 25 feet by 20 feet, with a 15-foot-high arched ceiling. • Scorch marks streak across the stone floor and walls, evidence of Cryovain’s devastating cold breath. 2. Atmosphere: • The room reeks of unwashed orcs, burnt fabric, and half-cooked meat. • Gnawed humanoid bones (dwarf, elf, human) litter the corners, cracked open for marrow. 3. Evidence of Cryovain’s Rampage: • A trail of frost-scorched floor and shattered doors leads northeast toward areas H19 and H20. • The dragon likely burst in through H11, tore through this chamber, and continued through the barracks, killing indiscriminately. 4. Exploration Hook – Loot from the Ashes: • DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check while sifting through the filth reveals a leather sack wedged under a broken bedframe. • The sack contains: • 450 copper pieces • 182 silver pieces • A cracked spyglass (100 gp despite the cosmetic damage) with fine elven filigree—likely looted from a noble traveler • A DC 15 Intelligence (Arcana or History) check on the spyglass reveals it once belonged to a wizard of Leilon, who vanished along the Sword Coast a decade ago (optional lead-in to other plot threads or quests). 5. Optional Encounter – Creeping Survival: • If you wish to add tension, you can include a starved ghoul hiding beneath the debris. A character who searches the fireplace or pokes the refuse might trigger a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw as it lunges out, snarling and desperate

note.name: H19. Orc War Chief’s Lair
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: This once-regal chamber is a ruin of violence and vanity. The smashed remnants of gilded chairs and ornate banners lie strewn among broken tusks and cracked bones. The stench of blood and rot clings to the air, stronger here than anywhere else in the fortress. In the center of the room, a severed orc hand clutches a gleaming greataxe, its haft still wrapped in the orc’s death-grip.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions & Layout: • Room measures 30 by 25 feet, with a 15-foot-high arched ceiling. • A massive hearth dominates the northern wall, half-filled with burned tapestries and smashed crates. 2. Atmosphere: • Thick, coppery scent of dried blood and rotting flesh fills the space. • Trophies of conquest are nailed to the walls—cracked dwarven helms, torn tabards, and rotting severed heads (elves, dwarves, rival orcs). 3. Cryovain’s Attack: • Claw marks gouge the stone floor. Icicles still dangle from the corners of the ceiling, and frozen pools glisten near broken furniture. • The orc war chief, Kra, made his final stand here but was devoured by Cryovain. 4. Treasure: • The greataxe clutched in the severed hand is a finely crafted nonmagical greataxe, stolen from Delsendra Amzarr’s quarters (see H17). Its haft is carved with ancient Chondathan battle prayers. • Among the rubble: • Ornate wooden chair with six red coral branches embedded in its backrest. Each coral branch is worth 25 gp, and they can be pried out with a DC 10 Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) or a dagger and 10 minutes of work. • Optional Magic Item (DM’s choice): You may choose to hide a minor magic trinket here, such as an Orb of Direction or a Spell Scroll (Identify), tucked under a bloodstained bear pelt. 5. Investigation Opportunities: • DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation) reveals a burnt tapestry fragment depicting the old warlord Delsendra Amzarr on horseback—a forgotten symbol of valor and nobility before the fall of the hold. • DC 15 Intelligence (History) check on the axe identifies it as belonging to a noble family of Tethyr, stolen generations ago during an orc raid—this could be used to barter with nobility later. 6. Optional Encounter – Restless Trophy: • If the players disturb the severed heads, one of them (an elven mage) animates as a talking skull via lingering magic (like speak with dead) and croaks a cryptic warning: “He waits in the cold sky… Cryovain does not hoard, he devours.

note.name: H20. Roof LAIR
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text: Wind howls across the rooftop, pulling at cloaks and stinging skin with ice-laden gusts. A 3-foot-high stone battlement rims the edge, broken in places where masonry has crumbled into the abyss below. The floor beneath your boots glistens—an unbroken sheet of rime-covered stone. And there, at the center of this icy perch, sprawled like a serpent atop a throne, is Cryovain.
The dragon’s pale, scaly hide shimmers faintly with frost. His massive wings are tucked like sails furled against a frozen mast. Vaporous plumes rise from his nostrils with every deep, slumbering breath. One twitch… one wrong sound… and this ancient ruin will erupt with death.
DM Notes: 1. Dimensions & Layout: • The rooftop measures 60 by 80 feet, open to the sky with no cover beyond the 3-foot-high battlement. • Slippery ice covers the surface (see below). • Four chimneys (linked to H12, H13, H14, H17) rise 5 feet above the rooftop—too narrow to squeeze through, even for Small creatures. 2. Environmental Conditions: • Slippery Ice: All movement on the rooftop is difficult terrain. • When a creature other than Cryovain moves on the ice for the first time on its turn, it must make a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or fall prone. • Elevation: The rooftop sits 80 feet above the mountainside path, with sheer drops on three sides. A fall from the roof causes 8d6 bludgeoning damage, and possibly more if they hit outcroppings. 3. Cryovain’s Behavior: • At rest: Cryovain slumbers in a 10-foot-square patch near the center of the roof. • He awakens if: • Damaged or targeted by a spell. • A loud sound occurs (combat, thunderwave, etc.). • Someone gets within 15 feet and whispers in his ear. • Once awakened: Cryovain takes off and circles the fortress, using his aerial speed to look for intruders. • If not provoked further, he returns to the roof and waits for foes to come to him. 4. Tactical Considerations: • Cryovain starts the encounter prone and surprised unless alerted. • Once awake, he prefers to fight from the air, diving in and using Frightful Presence and Cold Breath, then withdrawing upward. • If injured to half HP or less, Cryovain becomes increasingly reckless, unwilling to abandon the hold but more likely to crash through the rooftops or swoop down into the fortress (see below). • Alternative Movement: Cryovain can squeeze through doorways and chimneys, but he avoids confined spaces unless desperate or enraged. 5. Encounter Scaling & Adjustments: • Consider terrain use: • PCs may try to shove Cryovain off the rooftop (contested Athletics). • Allow use of the chimneys for clever traversal or ambushes. • Offer Skill-Based Opportunities (see sidebar below).
Optional Sidebar: Rooftop Opportunities • Climbing the Chimneys: A DC 13 Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check lets a Small or Tiny PC climb out of a chimney for a rooftop ambush. • Blind the Dragon: A successful DC 15 Sleight of Hand or Ranged Attack with a cloth can blind Cryovain temporarily by targeting his eyes or nostrils. • Icicle Traps (Optional): PCs might trigger or dislodge heavy icicles above the battlements. A successful DC 15 Survival check finds a place to do so, dealing 3d10 piercing damage on a hit

note.name: Running Cryovain
note.text:
Setup and Atmosphere
Cryovain is not just a final boss—he’s the capstone symbol of chaos in the Sword Mountains. This rooftop confrontation should feel cinematic: clouds roil, snow cuts sideways on the wind, and the ice-slicked stones beneath the party’s feet crackle with each step.
Combat Start
Cryovain begins asleep, curled atop the center of the rooftop. He awakens only if: • He takes damage, is the target of a spell, or hears a loud sound (combat, thunderwave, etc.). • Someone whispers within 15 feet. If awoken, he takes flight, seeking height and dominance.
Environmental Features • Rooftop Dimensions: 60x80 feet. • Ice-Covered Floor: Difficult terrain. Non-Cryovain creatures must make a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or fall prone the first time they move each turn. • 3-Foot Battlement: Provides half cover when crouched behind.
Cryovain’s Combat Tactics
Instinctual Tactics • Open with Cold Breath if multiple PCs are in a cone. • Use flight to reposition or retreat if bloodied. • Focuses on soft targets (casters, injured PCs). • Cryovain is not smart, but is brutal, persistent, and loves showy kills.
Use of Multiattack
If his breath is unavailable, Cryovain will use: • 1 Bite (2d10+4 + 1d8 cold) + 2 Claws (2d6+4). He prefers to target a downed or wounded character for maximum intimidation.
Breath Recharge • Rolls d6 at start of turn; recharges on 5–6.
Cryovain Encounter Action Flow (Example Round)
Let’s say Cryovain is awake, at half HP, and airborne (40 ft up). The party consists of: • Yote (Soulknife Rogue) • Nsyldam (Shadow Monk) • Riverine (Fighter with Hellie) • Cromwell (Swashbuckler Rogue)
Cryovain’s Turn (Round 3): 1. Breath Recharge: Rolls a d6—result is 5. Recharge successful. 2. Tactical Scan: Spots Nsyldam, Riverine, and Hellie grouped within 30 ft. 3. Action: Cold Breath in a 30-ft cone. • Nsyldam, Riverine, and Hellie must make DC 15 Constitution saves. • Nsyldam succeeds: takes 22 cold. • Riverine fails: takes full 45 cold. • Hellie fails: takes 45 cold and is on death’s door. 4. Movement: Flies 20 ft higher (60 ft) to keep distance from melee. 5. Roars a Challenge: Purely narrative intimidation—could trigger Frighten-like RP effects if PCs fail Wis saves.
Nsyldam’s Turn: • Uses Step of the Wind to Dash and jump across icy terrain. • Tries to climb chimney (Athletics DC 15). • Readies an action: if Cryovain lands, she strikes with her shadow-enhanced quarterstaff.
Skill Opportunities During the Fight
Let your players shine through tactics, not just dice: • Athletics (DC 13): Leap between icy chimneys to reposition. • Sleight of Hand (DC 15): Throw powder or cloak over Cryovain’s eyes to blind for a round. • Insight (DC 10): Realize Cryovain avoids confined spaces—bait him into traps or tunnels. • Persuasion/Deception (DC 18): Cryovain is not smart—but his vanity is real. Clever lies might confuse him for a round.
Optional Layer: Cryovain’s Behavior at 25% HP • Becomes reckless: crashes through the ceiling of H12 or H13. • Begins grabbing PCs in claws and throwing them off the roof (Athletics contest, DC 17 to resist). • Starts roaring and calling the storm—up to you whether this summons environmental effects (fog, lightning, etc.)

note.name: H21. Undercroft
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The narrow staircase creaks beneath your feet as you descend into a tight, freezing corridor. The ceiling lowers to just eight feet overhead, and your breath fogs the air. Stone walls press close on either side, and every step echoes with a hollow finality. Chiseled above each door is a single word, etched in blocky Common script: “CRYPTS.”
DM Notes: • This chamber serves as a hub for the crypts beyond (H22–H23). • It’s deathly cold. Any open skin numbs in seconds, and ice coats the lintels and floor edges. • Sound is muffled here due to the heavy air and thick stone construction. • The entire undercroft is devoid of light.
Sensory Details: • Smell: Dry stone and faint rot; the chill burns the nose. • Sounds: Occasional echoing drop of water; your own breathing magnified. • Feel: The temperature here is bitterly cold—enough to burn the lungs slightly on deep inhales.
Exploration Hook: • PCs might sense they’re being watched. This is false—but a good moment to build tension before H22

note.name: H22. Crypts
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
These cold, claustrophobic corridors are carved directly into the mountain’s bedrock. Rows of alcoves line the walls—each one containing a long stone casket marked with faint, weatherworn runes. Some lids are cracked or shifted slightly ajar. Rusty weapons and decayed armor lie with the long-dead soldiers entombed here.
DM Notes: • There are no traps or undead, but the oppressive silence and the slight gaps in some caskets lend themselves to false scares. • The remains belong to Delsendra Amzarr’s fallen troops. The PCs might find ancient insignia or ruined military orders if they investigate. • These crypts were never properly consecrated after the warlord’s death—so the spiritual air is tense but inert.
Exploration Opportunities: 1. Casket Search (DC 13 Investigation): PCs find: • Rusty, unusable armor and swords. • A broken warhorn with engraved silver mouthpiece (worth 10 gp). • An Amzarr Legion insignia badge—could impress historians or be repurposed as a token in future interactions. 2. Arcana or Religion (DC 15): Identifies subtle residual enchantments—the dead were given magical rites of preservation, long since faded.
Flavor Detail for Caskets: • Some caskets have ice crystals creeping through their seams—Cryovain’s magical chill penetrates even here. • Tiny bones (possibly of old familiars or pets) can be found in a few warrior tombs

note.name: H23. Empty Crypt and Secret Exit
note.text:
Read-Aloud Text:
The narrow hall ends at a wider tomb with five stone caskets. Four stand empty, their lids pushed aside and interiors bare. The fifth casket—centered under a carved arch—still rests sealed and dust-covered. The cold here is deeper than elsewhere, as if the mountain itself is holding its breath.
A bitter draft wafts from faint seams in the southern wall, suggesting a hidden way out.
DM Notes: • This was Delsendra Amzarr’s emergency escape chamber, prepared in case the fortress ever fell. • Four of the five caskets are red herrings—empty, save for dust and broken pieces of old wood. • The central casket contains a dismantled toboggan escape sled, hidden as a final contingency plan. • Secret Exit: A one-way secret door in the south wall can only be opened from within. A creature must pull a hidden handle behind the casket (DC 12 Perception to spot). From outside, it requires a knock spell or similar magic to open.
Toboggan Details: • The parts are clearly marked for assembly and reinforced with ancient dwarven clasps. • It takes 10 minutes to assemble the toboggan fully. • Once launched, it barrels down the mountainside at high speed (DM can call for Dexterity or Acrobatics checks if desired for control). • It’s one-time use, and seats 2 Medium creatures or 3 Small creatures comfortably. Additional passengers impose disadvantage on control checks due to weight imbalance.
Sensory Notes: • Sight: Thin light leaks in through frost-webbed cracks above; the room is otherwise in shadow. • Sound: Your footsteps are muted; every movement feels louder than it should. • Smell: Cold earth, ancient wood, and the faintest scent of cedar from the toboggan’s treated frame. • Touch: The air bites like needles on exposed skin; stone and wood are brittle with frost.
Narrative Use: • This can be a dramatic last-ditch escape after fighting Cryovain or as a cinematic moment if the party is near collapse. • Alternatively, it might offer a clever exit from a sealed or surrounded situation, surprising the players with a non-combat resolution

note.name: Wrapping Up
note.text:
A. If Cryovain is Slain
The white dragon’s death marks a turning point in the Sword Mountains and the region surrounding Phandalin.
Narrative Impact: 1. The Weather Breaks: Within days, the unnatural cold around the mountain lifts. Birds return, and travel through the high passes grows safer. 2. A Name Remembered: Locals begin to speak of the adventurers who ended the reign of the dragon. Taverns name drinks after them; bards compose early verses. 3. Opportunities Arise: • The hold might become available as a stronghold if restored. • Dwarves of the Sword Mountains could offer aid in rebuilding. • Factions like the Harpers or the Lord’s Alliance may approach the party for future missions. 4. Cryovain’s Body: Depending on how it was dealt with, the corpse might yield trophies (teeth, claws, scales, or heart), or it might become an eerie monument high atop the ruined keep.
Reward Considerations: • If the party didn’t find Cryovain’s hoard elsewhere, you can place additional treasure here (e.g., frost-covered chests embedded in ice beneath the rooftop). • NPCs from Phandalin may offer gifts or deeds to nearby land, or throw a festival in the party’s honor.
B. If Cryovain Escapes
If the party fails to kill Cryovain or chooses to flee:
Narrative Consequences: 1. The Dragon’s Fury: Cryovain goes on a rampage, destroying nearby outposts, burning caravans with frost, and freezing Phandalin’s wellspring. 2. The Clock Ticks: Word spreads—Cryovain must be stopped before the damage worsens. 3. A Second Chance: The dragon’s patterns become predictable, and scouts or captured orcs might reveal where it lairs next. 4. DM Guidance: Cryovain’s next lair might be the Circle of Thunder, a frozen cave system, or even an ancient ruin revealed by melting snows.
C. If the Party Claims the Hold
Should the players defeat Cryovain and decide to restore Icespire Hold, this opens the door to a stronghold campaign.
Stronghold Hooks: 1. The Hold Rebuilt: Dwarves, humans, or gnome engineers from Tinkleguard or Neverwinter arrive to assist. 2. New Threats: The destruction of Cryovain attracts opportunists—ogres, frost cultists, white dragon wyrmlings, or worse. 3. Faction Involvement: Factions may compete for influence over the hold, offering support—or interference. 4. Legacy: The players might rename the fortress and make it the center of their influence in the region

note.name: The Letter From The Cult Of Tiamat
note.text:
Item Found: Magically Sealed Letter Bearing the Sigil of Tiamat
Location: Discovered in a scorched, frost-rimed iron strongbox buried in H21 – Undercroft or frozen in the talons of a long-dead courier on the rooftop (H20 – Roof), preserved by the cold.
Physical Description: This letter is bound in blackened parchment, singed at the edges, and tightly curled. Its wax seal bears the mark of five dragon heads fanning from a single neck—a crude depiction of Tiamat. The seal glows faintly with eldritch power, thrumming with arcane energy.
Magical Ward
The letter is warded with a modified glyph of warding, enchanted to burn the letter to ash if forcibly opened. A detect magic spell reveals abjuration and evocation magic, and a successful DC 15 Arcana check identifies it as a protective seal keyed to Tiamat’s divine essence.
To Open the Letter: • Requires a dispel magic spell (DC 15) or a Remove Curse cast by a character of 3rd level or higher. • Alternatively, a high-ranking Harper, Order of the Gauntlet, or arcane scholar in Waterdeep or Neverwinter may know how to disarm it. • If opened without breaking the seal safely, the letter self-immolates and deals 4d6 fire damage to the opener.
Translation (Draconic → Common)
Once unsealed, the letter contains the following message, inked in dark crimson:
“Wyrmspeaker Varram— The White has stirred in the mountains. Let it rise, and let its fury mask our movements across the Sword Coast. The Draakhorn will soon sound. Make ready the Mask. —S”
Character Clues 1. DC 13 Religion: Recognizes the five-headed sigil as Tiamat’s. 2. DC 15 Arcana or History: Identifies the Draakhorn as an ancient artifact tied to dragonkind—its sounding is a harbinger of great draconic gatherings. 3. DC 17 Investigation: Finds ocean salt residue on the parchment’s edges—suggesting sea travel from Luskan, Baldur’s Gate, or Sea of Moving Ice.
Narrative Hooks • Cryovain was merely a distraction: a wild pawn released to obscure the Cult of the Dragon’s true movements. • “The Mask” may refer to the Dragon Masks, central to Tiamat’s summoning. • “S” may be short for Severin, the Cult’s current leader

note.name: Welcome!
note.text: Welcome to my Gamemaster 5 Campaign. The intent of this campaign is to run Dragon of Icespire Peak and eventually hook it into Tyranny of Dragons for a long term campaign. This contains hints for ToD later, but not any of the content for it. This adventure file is perfect for starting a new group with a solid foundation, and then beginning to explore where you want to take things later. Modify these notes as you see fit! Use them as prompts to inform your own DM creativity. Most of the content is the same as written officially, but I have prepped more thoroughly and included extra information (and therefore may have taken some creative liberties, as any good DM does).

note.name: Active Quest Log
note.text: Use this section to create an active quest log of the party’s ambitions as they adventure!

note.name: d20 Tiamat Clues
note.text:
1. A Crude Sigil
Found carved into a rock face or burned into wood: a five-headed dragon symbol, each head shaped for a different color (black, blue, green, red, white). No one local knows what it means.
2. Charred Map Fragment
A half-burned parchment shows the Sword Coast, with several towns circled in red. The words “SEEDS OF TIAMAT” are scribbled in Draconic near the coast.
3. Kobold Prayer Banner
Discovered in a kobold warren: a banner stitched from stolen cloth. Written in poor Common:
“Glory to the Queen Below! Cold flame rise. Five heads, one heart.”
4. Dead Cultist’s Journal
A leather-bound book found on a cloaked figure. Its final entry reads:
“Shipment heads to Naerytar next. Our queen stirs. We need more tribute.”
5. Whisper in the Wind
A divine caster receives a vision while meditating: a vast echoing roar, followed by the phrase, “The chains crack. She breathes again.”
6. Strange Coin
A silver coin minted in an unknown design: one side bears five dragon heads, the other a burning star. Magic reveals necrotic energy clinging to it.
7. Harbin Wester’s Guest
Someone shady has visited Phandalin’s townmaster—cloaked, polite, and paid in pristine gold. Harbin claims they were “just asking about dragon sightings.”
8. Frozen Offering
In Cryovain’s hoard lies a ritual box of incense and bone dust—identical to offerings described in ancient cult texts to summon draconic spirits.
9. Letter in a Locked Chest
“Resplendent Dread, Our shrine in Leilon is secure. The clawed ones obey. The wyrmling will rise or fall—it matters not. You are the key.”
10. Dreams of Fire
One player dreams of a burning city and a massive shadow with five necks, blocking out the sun. A voice whispers: “You will kneel.”
11. Captured Cult Courier
A young cultist, captured after a failed ambush, shouts:
“You’re too late! The hoard grows! Our queen ascends!”
12. Vision in a Dragon’s Eye
When a PC slays a draconic creature, they glimpse—briefly—a pale throne of bones and gold, upon which five heads writhe in shadow.
13. Scroll from the East
A wizard in Neverwinter shows the party a confiscated scroll:
“Raids increase. Cult moves under cover. We suspect they prepare a ritual of calling.”
14. Kobold Chant
Kobolds in a cave rhythmically repeat:
“Five flames wake. Five teeth bite. Cold first, then red. Then death.”
15. Blasted Outpost
The party stumbles on a destroyed frontier post. Among the ashes: a cultist robe, partially intact, with a red dragon scale sewn into the collar.
16. Stone Relic
In a temple ruin is a small altar with a cracked relief of a winged woman surrounded by dragons. A DC 15 Religion check reveals it depicts Tiamat in exile.
17. Diviner’s Warning
A seer at a roadside shrine warns the party:
“The stars churn. A storm of wings comes. Gold is not the only treasure they seek.”
18. Journal of a Madman
Scrawled notes found in an abandoned cabin:
“They bring it west. Piece by piece. Blood and scale. Flame and fang. Tiamat waits in chains.”
19. Arcane Residue
After defeating a spellcaster, detect magic reveals the residual energy of Teleportation Circle linked to Cult of the Dragon sigils.
20. Message on Dragonhide
Tanned and stretched dragonhide, found nailed to a cave wall. Scrawled in blood-red ink:
“Kneel before the Queen of Many Mouths. The wyrms shall reign.”

note.name: Stone Cold Reavers Improv Kit
note.text:
The Stone-Cold Reavers are a quartet of veteran mercenaries turned brigands. Smart enough to follow Cryovain to his lair, they now squat inside the gatehouse of Icespire Hold, waiting for the dragon to leave. They are selfish, gritty, and always calculating angles—but not needlessly cruel unless pushed.
Treat them as morally gray party rivals—resourceful, sarcastic, and dangerous. They might help the party under certain terms, betray them, or challenge them to reach the hoard first.
Shared Traits (Group Behavior): • Motivations: Want Cryovain’s treasure; distrust outsiders; willing to team up temporarily if it helps them survive or profit. • Tactics: Dirty fighters—ambushes, distractions, and threats over diplomacy. They’re not suicidal and will surrender or flee if two members fall. • Social Dynamics: They’re a found family, but one held together by necessity, not affection. Lots of in-fighting, sarcastic jabs, and “you owe me” energy.
Reaver NPC Profiles
1. Syleen Wintermoon (Leader) • Visual Trait: Flame-red ponytail, ice-blue eyes, and a bone-carved necklace made from her first kill. • Quirks: Compulsive liar, always assumes others are lying. • Sample Quips: • “Trust me, you really don’t want to go upstairs. Or do. I love a good scream.” • “You look like the type who thinks ‘fair fight’ means something. That’s adorable.” • “We were just about to take the dragon down ourselves. Honest. Cross my shriveled heart.”
2. Runa Vokdottir (Scout & Archer) • Visual Trait: Pale skin from Icewind Dale, black braid threaded with orc tusks. • Quirks: Barely speaks, but when she does—cutting and precise. • Sample Quips: • “You breathe too loud. That’s how you die up here.” • “I’ll take the dragon. You take the fall.” • “They always beg for warmth, in the end. Never works.”
3. Brakkis Elspaar (Grumbler & Tactician) • Visual Trait: Balding with a potbelly, constantly chewing on dry jerky. • Quirks: Loves dogs. Hates his knees. Always talks about retirement. • Sample Quips: • “Don’t take this personal. I just don’t like new faces.” • “If I get frostbite again, I’m putting that dragon in a stew.” • “I once had a plan. Then I met people like you.”
4. Jabarl the Orc-Biter (Bruiser & Stablemaster) • Visual Trait: Missing nose bridge from an old orc duel, wears a leather muzzle when sleeping. • Quirks: Talks to horses more than people. • Sample Quips: • “If you touch the horses, I touch you. And not in a fun way.” • “I used to cave in skulls for kings. Now I do it freelance.” • “You wanna fight over loot or live through the night? Decide quick.”
Improvised Reactions & Roleplay Hooks
Scenario Reaver Response (Roll a d4) Party offers alliance 1) Syleen proposes a split—then double-crosses. 2) Brakkis asks for warm rations and plays diplomat. 3) Runa remains silent but watches. 4) Jabarl tests a PC’s strength first. Party mentions dragon hoard 1) Syleen becomes intensely curious. 2) Brakkis mutters about “already scoured this dump.” 3) Jabarl gets twitchy. 4) Runa warns: “The dragon’s still here.” Party seems weak or wounded 1) Jabarl growls and paces. 2) Syleen leans in with fake sympathy. 3) Brakkis offers a “safe place” to rest—trap. 4) Runa snorts. “Snow’ll bury them for us.”
Combat Roles • Syleen: Dual-wields shortswords, uses Disarming Attack and Trip Attack. • Runa: Ranged longbow with poison-tipped arrows. • Brakkis: Heavy crossbow and net for disabling. • Jabarl: Greatclub, grappler tactics, enrages on critical hits

note.name: Anchorites Of Talos (Neverwinter Wood) Traits and Rumors
note.text:
The Anchorites of Talos are zealous storm-worshipers who revere Talos, the chaotic evil god of storms, destruction, and reckless fury. These individuals live in seclusion, seeking to unleash divine chaos in the form of lightning, thunder, and natural disasters upon civilization. Their ultimate goal is to tear down order and drown the world in the fury of the storm.
They are most prominent in the Neverwinter Wood, where shrines, ritual sites (such as the Circle of Thunder and the Tower of Storms), and long-forgotten sacred groves have become corrupted with their rites.
Beliefs and Practices • Storms Are Divine Judgment – Anchorites view every storm as a message from Talos, a sign that destruction is not only natural, but holy. • Sacrifice by Thunder – Blood sacrifices—animal or humanoid—are common in their rituals, usually performed at storm-wracked altars or stone circles. • Enemies of Civilization – They seek to disrupt roads, destroy ships, and collapse communities, believing mortal order offends Talos. • Talos’s Touch – Some anchorites mutilate themselves with lightning-scarred tattoos, metal piercings, or ritual burns to show their faith.
Notable Anchorites • Moesko (Tower of Storms) – A half-orc who gave his heart—literally—for Talos’s light. Haunts the lighthouse with ritual power. • Flenz, Narux, and Yargath (Circle of Thunder) – Storm druids and zealots who summon Gorthok the Thunder Boar, a sacred beast of Talos.
Common Traits
Feature Description Spells Anchorites use druidic magic twisted with lightning, thunder, and storm motifs (e.g., thunderwave, call lightning). Claws of Talos Many bear mutated or magical claws—gifted through divine rituals. Trophies of the Storm They collect charred bones, broken compasses, melted holy symbols of rival gods. Mannerisms They chant in Draconic or Primordial, laugh when thunder claps, and often speak in riddles referencing waves, winds, and ruin.
d6 Anchorite Rumors & Clues
d6 Rumor or Clue 1 “They say the storm druids whisper to boars with lightning in their breath… and one came alive.” (Clue about Gorthok.) 2 A half-burned journal in an abandoned cabin reads: “Talos’s eye opens near the sea. The lighthouse heart beats still.” (Clue about Moesko.) 3 “Folk say the lightning over Neverwinter Wood is never natural. It dances to chants, not clouds.” (General hint about Circle of Thunder.) 4 A merchant claims to have seen a ship torn apart with no storm in sight. “The light from the cliffs pulled them in. Like magic.” (Reference to Tower of Storms.) 5 A dying orc mutters, “The god of storms gave us power… but the price was blood. So much blood.” (Indicates Talos worship is growing among displaced tribes.) 6 A worn map shows ancient druidic symbols scratched over key sites—Phandalin, the Circle of Thunder, and a location marked only as “The Scar.” (Hook for a future Talos site.

note.name: Sword Coast Wilderness Kit
note.text:
1. Terrain Themes
Use these to flavor the landscape and prompt encounters. • Tangled Pines of Neverwinter Wood – Dark evergreens twisted by old magic. The wind always seems to whisper secrets. • Triboar Trail Ravines – Sharp gullies flanked by ancient cart paths and rusting wagon parts. • Sword Mountain Foothills – Jagged slopes where goat paths wind past dragon-burnt ruins and craggy watchtowers. • Moonlit Meadows – Rolling hills that glow faintly silver at night. Selûnite pilgrims claim they protect travelers in these parts.
2. Exploration Events & Finds
Use as wandering discoveries or exploration flavor. 1. Abandoned Camp • A half-burned journal describes “sightings of a golden stag with stars in its eyes.” • DC 12 Investigation reveals a hidden compartment in a bedroll with 3 electrum rings (worth 25 gp each). 2. Twilight Grove • Trees grow in a perfect circle; their leaves shimmer violet at dusk. • Arcana DC 14 reveals the grove is watched by a dormant dryad spirit. 3. Collapsed Shrine to Mystra • Marble faceplate shattered, arcane sigils dulled with age. • DC 15 Arcana: touching the altar gives a fleeting glimpse of a spellbook page with a unique homebrew cantrip. 4. Blood and Snow • Drag marks vanish into a snowy ridge. Investigation DC 12 shows clawed humanoid footprints (ghouls or ice-touched bandits). 5. Waystone of the Moonwatcher • A cracked standing stone covered in phases of the moon. A prayer to Selûne grants the caster advantage on the next Wisdom (Insight) check.
3. Wilderness NPCs 1. Old Wint Calloway • Weathered half-elf hermit in a robe stitched with beetle shells. • Quips: • “Don’t trust the moss—it’s been listening.” • “You seen the moon cry before? I have. Right over these hills.” • Claims he speaks with owlbears in dreams. May hold dream-lore Yote would understand. 2. Sereta of the Hollow • Gruff dwarf huntress, missing three fingers, rides a silent elk. • Quips: • “You think cold like this is Cryovain? Nah. This cold’s older.” • “Give me one reason not to shoot you.” • Can guide the party—but demands a favor in return: recover her brother’s hammer from a bandit den. 3. Kelthrin the Ghost Cartographer (encountered only under a full moon) • Pale human in faded blue robes, maps stitched into their cloak. • Leaves behind a glowing trail—follow it to find a hidden ruin or treasure site.
4. Wilderness Creatures (Fauna & Flora) • Fauna: • Silver-Fanged Wolves – Larger than normal, eyes glow under starlight. Natural predators warped by Cryovain’s presence. • Moonfen Toads – Bioluminescent frogs found in river shallows. Their croak has a faint calming effect. • Ashcloaks – Raven-like birds with soot-colored feathers. Often precede signs of dragon activity. • Flora: • Frostfern – Found only near white dragon lairs. Glows faintly at night and can be made into a resistance potion. • Wailing Willow – Tree with twisting boughs; at night, it produces moaning sounds. Considered unlucky to sleep beneath. • Redroot Vine – Used in anti-inflammatory poultices. DC 10 Nature to identify.
5. Encounters (Use as Random Events or Side Hooks) 1. Cultist Camp (Tyranny Hook) • A burned circle and half-buried banner showing a five-headed dragon symbol. Evidence of recent activity. • One note half-burned reads: “The hoard must not stall. Talis is watching.” 2. Wounded Griffon • Stuck in a thicket, wing broken. If helped, it may return later during Cryovain’s fight. • DC 15 Animal Handling to calm it; magical healing helps it fly again in 2d4 days. 3. Riddle-Stone Bridge • Stone guardian speaks: “I was never born, yet I die every day. What am I?” (Answer: “The sun.”) • Correct answer reveals a hidden path to a treasure stash (50 gp, potion of climbing, Harper pin). 4. Emerald Enclave Patrol • A trio of rangers tending to an injured owlbear cub. They warn of twisted beasts ahead—Cryovain’s corrupting magic is spreading.
6. Ruins & Campsites 1. Watcher’s Hollow • A ruined watchtower overlooking an icy valley. Nesting hawks use it now, but a +1 arrow is wedged in a roof beam. 2. The Split Tree Camp • Used by druids long ago. A carved face in the tree weeps sap if you speak to it in Sylvan. 3. Clifftop Cairn • Built by ancient dwarves. Buried beneath is a rusted helm that grants immunity to being frightened while worn, but causes disturbing dreams
